Beitzah



Daf 1a



Daf 1b



Daf 2a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an egg that was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival</span> (<span class="it-text">Eduyyot</span> 4:1), <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: It may be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> even on that day, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel say: It </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may not be eaten, </span>as the Gemara will explain at length. Apropos this exceptional case, in which Beit Shammai are lenient and Beit Hillel are strict, the mishna cites additional <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of the Festivals in which this unusual phenomenon occurs (<span class="it-text">Yoma</span> 79b). <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: Leaven, </span>i.e., dough that has leavened to such an extent that it is no longer used as food but as a leavening agent for other dough, is prohibited on Passover in the measure <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">olive-bulk</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> However, the measure for edible <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bread </span>is greater, that <span class="gemarra-regular">of a large </span><span class="gemarra-regular">date-bulk</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: </span>For both <span class="gemarra-regular">this and that, </span>the measure is that <span class="gemarra-regular">of an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">olive-bulk</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
Furthermore, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who slaughters an undomesticated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> animal or a bird on a Festival </span>(<span class="it-text">Eduyyot</span> 4:2), in which case there is a mitzva from the Torah to cover the blood after slaughtering (Leviticus 17:13), <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: He digs </span>earth <span class="gemarra-regular">with a shovel and covers </span>the blood with that earth <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He may not slaughter </span><span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he had earth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prepared </span>for that purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">while it was still day. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>even Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">concede that if one </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>the animal or the bird, <span class="gemarra-regular">then he should dig with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a shovel and cover </span>the blood. Additionally, they agree <span class="gemarra-regular">that the ashes of a stove are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>for the use of covering blood, as will be explained by the Gemara.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara inquires: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">are we dealing </span>in this mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we say </span>that the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a chicken </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that is designated for eating, </span>i.e., one planned to slaughter and eat a chicken that laid an egg, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is the reason that Beit Hillel </span>prohibit eating the egg? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is food that has been separated [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">de’ifrat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The entire chicken is considered food, as it is designated for eating, and this egg is simply a part that became detached. Just as one may partake of the chicken itself on a Festival, its egg should likewise be fit for consumption.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the mishna must be referring to the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a chicken designated for laying eggs. </span>Since the owner of this chicken decided not to eat it on the Festival, it is classified as set-aside [<span class="it-text">muktze</span>], and <span class="it-text">muktze</span> items may not even be moved, let alone eaten. Since the chicken itself is <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, its egg is <span class="it-text">muktze</span> as well.
The Gemara asks: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reason of Beit Shammai </span>for permitting one to eat the egg? After all, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span><span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara expresses surprise at this question: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is the difficulty? Perhaps Beit Shammai do not hold </span>that there is a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> There are different opinions with regard to the scope of the prohibition of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. It is possible that Beit Shammai, like other <span class="it-text">tanna</span><span class="it-text">’im</span>, maintain that there is no prohibition of this type of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. Perhaps this is the subject of their dispute with Beit Hillel. 
Before stating its proposed solutions for this difficulty, the Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">It</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> enters our mind </span>to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">even one who permits</span> moving an item that was <span class="gemarra-regular">set aside </span>by its owners on a Festival or Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibits </span>the owners from doing so <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>an object that <span class="gemarra-regular">came into being [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nolad</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> on a Festival. One may not move an object that came into being on a Festival or Shabbat, since the owner never entertained the notion that he would be able to use it. This egg is certainly an object that came into being on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the reason of Beit Shammai?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: Actually, </span>the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a chicken designated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for laying eggs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> However, our previous assumption was mistaken, as the Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">who holds </span>that there is a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span> in general also <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that there is a prohibition of objects that <span class="gemarra-regular">came into being</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> while one <span class="gemarra-regular">who does not hold </span>that there is a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span> likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">does not hold </span>that there is a prohibition of objects that <span class="gemarra-regular">came into being </span>(<span class="it-text">Shabbat</span> 45b). Consequently, the dispute can be summed up as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai</span> hold <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>who maintains that there is no prohibition of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel </span>hold <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yehuda, </span>who rules that there is a prohibition of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>.
The Gemara is puzzled by this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">did Rav Naḥman </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say that </span>Beit Hillel hold in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shabbat</span> 143a) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: One </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">remove bone</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and shell</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> left from the meal <span class="gemarra-regular">from the table, </span>despite the fact that they are inedible and are <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: </span>It is prohibited to do so; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">remove </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the entire board [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tavla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> that is the table surface, which is a vessel that may be carried, <span class="gemarra-regular">and shake </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>all at once. By moving the table, which is not <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, one is able to shake off the bones and shells, but he may not move the items themselves. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Naḥman said:</span> That version of the mishna is not in accordance with the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>; rather, the opinions should be reversed, as <span class="gemarra-regular">we</span> have <span class="gemarra-regular">nothing othe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> than the following version of this dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai </span>hold <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>who maintains that the prohibition of <span class="it-text">muktze</span> applies, while <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel </span>hold <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>who maintains that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="it-text">muktze</span> does not apply. Why, then, does Rav Naḥman explain that the ruling of Beit Hillel in the case of the egg in the mishna is based on the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, who holds that there actually is a prohibition of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>?
The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>in reply: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to Shabbat, </span>this is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught us an unattributed </span>mishna, which is generally accepted as the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon, as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shabbat</span> 156b): <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">cut pumpkin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before an animal </span>to facilitate their consumption, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>likewise one may cut up <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal carcas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before dogs, </span>even if the animal died on Shabbat, to enable them to consume it. Although that carcass is classified as <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, it may be moved on Shabbat. 
The Gemara concludes: That unattributed mishna in tractate <span class="it-text">Shabbat</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. For this reason, Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">establishes </span>that the dispute between Beit Hillel and Beit Shammai should be understood to mean <span class="gemarra-regular">that Beit Hillel</span> hold <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>whom the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> apparently follows, as there is a principle that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is always in accordance with Beit Hillel’s opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>

Daf 2b

<span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a Festival, </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught us an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">unattributed </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>(<span class="it-text">Shabbat</span> 156b), <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna in this tractate: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not chop woo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">from beams </span>prepared for use in construction work, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>may one chop kindling wood <span class="gemarra-regular">from a beam that broke on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a Festival. </span>As the beams were not prepared for this use when the Festival began, they are classified as <span class="it-text">muktze</span>; this demonstrates that an unattributed mishna prohibits <span class="it-text">muktze</span> on a Festival. Consequently, Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">establishes </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Beit Hillel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>who prohibits <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. He does so by asserting that the mishna is referring to the case of a chicken designated for laying eggs, which is <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. This concludes the Gemara’s explanation of Rav Naḥman’s rendering of the tannaitic dispute.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now since, </span>i.e., consider the following: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who is the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span>wrote and edited the Mishna, and arranged <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">unattributed </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mishnayot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>It was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. Since the same Sage formulated the statements in both tractates, the question arises: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">stated the unattributed opinio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and ruled <span class="gemarra-regular">for us</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, and what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is different </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">stated the unattributed opinion </span>and ruled <span class="gemarra-regular">for us</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda? </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">They </span>answer and <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, which is stringen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> with regard to its punishments (see 35b), <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore people <span class="gemarra-regular">will not come to treat it with contempt, </span>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">taught us the unattributed </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, who rules leniently. </span>Conversely, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival, which is lenient, </span>as certain labors may be performed on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore people <span class="gemarra-regular">will </span>be more likely to <span class="gemarra-regular">come to treat it with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">contempt, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">stated the unattributed opinion for us in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who rules stringently.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>manner <span class="gemarra-regular">did you </span>ultimately <span class="gemarra-regular">establish </span>the mishna? It was established as referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a chicken designated for laying eggs, and </span>the prohibition is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. If so, rather than disputing with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to an egg </span>laid on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">let them dispute </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">chicken </span>itself. Instead of considering the secondary detail of an egg, Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel could discuss whether or not the chicken itself may be slaughtered on a Festival. 
The Gemara answers: Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel also disagree with regard to the chicken, but the dispute was phrased in this manner <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">convey the far-reaching natur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shammai. </span>The formulation of the mishna emphasizes the extent of Beit Shammai’s lenient opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">in the case</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>an egg, which is not a regular <span class="it-text">muktze</span> item but an item that <span class="gemarra-regular">came into being, </span>an especially stringent type of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, Beit Shammai nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">permit </span>it. By stating the dispute with regard to an egg, the mishna stresses Beit Shammai’s lenient opinion.
The Gemara raises an objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let them disagree with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to a chicken, </span>rather than an egg, <span class="gemarra-regular">to convey </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the far-reaching nature of </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who prohibit </span>its use <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>in the more lenient case <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And if you say </span>it is better to present the dispute as in the mishna, so as to clarify the more lenient opinion, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the strength of leniency</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is preferable </span>(<span class="it-text">Berakhot</span> 60a), there is another option: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let them disagree with regard to both of </span>these cases.
The mishna could have said: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a chicken designated for laying eggs, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it and its eggs, Beit Shammai say: It may be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eaten, and Beit Hillel say: It may not be eaten</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>In this manner, the mishna could have referred to all aspects of the dispute, without the need for any lengthy addition. Consequently, Rav Naḥman’s explanation of the mishna is inadequate. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabba said: Actually, </span>the above explanation should be rejected. <span class="gemarra-regular">We are dealing with a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> chicken designated for food and we are dealing with </span>an egg that was laid <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festiva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that occurs </span><span class="gemarra-regular">after Shabbat, </span>i.e., on a Sunday. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the relevant issue is not the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>; rather, one may not eat the egg <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">preparation</span> from Shabbat to a Festival.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in this regard, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">any eg</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> laid now was </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">fully develope</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> yesterday</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and merely emerged from the chicken today. Consequently, an egg laid on a Festival that occurred on a Sunday may not be eaten, as it was prepared on Shabbat, despite the fact that it was prepared naturally, by Heaven, rather than by man.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabba, </span>who prohibits one to derive benefit even from something that was not prepared by man, conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his</span> standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning. As Rabba said: What is </span>the meaning of that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is writte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> with regard to the manna: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">And it shall come to pass on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sixth day, that they shall prepare that which they bring</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Exodus 16:5)? According to Rabba, it can be inferred from this verse that on an ordinary <span class="gemarra-regular">weekday,</span> “the sixth day,” <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">prepare </span>what is needed <span class="gemarra-regular">for Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>similarly, on an ordinary <span class="gemarra-regular">weekday one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">prepare </span>what is needed <span class="gemarra-regular">for a Festival. </span>However, on <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not prepare for Shabbat, and </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not prepare for a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to</span> Rabba: <span class="gemarra-regular">However, if </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">so, </span>and the concern is only due to preparation, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>an egg laid on <span class="gemarra-regular">a regular Festival, </span>one that does not occur on a Sunday, <span class="gemarra-regular">be permitted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rabba responded: That egg is not prohibited by Torah law, but by rabbinic <span class="gemarra-regular">decree, due to </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival </span>that occurs <span class="gemarra-regular">after Shabbat. </span>Abaye asked: On <span class="gemarra-regular">a regular Shabbat, </span>one that does not occur after a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">be permitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to eat an egg that was laid on that day, provided that one does not cook it. Rabba similarly answered: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to a Shabbat </span>that occurs <span class="gemarra-regular">after a Festival. </span>
Abaye further asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">And do we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> issue a decree </span>of this kind? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> (see 6b): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who slaughters a chicken </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> finds inside it fully developed eggs </span>with their shells, <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted to eat them on the Festival. And if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is so, </span>that that the aforementioned decree is in effect, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him issue a decree </span>and prohibit these eggs found inside the chicken, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to those that are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">laid on that day. </span>
Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>This is not difficult, as the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">fully developed egg</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> found <span class="gemarra-regular">inside their mother is an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> uncommon matter, and </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncommon matter</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Sages did not issue a decree </span>as a preventive measure (<span class="it-text">Eiruvin</span> 63b). The Sages issued their decrees only for usual situations, in which people might err, but they did not apply them to rare cases. This concludes the Gemara’s discussion of Rabba’s explanation.
The Gemara proceeds to explain other interpretations of the mishna. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>An egg laid by a chicken designated for food is prohibited for a different reason: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree due to fruits that fal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> from a tree (<span class="it-text">Eiruvin</span> 39b). Fruits that fall from a tree on Shabbat or a Festival may not be eaten, and the same applies to eggs that emerge from a chicken.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rav Yosef: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">fruits that fall, what </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>that the Sages prohibited them? 

Daf 3a

It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree lest </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">climb </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">and pic</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> the fruit, as this would constitute the prohibited labor of harvesting. If so, the prohibition against eating fruit <span class="gemarra-regular">is itself </span>due to <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree. And will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we arise and issue a decree to </span>prevent violation of another <span class="gemarra-regular">decree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Rav Yosef responded: That is not so; rather, when the Sages issued the initial decree, they enacted the prohibitions against both fruit that fall and a laid egg, as <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>the prohibitions <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>components of <span class="gemarra-regular">one decree. </span>In other words, the similar cases of the fruit and the egg were both included in the original decree.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak said </span>a different reason: An egg that was laid on a Festival is prohibited as <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree due to liquids that seepe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> from the fruit (<span class="it-text">Eiruvin</span> 39b), which is prohibited on that day. The legal status of an egg that was laid on a Festival is like that of liquids that seeped from a fruit on a Festival. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">liquid that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> seeped </span>from fruit, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reason </span>that the Sages prohibited it? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree lest one </span>purposely <span class="gemarra-regular">squeeze </span>the fruit, and thereby perform the prohibited labor of threshing. However, the prohibition against consuming this juice <span class="gemarra-regular">is itself </span>a rabbinic <span class="gemarra-regular">decree. And will we arise and issue a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">decree to </span>prevent violation of another <span class="gemarra-regular">decree? </span>Rabbi Yitzḥak replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">All </span>the prohibitions <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>components of <span class="gemarra-regular">one decree. </span>When the Sages prohibited this juice, they banned the eating of an egg laid on a Festival for the same reason, as the actions are similar. 
As various explanations have been offered for this mishna, the Gemara seeks to clarify why each Sage was dissatisfied with the other explanations and suggested an alternative. The Gemara says: <span class="gemarra-regular">All of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them, </span>Rabba, Rav Yosef, and Rabbi Yitzḥak, <span class="gemarra-regular">did not state </span>their explanations <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>stated in <span class="gemarra-regular">our </span>previously stated <span class="gemarra-regular">objection </span>to Rav Naḥman’s explanation. The other Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">also did not state </span>their explanations <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba, </span>as they <span class="gemarra-regular">do not </span>accept that there is a Torah prohibition of using items whose <span class="gemarra-regular">preparatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> was from Shabbat to a Festival or from a Festival to Shabbat.
<span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>the following question arises: Since <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef </span>provides an explanation that is similar to that of Rabbi Yitzḥak, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reason </span>that he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not state </span>his explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak? </span>The Gemara answers that Rav Yosef could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">An egg is food, and fruit is food, </span>i.e., an egg is comparable to fruits that fall. This observation would serve <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude juice, which is not food </span>but drink. Consequently, an egg is not comparable to juice and would not be included in the same decree.
The Gemara asks the reverse question: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to<span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yitzḥak, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reaso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that he <span class="gemarra-regular">did not state </span>his explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef? </span>The Gemara answers: He could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that the case of an egg is more similar to juices that seep from fruit. How so? <span class="gemarra-regular">An egg is enclosed </span>inside a chicken before it is laid, and likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">juice is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> enclosed </span>inside the fruit. This observation serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude fruits</span> that fall from a tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">which are standing exposed </span>on the tree. Therefore, the comparison between fruits that fall and an egg is weaker than the comparison between liquid that seeped from fruit and an egg. 
§ The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan also holds </span>that the prohibition against eating an egg laid on a Festival is <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to liquid that seeped </span>from fruit. What proof can be cited for this? It is proven <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yoḥanan raised a contradiction </span>between one statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yehuda </span>and a different statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yehuda, and he resolved </span>the apparent contradiction in a manner that indicates his own opinion. 
The Gemara elaborates on the previous statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shabbat</span> 143b): <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not squeeze fruit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to extract</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> liquids from them </span>on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if </span>the liquids <span class="gemarra-regular">seeped</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> out on their own, it is prohibited </span>to use them on Shabbat, lest he come to squeeze fruits intentionally. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda says: If </span>the fruit is designated <span class="gemarra-regular">for eating, </span>e.g., apples, the liquid <span class="gemarra-regular">that seeps from them is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permitted. </span>Since there is no concern that one might squeeze the fruit, there is no reason to prohibit its liquid. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the fruit was originally designated <span class="gemarra-regular">for liquids, </span>such as grapes for wine, there are grounds for concern that one might squeeze them, and therefore the liquid <span class="gemarra-regular">that seeps</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from them is prohibited.</span>
From the fact that Rabbi Yehuda said that liquid from fruit intended for eating is permitted, one can infer that, <span class="gemarra-regular">apparently, all food </span>that comes out of another food <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>classified as <span class="gemarra-regular">food that was separated, according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda. </span>Food that was separated is not considered a new food, but part of the food that previously existed.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>against this from a different source: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehuda said further, </span>concerning untithed fruit, which may not be rendered fit to be eaten on a Festival by separating <span class="it-text">teruma</span> and tithes from it (<span class="it-text">Eiruvin</span> 39a): <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may stipulate a condition with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a baske</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>untithed <span class="gemarra-regular">frui</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the first day </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of a Festival, </span>and say: If today is the true Festival day, the second Festival day is actually a weekday. Therefore, this fruit is permitted, once I separate tithes from it, as on any other weekday. And vice versa: If today is, in fact, a weekday, and tomorrow is the Festival, I hereby separate its tithes today. 
Likewise, on the following day, he should again stipulate: If today is a weekday and yesterday was holy, I hereby separate tithes from the fruit now; if today is holy and yesterday was a weekday, separating the tithes yesterday was sufficient. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he </span>may then <span class="gemarra-regular">eat </span>the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">second </span>Festival day, as in either case no prohibition is involved. <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, an eg</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> laid on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span>Festival day may <span class="gemarra-regular">be eaten on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">secon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> day, regardless of which day is the actual Festival. 
Rabbi Yehuda’s statement indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> second </span>day, <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>it is permitted to partake of the egg; but if the egg was laid <span class="gemarra-regular">on the first</span> day, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>one may not eat it. If so, Rabbi Yehuda apparently contradicts himself, as he said previously that liquid from food prepared for eating has the same status as the food itself, and that its emergence is considered to be nothing more than the separation of two foods from each other. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan resolves </span>the difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">The</span> attribution of the <span class="gemarra-regular">opinions </span>with regard to the second day of the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">is reversed </span>(<span class="it-text">Berakhot</span> 17b), so that Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion corresponds with his ruling above.
The significance of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement for the issue at hand is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">raised a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">contradiction between </span>the cases of an egg and liquid that oozed, one may <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from this that it is the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> same reason </span>in both cases, i.e., an egg is prohibited on a Festival due to the rabbinic decree against liquid that oozed from fruit. 

Daf 3b

With regard to the contradiction presented by Rabbi Yoḥanan, which led him to suggest that the opinions should be reversed, <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said </span>that this is not the only possible resolution: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, do not revers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the opinions. Rather, in the case of the two Festival days, one could claim that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda spoke to them in accordance with the statement </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the Rabbis, </span>rather than presenting his own opinion. 
If so, Rabbi Yehuda’s statement should be understood as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">In my </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">even on the first </span>Festival day, the egg is <span class="gemarra-regular">also permitted, as it is food that was separated. However</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, according to your </span>opinion, which is that you prohibit liquid that comes from food, <span class="gemarra-regular">at least agree with me that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is permitted on the second </span>day, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> two sanctities. </span>The first and second days of Rosh HaShana are not one unit, but two separate entities. Therefore, it is possible that the first day is sacred, while the second is a weekday. Consequently, an item prohibited on the first day might be permitted on the second. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbis said to him: No, </span>the two days <span class="gemarra-regular">are one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sanctity, </span>i.e., they are viewed as a single continuous unit. The uncertainty applies equally to both of them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, son of Rav Ulla, said: </span>There is an alternative resolution to the contradiction raised by Rabbi Yoḥanan. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>in the case of the egg laid on a Festival, Rabbi Yehuda prohibited eating the egg since it is not from a chicken designated for food, whose legal status is that of food. Rather, the case refers <span class="gemarra-regular">to a chicken designated for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> laying eggs, and Rabbi Yehuda </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as he holds </span>that there is a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Since the egg is produced by something <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, it is certainly <span class="it-text">muktze</span> itself, which means that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of food that was separated is inapplicable to this case.
§ The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which clarifies the issue differently: <span class="gemarra-regular">Both an egg that was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> laid on Shabbat and an egg that was laid on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a Festival </span>are considered to be <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, and therefore in both cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not move </span>the egg, neither for the sake of food nor for any other purpose: <span class="gemarra-regular">Not to cover a vessel with it, nor to support </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the legs of a bed with it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>if one wishes, he may <span class="gemarra-regular">cover </span>the egg <span class="gemarra-regular">with a vessel, </span>without handling the egg itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that it does not break </span>from being accidentally trodden upon. Although it is prohibited to move the egg itself, it is nevertheless permitted to move a vessel for its sake. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>even if there is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>with regard to whether this egg was laid on a Festival, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibite</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to move it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And, </span>furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it became intermingled with a thousand </span>permitted eggs, they are <span class="gemarra-regular">all prohibited</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara notes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba, who said </span>that an egg is prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the lack of <span class="gemarra-regular">preparation, </span>this case involves <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertainty </span>with regard to the legal status of an item prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertainty </span>with regard to the legal status of an item prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law, </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is stringent. </span>Therefore, the egg is prohibited even if there is uncertainty whether it was laid on a Festival.
<span class="gemarra-regular">However, according to</span> the opinions of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yose</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi Yitzḥak, who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that an egg is prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">due to a decree, </span>this case involves <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertainty </span>with regard to the legal status of an item prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law, and </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertainty </span>with regard to the legal status of an item prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law, </span>the ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is lenient. </span>
The Gemara answers: In <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">we have arrived at </span>a different case. The case does not involve the prohibition of an egg laid on a Festival; the case involves an egg laid by a chicken with regard to which there is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>whether it is <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal with a condition that will cause it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to die within twelve months [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>which is prohibited by Torah law. The uncertainty with regard to the legal status of the chicken is relevant to the egg. 
The Gemara raises a difficulty with this response: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, say the latter clause </span>of that same <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If it <span class="gemarra-regular">became intermingled with a thousand </span>other eggs, they are <span class="gemarra-regular">all prohibited. Granted, if you say </span>that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>whether the egg was laid on <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>whether it was laid on <span class="gemarra-regular">a weekday, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is an object whose prohibition is temporary, </span>as the egg will be permitted on the following day, and the principle is: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any object whose prohibition is temporary is not nullified</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, even by a thousand </span>permitted items. Since its prohibition will lapse on its own, there is no need to make use of the option of nullification.
<span class="gemarra-regular">However, if you say </span>that the egg referred to in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertain</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, it is an object whose prohibition is not temporary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as there is no way to permit the prohibition of <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it should </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">be nullified by </span>a simple <span class="gemarra-regular">majority.</span>
The Gemara adds: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an egg is significant and is not nullified, </span>as nullification applies only to items that have no intrinsic significance, while a significant object cannot be nullified, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>works out <span class="gemarra-regular">well according to the one who said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">learned: Any </span>item <span class="gemarra-regular">whose manner is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">to be counted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., that is sometimes sold by unit, rather than by weight or volume, is considered significant. An egg falls into that category, as it is sometimes sold by unit.
<span class="gemarra-regular">However, according to the one who said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned: That </span>item <span class="gemarra-regular">whose manner is </span>exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be counted, </span>i.e., that is always sold by unit, is considered significant, <span class="gemarra-regular">what can be said? </span>Although eggs are often sold by unit, they are also often sold by weight or volume.
The Gemara cites the mishna where the dispute cited above appears. <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>(<span class="it-text">Orla</span> 3:6–7): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who had bundles of clover, </span>a type of legume, that were <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds </span>of food crops that grew <span class="gemarra-regular">in a vineyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> from which it is prohibited to derive benefit, those bundles <span class="gemarra-regular">must be burned. </span>If the bundles <span class="gemarra-regular">were intermingled with others, and </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">others </span>were intermingled <span class="gemarra-regular">with others, they must all be burned. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">They may be nullified by one </span>part in <span class="gemarra-regular">two hundre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> similar parts. When the prohibited portion is less than one-half of one percent of the permitted portion, the prohibition is nullified. 
The mishna continues: Rabbi Meir says that they must all be burned, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir would say: That whose manner is </span>exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be counted, </span>is considered significant and cannot be nullified. Therefore, it <span class="gemarra-regular">renders </span>the entire mixture <span class="gemarra-regular">forbidden, </span>and it must be burned. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: Only six items </span>are sufficiently significant to <span class="gemarra-regular">render </span>the entire mixture <span class="gemarra-regular">forbidden. Rabbi Akiva says: </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">seven. And they are: </span>High-quality <span class="gemarra-regular">nuts </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">Perekh, and pomegranates </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">Badan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and sealed barrels </span>of wine, <span class="gemarra-regular">and branches of spinach</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and cabbage stalks</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Greek pumpkin. Rabbi Akiva adds: Even loaves of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> homeowner.</span>
Different prohibitions apply to these seven items. <span class="gemarra-regular">That which is fit </span>to be forbidden due <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">orla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> fruit that grows during the first three years after a tree is planted, is forbidden due to <span class="gemarra-italic">orla</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. That which is fit </span>to be forbidden due <span class="gemarra-regular">to diverse kinds </span>of food crops that grew <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a vineyard </span>is forbidden due to <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds in a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vineyard </span>(<span class="it-text">Avoda</span> <span class="it-text">Zara</span> 74a). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it was stated about </span>the wording of this mishna that there is an amoraic dispute. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned: </span>Only <span class="gemarra-regular">that whose manner</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>exclusively <span class="gemarra-regular">to be counted </span>is significant and cannot be nullified, and it is therefore prohibited by Rabbi Meir. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned: Any </span>item <span class="gemarra-regular">whose manner is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">to be counted, </span>is significant and cannot be nullified.
Returning to the matter of the egg, the Gemara reprises its question: This works out <span class="gemarra-regular">well according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, but according to Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yoḥanan, what can be said? </span>Since an egg is not sold exclusively by unit, it is not significant. Therefore, the egg of a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span> should be nullified by a simple majority.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>According to Rabbi Yoḥanan, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who said that an egg cannot be nullified, <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> the <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">litr</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dried figs, who, </span>based on his statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Any item </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that is counted, even </span>if it is prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic </span><span class="gemarra-regular">law, cannot be nullified, and all the more so </span>items prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law, </span>e.g., the egg of a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we learned </span>in a mishna: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">litra</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">dried figs, </span>whose stems were removed, and were dried and pressed in different vessels and shaped into circles, the obligation to tithe fruits is by rabbinic law. If one forgot to tithe the figs, and later remembered that he placed the figs into a barrel, and during the process of producing a circle <span class="gemarra-regular">he pressed </span>the figs <span class="gemarra-regular">onto the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> mouth </span>of one of the <span class="gemarra-regular">circular </span>vessels in which the circles are formed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and does not know into which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">circular </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">he pressed it; </span>or, if he recalls that he pressed it <span class="gemarra-regular">on the mouth of a barrel, but </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does not know in which barrel he pressed it, </span>or if he recalls that he pressed it <span class="gemarra-regular">on the mouth </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of a </span>straw <span class="gemarra-regular">receptacle, but does not know in which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">receptacle he pressed it, Rabbi Meir says </span>that in all these cases there is a dispute between the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> of the previous generation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer </span>

Daf 4a

<span class="gemarra-regular">says: One considers the upper </span>circles of dried figs <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> though they are separate </span>pieces, rather than one unit. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the lower ones, </span>which were there beforehand and have certainly been tithed, <span class="gemarra-regular">nullify the upper ones, </span>as there are enough circles of figs in the entire barrel to nullify the upper <span class="it-text">litra</span>. 
In contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua says: If </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there are one hundred mouths </span>of different barrels or circular vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the prohibited <span class="it-text">litra</span> of untithed figs on the mouth of one of the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">is nullified </span>by a ratio of one part of prohibited figs to one hundred parts of similar, permitted figs. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if not, </span>all of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>circles of figs at the <span class="gemarra-regular">mouths </span>of the barrels or circular vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are prohibited, </span>as one of them clearly contains a prohibited <span class="it-text">litra</span> that has not been nullified. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span>figs on the <span class="gemarra-regular">insides </span>of the vessels <span class="gemarra-regular">are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted, </span>as the prohibited figs certainly did not reach there.This is Rabbi Meir’s version of the dispute.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says </span>a different version of the dispute. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: If there are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one hundred mouths </span>of vessels with permitted figs present <span class="gemarra-regular">there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>in addition to the prohibited one, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is nullified </span>by the one hundred permitted mouths. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if not, the </span>figs at the <span class="gemarra-regular">mouths are prohibited and </span>those at <span class="gemarra-regular">the bottom</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are permitted. Rabbi Yehoshua says: Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">there are three</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hundred mouths </span>present <span class="gemarra-regular">there, they are not nullified, </span>as this <span class="it-text">litra</span> cannot be nullified in any manner. Rav Pappa was referring to this opinion when he said that there is a <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, meaning Rabbi Yehoshua in Rabbi Yehuda’s version, who maintains that even an item occasionally sold by unit, e.g., a circle of dried figs, can never be nullified. 
The same mishna further states: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one pressed </span>the <span class="it-text">litra</span> of figs <span class="gemarra-regular">into a circular </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">but he does not know into which circular </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pressed it, everyone agrees </span>that the prohibited fig cakes <span class="gemarra-regular">are nullified. </span>The Gemara expresses surprise at this statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Everyone </span><span class="gemarra-regular">agrees? This is </span>the very matter of <span class="gemarra-regular">their dispute, </span>whether or not the <span class="it-text">litra</span> is nullified.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: This is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">said, </span>i.e., he meant the following: <span class="gemarra-regular">One pressed it onto a circular </span>vessel but <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">know onto which place, </span>which side of the <span class="gemarra-regular">circular </span>vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">he pressed it, whether on its north or on its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> south </span>side. In this case, as the prohibited <span class="it-text">litra</span> is not located in a specific place and it cannot be distinguished from the others, it certainly cannot be considered an object of significance, and <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">nullified. </span>
The Gemara explained why the egg mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, an egg laid by a chicken that is a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>, cannot be nullified even if it is mingled with a thousand permitted eggs. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Actually</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> can be explained as referring to a case where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>whether it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival or a weekday. </span>While it is true that according to most opinions this is a rabbinic prohibition, and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is generally lenient with regard to uncertainties involving rabbinic law, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is an object </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whose prohibition is temporary. And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any object</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whose prohibition is temporary, even </span>if it involves a <span class="gemarra-regular">rabbinic</span> prohibition, it <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot be nullified.</span>
§ It <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say in the name </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Eliezer: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an egg </span>laid on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">it and its mother may be eaten. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">are we dealing? If we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that this is dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with a chicken designated for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">food, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obviou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">it and its mother are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted. Rather, </span>say that this is dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with a chicken</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> designated for laying eggs, </span>but in that case <span class="gemarra-regular">it and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its mother are </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. Rabbi Zeira said </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should be understood as follows: The egg may <span class="gemarra-regular">be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> eaten on account of its mother; </span>if it is permitted to eat the chicken, the egg may also be eaten. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? </span>In which case is it necessary to apply this ruling? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>It is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">bought </span>this chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">without </span><span class="gemarra-regular">specifying </span>whether he intended to eat it or use it for its eggs. In that case, if the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">it has been </span>retroactively <span class="gemarra-regular">clarified that </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">intended for food, </span>and the eggs it lays are, therefore, permitted. If it was <span class="gemarra-regular">not slaughtered, it has </span><span class="gemarra-regular">been </span>retroactively <span class="gemarra-regular">clarified that it </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">intended for laying eggs, </span>and the eggs it lays are prohibited.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari said </span>that the phrase: It and its mother may be eaten, should not be taken literally. Rather, the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is teachin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an exaggeration [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">guzma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> for extra emphasis, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-italic">A</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: An egg</span> may <span class="gemarra-regular">be eaten, it and its mother, and a chick</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and its shell. </span>
The Gemara clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of this addition: <span class="gemarra-regular">Its shell? If we say </span>it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> actual shell, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a shell edible? Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> must be referring to the consumption of <span class="gemarra-regular">a chick </span>that is still <span class="gemarra-regular">in its shell. </span>This explanation is problematic, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov only </span>in permitting the eating of a chick immediately after it hatches, <span class="gemarra-regular">when it has </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">entered the world. However, when it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">entered the world, </span>i.e., if the chick is still in its shell, <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not disagree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Even the Rabbis accept that this chick has the status of a creeping animal and may not be eaten. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>evidently the expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">A chick and its shell, </span>should not be understood literally, as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">an exaggeration</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Here, too, </span>the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">It and its mother may be eaten, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> exaggeration. </span>It does not mean literally that the chick and its mother may be eaten, but is merely a statement of emphasis that the egg is undoubtedly permitted.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disputed the following issue (<span class="it-text">Eiruvin</span> 38b): If <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat and a Festival</span> occur on consecutive days, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span>An egg <span class="gemarra-regular">laid on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this one is prohibited on that one</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yoḥanan said: </span>An egg <span class="gemarra-regular">laid on this one is permitted</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on that one. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav holds </span>that when Shabbat and a Festival occur on consecutive days, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>continuous <span class="gemarra-regular">sanctity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., a single, indivisible day.
<span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rav say: The</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">four elders</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who ruled <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who said: </span>When a Shabbat and a Festival occur consecutively, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are two sanctities </span>rather than one long day; therefore, a joining of Shabbat boundaries need not be placed on a weekday, but may be placed on the first of the holy days to allow going beyond the Shabbat boundary on the second. Evidently, this issue cannot be the basis of their dispute. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, here</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they disagree with regard to Rabba’s preparation, </span>i.e., an item that was prepared on its own from one day to the other, whose use Rabba prohibits. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav holds</span> that items prepared by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba’s preparation </span>are prohibited, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan does not hold </span>that items prepared by means of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba’s preparation </span>are prohibited.
The Gemara comments: This dispute is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>An egg <span class="gemarra-regular">laid on Shabbat may be eaten on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival; </span>if it was laid <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival, it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may be eaten on Shabbat. Rabbi Yehuda says in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">name of Rabbi Eliezer: </span>This opinion is not unanimous; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is still a </span>matter of <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute, as Beit Shammai </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say it may be eaten, and Beit Hillel say it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may not be eaten, </span>just as they disagreed about whether an egg is permitted on the day on which it was laid.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Ahava’s host [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ushpizikhnei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> had these eggs </span>that were laid on a Festival that occurred on a Friday, and the host was unsure whether eggs laid on the Festival were permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival for </span>use on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He came before </span>his guest, Rav Adda, and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to roasting </span>these eggs <span class="gemarra-regular">now, </span>on the Festival, although eating them today is prohibited due to <span class="it-text">nolad</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and let us eat them tomorrow, </span>as they will be no longer be prohibited due to <span class="it-text">nolad</span>?
Rav Adda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">your opinio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that led you to pose this question? You evidently assume that in the dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yoḥanan, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>and therefore an egg laid on one day will be permitted on the following day. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">even Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yoḥanan permitted </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">to swallow it only </span>raw, <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the next day, </span>when it is no longer prohibited; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on the same day </span>that it was laid, he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permit one even to move it, and certainly not to roast it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught </span>likewise in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">both an egg </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that was laid on Shabbat and an egg that was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">laid on a Festival, one may not move it, neither </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to cover a vessel with it nor to support the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">legs of a bed with it.</span>
The Gemara relates a similar incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa’s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">host, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain man who came before Rav Pappa, had </span><span class="gemarra-regular">these eggs </span>that were laid on <span class="gemarra-regular">a Shabbat that </span>occurred before <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival. He came before him </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to whether it is permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">to eat </span>these eggs <span class="gemarra-regular">tomorrow, </span>on the Festival? Rav Pappa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Go </span>away from me <span class="gemarra-regular">now, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and come </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">tomorrow. </span>He said this because <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">not place a disseminato</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before him </span>to explain his lectures, <span class="gemarra-regular">from one Festival </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the end of the <span class="gemarra-regular">other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the second Festival day, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to drunkenness. </span>Since it was customary in those times to drink a great deal of wine during Festival meals, Rav was concerned that his mind would not be sufficiently clear to issue a public ruling. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>that man <span class="gemarra-regular">came </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the following day, </span>Rav Pappa <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>

Daf 4b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Had </span>I issued a ruling for you <span class="gemarra-regular">then</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, I would have forgotten </span>the correct response, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">would have said to you, </span>based on the accepted principle that in the case of a dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>that the eggs are permitted. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav with regard to these three </span>issues, in connection to the sanctity of Festivals and Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>his ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">lenient, or whether </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">stringent. </span>This is one of those three cases in which the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rav. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">branches that fell from a palm tre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on Shabbat, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited to kindle them on a Festival </span>that occurs the next day. <span class="gemarra-regular">And do not reply to me </span>by asking why I permit <span class="gemarra-regular">an egg </span>to be eaten on the following day. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for the distinction between the two cases? In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">egg, because on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">day </span>of Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">itself it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">also fit to be swallowed </span>raw <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to be eaten <span class="gemarra-regular">only the following day, one knows </span>that an egg <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited on the day </span>it was laid. In contrast, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">branches, which are not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fit </span>for kindling <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">day </span>of Shabbat, as kindling a fire is prohibited, <span class="gemarra-regular">if you permit them </span>to kindle the wood on the Festival that occurs on <span class="gemarra-regular">the following day</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they will </span>mistakenly <span class="gemarra-regular">come to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">day</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>fell off the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">they are also permitted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And </span>as for the reason the branches were not kindled <span class="gemarra-regular">yesterday </span>when they fell from the tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was due</span> only <span class="gemarra-regular">to Shabbat, as they were not fit for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">kindling </span>then.
