<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mattana said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">branches that fell from a palm tree </span>directly <span class="gemarra-regular">into an oven on a Festival, one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">add to </span>those branches <span class="gemarra-regular">wood prepare</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> from the previous day, which may be used for kindling, <span class="gemarra-regular">and kindle them </span>all together. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t he turn over </span>and move <span class="gemarra-regular">the prohibited </span>wood in the course of the cooking process? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since most </span>of the wood <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permitted, when he turns </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">over, he turns over permitted </span>wood, as the prohibited part is nullified by the majority. 
The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t he </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">nullif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a prohibited</span> item <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>by adding permitted wood to the pieces of wood that fell into the oven, which are prohibited? <span class="gemarra-regular">And we learned </span>in a mishna (see <span class="it-text">Terumot</span> 4:9): <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not nullify a prohibited </span>item <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">applies only to </span>items prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law; however with regard to </span>items prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rabbinic law, </span>as in this case involving the prohibition of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">nullif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> the prohibition <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who said: Any </span><span class="gemarra-regular">object whose prohibition is temporary, even </span>if the prohibition applies <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot be nullified, what is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there to say? </span>Doesn’t Rav Ashi agree that it is permitted to kindle the wood after the Festival? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">applies only where the prohibited </span>item <span class="gemarra-regular">remains intact; here, </span>however, <span class="gemarra-regular">the prohibited </span>item <span class="gemarra-regular">is burned, </span>as the wood is turned over when it has already become charcoal. Therefore, one does not perform any action with prohibited items. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that there is a dispute between <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> for the <span class="gemarra-regular">two Festival days </span>observed <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Diaspora</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>An egg that <span class="gemarra-regular">was laid on this </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permitted on that </span>one, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rav Asi said: </span>An egg that <span class="gemarra-regular">was laid on this </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say that Rav Asi holds </span>that the two days <span class="gemarra-regular">are one sanctity. But didn’t Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Asi </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">recite </span><span class="gemarra-italic">havdala</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the prayer of distinction at the end of a holy day, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival </span>day of the Diaspora <span class="gemarra-regular">to the other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> This shows that, in his opinion, the first day is the true Festival, while the second day is considered a weekday. In earlier generations, they observed the second day of the Diaspora because they were unaware when the court sanctified the New Moon to mark the beginning of the month. Today, that determination is accomplished by means of calculations known to all, and the second day is observed as the custom of our fathers, not due to any uncertainty.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi was uncertain</span> whether the Sages’ ordinance that the second day is to be observed as a Festival was a fixed ordinance that applies even when the calculations determining the New Moon are known to all; or whether the ordinance was based strictly on the uncertainty stemming from their lack of awareness. Today, when everyone is aware of the beginning of the month, the second day is a weekday. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">he acted stringently</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> here, </span>and prohibited eating an egg on the second day that had been laid on the first day. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>he also acted <span class="gemarra-regular">stringently here, </span>and recited <span class="it-text">havdala</span> between the two days.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">reasonable </span>to say <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi </span>that the Sages considered the two days as one and it is not a practice instituted due to uncertainty, <span class="gemarra-regular">as today we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">know the determination of the </span>first day of the new <span class="gemarra-regular">mont</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> based on a fixed calendar and the precise dates of the Festivals are known by all, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> observe </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">days </span>of the Diaspora. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>On the contrary, It is <span class="gemarra-regular">reasonable </span>to say <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>that the second day is observed as a Festival due to uncertainty, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Rosh</span> <span class="it-text">HaShana</span> 22b): <span class="gemarra-regular">Initially, </span>after the court sanctified the new month, <span class="gemarra-regular">they would light torches </span>on the mountain tops, from one peak to another, to signal that the New Moon had been sanctified. <span class="gemarra-regular">After the Samaritans </span>[<span class="gemarra-italic">Kutim</span>] <span class="gemarra-regular">disrupted </span>this method by lighting torches at the wrong times, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that messengers should depart </span>to inform the people of the start of the month. Since the messengers could not reach all Diaspora communities before the beginning of the Festival, the Sages instituted that an additional Festival day should be observed there, due to the resultant uncertainty with regard to which day was the actual Festival day. 
Abaye continues his argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Samaritans had desiste</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> from their interference, the Sages would have restored the earlier custom and <span class="gemarra-regular">we would observe </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one day. And</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>similarly, in a place <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">messengers arrived </span>from Jerusalem on time, <span class="gemarra-regular">we observe </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">day.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And now that we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> know the determination of the </span>first day of the new <span class="gemarra-regular">month, what is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we observe two </span>Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">days </span>in the Diaspora? <span class="gemarra-regular">Because they sent </span>a warning <span class="gemarra-regular">from there, </span>from Eretz Yisrael: Although now there is a fixed calendar and there is no uncertainty, <span class="gemarra-regular">be careful to</span> observe <span class="gemarra-regular">the custom of your fathers </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you received, </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">at times the monarchy </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">issue decrees </span>of persecution restricting Torah study and the fixed calendar may be forgotten. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the people will <span class="gemarra-regular">come to </span>have their proper observance of the Festivals <span class="gemarra-regular">be disrupted </span>again. However, the fundamental <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that the observance of two Festival days is based on uncertainty.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was </span>further <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>that the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> discussed a similar problem, with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">two Festival days of Rosh HaShana. Rav and Shmuel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">both said: </span>An egg <span class="gemarra-regular">laid on this </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on that one, </span>as the two days of Rosh HaShana have a special status. <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Rosh</span> <span class="it-text">HaShana</span> 30b): <span class="gemarra-regular">Initially, </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">would accept testimony</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>witnesses who saw the new moon to establish the first day of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>new <span class="gemarra-regular">month. </span>This system would also be used for the first of Tishrei, which is Rosh HaShana, and the court would accept this testimony on <span class="gemarra-regular">the entire </span>thirtieth <span class="gemarra-regular">da</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> of the month of Elul. <span class="gemarra-regular">Once</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, the witnesses tarried </span>and managed <span class="gemarra-regular">to arrive </span>only when the hour was late, 

Daf 5a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and the Levites </span><span class="gemarra-regular">erred in the song</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> They were unsure whether to sing the weekday song or that of Rosh HaShana during the sacrifice of the afternoon daily offering, as it was unclear whether or not witnesses would arrive that day. From that point on, the court <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted that they would accept </span><span class="gemarra-regular">witnesses </span>who came to testify that that day was Rosh HaShana <span class="gemarra-regular">only up to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">minḥa</span> time, i.e., when the daily afternoon offering was sacrificed. If witnesses had not arrived by then, they would declare Elul a thirty-day month and calculate the dates of the Festivals accordingly.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if witnesses came from </span><span class="gemarra-italic">minḥa</span> time <span class="gemarra-regular">onward, </span>although the calculations for the dates of the Festivals began only from the following day, the people would nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">observe </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that day </span>on which the witnesses arrived as <span class="gemarra-regular">sacred, and </span>they would also observe <span class="gemarra-regular">the following day </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">sacred. </span>On the second day, they observed Rosh HaShana in full, both by sacrificing its offerings as well as calculating the upcoming Festivals from that date. It is evident that the observance of two days of Rosh HaShana did not stem from uncertainty in the Diaspora as to when the Festival began. Rather, the Sages instituted that the two days of Rosh HaShana are one unit due to the inherent difficulty in determining the date of a Festival that is celebrated on the first of the month.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: From </span>the time of <span class="gemarra-regular">the ordinance of Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> onward, an egg</span> laid on one day of Rosh HaShana <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted </span>on the other. <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Rosh</span> <span class="it-text">HaShana</span> 30b): <span class="gemarra-regular">After the Temple was destroyed, Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> instituted that </span>the court <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span>once again <span class="gemarra-regular">accept testimony </span>to determine the start of <span class="gemarra-regular">the month all day. </span>Since the concern about errors was no longer relevant, they reverted to the original custom. As the court was aware of the exact date based on the testimony of the witnesses, those in proximity to the court kept only one day of Rosh HaShana. Those who lived far from the court observed two days merely due to uncertainty, and as one of those days was certainly a weekday, an egg laid on the first day was permitted on the second.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: But didn’t Rav and Shmuel both say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an egg is prohibited? </span>Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Your question is out of place; <span class="gemarra-regular">I say to you </span>a statement in the name of the distinguished <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Yoḥanan ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Zakkai, and you say to me </span>a ruling of the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and Shmuel? </span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and Shmuel, </span>isn’t it true that <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna is difficult, </span>as it indicates that the special status of Rosh HaShana has been revoked? The Gemara answers that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is for us, </span>those who live outside of Eretz Yisrael, who have kept the ancient custom of observing two Festival days, and therefore Rosh HaShana is still considered one long day and constitute a single sanctity. Conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>ruling of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is for them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the inhabitants of Eretz Yisrael. Since Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai instituted that the court should once again accept testimony all day concerning the new moon, then even if circumstances dictate that Rosh HaShana would be observed for two days, each day is considered an independent sanctity.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yosef said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Even from the </span>time of the <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance of Rabban Yoḥanan</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Zakkai onward, an egg </span>remains <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for the opinion of Rav Yosef? It is that the decree prohibiting an egg laid on the first day of Rosh HaShana on the second day of Rosh HaShana <span class="gemarra-regular">is a matter that </span>was established <span class="gemarra-regular">by a vot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of the Sanhedrin, after that occasion on which the witnesses failed to arrive on time, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">any matter that </span>was established <span class="gemarra-regular">by a vote requires another </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vote to permit it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> A new vote must be taken to render the prohibited item permitted, as the prohibition does not lapse even if the reason for the decree no longer applies. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: From where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do I say </span>my opinion? <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is written, </span>after the Jews received the Torah: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Go, say to them: Return</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to your tents</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Deuteronomy 5:26), where “your tents” is referring to your wives. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it says, </span>before the revelation at Sinai: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">When the ram’s horn sounds long, they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may come up to the mount</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Exodus 19:13). And it is stated: “Be ready for the third day, do not come near a woman” (Exodus 19:15). In other words, although the original prohibition served a particular purpose, in this case the giving of the Torah, it was nevertheless necessary to explicitly render the prohibition permitted.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this idea <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: The fruit of a <span class="gemarra-regular">fourth-year grapevine</span> have the status of second-tithe fruits, and therefore their owner <span class="gemarra-regular">would ascend to Jerusalem </span>and eat them there. If he was unable to do so, due to the distance involved or the weight of the load, he could redeem the fruits with money where he was, and later redeem that money for other fruits in Jerusalem. However, the Sages decreed that fruit from the environs of Jerusalem should not be redeemed, but that the owners should bring the fruit itself to Jerusalem. The environs of Jerusalem for this purpose were defined as <span class="gemarra-regular">a day’s walk in each </span><span class="gemarra-regular">direction. And this is its boundary: Eilat to the north; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Akrabat to the south; Lod to the west; and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Jordan to the east</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Ulla said, and some say Rabba </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar bar Ḥana </span>said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>For <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>did the Sages institute this ordinance, that someone who lived near Jerusalem must bring his fruit there? <span class="gemarra-regular">In order </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to adorn the markets of Jerusale</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with fruit, </span>as this decree ensured that there was always an abundance of fruit in Jerusalem for people to eat.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And it was</span> further <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer </span>ben Hyrcanus, a student of Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai, <span class="gemarra-regular">had a fourth-year</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> grapevine </span>located between Lod and Jerusalem, <span class="gemarra-regular">to the east </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Lod alongside the village of Tavi. </span>The grapevine was within the environs of Jerusalem for the purpose of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. Rabbi Eliezer could not bring the fruit to the Temple, as it had been destroyed, 

Daf 5b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he sought to render </span>the fruit <span class="gemarra-regular">ownerless </span>in favor <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the poor, </span>for whom it would be worth the effort to bring the fruit to Jerusalem. <span class="gemarra-regular">His students said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: Rabbi, </span>there is no need to do so, as <span class="gemarra-regular">your colleagues have already voted </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">you and permitted it.</span> The members of the Sanhedrin have already taken a vote and permitted the redemption of the fruit of a fourth-year grapevine even near Jerusalem. The reason is that after the destruction of the Temple there is no need to adorn the markets of Jerusalem. The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who are</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Your colleagues? </span>This is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara infers from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason is that they </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">voted </span>to annul the decree, which indicates that if <span class="gemarra-regular">they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> had not voted, </span>the ordinance would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have lapsed on its own, despite the fact that its justification was no longer applicable. Similarly, the prohibition of a laid egg is not nullified, as it was never explicitly permitted.
The Gemara to seeks to clarify why Rav Yosef cited two verses as proof. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the reason for: <span class="gemarra-regular">And it says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Why does Rav Yosef find it necessary to quote a second verse? The Gemara explains that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is </span>what he <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying. Now since it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is written:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Be ready for the third day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not come near a woman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Exodus 19:15), <span class="gemarra-regular">why do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I </span>need the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Go, say to them: Return to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> your tents</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Deuteronomy 5:26)? After three days the prohibition would lapse in any case. <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from this </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span><span class="gemarra-regular">matter </span>established by <span class="gemarra-regular">a vote requires another vote to permit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>an alternative explanation, that the instruction to “return to your tents” was not given to permit the men to return home to their wives, but rather <span class="gemarra-regular">it came </span>as a special command <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>fulfill <span class="gemarra-regular">the mitzva of conjugal rights, </span>i.e., the obligation of a man to engage in periodic marital relations with his wife, then it was to refute this possibility that Rav Yosef continued: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a different proof from another verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">When the ram’s horn sounds long, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they may come up to the mount</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Exodus 19:13).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Now since it is written:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Neither shall</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the flock</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor the herds feed before that mount</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Exodus 34:3), this indicates that the prohibition applies only when the Divine Presence is revealed on the mountain, and it is permitted immediately afterward. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">When the ram’s horn sounds long”? </span>Why is a special signal required? <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclude from this </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">any matter </span>established by <span class="gemarra-regular">a vote requires another vote to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permit it.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say: That </span>statement, that a specific vote is necessary, <span class="gemarra-regular">applies </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> matters prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law, but </span>in the case of a matter prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law, no, </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> does not apply, <span class="gemarra-regular">come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fourth-year grapevine. </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that the fruit of <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fourth-year grapevine </span>must be brought to Jerusalem and may not be redeemed is <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law, and they </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to Rabbi Eliezer: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your colleagues have already voted </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">you and permitted it. </span>This indicates that without a vote, the prohibition would not be abrogated.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if you say: </span>In the case of the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">an egg also, Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai took a vote</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on it and permitted it; </span>the Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> took a vote, </span>it was with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to testimony </span>to determine the start of the month; <span class="gemarra-regular">they did not take</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a vote to </span>annul the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">an egg.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an egg was </span>prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">by a vote</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Did the court take a special vote to render prohibited an egg laid on Rosh HaShana? Isn’t the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">egg dependent on </span>the matter of <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony? </span>When <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony </span>in the late afternoon <span class="gemarra-regular">was prohibited, </span>the eating of <span class="gemarra-regular">an egg </span>laid on Rosh HaShana <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>as well, and when this <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony was permitted, </span>the eating of <span class="gemarra-regular">an egg</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was </span>automatically <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted. </span>Rav Yosef’s observation is therefore incorrect. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda and Rav Shalman, </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>came <span class="gemarra-regular">from Bei Keloḥit, said: Even from the </span>time of the <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance of Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">onward, an egg </span>remains <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. What is the reason? May</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Temple speedily be built, </span>and the ordinance that testimony is accepted only until <span class="it-text">minḥa</span> time will be restored, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> people <span class="gemarra-regular">will say: Last year, didn’t we eat an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> egg </span>laid on the first day of Rosh HaShana <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span> the following day, <span class="gemarra-regular">the second Festival </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>Rosh HaShana? <span class="gemarra-regular">Now, too, we will eat </span>it, like last year. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they will not know </span>the significant difference in <span class="it-text">halakha</span> between the two cases, as <span class="gemarra-regular">last year </span>the two days of Rosh HaShana were <span class="gemarra-regular">two sanctities, and now they are one</span> long <span class="gemarra-regular">sanctity.</span>
The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>that this is the concern, <span class="gemarra-regular">we also should </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not accept testimony </span>nowadays. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason? May the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Temple speedily be built, and </span>the people <span class="gemarra-regular">will say: Last</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> year, didn’t we accept testimony </span>to determine the start of <span class="gemarra-regular">the month all day? Now, too, we will accept</span> the testimony of witnesses even after <span class="it-text">minḥa</span> time.
The Gemara rejects this challenge: <span class="gemarra-regular">How can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> compared? There, </span>with regard to witnesses, <span class="gemarra-regular">testimony is entrusted </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the court, </span>and the court is capable of distinguishing between the reasons for decrees. <span class="gemarra-regular">An egg, </span>however, is <span class="gemarra-regular">entrusted </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to all, </span>and as not all people will consult a Sage about the status of their eggs, there is a legitimate concern about error. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Even from the </span>time of the <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinance of Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai and onward, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an egg </span>remains <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. </span>Rava explained his reasoning: <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai conced</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that if witnesses came</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span><span class="gemarra-italic">minḥa</span> time <span class="gemarra-regular">and onward, </span>even after the destruction of the Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">then one observes that day </span>as a <span class="gemarra-regular">holy </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">the following day </span>as a <span class="gemarra-regular">holy</span> day? The only difference is that during the time of the Temple any testimony delivered on the first day was not taken into account at all, which meant the second day was considered the first of the new year, whereas during the time of Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai the new year was counted from the first day. 
As far as the sanctity of the Festival is concerned, however, the second day was also treated as sacred, which proves that when two days were observed in Eretz Yisrael, they were considered a single sanctity rather than two. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava said </span>in summary: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav in these three </span>cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>the ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">lenient</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, or whether </span>the ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">stringent. </span>

Daf 6a

§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">died on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> first day of a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gentiles should attend to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his </span>burial. If he <span class="gemarra-regular">died on the second day of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Jews should attend to his </span>burial. <span class="gemarra-regular">And even</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to the two Festival days of Rosh HaShana</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that the legal status of the two days is like that of the two days of the Festivals; however, <span class="gemarra-regular">that is not so with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an egg </span>that was laid on the first day of Rosh HaShana, as it remains prohibited on the second day.
The Sages of <span class="gemarra-regular">Neharde’a say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Even with regard to an egg, </span>Rosh HaShana is no different from other Festivals, as an egg laid on the first day is permitted on the second. <span class="gemarra-regular">As what do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you think</span> i.e., what is your concern; <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>witnesses will fail to arrive, and the court <span class="gemarra-regular">will proclaim </span>the month of <span class="gemarra-regular">Elul full, </span>i.e., thirty days long, and begin counting the year only from the following day? In that case, both days are kept as sacred <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t Rav Ḥinnana bar Kahana say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span> in this regard: <span class="gemarra-regular">From the days of Ezra and onward</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we have not found </span>that the month of <span class="gemarra-regular">Elul </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">full</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the Sages employed various methods to ensure that there would be no need to add a thirtieth day. Consequently, Rosh HaShana would always occur on the thirtieth day after the beginning of Elul.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: We said </span>that Jews should attend to the dead on the second day of Rosh HaShana <span class="gemarra-regular">only when </span>the burial of the corpse <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">been delaye</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and for some reason the burial was not on the day that he died. In that case, the body might begin to decay, and the dignity of the dead is at stake. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>if the burial <span class="gemarra-regular">has not been delayed, </span>and there is no concern for the dignity of the corpse, its burial may not be attended to on the Festival; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">we delay it </span>until the Festival has ended. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: Even </span><span class="gemarra-regular">though </span>the burial <span class="gemarra-regular">was not delayed, </span>but it is the day that he died, <span class="gemarra-regular">we still do not delay </span>the burial. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the dead, the Sages equated </span>the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">the second Festival day with </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">a weekday. </span>This is true to such an extent that on a Festival it is permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">even to cut </span>material to fashion <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cloak for </span>the deceased. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, it is permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">to cut myrtles for </span>the deceased, to be placed on the bier in their honor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: And nowadays, when there are </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥabarei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> this practice must be adjusted. The <span class="it-text">ḥabarei</span> were Persian priests who made false accusations against Jews in Babylonia. They cited the fact that Jews were burying their dead on the second Festival day as proof that the day was not holy, and they forced them to work on that day. Since <span class="gemarra-regular">we are concerned </span>about this possibility, we do not bury the dead on the second day.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sat before Rav Ashi on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> two Festival days of Rosh HaShana, </span>which occurred that year on Thursday and Friday. Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">observed that </span>Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">was sad. He said to him: Why is the Master </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sad? He said to him: </span>Because <span class="gemarra-regular">I did not prepare </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a joining of cooked foods, </span>and therefore I cannot prepare food or light a candle on Rosh HaShana for the upcoming Shabbat. When a Festival immediately precedes Shabbat, a joining of cooked foods is prepared before the Festival with ready-to-eat food. It is kept until Shabbat, symbolically indicating that any food prepared on the Festival for Shabbat is merely a continuation of that initial preparation.
Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: And let the Master </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prepare a joining of cooked foods now, </span>on the first day of Rosh HaShana, a Thursday. <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t Rava say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">A person may prepare a joining of cooked foods from </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival day </span>of the Diaspora <span class="gemarra-regular">to another, by stipulatin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> the following condition: If today is a weekday and tomorrow is holy, this shall be my joining of cooked foods, by means of which I may prepare food tomorrow for Shabbat; if today is holy and tomorrow a weekday, it is permitted to prepare food tomorrow as it is on any regular weekday, and a joining of cooked foods in not needed. 
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: </span>You can <span class="gemarra-regular">say that Rava stated </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the regular <span class="gemarra-regular">two Festival days of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Diaspora; </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">did he </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say so with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the two Festival days of Rosh HaShana? </span>The two days of Rosh HaShana are considered one long day, and they are both equally holy.
Ravina replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t </span>the Sages of <span class="gemarra-regular">Neharde’a say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even an egg </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted </span>on the two days of Rosh HaShana, which are treated exactly the same as other Festival days in the Diaspora? The same ruling should apply to a joining of cooked foods. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mordekhai said to </span>Ravina: This does not resolve Rav Ashi’s difficulty, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the Master, </span>Rav Ashi, <span class="gemarra-regular">explicitly said to me that he does not hold </span>in accordance <span class="gemarra-regular">with this </span>opinion of the Sages of <span class="gemarra-regular">Neharde’a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Rather, he maintains that Rosh HaShana differs from other Festivals, and in this case there is no way to make up for failure to prepare a joining of cooked foods.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disputed the following case: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a chick that hatched on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival, Rav said: It is prohibited. And Shmuel, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">some say Rabbi Yoḥanan, said: It is permitted. </span>The Gemara explains the reasoning for their respective opinions. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: It </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span><span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And Shmuel, and some </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say Rabbi Yoḥanan said: It is permitted, since it itself </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is rendered permitted through slaughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The slaughter of the chicken, which renders it fit to be eaten, is made possible by its hatching. Consequently, hatching likewise removes the prohibition of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Kahana and Rav As</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to Rav: And what is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the difference between this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">a calf</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> born on a Festival, </span>since you agree that a calf may be slaughtered on that day? <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>There is a difference. <span class="gemarra-regular">Since </span>a calf inside its mother is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared on account of its mother, by slaughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is as follows: If a cow is slaughtered, the calf inside its womb is also permitted. Therefore, that calf never had the status of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, whereas the chick was considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span> before it hatched.
Rav Kahana and Rav Ashi further challenged Rav: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the difference between this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>If the mother has a condition that will cause it to die within twelve months, neither it nor the calf inside it may be eaten. Nevertheless, after it is born the calf may be slaughtered on a Festival and it is permitted. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">silent </span>and did not offer an answer, as though he did not know how to respond to the question.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef: What is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav was silent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Let him say </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to them: </span>Even a calf born to a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span> mother is not considered fully <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">since it is prepared on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> account of its mother </span>to be fed <span class="gemarra-regular">to dogs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> On a Festival, it is permitted to slaughter a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span> and give it to dogs as food, and therefore the calf is not fully <span class="it-text">muktze</span> even before it is born. By contrast, a chick in its shell is not intended as food for dogs, and therefore a chick that hatched on a Festival was unfit for use when the Festival began. Consequently, it was considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span> and it is now <span class="it-text">nolad</span>, an object that came into being on Shabbat or a Festival, and it is therefore prohibited.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>

Daf 6b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Now, </span>we know that food <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared, </span>i.e., fit, <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> human </span>consumption that became spoiled <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>automatically considered <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for dogs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as we learned </span>in a mishna (see 2a): <span class="gemarra-regular">One may cut pumpkins before an animal </span>to facilitate their consumption, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>likewise one may cut up an <span class="gemarra-regular">animal</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> carcass, </span>even of an animal that died on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">before</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dogs. Rabbi Yehuda says: If </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was not </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">a carcass, </span>i.e., it was not dead and fit for dogs, <span class="gemarra-regular">prior to Shabbat, it is prohibited, because it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not in the </span>category of items considered <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>for use on Shabbat. This shows that although this animal was fit for human consumption while alive, it does not automatically become prepared for dogs once it dies. If so, can food <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared for dogs </span>be considered <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared for humans?</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">He said to him: Yes. </span>It is not surprising that something <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>and fit <span class="gemarra-regular">for humans is not </span>considered fit and <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared for dogs, as that which is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fit for a person, one does not throw it to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dogs, </span>and he has therefore removed that animal from his mind. However, something <span class="gemarra-regular">that is prepared for dogs </span>is also considered fit and <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared for humans, as a person’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mind is on anything fit to </span>be eaten by <span class="gemarra-regular">him. </span>One does not completely remove from his mind even food meant for dogs, if it is kosher and edible. Consequently, one has in mind the possibility that he might eat the calf of a cow that is a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span> once it is born, since at that point it will be kosher and edible.
With regard to the dispute itself, the Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav; and it is taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, and some say </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan. </span>
The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> A calf born on a Festival is permitted; a chick</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> born on a Festival is prohibited. And what is the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> difference between this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">and that one? This one, </span>the calf, <span class="gemarra-regular">is prepared on account of its mother by slaughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; and that one, </span>the chick, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not prepared on account</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of its mother. </span>
The Gemara further explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught</span> in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and some say </span>it is the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: A calf born on a Festiva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a chick born on a Festival is </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted. What </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is the reason? This one, </span>the calf, <span class="gemarra-regular">is prepared on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">account of its mother; and that one, </span>the chick, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">itself rendered permitted through slaughter. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A chick born on a Festiva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prohibited. Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: Even on a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> weekday, </span>the chick <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited </span>on the day it hatched <span class="gemarra-regular">because its eyes have not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">opened</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> A small chick of this kind is not yet considered a bird fit for consumption; rather, it is similar to a creeping animal.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with whose</span> opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is that which is taught: </span>The verse that states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Even all creeping animals that creep upon the earth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>you shall not eat them, for they are a detestable thing” (Leviticus 11:42) comes <span class="gemarra-regular">to include </span>in the list of prohibited creeping animals even <span class="gemarra-regular">chicks that have not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">opened</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their eyes. In accordance with whose </span>opinion is this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Ya’akov.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: An egg is fully </span>formed <span class="gemarra-regular">upon its emergence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> i.e., it is not considered an egg until it is laid. The Gemara inquires: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of the statement: An egg <span class="gemarra-regular">is fully formed upon its emergence? </span>To which issue is Rava referring? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>he meant an egg <span class="gemarra-regular">is fully formed </span>and called an egg only <span class="gemarra-regular">upon its emergence, and </span>at this stage <span class="gemarra-regular">it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted to eat it with milk</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> this indicates that while an egg is still <span class="gemarra-regular">inside its mother, </span>even if it is fully formed, it is considered meat and it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to eat it with milk. But isn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> slaughters a chicken and finds fully </span>formed <span class="gemarra-regular">eggs inside it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, it is permitted to eat them with milk</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rav’s statement should be explained as follows: An egg <span class="gemarra-regular">is fully formed upon its emergence </span>in that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted to eat it on a Festival </span>only if the entire egg emerged on a weekday. The Gemara expresses surprise at this claim: This indicates that if an egg is found <span class="gemarra-regular">inside its mother, it is prohibited to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eat it on a Festival. But isn’t it taught:</span> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who slaughters a chicken and finds</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fully </span>formed <span class="gemarra-regular">eggs inside it, it is permitted to eat</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them on a Festival?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teaches u</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that which the mishna did not </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">teach us, </span>and Rav stated the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> accordingly; however, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>in the mishna here, as it says in the mishna: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an egg laid on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival, Beit Shammai say it may be eaten, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel say it may not be eaten. And Beit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shammai and Beit Hillel disagree only with regard to </span>an egg that was already <span class="gemarra-regular">laid, but </span>concerning eggs <span class="gemarra-regular">inside their </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mothers, all agree </span>that they <span class="gemarra-regular">are permitted.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that the mishna should be explained in the opposite manner, as <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel also prohibit </span>eggs <span class="gemarra-regular">inside their mothers, and </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: Laid, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">to convey the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">far-reaching nature of </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they permit even </span>an egg that <span class="gemarra-regular">was laid. However, </span>consider <span class="gemarra-regular">that which is taught </span>in the aforementioned <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who slaughters a chicken and finds inside it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fully formed eggs, it is permitted to eat them on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a Festival. </span>In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion is this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? It is the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">neither </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai nor </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>Rav certainly did not prohibit an egg that has not yet been laid. Instead, his statement should be explained as follows: An egg <span class="gemarra-regular">is fully formed upon its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> emergence, and it produces chicks, </span>i.e., an egg laid in the regular manner can be incubated and a chick will hatch from it. By contrast, an egg that remained <span class="gemarra-regular">inside its mother cannot produce chicks. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is the practical </span>halakhic <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>of this observation? The Gemara answers: It is relevant <span class="gemarra-regular">for buying and selling. </span>In other words, the difference between the types of eggs has ramifications for terms of commerce. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like </span>that incident involving <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the general public: <span class="gemarra-regular">Eggs </span>

Daf 7a

<span class="gemarra-regular">of a live </span>chicken, <span class="gemarra-regular">who has? </span>He sought to purchase eggs of this kind. <span class="gemarra-regular">They gave him eggs of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a slaughtered </span>chicken. <span class="gemarra-regular">He came before Rabbi Ami, </span>claiming he had been cheated. Rabbi Ami <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the sellers: This <span class="gemarra-regular">is a mistaken transaction</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and it is rescinded; </span>the sale is void. 
The Gemara asks: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obviou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that the transaction is void, as he specified exactly what he wanted. The Gemara answers: The ruling is necessary, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>individual <span class="gemarra-regular">wants them for food </span>rather than for chicks, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that which he said, </span>that he is looking for eggs <span class="gemarra-regular">of a live </span>chicken, he said only <span class="gemarra-regular">because they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are hard-shelled, </span>mature eggs. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the practical </span><span class="gemarra-regular">difference, </span>i.e., what is this man claiming from the seller according to this rejected interpretation? He is merely demanding <span class="gemarra-regular">to refund him the difference </span>in value <span class="gemarra-regular">between the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tw</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> types of eggs. Rabbi Ami therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the sale involved a fundamental error, as the eggs of a slaughtered chicken are unfit for incubation. The transaction is therefore void. 
The Gemara relates a similar incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">A certain</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> person said to </span>vendors: Does <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone </span>have <span class="gemarra-regular">eggs of </span>a chicken that has had relations with <span class="gemarra-regular">a rooster? </span>Does <span class="gemarra-regular">anyone</span> have <span class="gemarra-regular">eggs of a rooster? They gave him eggs </span>that a hen had <span class="gemarra-regular">absorbed from the ground, </span>i.e., which had not been fertilized by a rooster. <span class="gemarra-regular">He came </span><span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi Ami </span>claiming that he had been cheated. Rabbi Ami <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">is a mistaken transaction, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is rescinded.</span>
The Gemara again asks: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that this is the case. The Gemara explains: The ruling is necessary, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">wants </span>the eggs <span class="gemarra-regular">for food, and that which he said, </span>that he wants eggs <span class="gemarra-regular">of a rooster, </span>he said only <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they are fatter. What is the practical difference; </span>i.e., what is this man claiming from the seller according to this rejected interpretation? He is merely demanding <span class="gemarra-regular">that they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> should refund him the difference </span>in value <span class="gemarra-regular">between the two</span> types. Rav Ami therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this is not the case; rather, the sale is void.
The Gemara suggests another explanation of Rav’s statement. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the meaning of the claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">An egg is fully </span><span class="gemarra-regular">formed upon its emergence? </span>It means that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is fully </span><span class="gemarra-regular">formed with the emergence of most of it, in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan. As Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>It is taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an egg, most of which emerged </span>from the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival eve, and </span>the egg <span class="gemarra-regular">returne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> inside the mother and was finally laid on the Festival itself, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted to eat </span>this egg <span class="gemarra-regular">on the Festival. </span>Since most of the egg had emerged before the Festival began, it is considered to have been laid the day before.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And some say </span>the following explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>the meaning of the expression: <span class="gemarra-regular">Fully formed upon its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> emergence? </span>It means that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is fully formed upon the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> emergence of all of it. </span>The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Upon </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the emergence of all of it, yes, </span>it is fully formed at this stage; <span class="gemarra-regular">however, </span>if only <span class="gemarra-regular">most of it</span> came out the day before, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>it is not considered fully formed. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this reading serves <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yoḥanan. </span>In any case, Rav’s statement can correspond to this statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
§ Apropos the halakhic status of eggs found inside a slaughtered chicken, the Gemara discusses <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who slaughters a chicken and finds inside it fully formed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> eggs, it is permitted to eat </span>these eggs <span class="gemarra-regular">with milk</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Rabbi Ya’akov says: If </span>the eggs <span class="gemarra-regular">were </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">attached</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by sinews, it is prohibited </span>to eat them with milk, as they are considered meat.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who is the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who eats</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the unslaughtered carcass of a kosher bird</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or <span class="gemarra-regular">from a cluster of eggs </span>that are still attached to it by sinews, or <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">bones, or from the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sinews, or from meat that has been detached from a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> live </span>animal, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually pure </span>because none of these are considered part of the meat of the bird, and therefore they do not impart the ritual impurity of an animal carcass. 
However, if one ate <span class="gemarra-regular">from the ovary of </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">eggs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which contains very small eggs that do not possess any of the regular characteristics of eggs, or if he took a piece <span class="gemarra-regular">of the craw or the intestines</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, or if he melted the fat </span>of a dead bird <span class="gemarra-regular">and swallowed it, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually impure </span>from the impurity imparted by the unslaughtered carcass of a bird.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Who is the</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>that if one ate <span class="gemarra-regular">from a cluster</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of eggs he is pure, </span>which indicates that eggs still attached by sinews to the chicken are not considered part of the meat of the bird? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>This ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov. For if </span>you say it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov, didn’t </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he say: If </span>the eggs <span class="gemarra-regular">were attached by sinews </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to eat them with milk, indicating that he considers these eggs meat of the chicken. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>do you draw this conclusion? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps Rabbi Ya’akov stated </span>that these eggs are part of the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">only there, with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibition </span>against eating the eggs with milk; <span class="gemarra-regular">however, </span>perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to ritual impurity </span>he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>say that these eggs are considered part of the chicken. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to </span>ritual <span class="gemarra-regular">impurity let us also issue a decree</span> and be stringent in a case of uncertainty and therefore rule that these attached eggs should be considered part of the chicken, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>would serve to <span class="gemarra-regular">proliferate impurity, and we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do not proliferate impurity </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic law</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> One does not declare an item ritually impure by rabbinic law merely because uncertainty has arisen with regard to its status. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And some say </span>a different version of this discussion, according to which the question is: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who is the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>that if one eats <span class="gemarra-regular">from the ovary of </span>its <span class="gemarra-regular">eggs he is ritually impure?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yosef said: It is Rabbi Ya’akov, who said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: If </span>the eggs <span class="gemarra-regular">were attached by sinews, they are prohibited</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Abaye said to him: From where </span>do you know <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> the term <span class="gemarra-regular">ovary </span>means: <span class="gemarra-regular">From these </span>eggs <span class="gemarra-regular">that are hanging</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the ovary; perhaps </span>it is referring to the <span class="gemarra-regular">ovary</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> itself, </span>the part of the flesh of the bird where the eggs develop?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if you say: </span>If it is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the ovary </span><span class="gemarra-regular">itself, what </span>is the purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">of stating </span>this? It is obvious that the ovary itself is meat. One can answer as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as it is in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">the craw and the intestines, that even though they are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">meat </span>according to all opinions, <span class="gemarra-regular">since there are people who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do not eat </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was necessary to teach us </span>that they have the status of meat; <span class="gemarra-regular">here, too, </span>with regard to an ovary, <span class="gemarra-regular">since there are people who do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not eat </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was necessary to teach us </span>that it may not be eaten with milk. Therefore, this argument does not prove that this version of the discussion is incorrect.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any </span>species <span class="gemarra-regular">whose intercourse </span>occurs only <span class="gemarra-regular">in the </span>hours of the <span class="gemarra-regular">day </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">born </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">by day; any </span>species <span class="gemarra-regular">whose intercourse </span><span class="gemarra-regular">occurs </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">at night is born </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">by night; any </span>species <span class="gemarra-regular">whose intercourse occurs either by day or by night </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is born either by day or by night. </span>The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any </span>species <span class="gemarra-regular">whose intercourse occurs by day is born </span><span class="gemarra-regular">by day, this </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a chicken</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Any </span>species <span class="gemarra-regular">whose intercourse occurs by night is born by night, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this is a bat. Any </span>species <span class="gemarra-regular">whose intercourse occurs either </span><span class="gemarra-regular">by day or by night, </span>this means <span class="gemarra-regular">a human </span>being <span class="gemarra-regular">and all that are similar to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said: Any </span>species <span class="gemarra-regular">whose intercourse occurs </span><span class="gemarra-regular">by day is born by day, this is a chicken. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="gemarra-regular">practical </span>halakhic <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>of this statement? The Gemara answers: The halakhic difference is with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to that which Rav Mari</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> son of Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Kahana </span>said, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav Mari, son of Rav Kahana said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">examined a chicken’s nest on a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> eve and did not find an egg in it, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the following day, </span>on the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">he rose early </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and found an egg in it, </span>the egg is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted, </span>as it can be assumed it was not laid that night.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t he examine </span>the nest before the Festival and fail to find an egg there? If so, the egg must have been laid on the Festival. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">examine very carefully. And even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he did examine carefully, </span>you can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">most of </span>the egg <span class="gemarra-regular">emerge</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> on the eve of the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">and returned </span>inside its mother, and this ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan. </span>This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> shows that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> does not take into account the possibility that a chicken could lay an egg at night.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? But didn’t Rabbi Yosei</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Shaul say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one examined a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> chicken’s nest on a Festival eve and did not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> find an egg in it, and the following day he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rose early and found an egg in it, it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prohibited? </span>This indicates that a chicken might indeed lay an egg at night. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>an egg <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">absorbed from the earth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., one that was not formed by male fertilization. An egg that is not produced by intercourse can be laid at night as well.
The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari’s</span> case <span class="gemarra-regular">too, </span>you can <span class="gemarra-regular">say that </span>the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">absorbed from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the earth </span>and laid the egg during the night of the Festival. How, then, could Rav Mari permit the egg? The Gemara answers: There it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is a male with it. </span>The Gemara asks: Even <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is a male with it, </span>one can <span class="gemarra-regular">also say that it absorbed from the earth </span>rather than from the male. The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>as a tradition that <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere that a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">male is present, </span>a chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">does not absorb from the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">earth.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Until where </span>exactly is it considered to have a male with it; How near must a rooster be for this principle to come into effect? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Gamda said in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the name of Rav: </span>The male must be <span class="gemarra-regular">any place </span>

Daf 7b

<span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the hen can <span class="gemarra-regular">hear its voice by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">day, </span>when sounds cannot be heard as easily as at night. If the chicken is close enough to hear the rooster’s call by day, the rooster is considered close enough to the chicken that the latter will produce eggs only through fertilization by the male.
