The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Mari took action </span>in accordance with this opinion, when he found an egg on a Festival morning after he had looked in the nest the day before and failed to find an egg there. He examined <span class="gemarra-regular">up to </span>a distance of <span class="gemarra-regular">sixty houses </span>from the chicken, and although he did not find a rooster within this area, he assumed there was one further away and permitted the egg.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a river </span>between the rooster and the chicken, the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cross </span>the river; <span class="gemarra-regular">but if there is a bridge, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">crosses </span>the river. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if there is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">a rope</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bridge </span>suspended across the river, the chicken will <span class="gemarra-regular">not cross</span> on the rope. The Gemara comments: Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident </span>occurred in which a chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">crossed over on a rope bridge</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>However, one may not rely on this possibility.
The Gemara further asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>manner <span class="gemarra-regular">did you establish </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of Rabbi Yosei ben Shaul, who prohibits eating an egg discovered in a nest on a Festival morning after the previous day’s examination revealed nothing? You said that it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>which the chicken <span class="gemarra-regular">absorbed from the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> earth. </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>discuss <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>a situation in which <span class="gemarra-regular">one examined </span>the nest the evening before? The same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> should apply <span class="gemarra-regular">even when one did not examine </span>the nest beforehand. 
The Gemara answers: In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he did not examine </span>the nest, one could <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the egg <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>laid <span class="gemarra-regular">yesterday</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and there is no reason to prohibit its use. Rabbi Yosei ben Shaul therefore specified that he checked the day before and is certain that the egg was not laid prior to the Festival. The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, when he examined </span>the nest <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, say: </span>Perhaps this <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a case in which <span class="gemarra-regular">most of </span>the egg <span class="gemarra-regular">emerged and returned, and </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yoḥanan? </span>The Gemara answers: The case discussed <span class="gemarra-regular">by Rabbi Yoḥanan, </span>where most of the egg emerged from the chicken and returned, <span class="gemarra-regular">is uncommon, </span>and therefore it is assumed not to have occurred. 
Apropos one statement of Rabbi Yosei ben Shaul in the name of Rav, the Gemara cites another ruling that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei ben Shaul said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">This crushed garlic </span>poses the <span class="gemarra-regular">danger of exposure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If mashed garlic is not properly covered, there is concern that a snake might have tasted from it and thereby injected its venom into the food. This garlic is consequently prohibited as a health risk.
§ The mishna states that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: </span>The measure that determines liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">leaven </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">an olive-bulk</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> However, the measure for leavened bread is greater, a large date-bulk. According to Beit Hillel, the measure in both cases is an olive-bulk.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Beit Shammai? </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that the measures are equal, <span class="gemarra-regular">let the Merciful One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> write </span>only the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread, and it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">would not be necessary </span>to write <span class="gemarra-regular">leaven, and I would </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>an <span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">fortiori</span> inference: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the measure that determines liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread, whose leavening is not </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">extensive, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">an olive-bulk, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">leaven, whose leavening is extensive, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">all the more s</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> should the measure that determines liability be an olive-bulk. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the explicit reference to <span class="gemarra-regular">leaven that the Merciful One </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wrote </span>in the verse: “Seven days there shall be no leaven found in your houses” (Exodus 12:19)? It must be <span class="gemarra-regular">to tell you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the measure of this, </span>leavened bread, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not equal to the measure of that</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> leaven. Rather, the measure that determines liability for leaven is smaller. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel </span>maintain that both the mention of both leaven and leavened bread <span class="gemarra-regular">are necessary. As if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Merciful One had written </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">leaven, I would have</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said </span>its measure that determines liability is an olive-bulk <span class="gemarra-regular">because its leavening is extensive. However, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bread, </span>whose <span class="gemarra-regular">leavening is not extensive, say no, </span>that is not the measure. Therefore, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to mention leavened bread as well. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>conversely, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One had written </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread, </span>I would have said that the measure that determines liability for leavened bread is an olive-bulk, <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is fit for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">consumption </span>on its own; <span class="gemarra-regular">however, leaven, which is not fit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for consumption </span>on its own but only when used as a leavening agent for dough, <span class="gemarra-regular">say no, </span>its measure is not like that of leavened bread. Therefore, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to mention both cases.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai, don’t they hold </span>in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Zeira’s </span>opinion? <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Zeira said, </span>the verse states: “Seven days there shall be no leaven found in your houses, for whoever eats that which is leavened, that soul shall be cut off from the assembly of Israel” (Exodus 12:19). <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse begins with leaven and ends with leavened </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bread to say to you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">leaven is equivalent to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread. </span>How, then, can Beit Shammai maintain that the two are prohibited by different measures?
The Gemara answers: Indeed, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the measure that determines liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">eating, everyone agrees </span>that the same measure applies to leavened bread and leaven. <span class="gemarra-regular">When they disagree </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">removal </span>of leavened bread from one’s house. <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">removal from </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">eating. </span>Rather, with regard to the obligation of removal, different measures apply to leavened bread and leaven. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we derive </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">removal from </span>the measure that determines liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">eating.</span>
The Gemara comments: This idea <span class="gemarra-regular">was also stated </span>explicitly by <span class="it-text">amora’im</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel was stated <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">removal </span>of leavened bread; however, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the measure that determines liability for <span class="gemarra-regular">eating, everyone agrees </span>that the measure for both <span class="gemarra-regular">this and that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">an olive-bulk. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">And no leavened bread shall </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be seen with you, and no leaven shall be found </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in all your borders</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Exodus 13:7). <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>obligation to remove leavened bread <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>subject to <span class="gemarra-regular">a dispute between Beit Shammai</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Beit Hillel, as Beit Shammai say: </span>The measure that determines liability for removal of <span class="gemarra-regular">leaven </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">an olive-bulk</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>the measure for leavened bread is <span class="gemarra-regular">a large date</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-bulk, and Beit Hillel say: </span>The measure for <span class="gemarra-regular">both this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and that </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">an olive-bulk. </span>This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> indicates that the dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel is with regard to the obligation to remove leavened bread, not liability for eating it.
§ The mishna states that Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel also dispute whether or not <span class="gemarra-regular">one who slaughters an undomesticated animal or</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a bird on a Festival, </span>without having prepared earth the day before with which to cover the blood after the slaughter, may dig out earth on the Festival itself to cover the blood. 
The Gemara analyzes the wording of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who slaughters </span>an animal; this indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">after</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the fact</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> yes, </span>one may dig out dirt, but <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, no, </span>even Beit Shammai agree that one may not slaughter an undomesticated animal or a bird if there is no prepared dirt. Otherwise, the mishna would have said: One may slaughter an undomesticated animal or a bird on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">Say the latter clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say </span>that one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not slaughter </span>it. This proves <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>Beit Shammai, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that one <span class="gemarra-regular">may slaughter </span>it even <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>and meant the following: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> slaughter </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and cover </span>the blood. They are emphasizing that one may not cover the blood even if he slaughtered an animal, whereas Beit Shammai maintain that if one slaughtered he may cover the blood <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>.
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say the latter clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">concede</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that if he </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered, then he may dig with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a shove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and cover </span>the blood, which indicates that Beit Hillel were not emphasizing the covering of the blood. This proves <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first clause </span>of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>referring to one’s action <span class="gemarra-regular">after the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fact</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> but to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is what </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying. </span>The phrase: One who slaughters an animal, is not a broad directive on how to act, but rather it means: If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">one who slaughters </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">comes to consult </span>a Sage on how to proceed, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>should the Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him? Beit Shammai say </span>that the Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">says to him: Slaughter </span>it <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">dig, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and cover </span>the blood. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: He may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> slaughter </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">only if he had earth </span>that was <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared while it was still day. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef </span>provided a slightly different explanation of the mishna and <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> slaughters animals who comes to consult, what does </span>the Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him? Beit Shammai say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he says </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him: Go dig, slaughter </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">and cover </span>the blood. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: He may slaughter </span>the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">only if he had earth </span>that was <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared while</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it was still day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to Rav Yosef: Let us say</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Master, </span>i.e., Rav Yosef, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabba </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>the following statement <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Zeira </span>said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said, as Rabbi Zeira said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: One who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters </span>an undomesticated animal or bird is obligated to perform the mitzva of covering the blood, and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">he must </span><span class="gemarra-regular">place earth beneath </span>the blood <span class="gemarra-regular">and earth above </span>it,<span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">And he shall pour out its </span><span class="gemarra-regular">blood and cover it in earth</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Leviticus 17:13). It <span class="gemarra-regular">is not stated: </span>Cover it with <span class="gemarra-regular">earth, but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">in earth,</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>indicating that the blood must be concealed inside the earth. The verse thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches that one who slaughters </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">must</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> place earth beneath and earth above </span>the blood.
Abaye is suggesting <span class="gemarra-regular">that the Master is of </span>the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Zeira, </span>and therefore he requires one to dig first and only afterward slaughter the animal and have the blood flow onto that earth and then cover it with additional earth, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba is of </span>the opinion that the ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>in accordance with the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Zeira.</span>
Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Abaye: This is not so; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to me and </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabba we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>of the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Zeira, and here we disagree </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span>matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">if there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>prepared <span class="gemarra-regular">earth beneath, yes, </span>in that case one may slaughter an animal, but <span class="gemarra-regular">if there is no </span>earth prepared beneath, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>he may not slaughter it at all. Why not? Rabba says: <span class="gemarra-regular">We are concerned </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps one will</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> reconsider and not slaughter </span>it at all, and he will have dug a hole on a Festival unnecessarily. <span class="gemarra-regular">And according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to my </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">on the contrary: This </span>situation, in which he is permitted to dig first, <span class="gemarra-regular">is preferable, since</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if you do not permit him </span>to dig in all cases for the purpose of slaughter, <span class="gemarra-regular">he will </span>be unable to eat meat and will <span class="gemarra-regular">refrain from rejoicing on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival. </span>
§ That mishna states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">concede that if one </span>transgressed and <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered an </span>animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">then he digs with a shove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and covers </span>the blood. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zerika said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said: And that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">when one has a shovel </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">embedde</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in the ground <span class="gemarra-regular">while it was still day, </span>before the onset of the Festival. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>what purpose does an embedded shovel serve; <span class="gemarra-regular">doesn’t he </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">perform </span>the act of <span class="gemarra-regular">crushing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as one must crush the lumps of earth to make the soil fit for covering? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>

Daf 8a

Here it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> loose earth </span>that does not require further crushing. 
The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>even in the case of loose earth, <span class="gemarra-regular">one makes a hol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> by the very act of removing the earth or the shovel from that place. The Gemara answers: This ruling is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba, as Rabbi Abba said: One </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who digs a hole on Shabbat, </span>but he <span class="gemarra-regular">needs only </span><span class="gemarra-regular">its eart</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> and has no interest in forming a pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt for </span>that act. Since he has no interest in the hole, he is considered to have performed a destructive act, and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that one who commits a destructive act is not liable for the performance of prohibited labor on Shabbat and Festivals. 
§ The mishna states: <span class="gemarra-regular">That the ashes of a stove are prepared. </span>The Gemara express puzzlement at this statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">The ashes of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a stove, who mentioned anything about it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Why does the mishna suddenly speak about the ashes of a stove when it had not previously discussed or even mentioned them? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: This is what </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">said: And the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ashe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a stove are prepared</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In other words, everyone agrees that in addition to prepared earth, the ashes of a stove are also considered prepared, and one may cover the blood with them. It is not necessary to prepare these ashes especially for this purpose the day before. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: They only taught </span>that the ashes of a stove are considered prepared if the stove <span class="gemarra-regular">was ignited on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Festival eve, </span>so that the ashes had already formed at the start of the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">it was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ignited on the Festival </span>itself, the ashes are <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>the ashes are still hot and <span class="gemarra-regular">fit to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">roast an egg in them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> they are not considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, and therefore it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to use them for covering as well. 
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">When they said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the ashes of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stove are prepared, they said </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">only when it was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ignited on the Festival eve; however, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">it was ignited</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the Festival, </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. And if </span>the ashes are still hot and <span class="gemarra-regular">fit to roast an egg in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them, </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted.</span>
The Gemara further states: If before the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">one brought earth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into his garde</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or his ruin </span>to use for various needs, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted to cover </span>blood <span class="gemarra-regular">with it. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">said: A person may bring in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a basketfu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of eart</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> the day before the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">and use </span>both the basket and the earth it contains <span class="gemarra-regular">for all his needs </span>on the Festival.
With regard to this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Zutra </span>added and <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in public <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra the Great </span>that the application of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is limited: <span class="gemarra-regular">And that is </span>the case only <span class="gemarra-regular">if one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">designated a corner for this </span>earth, thereby demonstrating that he intends to use it for all his requirements, rather than merely bringing earth in to scatter over the floor of the house. In that case, the dirt is nullified. It is considered part of the floor, which means that it is once again classified as <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. 
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>against this from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bikkurim</span> 4:9): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">koy</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a kosher animal with characteristics of both domesticated and non-domesticated animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not slaughter it on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival, </span>as it is uncertain whether or not its blood requires covering. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if one did slaughter it, he may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not cover its blood</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is so,</span> that one may use his basket of earth as he wishes, as claimed by Rav Yehuda, even if a <span class="it-text">koy</span> is definitely a domesticated animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him cover it, in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda.</span>
The Gemara expresses surprise at this objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> according to your reasoning, </span>one could equally suggest: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let him</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cover </span>the blood of the <span class="it-text">koy</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with ashes of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stove or with </span>earth dug up with <span class="gemarra-regular">an embedded shovel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rather, </span>this mishna must be referring to a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where one does not have </span>prepared earth to use for covering the blood; <span class="gemarra-regular">here too, </span>one can say <span class="gemarra-regular">that he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not have </span>a basket of earth ready for all his needs.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, </span>if the mishna is referring to a situation where one does not have prepared earth, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>discuss <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>the case of a <span class="it-text">koy</span>, where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty</span> whether there is a mitzva to cover its blood? <span class="gemarra-regular">Even</span> in the case of an undomesticated animal, whose blood must <span class="gemarra-regular">certainly </span>be covered, slaughter should <span class="gemarra-regular">also not </span>be permitted, as the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel that one may not slaughter if he does not have prepared earth.
The Gemara explains that this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is speaking</span> utilizing the style of: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not necessary, </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is not necessary </span>to state the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">definite </span>undomesticated animals and birds, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">to slaughter </span>them; <span class="gemarra-regular">however, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertainty</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Due to the joy of the Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> let one slaughter </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and not cover </span>its blood, as there is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty </span>whether there is a mitzva to cover its blood, and therefore it is overridden by the mitzva to rejoice on a Festival. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us</span> that one should not slaughter it <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span> if he does not have something prepared with which to cover the blood. 

Daf 8b

The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause teaches: And if he slaughtered it one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may not cover its blood, it may be inferred that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the first clause we are dealing with </span>a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where he does have </span>something with which to cover the blood. If he does not have anything he can use, why is it necessary to state that one may not cover it? And consequently, if he does in fact have material with which to cover the blood, why may he not do so, either with his basket of earth, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, or with the ashes of a stove? 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabba said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the ashes of a stove, </span>which the mishna stated are prepared, are <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>covering the blood in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a definite </span>obligation, but they <span class="gemarra-regular">are not </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared for </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Although his intention was to use these ashes to cover the blood of any animal he slaughters, whether in a definite or an uncertain case, they are nevertheless not considered prepared for an uncertain case.
The Gemara inquires: In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of uncertainty, what is the reason </span>that the ashes are not considered prepared? If the reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that one makes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a hole </span>in the mound of ashes when he removes part of it for covering, in <span class="gemarra-regular">a definite </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> also makes a hole. </span>If it is prohibited to make a hole, that prohibition applies in all cases. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one must say, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Abba, </span>that the making of this hole is not considered prohibited labor, as he is merely performing a destructive act. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">here too, </span>in a case of uncertainty, there should be no cause for concern, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the Gemara retracts from the previous suggestion and offers an alternative: With regard to a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty, what is the reason</span> that it is prohibited? The reason is that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps one</span> will forget and <span class="gemarra-regular">perform crushing </span>with this earth, to ready it for covering. However, the same problem arises as before: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">we should also decree </span>against covering the blood in <span class="gemarra-regular">a definite </span>case, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>he might <span class="gemarra-regular">crush </span>the earth. The Gemara answers: This presents no difficulty, as when one fulfills the mitzva of covering the blood in <span class="gemarra-regular">a definite</span> case, even <span class="gemarra-regular">if he performs crushing, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">positive </span>mitzva of covering the blood <span class="gemarra-regular">comes and overrides </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibition </span>concerning the desecration of a Festival.
The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that we said </span>the following principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">A positive </span>mitzva <span class="gemarra-regular">comes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and overrides a prohibition </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">such as </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">circumcision of </span>a child who has <span class="gemarra-regular">leprosy. </span>Cutting off a leprous blemish is a violation of a prohibition. However, if a baby’s foreskin is leprous, it is permitted to cut it off by circumcision. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>the principle applies to a case of a linen <span class="gemarra-regular">cloak on </span>which woolen <span class="gemarra-regular">ritual</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fringes </span>are placed, despite the prohibition against wearing diverse kinds, i.e., a mixture of wool and linen. 
The Gemara explains the difference between those <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> and the issue at hand. In those cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">at </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that one uproots </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibition, </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">fulfills </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">positive </span>mitzva with the same act. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case of covering blood, two separate actions are involved, as <span class="gemarra-regular">at the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> time that one uproots </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibition, </span>when he crushes the earth, he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not fulfill </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">positive </span>mitzva of covering the blood. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as it is possible to say <span class="gemarra-regular">that when one crushes </span>the earth, <span class="gemarra-regular">he covers </span>the blood with it; he fulfills the positive mitzva by means of the same action through which he uproots the prohibition.
The Gemara challenges this explanation from a different perspective: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ultimately, a Festival is </span>a mitzva that includes both the <span class="gemarra-regular">positive </span>mitzva of rest <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>also the <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibitio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> against performing prohibited labor, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>there is a principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">a positive </span>mitzva by itself <span class="gemarra-regular">does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not override a prohibition and a positive </span>mitzva together. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the Gemara rejects the previous explanation, in favor of the following. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> One’s initial <span class="gemarra-regular">intention </span>is to use <span class="gemarra-regular">the ashes of a stove</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>a mitzva that is <span class="gemarra-regular">definite, and he does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">intention for </span>cases of <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty. </span>One may not use an article on a Festival for a purpose which he did not have in mind beforehand. 
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rava follows his </span>regular line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning </span>in this regard, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rava said: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">brought </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in earth </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to cover </span>a baby’s <span class="gemarra-regular">excrement </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with it </span>on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cover with it the blood of </span>a slaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">bird. </span>Since he prepared this earth for a case of uncertainty, as it is possible that the baby will not soil the house, he certainly intended to use it for covering the blood of a bird prepared before the Festival for slaughter. If, however, one prepared the earth at the outset to cover <span class="gemarra-regular">the blood of a bird</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is prohibited </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to cover excrement with it, </span>as he did not know in advance that he would require the earth for this purpose. He had only definite uses in mind, not possible ones such as covering excrement.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharbel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Even</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">one brought in earth to cover the blood of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a bird with it, it is permitted to cover excrement</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with it, </span>as it cannot be said that he did not intend this usage. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">They say in the West</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Eretz Yisrael, that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥama and Rabbi Zeira disagree with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to </span>this issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">and some say </span>it was disputed by <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava, son of Rav Yosef bar Ḥama, </span>commonly mentioned in the Babylonian Talmud as Rava, without the patronymic, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira. </span>The Gemara elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">koy</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is similar to excrement </span>in this regard. Just as one may cover the blood of a bird with earth brought in for the purpose of covering excrement, he may likewise use it for covering the blood of a <span class="it-text">koy</span>, as both the case of excrement and the case of the <span class="it-text">koy</span> are cases of uncertainty. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one said: A </span><span class="gemarra-italic">koy</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not similar to excrement</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since the covering of excrement is common, it is regarded as a definite purpose in comparison to a <span class="it-text">koy</span>, which is by definition an uncertain case. It is therefore prohibited to cover the blood of a <span class="it-text">koy</span> with earth prepared for the sake of covering excrement.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Conclud</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that Rava is the one who sai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">koy</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is similar to excrement, as Rava said: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">brought in earth to cover excrement with it, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted to cover the blood of a bird </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with it; </span>if he did bring in earth to cover <span class="gemarra-regular">the blood of a bird, it is prohibited to cover </span><span class="gemarra-regular">excrement with it. </span>One intends to use the earth for the definite rather than the uncertain purpose, and likewise in the case of a <span class="it-text">koy</span>. The Gemara summarizes: Indeed, <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude</span> that this is the correct version of the opinions in the dispute.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami, son of Rav Yeiva, said </span>a different reason: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">koy</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, this is the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning </span>for the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may not cover </span>its blood: It is not because this action would constitute prohibited labor; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>a rabbinic <span class="gemarra-regular">decree due to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permission of its </span>prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">fat. </span>If one were to cover its blood, people might think that a <span class="it-text">koy</span> is definitely an undomesticated animal, and it is well known that the fats of an undomesticated animal may be eaten, whereas those of a domesticated animal are prohibited. 
The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, even on a weekday </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>the blood of a <span class="it-text">koy</span> should not be covered, due to this concern. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">On a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">weekday, </span>people will <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he needs to clean his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard, </span>and that he is covering the blood merely to keep his courtyard presentable, rather than to fulfill the mitzva of covering blood.
The Gemara asks: And if <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered </span><span class="it-text">a</span> <span class="it-text">koy</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in a dunghill, </span>a place used for the disposal of refuse, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to say? </span>It will be evident that he is not concerned about its cleanliness, and that he is attempting to perform the mitzva of covering blood. Alternatively, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he comes to consult </span>a Sage concerning whether or not he should cover the blood of a <span class="it-text">koy</span> on a weekday, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to say? </span>If the owner of the <span class="it-text">koy</span> is instructed to cover the blood, would he not come to the erroneous conclusion that its fats are permitted?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">On </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a weekday, even if </span>the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">is uncertain, the Sages </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">take the trouble and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cover </span>it, as it involves the possible fulfillment of a mitzva. <span class="gemarra-regular">On a Festival, </span>however, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>there is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty, would</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Sages say to him: Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">take the trouble</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and cover </span>it? If one was told to cover the blood on a Festival, this would indicate that a <span class="it-text">koy</span> is definitely an undomesticated animal. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira teaches </span>the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Not only did </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that the blood of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ko</span><span class="gemarra-italic">y</span> should not be covered on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even if one slaughtered a domesticated animal, </span>whose blood need not be covered, and also slaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">an undomesticated animal or</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a fowl, </span>whose blood must be covered, <span class="gemarra-regular">and their bloods</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> became mingled together, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to cover </span>the mixture of blood <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei bar Yasini</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: They taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only</span> in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one cannot cover </span>the entire mixture <span class="gemarra-regular">by one thrust </span>of a shovel. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he can</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cover it with one thrust, it is permitted. </span>Since the entire amount of blood can be covered with a single action, it does not matter if one unnecessarily covers the blood of a domesticated animal while performing the mitzva of covering the blood of a fowl or an undomesticated animal.
The Gemara comments: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that this is the case; since he covers all the blood in a single action, clearly he performs a mitzva. The Gemara answers: This ruling is nevertheless necessary, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">should decree </span>and prohibit even <span class="gemarra-regular">one thrust, due to </span>the possibility that he might perform <span class="gemarra-regular">two thrusts. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Yasinia teaches us </span>that this concern is not taken into account. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered a bird on the eve of a Festival, one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not cover </span>its blood <span class="gemarra-regular">on the Festival </span>itself. 

Daf 9a

If <span class="gemarra-regular">one kneaded doug</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a Festival eve, </span>i.e., the day before the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may separate its</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In general, one may not separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> and tithes on a Festival. However, since it is permitted bake bread on the Festival for the requirements of the day, and because bread may not be eaten unless <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> has first been separated from it, separating <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> is considered a necessary stage in the preparation of bread, and the Sages permitted it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel’s father said: Even</span> if <span class="gemarra-regular">one kneaded dough on a Festival eve, he may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not separat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the Festival, </span>as he should have separated <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> then. The mitzva of separating <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> goes into effect at the time of the kneading of the dough.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say that Shmuel disagrees with his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father, as Shmuel said: </span>With regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from outside </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Eretz </span>Yisrael, where the separation of <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> is a rabbinic obligation, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may proceed to eat </span>the bread <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward separate </span>the <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> from the remainder of the dough. This statement indicates that the separation of <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> outside of Eretz Yisrael is not required to render the bread permitted, in contrast to the separation of <span class="it-text">teruma</span> and tithes from produce. Consequently, separating <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> is permitted on a Festival, as it does not involve a significant change. This contradicts the opinion of Shmuel’s father, who prohibited separating <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> that could have been separated before the Festival.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>This is not necessarily the case. <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t Shmuel concede that if one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">designated </span>a piece of dough <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> outside of Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited to non-priests? </span>This proves that even Shmuel admits that a certain measure of sanctity applies to the <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span>. Therefore, he might also agree with his father that it is prohibited to separate <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> on a Festival even outside of Eretz Yisrael.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may not carry a ladder, </span>which was used for reaching doves, <span class="gemarra-regular">from one dovecote to another. However, </span>one may move it slightly so that <span class="gemarra-regular">he tilts it from one window </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to another </span>in the same dovecote. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel permit </span>even carrying a ladder from one dovecote to another.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥanan bar Ami said: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>applies only in a case where one moves the ladder <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public </span><span class="gemarra-regular">domain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">as Beit Shammai hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who sees </span>someone carrying his ladder will <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">He </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">need </span>the ladder <span class="gemarra-regular">to plaster his roof, </span>to prevent rainwater from dripping into his house. In other words, an onlooker will suspect him of performing prohibited labor on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">his dovecote proves about </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> that he is not moving the ladder for the purpose of a transgression, as it is evident that he is placing the ladder alongside the second dovecote, and everyone will understand his intention. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, in the private domain, </span>where one will not be observed by strangers, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? But didn’t Rav Yehuda say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Wherever the Sages prohibited </span>an action <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the appearanc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of prohibition, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if one performs the act <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">innermost chamber, </span>where no one will see it, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. </span>The Gemara answers: This <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: One whose clothes fell into water on Shabbat or a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">may spread them out </span>to dry <span class="gemarra-regular">in the sun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, but he may not </span>do so <span class="gemarra-regular">opposite the masses, </span>i.e., in a place where people can see him, lest they suspect him of laundering on Shabbat. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi Shimon prohibit </span>doing so even in private.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>a different version of this discussion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥanan bar Ami said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>applies <span class="gemarra-regular">to the public</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> domain, as Beit Shammai are of </span>the opinion that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with that which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda </span>said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said, </span>and therefore Beit Shammai apply the decree to the private domain. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel, </span>by contrast, <span class="gemarra-regular">are of </span>the opinion that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>in accordance with that which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda </span>said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">However, in the public domain, everyone agrees </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to move the ladder.
The Gemara challenges this interpretation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Should we say </span>that Rav <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai?</span> According Rav Ḥanan bar Ami, only Beit Shammai maintains that anything prohibited by the Sages due to appearances may not be performed even in private.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: No, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-italic">’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If clothes fell into water on Shabbat or a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> spread them out in the sun but not opposite the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> masses. Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Shimon prohibit </span>doing so. Rav Ḥanan bar Ami accepts the opinion of the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, who rejects Rav’s principle. According to the opinion of that <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, it can be claimed that Beit Hillel also rejected Rav’s principle, and they permitted moving the ladder in private but not in public. Rav, on the other hand, follows the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Shimon in interpreting the opinion of Beit Hillel. 

Daf 9b

§ With regard to the mishna itself, the Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel agree that one may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">carry a ladder from one dovecote to another </span>to take doves; <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree only </span>after one has finished at the second dovecote, whether it is permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">to replac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the ladder to its original spot at the first dovecote, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shammai say: One may not replace </span>the ladder, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel say: One may even replace </span>it. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda said: In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> statement said? With regard to a dovecote ladder, </span>which clearly serves the purpose of taking doves. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of an attic ladder</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which has a variety of uses, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited, </span>as this will raise suspicions. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dosa says: One may tilt it from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one window to another </span>in the same dovecote. <span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the name of Rabbi Dosa: One may even shif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> the ladder from one place to another by shuffling its legs. 
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sons of Rabbi Ḥiyy</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> went out to the villages </span>to attend to their business. <span class="gemarra-regular">When they came </span>back, <span class="gemarra-regular">their father</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to them: Did any incident </span>requiring a ruling of <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">come to your </span>notice? <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to him: </span>The issue of carrying an attic <span class="gemarra-regular">ladder </span>to a dovecote <span class="gemarra-regular">came to our </span>notice, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we permitted it. </span>Rabbi Ḥiyya <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: Go out and prohibi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you permitted. </span>
The Gemara explains: Rabbi Ḥiyya’s sons <span class="gemarra-regular">thought </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Yehuda </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">do not disagree </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to an attic ladder, </span>this proves <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>do <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree. </span>Consequently, Rabbi Ḥiyya’s sons thought that according to the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, Beit Hillel permit even the use of a loft ladder, and they ruled in accordance with this opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that is not so, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>does not disagree with him, but rather <span class="gemarra-regular">he explains </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">reason of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>can this be inferred? <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: One may carry a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ladder from one dovecote to another. And if it enters </span><span class="gemarra-regular">your mind </span>to say that Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to an attic ladder, </span>if so, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may carry a ladder from one dovecote </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to another, </span>is inexact, as he <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span>have said: <span class="gemarra-regular">One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may carry a ladder to a dovecote. Rather, isn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this what </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a dovecote</span> ladder, <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>it is permitted to move it; however, in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an attic </span>ladder, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>one may not use it. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the others, </span>Rabbi Ḥiyya’s sons, what is their reasoning? The Gemara answers that they would reply: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A dovecote </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ladder? </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: From one dovecote to another, and </span>this simply means that it is permitted to do so <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to several dovecotes.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>a slightly different version of this incident. Rabbi Ḥiyya’s sons <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: The tilting of an attic ladder came to our </span>notice, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we permitted it. </span>We were asked whether an attic ladder positioned near a dovecote before the Festival may be moved from one window to another in the same dovecote, and we allowed it. Rabbi Ḥiyya <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Go out and prohibit that which you permitted. </span>The Gemara explains that <span class="gemarra-regular">they thought</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> That which the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prohibits, </span>i.e., moving an attic ladder, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dosa </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permits, </span>i.e. Rabbi Dosa is more lenient than the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> and permits moving even an attic ladder from one window to another. <span class="gemarra-regular">And that is not so. </span>Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">that which the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permits, </span>moving a dovecote ladder, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dosa prohibits. </span>He is more stringent and maintains that even a dovecote ladder may be moved only by tilting rather than in the usual manner.
§ The mishna taught: <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>everyone agrees that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may tilt </span>a dovecote ladder <span class="gemarra-regular">from one window to another </span>in the same dovecote. The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, with regard to rejoicing </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on the Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stringent, and </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel is lenient. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from the first mishna of the tractate (2a): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an undomesticated animal or a fowl on a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, Beit Shammai say: He may dig </span>earth <span class="gemarra-regular">with a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">shovel and cover </span>the blood, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel say: He </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may not slaughter </span>an undomesticated animal or a fowl, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he had earth prepared </span>for that purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">while it was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> still day. </span>This indicates that it is Beit Shammai who are concerned for the honor and joy of the Festival, and they are therefore lenient with regard to covering the blood; whereas Beit Hillel do not share the same concern and are stringent about covering the blood, despite the fact that their ruling might adversely affect the joy of the Festival.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The </span>attribution of the <span class="gemarra-regular">opinions </span>of the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is reversed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The opinion attributed to Beit Hillel is actually that of Beit Shammai, and vice versa. The Gemara rejects Rabbi Yoḥanan’s answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>do you infer that this extreme conclusion is necessarily the case? A different explanation is possible: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps Beit Shammai say </span>their opinion, that it is permitted to cover the blood, <span class="gemarra-regular">only there, where there is </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">a shovel embedded </span>in the earth ready for this purpose, and therefore there are grounds for a lenient ruling. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, where there is no</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> embedded shovel, </span>they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permit it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>it is possible to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel say </span>their opinion, that an act is permitted for the sake of the joy of the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">only here, where his dovecote, </span>the place where he ultimately positions the ladder, <span class="gemarra-regular">proves </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to him </span>that he intended to use his ladder for a permitted purpose; <span class="gemarra-regular">but there, </span>where there is no equivalent proof, they were <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>lenient. This shows that there is no clear contradiction between the rulings in the two cases.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the Gemara retracts the previous version and suggests that Rabbi Yoḥanan issued his statement with regard to a different issue: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">is difficult, this is </span>what is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>It was taught in a different mishna (10a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: One may not take </span>fledgling doves on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he shook </span>them, as an act of preparation, <span class="gemarra-regular">while</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it was still day. And Beit Hillel say: </span>It is indeed necessary to perform some act of preparation to permit the taking of fledglings on a Festival, but this does not have to be done by shaking them. Rather, it is enough if one <span class="gemarra-regular">stands </span>the day before <span class="gemarra-regular">and says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: I </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">take this </span>dove <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, with regard to rejoicing on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Festival, </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai is stringent and</span> that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel is lenient. And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a contradiction </span>as above: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who slaughters</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an undomesticated animal or a fowl on a Festival, </span>Beit Shammai are lenient and allow one to dig with a shovel to cover the blood, due to the joy of the Festival, whereas Beit Hillel do not permit one to slaughtering at all, unless there was a shovel ready from the day before. It was with regard to this contradiction that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The </span>attribution of <span class="gemarra-regular">the opinions</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is reversed. </span>
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not so, </span>as a different explanation is possible: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shammai only state </span>their lenient opinion, that it is permitted to cover the blood, <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is an embedded </span><span class="gemarra-regular">shovel. </span>

Daf 10a

<span class="gemarra-regular">However, where</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there is no embedded shovel, </span>even Beit Shammai did <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span> permit it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>it is possible that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel say</span> their opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">only here</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> since </span>a dove <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is prohibited by rabbinic law, and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he stands and says: I will take this and that, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">enough. However there, </span>where the prohibition applies by Torah law, they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>say so.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if there is a difficulty </span>involving a contradiction, <span class="gemarra-regular">this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is the difficulty, </span>from a different mishna (11a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: One may not take a large pestle </span>from a mortar, which is normally used for crushing wheat in the preparation of porridge, for any other purpose on a Festival, e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">to cut meat on it; and Beit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Hillel permit </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, with regard to rejoicing on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival, </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai is stringent, and </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel is lenient. And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> contradiction: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who slaughters an undomesticated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">animal or a fowl on a Festival, Beit Shammai </span>say: He may dig earth with a shovel and cover the blood, and Beit Hillel say: He may not slaughter an undomesticated animal or a fowl, unless he had earth prepared for that purpose while it was still day. It was in this regard that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The </span>attribution of the <span class="gemarra-regular">opinions is reversed. </span>
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>do you know this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not so. </span>Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say </span>their opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">only there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, where there is a shovel embedded </span>and prepared the day before, <span class="gemarra-regular">but where there is no embedded shovel, </span>they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>rule leniently. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>one can say that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>their opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">only here, </span>with regard to a pestle, <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">has the status of a vessel, </span>and therefore it is not completely <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, there, </span>in the case of slaughtering, Beit Hillel did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>issue a lenient ruling.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if there is a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">difficulty, this is the difficulty: </span>It is taught in a mishna (11a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One may not place </span>an unprocessed <span class="gemarra-regular">hide before those who </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">tread on it, </span>as this is an instance of the prohibited labor of tanning on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not lift </span>the hide from its spot, as it is considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is an olive-bulk of meat on it, </span>in which case it may be carried on account of its meat. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel permit </span>one to place a hide before those who will tread upon it.
Once again the Gemara states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to rejoicing on the Festival, </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai is stringent, and </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lenient.
