And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who slaughters an undomesticated animal or a fowl on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a Festival, </span>Beit Shammai say, <span class="gemarra-regular">etc. </span>Concerning this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yoḥanan said: The </span>attribution of the <span class="gemarra-regular">opinions is reversed. </span>
Here too, the Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>do you know this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps that is not so. </span>Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say </span>their opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">only there, where there is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a shovel embedded </span>and prepared the day before, <span class="gemarra-regular">but where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there is no embedded shovel, </span>they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>rule leniently. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, Beit Hillel say </span>their opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">only here, </span>with regard to a hide, <span class="gemarra-regular">which is suitable </span>for people <span class="gemarra-regular">to recline </span><span class="gemarra-regular">upon, </span>and therefore it is not completely <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, there, </span>in the case of slaughtering, they were <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>lenient.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, if there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is a difficulty, this is the difficulty, </span>as it is taught (11a): <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One may not remove </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">shutters </span>of a store <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival, </span>to open the store by raising them, due to the prohibition against building and demolishing on a Festival; <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel permit </span>not only to open the shutters, but <span class="gemarra-regular">even to replace </span>them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, with regard to rejoicing on the Festival, </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai is stringent, and </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Hillel is lenient. And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who slaughters an undomesticated animal or a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fowl on a Festival, </span>Beit Shammai say, <span class="gemarra-regular">etc. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>the contradiction between one statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai </span>and the other statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as it can be explained as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the slaughtering case, it is referring to a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is a shovel embedded </span>and prepared the day before; <span class="gemarra-regular">here, there is no embedded shovel, </span>and therefore Beit Shammai are stringent. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>the contradiction between one statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel </span>and the other statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult. </span>
It is with regard to this contradiction that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The </span>attribution of <span class="gemarra-regular">the opinions is reversed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>one can suggest a different answer without reversing the opinions: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel say </span>their lenient opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">only here</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in the case of the shutters, <span class="gemarra-regular">because</span> they maintain <span class="gemarra-regular">that there is no </span>prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">building with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to vessels and there is no </span>prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">dismantling</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to vessels, </span>which means that no Torah prohibition is violated in removing the shutters. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, there, </span>in the case of slaughtering, where there are no extenuating circumstances, Beit Hillel did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permit it. Consequently, there is no contradiction that necessitates a reversal of the opinions.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One may not take </span>fledgling doves from a dovecote on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">shoo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> the ones he wished to take <span class="gemarra-regular">while it was still day, </span>thereby preparing them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: </span>It is not necessary to shake; rather, it is sufficient if one <span class="gemarra-regular">stands </span>the day before <span class="gemarra-regular">and says: I </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">take this </span>fledgling <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥanan bar Ami said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel applies <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">first </span><span class="gemarra-regular">brood</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the first pair of fledglings hatched in the first month of the year from a pair of doves. Those fledglings are usually left in the nest and are not used for food. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Beit Shammai hold: We issue a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">decree </span>prohibiting taking them, as <span class="gemarra-regular">perhap</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> on the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will come to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reconside</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> after handling them and decide to leave them in their place, in which case he has moved them unnecessarily. However, once he has already shaken them, there is no further concern that he might change his mind on the Festival itself. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel hold: We </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do not issue a decree, </span>as there is no concern that one might change his mind, and therefore a verbal commitment is sufficient. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, with regard to the second brood</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the fledglings born on the second cycle in the following month, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">enough </span>for one <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stand and say: I </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">take this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">and that</span> one.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel, why does one need to say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: I </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">take this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him say: From here, </span>this dovecote, <span class="gemarra-regular">I will take tomorrow. </span>Why does one have to specify exactly which fledglings he plans to remove from the dovecote? 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel do not accept </span>the principle of retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation, </span>i.e., they reject the idea that a person’s original intention can be clarified retroactively, and therefore it cannot be said that the fledglings one takes on the Festival were the ones he had in mind beforehand, <span class="gemarra-regular">but didn’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ohalot</span> 7:3): If <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">corpse </span>is located <span class="gemarra-regular">in a house, and </span>the house <span class="gemarra-regular">has </span><span class="gemarra-regular">many entrances, </span>whether they are open or closed, not only is the inside of the house ritually impure as a tent of the dead, but <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>the entrances <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually impure </span>and impart impurity to the vessels they contain? The reason is that the corpse might be removed via any of the entrances, and therefore they all contract impurity.
If only <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>the entrances <span class="gemarra-regular">was open </span>after the person died, that entrance alone <span class="gemarra-regular">is ritually impure, </span>as the corpse will certainly be removed through it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and all </span>the other entrances remain <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually pure. </span>The same applies if <span class="gemarra-regular">one decided </span>from the outset <span class="gemarra-regular">to remove </span>the corpse <span class="gemarra-regular">through one of </span>the entrances, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>to carry it out <span class="gemarra-regular">through a window that is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> four by four </span>handbreadths in size, which is large enough for a corpse. This intention <span class="gemarra-regular">spares all the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">entrances</span> from ritual impurity, as it is clear that the corpse will not be removed through them. 
With regard to this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: This </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one had decided to remove </span>the corpse by a particular entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">before the person died, </span>so that the entrance through which the body would be removed was already determined at the time of death. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: </span>This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">even after the person died, </span>as the principle of retroactive designation is invoked, which means that the entrance through which the deceased will be removed is retroactively designated. This indicates that Beit Hillel do accept the principle of retroactive designation. 
The Gemara refutes this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Wasn’t it stated </span>by <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to this </span>mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>In this case, Beit Hillel referred only <span class="gemarra-regular">to purifying the entrances from that point</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> forward. </span>In other words, after one has decided on an entrance that he will use to remove the dead, any vessels in the space of the other entrances do not become ritually impure. However, vessels that were located inside the space of the other entrances before the decision was made remain impure. According to these <span class="it-text">amora’im</span>, Beit Hillel do not accept the principle of retroactive designation. <span class="gemarra-regular">And, so too</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, Rav Oshaya said: </span>This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to purifying the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> entrances from that point forward, </span>which indicates: <span class="gemarra-regular">From here onward</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, yes, </span>the entrances are ritually pure; <span class="gemarra-regular">retroactively, no, </span>they are not considered pure.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that there is a different way to resolve the conflicting rulings of Beit Hillel: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>in the case of ritual impurity, Beit Hillel maintain that all the entrances are ritually pure <span class="gemarra-regular">retroactively. And here, </span>with regard to fledglings, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the reason </span>why Beit Hillel insist that one designate which particular fledglings one plans to take on the Festival: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps one will move </span>fledglings, <span class="gemarra-regular">and put </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">down</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and again <span class="gemarra-regular">move </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and put </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">down </span>until he finds the pair he wants, thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">moving an object</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is not suitable for him, </span>i.e., which is <span class="it-text">muktze</span>.
The Gemara raises an objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if this is indeed the concern, <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is enough </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">one stands and says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: I </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">take this </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one. In this case, too, he does not touch them. It is therefore possible that he may reconsider his choice of fledglings on the Festival after he handles them. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> applies only </span>when one made his choice <span class="gemarra-regular">on the eve</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the Festival. </span>Since he knows that he may not alter his decision on the Festival itself even if he does not like the ones he chose, he definitively decides to take those fledglings and will not handle others. 

Daf 10b

<span class="gemarra-regular">However, on the Festival </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited, as sometimes </span>those that seemed to him to be <span class="gemarra-regular">fat ones will be foun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to be <span class="gemarra-regular">thin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and thin ones </span>will be found to be <span class="gemarra-regular">fat, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">move an object that is not suitable for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him, </span>thereby transgressing the prohibition against moving <span class="it-text">muktze</span> objects. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, sometimes they will all be found </span>to be <span class="gemarra-regular">thin, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and he will leave them </span>all, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he will come </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to neglect the rejoicing of the Festival. </span>If, however, one announces the day before: I will take this one and that one, he will indeed take only those fledglings, thereby enhancing his Festival joy. 
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If, on the eve of a Festival, one <span class="gemarra-regular">designated black </span>fledglings to be slaughtered, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>on the following day <span class="gemarra-regular">found white </span>ones in the dovecote, rather than the birds he had designated, or if one designated <span class="gemarra-regular">white </span>ones to be slaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">and found black </span>ones, or if one designated <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>fledglings to be slaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">found three, they are prohibited, </span>as these are not the same fledglings he had designated earlier. If, however, one designated <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>to be slaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">and found </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">two, they are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permitted, </span>as it is presumed that one of the fledglings escaped.
If one designated them <span class="gemarra-regular">inside </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the nest </span>and the next day he cannot find them there, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he found </span>fledglings <span class="gemarra-regular">before the nest, they are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited, </span>as they might be fledglings other than the ones he designated and left inside the nest. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are only those </span>fledglings in the immediate vicinity, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted, </span>as it can be assumed that these are the ones he designated inside the nest. 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: But it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that if one designated black ones to be slaughtered and found white ones, they are not the same birds. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: With what are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we dealing </span><span class="gemarra-regular">here</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one designated </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">black and white </span>ones to be slaughtered, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he arose and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">foun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">black ones</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the place </span>where the <span class="gemarra-regular">white ones </span>had been, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> white ones in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>of the <span class="gemarra-regular">black ones. Lest</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you say: These are those </span>same fledglings <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>they simply <span class="gemarra-regular">exchanged </span>places, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this claim is not accepted. Instead, it is assumed that <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>ones that he designated <span class="gemarra-regular">have gone to the </span>outside <span class="gemarra-regular">world, and these</span> ones that he found <span class="gemarra-regular">are others </span>that have come from elsewhere.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>this mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">supports Rabbi Ḥanina, as Rabbi Ḥanina said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>When resolving an uncertainty with regard to the identity of an item, if the <span class="gemarra-regular">majority </span>indicates one ruling but the item in question is <span class="gemarra-regular">proximat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to a source that indicates otherwise, one <span class="gemarra-regular">follows the majority. </span>In this case, the majority of fledglings are prohibited, as they were not designated for use on the Festival. Consequently, the found fledglings are prohibited, despite the fact that the nearest fledglings are the designated ones.
The Gemara refutes this suggestion: Perhaps it is <span class="gemarra-regular">as Abaye said </span>with regard to a different issue: We are dealing with fledglings located <span class="gemarra-regular">on a ledge</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a flat piece of wood protruding from the dovecote, around which many doves congregate. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a ledge. </span>Since other doves are regularly found there, the principle that one follows the majority rather than the proximate source does not apply, as both the majority of doves and the proximate source of doves are not the original ones, and therefore all the fledglings are prohibited.
The mishna taught that if one designated <span class="gemarra-regular">two and found three, they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are prohibited. </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whichever </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>look at this matter, the fledglings are prohibited. <span class="gemarra-regular">If these are others</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, they are other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that have not been designated. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if they are not others, </span>i.e., two of the fledglings that one designated are still there, nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>that he certainly did not designate and <span class="gemarra-regular">that is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mingled with them, </span>which renders the others prohibited as well. 
§ The mishna taught that if one designated <span class="gemarra-regular">three and found two</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are permitted. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">These are the same ones, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one of them has gone to the </span>outside <span class="gemarra-regular">world</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> leaving two behind. 
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say that the mishna is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">and not </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">placed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars </span>of tithe money in a safe place <span class="gemarra-regular">and found two hundre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> there, it is assumed that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">non-sacred </span>money <span class="gemarra-regular">and second-tith</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> money <span class="gemarra-regular">mingled </span><span class="gemarra-regular">together. </span>Someone must have come and added another hundred to his tithe money. Therefore, he separates one dinars from the total and states: Whatever part of this is the tithe, is fine; whatever part of it is non-tithe money, let it be used to redeem the tithe money, and this should be sanctified as tithe money in its place. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbis say: It is all non-sacre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> money. Since the money is not as he left it, the assumption is that someone took the original one hundred dinars; and he, or someone else, replaced it with two hundred dinars of regular money.
Conversely, if one <span class="gemarra-regular">placed two hundred </span>dinars <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">found one hundred dinars, </span>it is presumed that <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dinars has been left </span>in its place and is tithe money, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one hundred dinars </span>was <span class="gemarra-regular">removed. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: It</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is all non-sacred </span>money. It is assumed that someone removed all the money, and the one hundred dinars he found must have been placed there by someone else, and is not connected to the money he left. The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the case of fledglings apparently follows Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion in the case of second-tithe money.
The Gemara refutes this claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it can be explained, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it was stated with regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to this </span>mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar both</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: Fledglings are different, since they typically hop </span>from place to place. Therefore, it is possible that one of them escaped. By contrast, a money pouch cannot move of its own accord and must have been taken by someone. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">to answer</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to it: Fledglings are different, since they typically</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hop? But wasn’t it stated with regard to that</span> mishna, which deals with a money pouch, <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Yoḥanan</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rabbi Elazar </span>disagree over it: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two pouches</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>with one hundred dinars in each pouch. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>if all of the money was <span class="gemarra-regular">in a single pouch, everyone agrees</span> that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">non-sacred </span>money, as it is unlikely that only half of the money was removed while the other half was left in its place. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">to one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pouch, but with regard to two pouches, everyone agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred dinars </span>of tithe <span class="gemarra-regular">is left and one hundred</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dinars </span>has been <span class="gemarra-regular">removed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who said </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute</span> deals with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of two pouches, this is </span>why <span class="gemarra-regular">it was necessary to answer here: Fledglings are different, since</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they typically hop. However, according to the one who says</span> that the <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>involves a case <span class="gemarra-regular">of one pouch, but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to two pouches everyone agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one hundred</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dinars </span>of tithe <span class="gemarra-regular">is left and one hundred dinars </span>has been <span class="gemarra-regular">removed, now </span>consider: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">to answer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, with regard to it, </span>that there is a difference between that <span class="it-text">halakha</span> and the case of fledglings? <span class="gemarra-regular">You said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not disagree </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to two </span>separate <span class="gemarra-regular">pouches, </span>and therefore they certainly do not disagree in the case of fledglings.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: Here we are dealing with fledglings tied </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> with money <span class="gemarra-regular">pouches tied </span>together. In other words, when it is stated that the dispute applies to one pouch, this refers to two pouches that are tied together, as well. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and the rabbis agree only with regard to two pouches that are entirely separate. Consequently, it is necessary to explain that there is a difference between pouches tied together and fledglings tied together: <span class="gemarra-regular">Fledglings </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">release themselves</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from each other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span>and therefore it is possible that only one of them escaped, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">pouches cannot release themselves</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from each other. </span>Therefore, it is evident that someone must have taken them. Since they were tied together, he certainly took both of them.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if that is indeed the case, and it is obvious that someone came and took the money, what is Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s reasoning? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: Pouches, too, sometimes </span>

Daf 11a

<span class="gemarra-regular">their knot </span><span class="gemarra-regular">becomes worn </span>and untied. Consequently, it is possible that someone took only one of the two pouches.
§ The mishna taught that if one designated fledglings <span class="gemarra-regular">inside the nest and found </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">before the nest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">they are prohibited. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this supports </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥanina, as Rabbi Ḥanina </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>In a case involving <span class="gemarra-regular">a majority and </span>an item that is <span class="gemarra-regular">near, </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">follows the majority. </span>Since doves from the outside world are more numerous than those that one designated, the assumption is that these fledglings are from the majority, and therefore they are prohibited.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said, </span>in refutation of this claim: Here we are dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with a ledg</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> affixed to the front of the nest, where all the doves gather. Therefore, the principle pertaining to a majority and an item that is near does not apply to this case. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>Here <span class="gemarra-regular">we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are dealing with two nests, one above the other, </span>i.e., adjacent nests rather than any two nests. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is not necessary </span>to state that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">designated </span>the fledglings in <span class="gemarra-regular">the lower </span>nest <span class="gemarra-regular">and did not designate </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">in the upper one, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he found </span>fledglings <span class="gemarra-regular">in the lower one and he did </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not find </span>fledglings <span class="gemarra-regular">in the upper one, that </span>the fledglings <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. </span>The reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that we say: These </span>that were in the lower nest <span class="gemarra-regular">went to the </span>outside <span class="gemarra-regular">world, while these </span>still present <span class="gemarra-regular">have dragged themselves and come </span><span class="gemarra-regular">down. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, even </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if one designated </span>fledglings <span class="gemarra-regular">in the upper </span>nest <span class="gemarra-regular">and did </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not designate </span>fledglings <span class="gemarra-regular">in the lower </span>one, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he came</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and found </span>fledglings <span class="gemarra-regular">in the upper one and did not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> find </span>fledglings <span class="gemarra-regular">in the lower one, those </span>in the upper nest <span class="gemarra-regular">are also prohibited, as we say: Those </span>that he originally designated <span class="gemarra-regular">went to the </span>outside <span class="gemarra-regular">world, and those </span>in the lower nest <span class="gemarra-regular">have clutched and climbed. </span>Therefore, there is cause for concern in both of these cases.
The mishna states that <span class="gemarra-regular">if there are no </span>others <span class="gemarra-regular">there apart from them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, they are permitted. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? If we say </span>that the mishna is dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>fledglings that <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">able </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">fly</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>is possible <span class="gemarra-regular">to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">those </span>that he designated <span class="gemarra-regular">went to the</span> outside <span class="gemarra-regular">world, and the ones </span>that are present <span class="gemarra-regular">are other</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ones. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the mishna must be referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>fledglings that can only <span class="gemarra-regular">hop </span>from one place to another. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it deals with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>another dove <span class="gemarra-regular">nest within fifty cubits, </span>the fledglings might have <span class="gemarra-regular">jumped </span>and come from that nest; <span class="gemarra-regular">and if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there is no nest within fifty cubits, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are permitted, </span>for from where could they have come? <span class="gemarra-regular">As Mar Ukva bar Ḥama said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>creature <span class="gemarra-regular">that hops, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">does not hop more than</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fifty cubits</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there is </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">nest within fifty cubits, and </span>it deals with a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the additional nest <span class="gemarra-regular">is situated around</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a corne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> from the first nest, rather than in a straight line from it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say: </span>The fledglings <span class="gemarra-regular">jumped </span>from one nest to the other, the mishna therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere that </span>a fledgling <span class="gemarra-regular">hops and turns</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and sees its nest, it will </span>continue to <span class="gemarra-regular">hop. But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if </span>it can <span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>longer see its original nest, <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will not hop </span>any farther.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: One may not take a large </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pestl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> from a mortar, which is normally used for crushing wheat in the preparation of porridge, for any other purpose on a Festival, e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">to cut meat on it; and Beit Hillel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permit </span>it. Likewise, <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> place </span>an unprocessed <span class="gemarra-regular">hide before those who </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">tread on</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as this constitutes the prohibited labor of tanning on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> the hide from its place, as it is considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there is an olive-bulk of meat on it, </span>in which case it may be carried on account of its meat; <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel permit </span>it in both cases.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">agree that if one </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">cu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">meat </span>he needs for the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the pestle, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to move </span>the pestle farther on the Festival. The reason is that the vessel is <span class="it-text">muktze</span> as a utensil whose primary function is a prohibited use, and therefore it is permitted to handle it only when one requires it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>applies specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a pestle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> however, in </span>the case of a wooden anvil used <span class="gemarra-regular">for breaking bones, everyone agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted. </span>The Gemara asks: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious; we learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">A pestle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Why would one think that an object not even mentioned in the mishna is prohibited?
The Gemara answers: Abaye’s statement is necessary, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say: The same is true, </span>i.e., Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel disagree, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>with regard to a wooden anvil used <span class="gemarra-regular">for breaking bones; and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that which </span>the mishna specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: A pestle, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">to convey the far-reaching nature of </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they permitted </span>moving <span class="gemarra-regular">even an object whose </span>primary <span class="gemarra-regular">function </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">for a prohibited </span>use. Abaye therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> us </span>that Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not disagree with regard to a wooden anvil used for breaking bones.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some say</span> a different version of the previous discussion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: It</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is necessary </span>to say <span class="gemarra-regular">only: Even a new </span>wooden anvil used <span class="gemarra-regular">for breaking bones </span>is also permitted. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>Perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">one will reconsider and not break </span>bones <span class="gemarra-regular">on it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>but rather set it aside for a different purpose, Abaye therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this is not a concern. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is that so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Are Beit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shammai not concerned </span>about the possibility <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one might <span class="gemarra-regular">reconsider? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Beitza</span> 1:13): <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: </span>On a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not lead a butcher</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with a knife </span>in hand <span class="gemarra-regular">to an animal </span>located far from him, so that he can slaughter it; <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>may one lead <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal to a butcher with a knife</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>lest he reconsider, in which case he will have handled the knife unnecessarily, which is prohibited; <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: One may lead </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">from one to the other, </span>as they are not concerned about unnecessary use of the knife.
By the same reasoning, <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not bring spices or a pestle to a mortar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular">nor a mortar to spices and a pestle, </span>as he might change his mind and will have handled these utensils on the Festival for no purpose. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">One may bring one to the other, </span>as there is no concern that he may reconsider. This shows that Beit Shammai are, in general, concerned that one might reconsider, as they prohibit one to handle items for this reason.
The Gemara refutes this: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span><span class="gemarra-regular">can </span>these cases <span class="gemarra-regular">be compared? Granted, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal, one </span>is liable to <span class="gemarra-regular">come to reconsider, as </span>he might <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Let us leave </span>aside <span class="gemarra-regular">this animal, </span>as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">thin, and we will bring a different animal, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fatter than it. </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a pot, too, one </span>is liable <span class="gemarra-regular">to come to reconsider, as </span>he might <span class="gemarra-regular">say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Let us leave </span>aside <span class="gemarra-regular">this pot </span>of cooked food, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span> it <span class="gemarra-regular">requires spices </span>and would take great effort to prepare, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I will bring a different one that does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> require spices </span>and can be cooked as it is. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>with regard to a wooden anvil used for breaking bones, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to say? </span>Will one <span class="gemarra-regular">reconsider and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not break </span>the bones? <span class="gemarra-regular">Since he has slaughtered </span>an animal, it <span class="gemarra-regular">stands </span>ready for its bones <span class="gemarra-regular">to be broken, </span>as it cannot be eaten in any other way.
§ It was taught in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: One may not place </span>an unprocessed <span class="gemarra-regular">hide </span>before the one who will tread on it. The Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>(<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Beitza</span> 1:13): <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">agree that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one may salt meat for roasting on </span>this hide, and there is no concern that some of the salt will fall on the hide, which would be similar to tanning the hide by salting. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: They taught </span>that one may salt meat <span class="gemarra-regular">only for roasting, </span>in which case it is not salted a great deal. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>in the case of meat <span class="gemarra-regular">for a pot, </span>i.e., for cooking, the Sages did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>say that one may salt it on the hide, as meat must be well-salted on all sides before cooking, and a large amount of salt will inevitably spill onto the hide.
The Gemara asks: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>the one may not salt meat <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>cooking in a pot, as <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> just cited: <span class="gemarra-regular">For roasting, </span>and not for cooking. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This</span> comes to <span class="gemarra-regular">teach us that even </span>the permission to salt meat <span class="gemarra-regular">for roasting </span>applies only if one does so in the usual manner. However, if one salts it <span class="gemarra-regular">in a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> manner of </span>meat salted to be cooked in <span class="gemarra-regular">a pot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which requires more salt than is necessary for roasting, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: </span>On a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not salt the fats </span>of an animal, which is done so that they will not decompose and emit a foul odor. This is true even if the animal was slaughtered on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not turn </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them over</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The fats are unfit for use on the Festival, and therefore they are <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the name of Rabbi Yehoshua: One may spread </span>the fats <span class="gemarra-regular">out in the wind on pegs </span>to prevent them from decaying. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mattana said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mattana said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, according to the one who said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua, </span>this statement <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary. </span>Otherwise, <span class="gemarra-regular">it might enter your </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mind to say </span>that since this is a dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">an individual and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">many, </span>one should apply the principal that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">many. </span>Rav Mattana therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that, in this case, the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the individual. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">However, according</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the one who said </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance with </span>the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua, this is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious. </span>In a case involving <span class="gemarra-regular">an individual and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">many</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">many. </span>The Gemara answers: This ruling is nevertheless necessary, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say: Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehoshua’s opinion is </span>more <span class="gemarra-regular">reasonable, for if you do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not permit him </span>to air out the fats, <span class="gemarra-regular">he will</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> refrain and not slaughter </span>an animal at all. Rav Mattana therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this factor is not taken into consideration.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this case <span class="gemarra-regular">different from </span>placing <span class="gemarra-regular">a hide before those who will tread </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on it, </span>which Beit Hillel, whose ruling is accepted as <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, permit for the very reason that, if one is not allowed to do so, he will refrain from slaughtering animals? 

Daf 11b

The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of spreading out the hide, <span class="gemarra-regular">the matter is not </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">eviden</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> that it is spread out for tanning <span class="gemarra-regular">because</span> in its current state, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is fit to recline on</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and therefore it can be said that one placed it for this purpose. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>with regard to fats, he himself might <span class="gemarra-regular">come to say: What is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages permitted </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to me? So that it will</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not emit a foul odor. </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>if I <span class="gemarra-regular">spread them out, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span> is the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>if I <span class="gemarra-regular">salt them? </span>This reasoning will lead one to salt hides, which is a prohibited labor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: A person may salt</span> on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">several piece</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of meat at one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">time, although he requires </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one piece, </span>as it is all one act of salting. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Ahava </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">employ artific</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and salt bone </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">bone. </span>After salting one bone, he would say: I prefer this one instead, and would thereby salt all the meat in his possession.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not remove </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">shutters [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">terisin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of a store <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival, </span>due to the prohibition against building and demolishing. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel permit </span>one not only to open the shutters, but <span class="gemarra-regular">even to replace </span>them.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>are these <span class="gemarra-regular">shutters</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>This is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">shutters of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">shops</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The marketplace shops or stalls were large crates or wagons, not buildings. They were closed at night with shutters. The shopkeepers would open the shutters on the Festival so that people who did not manage to finish all of their Festival preparations before the Festival could take the articles they required and settle accounts with the storekeeper later. Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel disputed whether the shutters may be opened and closed on the Festival itself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Ulla said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">three matters, </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>an action <span class="gemarra-regular">whose result </span>is undesirable <span class="gemarra-regular">in order</span> to encourage a desirable <span class="gemarra-regular">initial </span>action. <span class="gemarra-regular">And these are </span>the three matters: First, they permitted spreading out the <span class="gemarra-regular">hide </span>of an animal slaughtered on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">before those </span>who will <span class="gemarra-regular">tread on it, </span>a stage in its tanning. This was permitted because the Sages wish to encourage slaughtering the animal to enable celebration on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>second, the Sages permitted the replacement of <span class="gemarra-regular">shutters of shops </span>on a Festival, so that storeowners could supply the Festival requirements for those in need. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the third permitted action is <span class="gemarra-regular">the replacement of a bandag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Temple. </span>If a priest had an injury on his hand, he would have to remove the bandage while performing the Temple service, as it is prohibited for any item to interpose between his hand and whatever he must handle as part of the rite. After concluding his Temple service, he was allowed to replace the bandage on Shabbat, despite the fact that this is ordinarily prohibited, so as not to discourage him from engaging in Temple service.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Raḥava </span>said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda said: </span>There is <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>one other matter, i.e., another instance where the Sages permitted an action whose result was undesirable in order to encourage a desirable initial action. This concerns a <span class="it-text">ḥaver</span>, a member of a group that is meticulous with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of ritual impurity, <span class="gemarra-regular">who opens his barrel </span>of wine or prepares <span class="gemarra-regular">and begins </span>to sell <span class="gemarra-regular">his dough </span>to pilgrims <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sake of the Festival.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who said: He </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may finish </span>selling all the bread made from that dough and all the wine in the barrel. Wine or dough sold to the general public is usually classified as ritually impure, as it might have been touched by an <span class="it-text">am</span> <span class="it-text">ha’aretz</span>, one who is not careful with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of ritual impurity. During a Festival, however, the Sages decreed that all wine and dough sold in Jerusalem is ritually pure, so as not to embarrass ignorant people, and they may therefore be bought even by a <span class="it-text">ḥaver</span>. Rabbi Yehuda adds that even if a large quantity of wine or dough remains after the Festival, it retains its status as ritually pure and one may continue to sell it to a <span class="it-text">ḥaver</span>. This is a case of permitting an action whose result is undesirable for the sake of an initial action, in that the Sages maintained the wine and dough’s status as ritually pure after the Festival in order to encourage people to sell wine and dough on the Festival. 
With regard to Ulla’s statement, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one may spread out an animal’s <span class="gemarra-regular">hide before those </span>who will <span class="gemarra-regular">tread on it. </span>Why did Ulla find it necessary to restate an explicit teaching of a mishna? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason of Beit Hillel </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the hide <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fit for reclining on it, and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if the animal was slaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">on the eve of the Festival, </span>it would <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be permitted to spread out its hide on the Festival. Ulla therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the reason for the leniency is that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>an action <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span><span class="gemarra-regular">result </span>was undesirable <span class="gemarra-regular">in order </span>to encourage a desirable <span class="gemarra-regular">initial </span>action. Consequently, in the case of an animal slaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">on a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival, yes, </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies; but with regard to one that was slaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">on the eve of a Festival, no</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>one may not spread out its hide.
The Gemara further asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the <span class="gemarra-regular">shutters of shops as well, </span>as the mishna states that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel permit </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">even to replace them. </span>The Gemara explains: This, too, is necessary. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say: Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Hillel’s reason </span>for being lenient <span class="gemarra-regular">is that there is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> no </span>prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">building </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to vessels and no</span> prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">dismantling </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to vessels. </span>Since these shops are not attached to the ground, they are vessels rather than houses, and it is therefore permitted to replace their shutters; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>as a result, the dismantlement and replacement of shutters of large vessels, <span class="gemarra-regular">even of </span>those found in <span class="gemarra-regular">houses, </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">als</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> be permitted. To counter this logic, Ulla therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the reason the Sages allowed the replacement of shutters of shops on a Festival is because they <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>an action <span class="gemarra-regular">whose result </span>is undesirable <span class="gemarra-regular">in order</span> to encourage a desirable <span class="gemarra-regular">initial </span>action. Consequently, in the case of the shutters <span class="gemarra-regular">of shops, yes, </span>they permitted their replacement; in the case of those <span class="gemarra-regular">of houses, no, </span>they did not allow it.
The Gemara further asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">the replacement of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bandage in the Temple as well: One may replace a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bandage in the Temple but not in </span>the rest of <span class="gemarra-regular">the country. </span>The Gemara explains that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is necessary. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say: What is the reason </span>that a bandage may be replaced? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because rabbinic decrees prohibiting labor</span> do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>apply <span class="gemarra-regular">in the Temple</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since the prohibition against applying a bandage is by rabbinic law, this leniency should apply to all who are in the Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">even</span> to <span class="gemarra-regular">a priest who is not a candidate </span>to perform the Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">service. </span>Ulla <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that this is not the case; rather, it is an instance where the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted a result for the sake of an initial action</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: If one is a candidate for service, yes, </span>he may replace his bandage; <span class="gemarra-regular">if one is not a candidate for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> service, no, </span>he may not replace his bandage.
The Gemara asks a similar question with regard to Raḥava’s addition: <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> opens his barrel </span>of wine, <span class="gemarra-regular">as well: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who opens his barre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> to sell its wine, and similarly in the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">begins</span> selling <span class="gemarra-regular">his dough for the sake of the Festival, </span>the substance is ritually pure. If some is left over, the <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> disputed whether it retains its presumed status as ritually pure after the Festival and one may continue to sell it to a <span class="it-text">ḥaver</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: He </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may finish </span>selling the wine or dough, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: He may not finish. </span>What is added by including it in the list of matters where a result is permitted for the sake of an initial action? 
The Gemara explains: Raḥava’s statement is necessary. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say: </span>It is permitted to finish selling the wine or dough because <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages rendered</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the ritual impurity of an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">am</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ha’aretz</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival as ritually pure, and although one did not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">begin </span>to sell this wine or dough on the Festival but at an earlier stage, he should <span class="gemarra-regular">likewise </span>be permitted to finish, as items do not contract ritual impurity on a Festival. To counter this logic, Raḥava therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us: </span>In this case, too, the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>an action <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span><span class="gemarra-regular">result </span>is undesirable <span class="gemarra-regular">in order </span>to encourage a desirable <span class="gemarra-regular">initial </span>action. <span class="gemarra-regular">If one had begun, yes, </span>he may finish selling; <span class="gemarra-regular">if one had not begun, no, </span>he may not do so.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Ulla, what is the reason that he did he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not state this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> alongside the other cases he listed? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">He is not dealing with </span>a case that is a matter of <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> He listed only cases where the ruling is unanimous. The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">These </span>other three matters <span class="gemarra-regular">are also </span>subject to <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute, </span>as they all involve a disagreement between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel. The Gemara answers: When <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai </span>express an opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">where Beit Hillel </span>disagree, Beit Shammai’s opinion is not considered a legitimate opinion in the <span class="gemarra-regular">Mishna, </span>and it is completely disregarded. Since everyone knows that Beit Shammai’s opinion is entirely rejected by <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, it is not taken into consideration. Therefore, those cases are not viewed as disputes at all. 
§ The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is taught:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> agree that one may remove shutters on a Festival. They</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> disagree only </span>as to whether it is permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">to replac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> them, as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Beit Shammai say: One may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not replace </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel say: One may even </span><span class="gemarra-regular">replace </span>them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And in what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>these shutters <span class="gemarra-regular">have a hing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that can be inserted into a slot in the side of the vessel. <span class="gemarra-regular">However</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they do not have a hinge, everyone agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted, </span>as this is merely replacement of a board, and it is not similar to building.
The Gemara challenges this claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>What is the situation in which Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel disagree? They disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the shutters <span class="gemarra-regular">do not have a hinge; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">however, if they have a hinge, everyone agrees </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. Abaye said </span>that the two sources can be reconciled: <span class="gemarra-regular">When they have a hinge on the side, everyone </span><span class="gemarra-regular">agrees </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited, </span>as the placement of a hinge in the side is a complicated endeavor that resembles building. If <span class="gemarra-regular">they have no hinge at all, everyone agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted, </span>as it is considered merely the replacement of a board. <span class="gemarra-regular">When they disagree, </span>it is with regard to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they have a hinge in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the middle </span>rather than on the side. 

Daf 12a

One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Beit Shammai, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">issue a decree </span>and prohibit <span class="gemarra-regular">a hinge in the middle </span><span class="gemarra-regular">due to a hinge on the side; and </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Beit Hillel, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not issue </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">decree. </span>Since placing a hinge of this type does not constitute the prohibited labor of building, it is permitted.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">carry out </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">neither a minor </span>child, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">lulav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, nor a Torah Scroll into the public</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> domain, </span>as none of these are required for the preparation of food; <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel permit </span>it.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> who reviews <span class="it-text">mishnayot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span> a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi: One who slaughters</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a gift </span><span class="gemarra-regular">offerin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival is flogged </span>for transgressing the prohibition: “No manner of work shall be done on them” (Exodus 12:16). Since this slaughtering was not performed for the purpose of eating, the action constitutes a prohibited labor on a Festival. 
Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>that <span class="it-text">tanna</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to you? It is </span>evidently in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai, who say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say: Since carrying out was permitted </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">for the purpose </span>of food preparation, it <span class="gemarra-regular">was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> also permitted not for that purpose</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> For if you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Hillel, they say: Since carrying out was permitted for the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> requirements </span>of food preparation, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was also permitted not for</span> these <span class="gemarra-regular">requirements. Here, too, </span>with regard to the prohibited labor of slaughtering, <span class="gemarra-regular">since slaughter was permitted for the requirements </span>of food preparation, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was also permitted not for </span>these <span class="gemarra-regular">requirements</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>It was permitted for any purpose that benefits people, whether directly or indirectly. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba strongly objects to this </span>reasoning: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>do you infer <span class="gemarra-regular">that Beit Shammai and Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Hillel disagree over this </span>issue? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps they disagree </span>about the following: The <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">carrying out </span>apply <span class="gemarra-regular">to Shabbat, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">there are no </span><span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor </span>a prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">carrying out </span>on a Festival. 
The Gemara clarifies the dispute according to this explanation: One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Beit Shammai, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> and the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">carrying out </span>apply <span class="gemarra-regular">to Shabbat, and</span> similarly the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">carrying out </span>apply <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a Festival. </span>The only difference is that, on a Festival, carrying, like other types of prohibited labor, is permitted for the sake of food preparation. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Beit Hillel, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> and the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">carrying out </span>apply <span class="gemarra-regular">to Shabbat, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">there are no</span> <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> nor a prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">carrying out on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a Festival, as it is written:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Neither carry forth </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a burden out of your houses on the Shabbat day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Jeremiah 17:22), from which Beit Hillel inferred: <span class="gemarra-regular">On Shabbat, yes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>carrying from one domain to another is indeed prohibited; <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a Festival, no, </span>it is not prohibited. According to this explanation, Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not disagree about whether a prohibited labor that is permitted for the purpose of food preparation on a Festival is also permitted when it does not serve that purpose.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef strongly objects</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to this </span>explanation of Rabba: <span class="gemarra-regular">However, if </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>that the dispute is whether the prohibition against carrying out applies on a Festival, Beit Hillel should permit one to move <span class="it-text">muktze</span> objects, as the prohibition of handling <span class="it-text">muktze</span> is an extension of the prohibition against carrying out. Consequently, <span class="gemarra-regular">let</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them differ with regard to </span>whether or not it is permitted to carry out <span class="gemarra-regular">stones </span>on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, from</span> the fact that Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">do not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> disagree with regard to stones </span>but concerning objects that serve some sort of purpose, <span class="gemarra-regular">conclude from this: </span>Everyone agrees that carrying out is prohibited on a Festival, and the Torah permitted it only when it is necessary for sustenance. 
Instead, Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to carrying out </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for the purpose </span>of food preparation.
