According to the opinion of Beit Hillel, since carrying out is permitted for the sake of sustenance, it is entirely permitted. According to Beit Shammai, the Sages permitted only labor that serves the purpose of food preparation.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan also holds </span>that Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree with regard to </span>the principle: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since carrying out is permitted </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">for the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> purpose </span>of food preparation, it <span class="gemarra-regular">was also permitted not for</span> this <span class="gemarra-regular">purpose, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teaches </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan: One who cooks the sciatic nerv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in milk</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a Festival and eats it is flogged </span>for violating <span class="gemarra-regular">fiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> distinct prohibitions. 
How so? (1) <span class="gemarra-regular">He is flogged due to </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">cooking </span>the sciatic <span class="gemarra-regular">nerve, </span>which is prohibited because the sciatic nerve is unfit for consumption; (2) <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he is flogged due to </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">eating </span>the sciatic <span class="gemarra-regular">nerve, </span>which is explicitly prohibited by the Torah; (3) <span class="gemarra-regular">and he is flogged due to </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">cooking meat in milk; </span>(4) <span class="gemarra-regular">and he is flogged </span><span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">eating meat </span>cooked <span class="gemarra-regular">in milk; </span>(5) <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>lastly, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is flogged</span>

Daf 12b

<span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">kindlin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> a fire on a Festival.
Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>that <span class="it-text">tanna</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Leave </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and teach it outside</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is not fit for discussion in the study hall. The opinion that there is a prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">kindling and cookin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">is not a mishna </span>worthy of serious consideration. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is a mishna </span>rather than an error, this statement is still not in accordance with the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>following the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai, who say: We do not say: Since</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> carrying out was permitted </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">for the purposes</span> of food preparation, it <span class="gemarra-regular">was also permitted </span>when performed <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>these <span class="gemarra-regular">purposes. Here, too, </span>we do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>say: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> kindling was permitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">for the purposes </span>of food preparation, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was also permitted </span>when performed <span class="gemarra-regular">not for </span>these <span class="gemarra-regular">purposes. </span>
The Gemara explains why the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cannot be attributed to Beit Hillel. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one were to suggest that this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> follows the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel, </span>this cannot be the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: Since carrying out was permitted for the purposes </span>of food preparation, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was also permitted </span>when performed <span class="gemarra-regular">not for </span>these <span class="gemarra-regular">purposes. Here, too, since kindling was permitted for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">purposes </span>of food preparation, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was also permitted </span>when performed <span class="gemarra-regular">not for </span>these <span class="gemarra-regular">purposes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, according to the opinion of Beit Hillel, kindling cannot be included amongst those prohibitions for which one is liable on a Festival.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The separation of <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> is permitted on a Festival, as one is permitted to prepare dough and bake it on a Festival, and bread may not be eaten without first separating <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not bring </span>separated <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥall</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>any of the other priestly <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw of a slaughtered animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">to a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">priest on a Festival, </span>though it is permitted to separate them from an animal slaughtered on a Festival. This is prohibited regardless of <span class="gemarra-regular">whether they were separated last evening, </span>i.e., before the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">or whether they were separated today. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel permit </span>it. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai said to </span>Beit Hillel: This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> can be derived by <span class="gemarra-regular">an analogy: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Ḥalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts </span>are both considered <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the priest, and </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> separated from produce is also <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift to the priest. Just as </span>you agree <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may not bring </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> to a priest on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, one may not bring the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to them: No, </span>this analogy is incorrect. <span class="gemarra-regular">If you said </span>that you derive the halakha from <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">its separation</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not allowed </span>on the Festival, how <span class="gemarra-regular">will you say</span> the same <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the gifts </span>from an animal or <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span>, concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">which their separation is allowed </span>on the Festival? Since it is not prohibited to separate these gifts, they may likewise be brought to a priest. 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">It </span><span class="gemarra-regular">enters your mind </span>to explain <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>when the mishna states: <span class="gemarra-regular">They were separated today, </span>it means: From animals <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered today</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And </span>the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">They were separated last evening, </span>is referring to animals <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered last evening. </span>The Gemara asks: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">whose opinion is </span>expressed in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not Rabbi Yosei nor Rabbi Yehuda, but </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda said: Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not dispute</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to gifts separated on the eve of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival, that one may bring </span>them to a priest on a Festival day itself along <span class="gemarra-regular">with gifts separated that day</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">those </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered that day. They disputed only</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">of bringing </span>gifts separated the day before <span class="gemarra-regular">by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> themselves, as Beit Shammai say: One may not bring </span>these gifts by themselves, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel say: One may bring</span> them. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Shammai would reason as follows: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Ḥalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and gifts</span> from a slaughtered animal are <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift to the priest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift to the priest. Just as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one may not bring </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> to a priest on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, one may not bring the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Beit Hillel said to them: No, </span>granted, <span class="gemarra-regular">if you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the reason is <span class="gemarra-regular">that separation is not allowed </span>on a Festival, but how <span class="gemarra-regular">will you say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts, </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">which separation is allowed </span>on the Festival? It is therefore permitted to bring these gifts to a priest as well. This is Rabbi Yehuda’s interpretation of the dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, according to which Beit Shammai prohibit bringing even gifts separated on the Festival itself.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei said: </span>That is not the correct record of the dispute, as <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">did not dispute about </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may bring </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the gifts </span>from an animal to a priest on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">They disputed only with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as Beit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shammai say: One may not bring </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: One may </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">bring </span><span class="it-text">teruma</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel would </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-italic">Ḥalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and gifts </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the priest, and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift to the priest. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Just as one may bring the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts </span>on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, one may bring </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Beit Shammai </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: No; if you said </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts, </span>concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">which their separation is allowed </span>on the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">will you say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, whose separation is not allowed? </span>
<span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that the dispute was as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not dispute with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, that one may not bring </span>it to a priest on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">They disputed only </span>the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">gifts, as Beit Shammai say: One may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bring </span>the other gifts, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel say: One may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bring </span>them. The Gemara proposes: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>only in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara does not even suggest that the mishna might be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, as it is clear that it cannot be reconciled with his explanation.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: Is it taught </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">They were separated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that day and were slaughtered that day? </span>No; <span class="gemarra-regular">it teaches</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: They were separated, and actually </span>the mishna should be explained as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">They were slaughtered last evening </span>and separated today, which is exactly what Rabbi Yehuda said. The Gemara asks: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us say </span>that the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda and not </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-italic">Aḥerim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it can still be claimed that, in their opinion, Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel disputed the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of these </span>animals that <span class="gemarra-regular">were slaughtered last evening</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>not those slaughtered on the Festival.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, this is </span>the same opinion as that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda. </span>What, then, is the difference between the opinions of Rabbi Yehuda and <span class="it-text">Aḥerim</span>? The Gemara answers: The practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>is with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">secondary </span>gifts. If one has gifts separated before a Festival, is he permitted to join them as secondary gifts along with others separated on the Festival and transport them together to a priest? Rabbi Yehuda maintains that secondary gifts may be brought to a priest, according to the opinion of Beit Hillel, whereas <span class="it-text">Aḥerim</span> prohibit it. 
With regard to the dispute cited in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei. </span>The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Tovi, son of Rabbi Neḥemya, had a bottle of </span><span class="it-text">teruma</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">wine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He came before Rav Yosef </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">bringing </span>this wine <span class="gemarra-regular">to a priest now, </span>on a Festival? Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: That is what Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who maintains that Beit Hillel permit one to bring <span class="it-text">teruma</span> to a priest on a Festival, and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with their opinion.
§ The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">The host of Rava, son of Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥanan, had bundles of </span>unprocessed <span class="gemarra-regular">mustard, </span>whose seeds remained in their stems. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said </span>to his guest, the Sage: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to crushing </span>these mustard stalks <span class="gemarra-regular">and eating from them on a Festival? </span>Rava, son of Rav Ḥanan, <span class="gemarra-regular">did not have </span>an answer readily available, so he <span class="gemarra-regular">came before Rava </span>to ask his opinion. Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that it was taught: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may husk </span><span class="gemarra-regular">kernel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> by rubbing them between one’s fingers, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one may </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">crush legumes on a Festival. </span>This statement indicates that it is permitted to crush mustard stalks. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye raised </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an objection to </span>Rava from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who husks kernels </span>of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat eve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, on the following day, </span>on Shabbat itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may winno</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> the chaff in an irregular manner by passing the kernels <span class="gemarra-regular">from hand to hand and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">eat </span>them. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one may not </span>do so, <span class="gemarra-regular">neither by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tray [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kanon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> that is occasionally used for sorting and separating the chaff <span class="gemarra-regular">nor with a large vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who husks kernels </span>of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival eve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, on the following day, he may winnow a little </span>grain <span class="gemarra-regular">at a tim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and eat, even with a tray </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or a large vessel. However, he may not </span>do so <span class="gemarra-regular">with a tablet, nor with a winnow, nor with a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sieve. </span>Since these vessels are designed for winnowing, they are used only for large quantities, and therefore it will appear as though he were preparing for after the Festival, which is certainly prohibited. In any case, the wording of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> indicates: <span class="gemarra-regular">On a Festival eve, yes, </span>one may husk or crush legumes; <span class="gemarra-regular">on the Festival </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>it is prohibited to do so.
The Gemara refutes this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that it is permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> can be understood. The reason is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">On Shabbat </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eve, </span>as husking grain may not be performed on Shabbat itself, for it might lead to a prohibited labor on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">he also taught in the latter clause: On a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival eve. </span>However, this does not mean that rubbing or crushing legumes is prohibited on the Festival itself. 
Abaye raises a difficulty against the opinion of Rava from a different angle: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>you say <span class="gemarra-regular">so, we </span>have thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">found </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-italic">terum</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for which separation is allowed</span> on a Festival. Before being rubbed, the grains of wheat were certainly not fit to be eaten, and therefore there was no obligation to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from them. Now that one has prepared them as food by rubbing them, he is obligated to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from them, and if one is permitted to eat them, he must be permitted to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from them first. <span class="gemarra-regular">And we learned </span>explicitly in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, if you said </span>that you derive the halakha from <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>where <span class="gemarra-regular">its separation is not allowed</span> on the Festival. This statement indicates that even Beit Hillel agree that one may not separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> of any kind on a Festival.
The Gemara refutes this challenge: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. </span>

Daf 13a

<span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>source, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, who holds that one must separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from kernels of grain on the stalk, and one may separate <span class="it-text">terumot</span> on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>source, the mishna, is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who maintains that there is no need to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from kernels of grain on the stalk, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">brought inside </span>his house <span class="gemarra-regular">stalks </span>of grain in order to grind them into flour and <span class="gemarra-regular">to make dough from them, he may eat from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them, as a snack, </span>before they are ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is exempt </span>from <span class="it-text">teruma</span>. Provided that the grain has not yet been fully processed, the obligation to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> does not apply. The Sages decreed that such produce may only be consumed casually and not as part of a regular meal.
However, if from the outset one brought in the stalks of grain not to grind them but <span class="gemarra-regular">to husk the kernels </span>and eat them a little at a time, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">obligates </span>him to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from them and prohibits him from partaking of the grain until he has done so. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> exempts </span>him from the obligation of <span class="it-text">teruma</span>. He maintains that not even this intention renders one obligated to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, as the obligation for <span class="it-text">teruma</span> applies only to fully processed grain.
The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yehuda, </span>you can <span class="gemarra-regular">also find </span>a case when one must separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from grain that has not been fully processed. How so? <span class="gemarra-regular">For example, if one brought inside</span> his house <span class="gemarra-regular">stalks of grain to make dough from them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>thereby rendering himself obligated to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he reconsidered </span>and decided <span class="gemarra-regular">to husk them </span>in order to eat the kernels <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival. </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, the prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">untithed </span>produce takes effect <span class="gemarra-regular">on that day </span>and one is obligated to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, only afterward is he permitted to eat the kernels.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one must say: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">terum</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> that Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel agree may not be separated on a Festival? It is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">most </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>e.g., grain that has been threshed and gathered into piles on the eve of the Festival. They do, however, admit that there are exceptional cases in which one may separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> on a Festival.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute, </span>concerning when the obligation to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> and the prohibition of untithed produce takes effect, is referring only <span class="gemarra-regular">to stalks </span>of grain, which are typically brought into a granary, where they are processed in a standard manner. Until that point, the grain is not prohibited as untithed produce. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">legumes, everyone agrees </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">bundles </span>are already regarded as <span class="gemarra-regular">untithed produce, </span>and <span class="it-text">teruma</span> must be separated from them at that stage. 
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say that </span>the following mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">supports him </span>(<span class="it-text">Terumot</span> 10:6): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who had bundles of fenugreek</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a type of legume, <span class="gemarra-regular">of untithed produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pound </span>these bundles to remove the seeds from them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he calculate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> how many seeds </span>the bundles <span class="gemarra-regular">contain and separates</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> based <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span>quantity of <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds, but </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>calculate and <span class="gemarra-regular">separate </span><span class="it-text">teruma</span> based <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span>quantity of <span class="gemarra-regular">stalks. </span>Although the stalks and leaves are also used for cooking, it is not necessary to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from them. <span class="gemarra-regular">What, is it not </span>the case that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yehuda, who said: There, </span>with regard to stalks of grain, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>yet ready to be tithed, and therefore not prohibited as <span class="gemarra-regular">untithed produce, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>i.e., with regard to the bundles of fenugreek, it is ready to be tithed and therefore prohibited as <span class="gemarra-regular">untithed produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>
The Gemara rejects this contention: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this is no proof, as it can be claimed that the mishna dealing with fenugreek <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, who obligates one to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> in the case of stalks of grain. The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If it is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, what novel element does the mishna provide? <span class="gemarra-regular">Why specifically </span>discuss <span class="gemarra-regular">fenugreek? </span>According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">even to stalks </span>of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">as well.</span>
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>then? Is the mishna in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Yehuda? </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him teach us </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">other types of legumes, </span>i.e., that they have the status of untithed produce when placed in bundles. <span class="gemarra-regular">And all the more so </span>this would apply to <span class="gemarra-regular">fenugreek, </span>which is eaten only in small quantities and is not processed in the manner of grain. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it cannot be proven that the mishna follows either the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, or that of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, as it <span class="gemarra-regular">was necessary </span>for the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> to state the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">fenugreek </span>for a different reason: It could <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say: Since </span>in the case of fenugreek <span class="gemarra-regular">the taste of its stalk and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its fruit </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">identical, </span>as the branches of the fenugreek add flavor to a dish, perhaps one should <span class="gemarra-regular">also separate</span> <span class="it-text">teruma</span> based <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the quantity of fenugreek <span class="gemarra-regular">stalks, </span>as well. The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that there is no obligation to do so, and this is the novel element of his statement.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said </span>the following: This <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>between Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to stalks </span>of grain; <span class="gemarra-regular">however, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">legumes, everyone </span><span class="gemarra-regular">agrees </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">bundles </span>are not yet ready to be tithed and are therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>prohibited as <span class="gemarra-regular">untithed produce. </span>The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to this: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who had bundles of fenugreek of untithed produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may pound </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">and calculat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> how many seeds they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">contain and separate </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> based <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span>quantity of <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">but he does not separate </span>based <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span>quantity of <span class="gemarra-regular">stalks. What, is this not </span>referring to the normal case of <span class="gemarra-regular">untithed produce of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., produce from which the regular <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, the initial portion taken from produce as the priests’ portion, must be separated?
The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is referring to a different case, that of first tithe that is still regarded as <span class="gemarra-regular">untithed produce, </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the tith</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that must still be separated from it. First tithe is given to the Levites, who must separate ten percent as <span class="it-text">teruma</span> of the tithe, to give to the priests. Before <span class="it-text">teruma</span> of the tithe is separated, the first tithe may not be eaten. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this statement is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Abbahu </span>said that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ben Lakish said, as Rabbi Abbahu said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ben Lakish said: </span>It can occur that a Levite might take the <span class="gemarra-regular">first tithe before </span>the <span class="it-text">teruma</span> is separated, <span class="gemarra-regular">while </span>the grain is still <span class="gemarra-regular">on the stalks. </span>The correct procedure is: After collecting the grain in a pile in the granary, one first separates <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, and only afterward separates first tithe to give to the Levites. 
If this order was not followed, and the first tithe was separated first while the grain was still attached to the stalks, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish maintains that the following <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Its name, </span>i.e., the fact that it has been designated first tithe, <span class="gemarra-regular">renders it </span>ready to be tithed and therefore prohibited as <span class="gemarra-regular">untithed produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as pertains <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the tithe </span>that must still be separated from it. This shows that there can be a separation of a type of <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, specifically the <span class="it-text">teruma</span> of the tithe, even before work on the produce has been completed, and this is the case to which the previously quoted mishna is referring.
The Gemara challenges this interpretation: If first tithe is considered untithed produce when it is named, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do I </span>need the act of <span class="gemarra-regular">pounding? Let </span>the Levite <span class="gemarra-regular">say to </span>the priest: <span class="gemarra-regular">As they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gave to me </span>stalks of grain, or unprepared bundles, <span class="gemarra-regular">so</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> I am giving </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">to you </span>in the same state. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a penalty</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> In other words, the Levite should indeed be entitled to issue this claim; however, as he acted improperly by taking his tithe prematurely, the Sages decreed that he may not separate the priest’s portion in its current state, but must first improve it.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is also</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Levite </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who was given stalks </span>of grain <span class="gemarra-regular">as his tithes, he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">renders them </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">a granary, </span>i.e., he must thresh and process them in the usual manner. Similarly, if he was given <span class="gemarra-regular">grapes, he renders them wine; </span>if he was given <span class="gemarra-regular">olives, he renders them oil; and </span>afterward he <span class="gemarra-regular">separates </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the tithe for them and gives them to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a priest. For just as </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">gedola</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., standard <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not separated </span>from unprocessed produce, 

Daf 13b

<span class="gemarra-regular">but only from the granary and the winepress,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so too, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the tithe is separated only from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the granary and the winepress. </span>
The Gemara asks: If the mishna is referring to produce from which <span class="it-text">teruma</span> <span class="it-text">gedola</span> has not been separated, it is appropriate to use the term: Calculates. However, according to the suggestion that it is referring to a first tithe, from which <span class="it-text">teruma</span> of the tithe must be separated, why does the mishna state: <span class="gemarra-regular">Calculates? </span>The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">should have said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Measures</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The amount of <span class="it-text">teruma</span> <span class="it-text">gedola</span> to be separated is calculated by estimation, as there is no fixed amount for this <span class="it-text">teruma</span> according to Torah law. With regard to the <span class="it-text">teruma</span> separated from first tithe, however, the Torah established the fixed amount of one-tenth, and one is required to measure precisely.
The Gemara explains: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span>mishna? It is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Abba Elazar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Gimmel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abba Elazar ben Gimmel says: </span>The verse states: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">your </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> shall be reckoned to you as though it were the corn of the granary and as the fullness of the winepress” (Numbers 18:27). <span class="gemarra-regular">The verse speaks of two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">terumot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. One </span>is <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">gedola</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one is </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the tithe. Just as </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">gedola</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is separated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">by estimatio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> and is not measured exactly, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>it is enough to separate it <span class="gemarra-regular">by thought</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as the word “reckoned” implies that the mere intention to separate a particular portion serves to remove the rest of the produce from its untithed state, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the tith</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> can also <span class="gemarra-regular">be separated by estimation and by thought.</span>
§ Since it was mentioned incidentally, the Gemara discusses <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>matter <span class="gemarra-regular">itself: Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Abbahu said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">first tithe, in a case in which </span>the Levite <span class="gemarra-regular">preceded </span>the priest while the grain was still <span class="gemarra-regular">on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stalks, its name renders it untithed produce, </span>until he separates from it the <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the tithe. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Sinc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the name of </span>the first <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe was called </span><span class="gemarra-regular">upon it, </span>the obligation of the <span class="it-text">teruma</span> of the tithe takes effect as well.
The Gemara cites a similar <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">first tithe, in a case in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which </span>the Levite <span class="gemarra-regular">preceded </span>the priest while the grain was still <span class="gemarra-regular">on the stalks</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> before it was threshed and turned into a pile, the owner separated first tithe before <span class="it-text">teruma</span>. In that case, the separated tithe is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt from</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">gedola</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Although <span class="it-text">teruma</span> <span class="it-text">gedola</span> should have been separated from the produce first, and it should have included some of the produce taken as the first tithe, the Levite is nevertheless exempt from separating this <span class="it-text">teruma</span>. 
This is because <span class="gemarra-regular">it is stated:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">And you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shall set apart from it a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for the Lord</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, even a tenth part of the tithe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Numbers 18:26), which indicates: <span class="gemarra-regular">A tenth part of the tithe, </span>i.e., the <span class="it-text">teruma</span> of the tithe, <span class="gemarra-regular">I, </span>God, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you</span> that you must separate it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>you are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>obligated in both <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">gedola</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the tithe from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said to Abaye: If</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so, </span>if there is a source for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">even if </span>the Levite <span class="gemarra-regular">preceded </span>the priest, i.e., first tithe was separated after the grain had been threshed and the kernels of grain placed <span class="gemarra-regular">in a pile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>then it should <span class="gemarra-regular">also be exempt </span>from <span class="it-text">teruma</span> <span class="it-text">gedola</span>. Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Pappa: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to your </span>claim, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">From all that is given you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, you shall set apart that which is the Lord’s</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Numbers 18:29). This verse indicates that God’s <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, i.e., <span class="it-text">teruma</span> <span class="it-text">gedola</span>, must be taken from all the produce, including the tithe.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what did you see </span>that led you to require the separation of <span class="it-text">teruma</span> <span class="it-text">gedola</span> from first tithe that was taken from processed grain piled in the granary but not from first tithe that was taken from grain on stalks? Abaye answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This, </span>grain that has been threshed and placed into piles, is completely processed and <span class="gemarra-regular">has become grain, and that</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>grain that remains on the stalk, <span class="gemarra-regular">has not </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">become</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> grain. </span>Until the grain is threshed and assembled in a pile, the obligation to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> does not take effect, as it is not considered grain. When such unprocessed grain is designated first tithe, it ceases to be untithed produce and the opportunity to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> from it has been missed. However, once the grain has been processed, and the obligation to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> has taken effect, it is as if the <span class="it-text">teruma</span> is already mixed in, and the obligation to separate it cannot be overridden by the fact that this produce has been designated first tithe. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>(<span class="it-text">Ma</span><span class="it-text">’asrot</span> 4:5): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who peels </span>grains of <span class="gemarra-regular">barley </span>to eat them raw <span class="gemarra-regular">may peel them one </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eat them </span>immediately without tithing them, as this is considered a casual manner of eating. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he peeled and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">placed </span>several of them <span class="gemarra-regular">into his hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to separate tithes. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said: And a similar </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">to Shabbat. </span>Peeling grains of barley one by one is not considered threshing, and it is permitted; if a whole handful of grains are peeled together, this does constitute the prohibited labor of threshing. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? But didn’t Rav’s wife </span><span class="gemarra-regular">peel for him </span>barley on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">by the cupful? And </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥiyya’s wife </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">peel </span>barley <span class="gemarra-regular">for him </span>on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">by the cupful. Rather, if </span>Rabbi Elazar’s comment <span class="gemarra-regular">was stated </span>in this context, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was stated with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to the latter clause </span>of that same mishna (<span class="it-text">Ma’asrot</span> 4:5): With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who husks kernels </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of wheat </span>by hand, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may blow </span>onto the chaff to disperse it <span class="gemarra-regular">a little at a time and eat </span>the kernels without separating tithes. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if he blows </span>on the kernels <span class="gemarra-regular">and puts </span>a large amount of them <span class="gemarra-regular">into his lap, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>to separate tithes from the food. It was with regard to this teaching that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar said: And a similar </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies <span class="gemarra-regular">to Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba bar Memel strongly objects to this: And</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the mishna, one should conclude: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, </span>if one peeled a handful of barley, it is considered prepared <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to tithes, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>it is not considered threshing <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? But is there anything </span>that, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to Shabbat, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>considered the <span class="gemarra-regular">completion of the labor </span>and may be performed; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to tithes, it is</span> considered the <span class="gemarra-regular">completion of the labor? </span>Isn’t the prohibition against work on Shabbat far more stringent than tithes in all its details?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet, son of Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Idi, strongly objects to this </span>claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>is there <span class="gemarra-regular">no</span> example of a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in which tithes are treated more stringently than Shabbat? <span class="gemarra-regular">And is </span>there not the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">their granary for tithes, as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ma’asrot</span> 1:5): <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the equivalent of <span class="gemarra-regular">their granary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the point at which the processing of various vegetable is completed so that they become obligated <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tithes? </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">cucumbers and gourds, </span>they become obligated <span class="gemarra-regular">from when one trims </span>the thin hairs that cover them <span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">misheyefaksu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>for those <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not trim, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from when he assembles them in a pile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we also learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Ma’asrot</span> 1:6), <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to onions, </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">from when one assembles </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them in a pile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Whereas with regard to Shabbat, </span>one who <span class="gemarra-regular">assembles </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">in a pile is exempt, </span>as this is not a prohibited labor on Shabbat.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what have you to say? </span>Why is one exempt if he forms a pile on Shabbat? <span class="gemarra-regular">The Torah </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">planned, </span>constructive<span class="gemarra-regular"> labo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> on Shabbat, the type of work that involves the creation of something new, and the formation of a pile is not considered that kind of labor. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, </span>with regard to peeling barley, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah prohibited</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> creative work. </span>Although collecting the peeled barley in one’s hand is considered the completion of the labor in respect to tithes, it is not prohibited labor on Shabbat.
Apropos husking kernels on Shabbat, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How may one hus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> grain on a Festival? <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said in the name of Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yosef: One </span>finger <span class="gemarra-regular">on another, </span>i.e., one may place the kernels between two fingers and rub. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Avya </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said in the name of Rav Yosef: </span>One may even do so <span class="gemarra-regular">one on two, </span>i.e., between the thumb and two fingers. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Since he alters </span>the manner in which he performs the activity, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may even </span>do so with <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>finger <span class="gemarra-regular">on all </span>the rest. 
The Gemara further asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>may one <span class="gemarra-regular">blow </span>on the grain, to winnow it in a permitted manner on Shabbat? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bar Ahava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: One blows</span>

Daf 14a

<span class="gemarra-regular">from the joints of his fingers and above</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., he does not place the kernels mixed with chaff in his palm but on his fingers, which is an unusual way to hold them. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">They laughed at this </span>explanation <span class="gemarra-regular">in the West, </span>Eretz Yisrael, saying: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since he alters </span>his behavior from the usual method, doing so <span class="gemarra-regular">even with </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">entire hand </span>should be permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">as well. Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Elazar said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">One may blow </span>while holding the grain <span class="gemarra-regular">with one hand </span>but not two, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he may even do so <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">all his strength, </span>as this is not considered similar to a prohibited labor at all.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: Spices may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be pounded </span>on a Festival in a slightly unusual manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">with a wooden pestle, and salt </span>may be pounded only <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>an earthenware <span class="gemarra-regular">flask or with a wooden pot </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ladle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in a manner very different from that of a weekday. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: Spices may be pounded in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">their </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">manner, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">with a stone pestle, and </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">salt, </span>although it must be pounded in an irregular manner, a slight modification such as pounding it <span class="gemarra-regular">with a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wooden pestle </span>is enough to render the act permitted.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">In any event, everyone, </span>both Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, <span class="gemarra-regular">agrees </span>that the pounding of <span class="gemarra-regular">salt requires </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a change; </span>it may not be performed in the regular weekday manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and Rav Ḥisda </span>disputed this issue. <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>Everyone knows that <span class="gemarra-regular">all dishes require salt, </span>and therefore one should prepare salt the day before the Festival. Since he failed to do so, this task may be performed on the Festival only in an unusual manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">But not all </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dishes require spices, </span>and therefore it is possible that on the day prior to the Festival, one was not aware that he would require spices on the Festival. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one said </span>a different reason: <span class="gemarra-regular">All spices lose their flavo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> and cannot be prepared ahead of time, <span class="gemarra-regular">and salt does not lose its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> flavor, </span>which means one could have prepared it the day before. Since he neglected to do so, he may prepare salt on the Festival only in an unusual manner.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the practical <span class="gemarra-regular">difference between</span> these two reasons? The Gemara answers: The practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them is </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one knew </span>beforehand <span class="gemarra-regular">which</span> type of <span class="gemarra-regular">dish he wants to cook </span>on the Festival. Since he knew which spices he would require, he could have prepared them the day before, and which case spices are no different from salt, and one should be required to prepare them in an unusual manner. However, if the reason is that spices lose their flavor, the fact that he knew which dishes he planned to prepare is of no relevance. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>there is a practical difference in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of saffron</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whose flavor does not dissipate over the course of a single day. Consequently, one who knows what dish he will prepare on the Festival could have prepared the saffron the day before.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: All </span>foods <span class="gemarra-regular">that must be pounded </span>before being eaten may be <span class="gemarra-regular">pounded in their </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">manner, and</span> this applies <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>to <span class="gemarra-regular">salt. </span>The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> didn’t you say </span>that everyone agrees that <span class="gemarra-regular">salt requires</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a chang</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in its manner of preparation? The Gemara answers: He <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir said: Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not disagree in </span>the case of foods <span class="gemarra-regular">that are </span>regularly <span class="gemarra-regular">pounded. </span>They both maintain <span class="gemarra-regular">that they may be pounded in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> their </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">manner, and salt </span>can be pounded together <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">They disagreed only </span>about whether it is permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">to pound </span>salt <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself, as Beit Shammai say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Salt may be </span>pounded <span class="gemarra-regular">with a flask and with a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wooden pot ladle for roasting, </span>i.e., in small quantities, as one does not require much salt for roasting meat, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>it may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be pounded in the large quantities required to salt meat <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>a cooked <span class="gemarra-regular">pot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: </span>It may be pounded <span class="gemarra-regular">by anything. </span>The Gemara expresses surprise at this last statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">By anything</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Can this enter your mind? </span>How can Beit Hillel say that one may pound salt in any manner, when it has been established that everyone agrees that this may be performed only in an unusual manner? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, say: </span>Salt may be pounded <span class="gemarra-regular">for anything, </span>whether it is a small quantity for roasting or a large quantity for salting meat. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Aḥa Bardela said to his son: When you pound </span>salt, <span class="gemarra-regular">tilt it </span>a little <span class="gemarra-regular">to the side and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">pound</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>so that it will at least be performed in a slightly different manner on a Festival. The Gemara similarly relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet heard the sound of a pestle </span>pounding salt on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said </span>to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>sound <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>coming <span class="gemarra-regular">from inside my house, </span>as I have instructed the members of my household not to do so. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps they tilted it </span>and pounded in a permitted manner? The Gemara answers: This could not have been the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>Rav Sheshet <span class="gemarra-regular">heard that it was a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> clear sound, </span>unlike the one produced when a pestle is tilted. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps they were </span>pounding <span class="gemarra-regular">spices</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which may be pounded in the regular fashion on a Festival? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The sound </span>produced by pounding <span class="gemarra-regular">spices</span> is distinctive, <span class="gemarra-regular">like a bark, </span>which he would have recognized.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: On a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not prepare groats [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tisanei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a dish comprised of grains of wheat crushed into quarters, which involves great effort, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor may one grind </span>grain <span class="gemarra-regular">with a mortar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and pestle. </span>The Gemara expresses puzzlement: These are <span class="gemarra-regular">tw</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> contradictory rulings. The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> first stated that groats alone may not be prepared, as this involves hard work, implying that other items may be ground. He subsequently states that one may not grind with a mortar and pestle at all. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is what he said: </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> should be amended to read as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not prepare groats? Because one may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not grind with a mortar and pestle.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And let </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> simply <span class="gemarra-regular">say: One may not grind with a mortar and pestle, </span>from which it can be inferred that groats may not be prepared. The Gemara explains that <span class="gemarra-regular">if he teaches </span>only: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not grind with a mortar and pestle, I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">would have said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this applies only to a large </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mortar and pestle, </span>whose use has the appearance of a weekday activity; <span class="gemarra-regular">but with a small mortar and pestle, </span>one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say it seems well, </span>and one may prepare even groats with this mortar and pestle. The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span><span class="gemarra-regular">us </span>that groats may not be prepared in any manner.
The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">isn’t it taught </span>explicitly in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may not grind with a large mortar and pestle, but </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one may grind with a small mortar and pestle? Abaye </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: Also, when </span>the first <span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was taught</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was taught </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a large mortar and pestle, </span>not a small one. In other words, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is stating two <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>, not one, as claimed previously. The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> first rules that one may not prepare groats even with a small mortar and pestle, and he subsequently states that one may not use a large mortar and pestle for any purpose. 

Daf 14b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; </span>the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> do not contradict one another. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>ruling, which permits a small mortar and pestle, <span class="gemarra-regular">is for us,</span> the residents of Babylonia, who do not have servants, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>statement <span class="gemarra-regular">is for them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the inhabitants of Eretz Yisrael, who have many servants. Since servants might treat the prohibition lightly, by using a large mortar and pestle and claiming they had used only a small one, they are prohibited from pounding in all cases.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> happened to come </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">to the house </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He brought to him porridge, </span>made from wheat groats, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he did not eat </span>it, out of concern that the wheat might have been pounded on the same day. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And perhaps they performed </span>the pounding <span class="gemarra-regular">with a small mortar and pestle, </span>in a permitted manner? The Gemara answers: This cannot be the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he observed that it was well ground, </span>which cannot be achieved by means of a small mortar and pestle. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And perhaps they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prepared it the day before, </span>on the Festival eve? The Gemara answers: This cannot be the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he observed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that the husks </span>of the groats <span class="gemarra-regular">were bright, </span>an indication that they had been prepared recently. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>instead that he refrained from eating for another reason, because <span class="gemarra-regular">the house </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Shmuel is different, as </span>he had slaves, and <span class="gemarra-regular">slaves </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">lax </span>with regard to prohibitions. Therefore, Mar Shmuel ought to have prohibited all forms of grinding in his house, to ensure that no one grind anything in an inappropriate manner.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who selects legumes on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival </span>by separating the edible and inedible portions, <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: He may select food and eat </span>it immediately, while leaving the refuse. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: He may select </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in his </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">manner, in his lap, with a tray, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or with a large vessel, but he may not </span>do so <span class="gemarra-regular">with a tablet, nor with a winnow, nor with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a sieve, </span>as these vessels are specially designed for selecting, which gives his action the appearance of a weekday activity. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Gamliel says: One may even wash </span>the legumes in water <span class="gemarra-regular">and skim off </span>the refuse floating on top.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">It </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Gamliel said: In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? </span>Under what circumstances did Beit Hillel permit the removal of the refuse in the weekday manner of selecting? In a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where the </span>quantity of the <span class="gemarra-regular">food is greater than the </span>quantity of the <span class="gemarra-regular">refuse. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">However, if </span>the quantity of <span class="gemarra-regular">refuse is greater than the </span>quantity of <span class="gemarra-regular">food</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one must remove </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the food and leave the refuse. </span>
The Gemara asks: If the quantity of <span class="gemarra-regular">refuse is greater than the </span>quantity of <span class="gemarra-regular">food, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is there an opinion that permits </span>it? Since the smaller amount of food is nullified by the refuse, the entire mixture is considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span> and may not be moved. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the removal of the refuse <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">greater in </span>terms of <span class="gemarra-regular">effort, and </span>yet it is <span class="gemarra-regular">smaller </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in size. </span>In other words, there is actually more food than refuse, but since greater effort is required to remove the refuse, it is preferable to remove the food. 
The mishna taught that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Gamliel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: One may even wash </span>the legumes in water <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> skim off </span>the refuse floating on top. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught</span> (<span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, <span class="it-text">Beitza</span> 1): <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: This was the custom of the house of Rabban Gamliel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, that they would bring a bucket full with lentils and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pour water in it, and then </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">food </span>would sink <span class="gemarra-regular">down and the refuse </span>would float <span class="gemarra-regular">up, </span>which spared them from having to separate the lentils from the refuse manually.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t the opposite taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, that the food rose to the top while the refuse sunk below? The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which says the refuse sinks down, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>refuse in the form of <span class="gemarra-regular">earth, </span>which sinks below the lentils; <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, where it is stated that the refuse rises, speaks <span class="gemarra-regular">of straw, </span>which floats on water.
