<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One may send</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> only </span><span class="gemarra-regular">portion</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of prepared food <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival, </span>but not any other gifts. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: One may </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">send </span>gifts of <span class="gemarra-regular">domesticated animals, undomesticated animals, and fowl, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whether alive or slaughtered. </span>Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may send wines, oils, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>vessels of <span class="gemarra-regular">flour, and </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">legumes, but not grain, </span>which is unfit for use, as one may not grind it on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shimon permits </span>sending gifts even in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">grain</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it can be made into porridge without being ground.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yeḥiel teaches: And </span>one may send these items <span class="gemarra-regular">provided that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he does not do it by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">convo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> of people, as they would look as though they were transporting merchandise to the marketplace. It is <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A convoy </span>consists of <span class="gemarra-regular">no less than three </span><span class="gemarra-regular">people</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> if there are fewer than three, it is not called a convoy and is permitted. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi raised </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a dilemma: </span>In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">three people and three </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">types </span>of food, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is this considered a convoy, or does the fact that there are three different types of food mean that each of them is considered a separate item? The Gemara answers: The dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved, as no answer was found. 
The mishna taught that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon permits</span> the sending <span class="gemarra-regular">of grain. It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon permits </span>the sending <span class="gemarra-regular">of grain, for example</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Wheat to prepare from it </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ludiyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a type of cookie; <span class="gemarra-regular">barley to place before his animal; </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">lentils to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prepare from them </span><span class="gemarra-italic">resisin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>a dish made from crushed lentils.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One may send </span><span class="gemarra-regular">clothes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">whether </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">sewn or whether they are unsewn, and even if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they contain diverse </span><span class="gemarra-regular">kinds</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a prohibited mixture of wool and linen [<span class="it-text">sha’atnez</span>]. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>one may do so only if <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>serve <span class="gemarra-regular">the purposes of the Festival. However, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one may not </span>send <span class="gemarra-regular">a spiked sandal, </span>which has nails fixed to it, as the Sages decreed that one may not wear a sandal of this kind on a Shabbat or Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor an unsewn shoe, </span>which is not suitable for a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: One may not even </span>send <span class="gemarra-regular">a white shoe, </span>which people do not usually wear, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">requires an artisan </span>to paint it black. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is the </span>general <span class="gemarra-regular">principle: </span>Anything <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may use on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival, one may send it.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks a question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>it is permitted to send <span class="gemarra-regular">sewn </span>clothes, as they are <span class="gemarra-regular">suitable for wearing. </span>With regard to clothes <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are not sewn as well, they are </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">suitable </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for covering </span>oneself. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in the case of clothes than contain <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds, for what </span>use <span class="gemarra-regular">are they suited? </span>Since these clothes may not be used on the Festival, why is it permitted to send them?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that clothes of diverse kinds <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">suited for one to place underneath himself, but isn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Neither shall there come </span><span class="gemarra-regular">upon you </span>a garment of diverse kinds” (Leviticus 19:19)? This verse teaches that one may not wear this garment, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>by Torah law <span class="gemarra-regular">you may spread it beneath you. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">However, the Sages said: It is prohibited to do so, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lest a thread [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nima</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wind itself around his flesh. </span>This shows that the Sages prohibited even spreading underneath oneself a cloth that contains a mixture of wool and linen. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say that </span>the allowance of cloth of diverse kinds is referring to a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">there is something separating between </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them, </span>i.e., one may place a garment of diverse kinds beneath another object, <span class="gemarra-regular">but didn’t Rabbi Shimon ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Pazi say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yosei ben Shaul said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said, in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the name of the sacred congregation in Jerusalem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Even </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">ten mattresses </span>placed <span class="gemarra-regular">one on top </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the other and </span>a cloth of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds underneath </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them, it is prohibited to sleep on them, as it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is stated:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Neither shall there come upon you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Leviticus 19:19).
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a curtain [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vilon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of diverse kinds, which may be hung up, as it is not an item of clothing. The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Ulla say: For what </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">did </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a curtain is ritually impure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., that it can contract the impurity of a vessel despite the fact that it is not directly used by people? <span class="gemarra-regular">Because the attendant warms himself with it. </span>Since attendants use curtains as makeshift blankets when they are cold, a curtain may not be made from a mixture of wool and linen. 

Daf 15a

<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to hard</span> clothes, upon which it is permitted to sit even if they are a mixture of wool and linen. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rav Huna, son</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rav Yehoshua, said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this hard felt</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">namta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> material produced in the town <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neresh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is permitted </span>to sit or recline on it, and one need not be concerned about the fact that it is a mixture of wool and linen. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">felt socks [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ardalayin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there is no </span>prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds regarding them, </span>as they are hard. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: These bundles for coins, </span>comprised of hard fabric or felt, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to them. </span>However, with regard to pouches <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>holding <span class="gemarra-regular">seeds, there is </span>a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to them, </span>as they are larger and softer than both felt socks and hard bundles for coins. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Both this and that have no </span>prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">diverse kinds</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to them because </span>using <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>items <span class="gemarra-regular">is not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">manner of keeping warm</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Even if these objects are placed close to one’s skin, this is not the usual way of wearing clothes and warming oneself, and therefore they are permitted.
§ The mishna taught: <span class="gemarra-regular">However, one may not </span>send <span class="gemarra-regular">a spiked</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sanda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span>on a Festival. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">A spiked </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sandal, what is the reason </span>that it may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be worn? The Gemara answers: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">due to an incident </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that occurred</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> A great tragedy resulted when people wore spiked sandals on Shabbat, which led the Sages to decree that these sandals may not be worn on a Shabbat or Festival.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a spiked sandal, it is prohibited to wear </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">but it is permitted to move it. </span>He clarifies: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is prohibited to wear </span>a spiked sandal, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">incident that occurred. And it is permitted</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to move it, from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: One may not send. For if it enters your </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mind </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">to move </span>a spiked sandal, <span class="gemarra-regular">now </span>consider: If <span class="gemarra-regular">it were prohibited to move it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>is the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">required </span>to state that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may send</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it? </span>Rather, it must certainly be permitted to move a spiked sandal inside the house, despite the fact that one may not wear it.
The mishna further teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Nor </span>may one send <span class="gemarra-regular">an unsewn shoe </span>on a Festival. The Gemara asks: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious, </span>as these shoes are unfit for wearing. The Gemara answers: This statement <span class="gemarra-regular">was necessary </span>only to teach <span class="gemarra-regular">that although </span>the shoe <span class="gemarra-regular">is attached with pins </span>and can be worn, it may not be sent on a Festival. Since it not properly sewn, it is not usually worn. 
The mishna teaches that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: One may not even </span>send <span class="gemarra-regular">a white shoe. It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda permits </span>the sending <span class="gemarra-regular">of a black </span>shoe <span class="gemarra-regular">but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prohibits </span>the sending <span class="gemarra-regular">of a white one because </span>a white one <span class="gemarra-regular">requires a lump of chal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> to color it properly. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei prohibits </span>the sending <span class="gemarra-regular">of a black </span>shoe <span class="gemarra-regular">because one needs to polish it. </span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And they do not disagree </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, as this <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage </span>ruled <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the custom <span class="gemarra-regular">of his locale, and </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage </span>ruled differently, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the custom of <span class="gemarra-regular">his locale. In </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the place of </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yehuda, the leather was made so that the side of the hide facing the <span class="gemarra-regular">flesh </span>is on the <span class="gemarra-regular">underneath, </span>facing the inside of the shoe, and therefore it does not require polishing; whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the place of </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Yosei, the leather was made so that side of the hide facing the <span class="gemarra-regular">flesh </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">above, </span>facing the outside of the shoe. That side is often cracked and uneven and requires smoothing and polishing. 
§ The mishna taught that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is the </span>general <span class="gemarra-regular">principle: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>article <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">use on a Festival, </span>one may send it. The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Sheshet permitted the Sages to send phylacteries on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival. Abaye said to him: But didn’t we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">learn </span>in the mishna: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>article <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one may use on a Festival, one may send it? </span>Phylacteries are not worn on Festivals. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is what </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any</span> article <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may use on a weekday</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may send it on a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">phylacteries, since </span>this topic <span class="gemarra-regular">has come before us </span>in the previous discussion, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us say </span>a novel <span class="gemarra-regular">matter about it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>If someone <span class="gemarra-regular">was coming on the road </span>on the eve of a Shabbat or Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he had <span class="gemarra-regular">phylacteries </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on his head, </span>as the practice then was to don phylacteries the entire day, but not at night, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sun set </span>before <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>arrived at his destination, signaling the beginning of the Shabbat or Festival, when phylacteries may not be worn or even moved, <span class="gemarra-regular">he places his hand </span><span class="gemarra-regular">upon the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> to cover them so that people will not see them <span class="gemarra-regular">until he reaches his house, </span>at which point he removes them. If <span class="gemarra-regular">he was sitting in the study</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with phylacteries on his head, and the day </span>of Shabbat or the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">was sanctified</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>was unprepared, <span class="gemarra-regular">he places his hand upon them until </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he reaches his house.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna, son of Rav Ika, raised </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an objection </span>from the following teaching: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one was coming </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on the road with phylacteries on his head, and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">day was sanctified </span>before <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>arrived at his destination, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">places his hand upon them until he reaches the house </span><span class="gemarra-regular">nearest the wall, </span>where he removes them and leaves them there. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he was sitting in the study hall, </span>outside the city, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the day was sanctified, for </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>was unprepared, <span class="gemarra-regular">he places his hand upon them until he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reaches a house that is near the study hall, </span>where there are people who can guard the phylacteries. This shows that one may not bring phylacteries all the way to his house, but only to the nearest place within the city boundary.
The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which teaches that one places the phylacteries in the house nearest the wall, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the phylacteries can be <span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarded </span>there, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that he may bring them all the way to his house, deals with a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where they are not safeguarded </span>in the nearest house.
The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the phylacteries are <span class="gemarra-regular">not safeguarded, why </span>discuss <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>the case of phylacteries that were <span class="gemarra-regular">on his head? Even </span>if one was not donning them but found them <span class="gemarra-regular">placed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on the ground, </span>he should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be required to don them and bring them to the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">for didn’t </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Eiruvin</span> 95a): <span class="gemarra-regular">One who finds </span><span class="gemarra-regular">phylacterie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> lying in a field outside of the city on Shabbat should don them and <span class="gemarra-regular">bring them into </span>the city <span class="gemarra-regular">one pair at a time? </span>
The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, where it was taught that one need not don the phylacteries if they were not already on his head, is referring to a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">where they are safeguarded from thieves and </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">from dogs. That </span>mishna, which stated that even if one found them on the ground, he must put them on and bring them into the city, is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they are safeguarded from dogs but are not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">safeguarded from thieves.</span>
The Gemara clarifies the novel element of the mishna’s ruling. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say: Since most thieves [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">listim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are Jews, who would not treat </span>phylacteries <span class="gemarra-regular">with contempt,</span> one should not be allowed to carry them because there is no danger that they will be desecrated if they are left in their place, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> takes the minority of cases into account. It is therefore appropriate to don the phylacteries and bring them into the city. 


Daf 15b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival that occurs </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat eve, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one may not cook on the Festival with the initial </span>intent to cook <span class="gemarra-regular">for Shabbat. However, he may cook </span>on that day <span class="gemarra-regular">for the Festival </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if he left </span><span class="gemarra-regular">over </span>any food, <span class="gemarra-regular">he left </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">over for Shabbat. </span>The early Sages also instituted an ordinance: The joining of cooked foods [<span class="it-text">eiruv</span> <span class="it-text">tavshilin</span>], which the mishna explains. <span class="gemarra-regular">One may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prepare a cooked dish </span>designated for Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eve and rely on it </span>to cook on the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">for Shabbat.</span>
The <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> disagreed with regard to the details of this ordinance: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: </span>For the purpose of the joining of cooked foods one must prepare <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cooked dishes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Beit Hillel say: One dish </span>is sufficient. <span class="gemarra-regular">And they </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">agree with regard to a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fish and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">egg that is </span>fried <span class="gemarra-regular">on i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> these are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">two dishes </span>for this purpose. 
If <span class="gemarra-regular">one ate </span>the food prepared before the Festival as an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> and none of it remained for Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">or if it was lost</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he may not </span>rely <span class="gemarra-regular">on it </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">cook with the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> initial </span>intent to cook for Shabbat. <span class="gemarra-regular">If he left any</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> part of </span>the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span>, he may <span class="gemarra-regular">rely on it </span>to cook <span class="gemarra-regular">for Shabbat. </span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where are these matters </span>derived? What is the source of the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the joining of cooked foods and of the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that one who failed to prepare such an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> may not cook on a Festival for Shabbat? <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said </span>that the source is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the verse states: “Remember the Shabbat day, to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">keep it holy” </span>(Exodus 20:8); from which he infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Remember</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>and safeguard it <span class="gemarra-regular">from another </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">that comes to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> make it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">forgotten</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> When a Festival occurs on Friday, preoccupation with the Festival and the preparation and enjoyment of its meals could lead one to overlook Shabbat. Therefore, the Sages instituted an ordinance to ensure that Shabbat will be remembered even then.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the reason </span>that the Sages instituted this ordinance in particular to ensure that Shabbat would not be overlooked? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>The Sages did so in deference to Shabbat, and they instituted an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">so that one will select a choice</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> portion for Shabbat and a choice portion for the Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>If one fails to prepare a dish specifically for Shabbat before the Festival, it could lead to failure to show the appropriate deference to Shabbat. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi stated </span>a different reason: The Sages did so in deference to the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">so that </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">will say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: One may not bake on a Festival for Shabbat </span>unless he began to bake the day before; <span class="gemarra-regular">all the more</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so, </span>one may not bake <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival for a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> weekday</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may prepare</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a cooked dish on a Festival eve and rely on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>to cook <span class="gemarra-regular">for Shabbat. Granted, according to Rav Ashi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who said </span>that the reason for an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">so</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">will say: One may not bake on a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival for Shabbat; that is </span>why <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival eve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, yes, </span>one may prepare the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span>, but <span class="gemarra-regular">on the Festival</span> itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>one may not do so, as it is a reminder that in principle one may not cook on a Festival for Shabbat. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, according to Rava, </span>who stated that the reason for the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> is to ensure that one selects choice portions for both the Festival and Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>does the mishna discuss <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>preparation <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> eve? Even </span>were one to prepare a dish for Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">on the Festival as well, </span>it would guarantee that he accord the appropriate deference to Shabbat. 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, it is indeed so; </span>that objective could have been achieved even on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>the Sages issued <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree </span>that the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> must be prepared on the Festival eve <span class="gemarra-regular">lest one be negligent </span>and fail to prepare one entirely.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cites </span>the proof for <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> <span class="it-text">tavshilin</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from here, </span>the following verse: “Tomorrow is a day of rest, a holy Shabbat to the Lord. <span class="gemarra-regular">Bake that which you will bak</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and cook that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">which you will cook, </span>and all that remains put aside to be kept for you until the morning” (Exodus 16:23). <span class="gemarra-regular">From here Rabbi Eliezer said: One may bake </span>on a Festival for Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>by relying <span class="gemarra-regular">on that which was </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">baked </span>for Shabbat the day before, and adding to it; <span class="gemarra-regular">and one may cook only </span>by relying <span class="gemarra-regular">on that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">which was </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">cooked. From this </span>verse <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages established </span>an allusion <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">joining of cooked foods from the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">There was an incident involving Rabbi Eliezer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who was sitting and lecturing about the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakhot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival throughout the entire </span>Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">day. </span>When <span class="gemarra-regular">the first group</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> left </span>in the middle of his lecture, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said: These</span> must be <span class="gemarra-regular">owners of extremely large jugs [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">pittasin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who apparently have huge containers of wine awaiting them as well as a comparable amount of food, and they have left the house of study out of a craving for their food. After a while <span class="gemarra-regular">a second group </span>departed. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: These are owners of barrels</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which are smaller than <span class="it-text">pittasin</span>. Later <span class="gemarra-regular">a third group </span>took its leave, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: These are owners of jugs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> even smaller than barrels.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A fourth group</span> left, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he said: These are owners of jars [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">laginin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which are smaller than jugs. Upon the departure of <span class="gemarra-regular">a fifth group, he said: These are owners of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cups</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which are smaller still. When <span class="gemarra-regular">a sixth group </span><span class="gemarra-regular">began to leave, he </span>became upset that the house of study was being left almost completely empty and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: These </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are owners of a curse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> i.e., they obviously do not have anything at home, so why are they leaving?
<span class="gemarra-regular">He cast his eyes upon the students </span>remaining in the house of study. Immediately, <span class="gemarra-regular">their faces began to chang</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> color out of shame, as they feared he was referring to them and that perhaps they should have departed along with the others instead of staying. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: My</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sons, I did not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">about you but about</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> those who left, because they abandon </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">eternal life </span>of Torah <span class="gemarra-regular">and engage in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">temporary life </span>of eating. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">At the time of </span>the remaining students’ <span class="gemarra-regular">departure </span>at the conclusion of Rabbi Eliezer’s lecture, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them </span>the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Go your way, eat the fat </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and drink the sweet, and send portions to him for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whom nothing is prepared, for this day is holy to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">our Lord; and do not be grieved, for the joy </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the Lord is your strength” </span>(Nehemiah 8:10).
The Gemara clarifies this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>above: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because they abandon eternal life and engage in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> temporary life. </span>The Gemara wonders at this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the joy of the Festival </span>itself <span class="gemarra-regular">a mitzva </span>and therefore part of eternal life? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">he said: </span>Physical <span class="gemarra-regular">joy on a Festival is </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">optional.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: A person has no </span>way of fulfilling the mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival </span>correctly <span class="gemarra-regular">apart from either eating</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and drinking, </span>thereby fulfilling the mitzva of joy in a completely physical manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">or sitting and studying </span>Torah, thereby emphasizing only the spiritual; and those who did not engage in Torah study to the fullest extent acted inappropriately. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span>There is no need for such a dichotomy; rather, simply <span class="gemarra-regular">divide it: Half to God, </span>Torah study, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">half to yourselves</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> engaging in eating, drinking, and other pleasurable activities.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And both of them derived </span>their opinions <span class="gemarra-regular">from one verse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the two of them addressed the same apparent contradiction between two verses, resolving it in different ways. <span class="gemarra-regular">One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> verse states: </span>“It shall be <span class="gemarra-regular">a solemn assembly for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Lord, your God” </span>(Deuteronomy 16:8), indicating a Festival dedicated to the service of God, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one verse states: “It</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shall be a solemn assembly for you” </span>(Numbers 29:35), indicating a celebratory assembly for the Jewish people. <span class="gemarra-regular">How is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>to be reconciled? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer holds </span>that the two verses should be understood as offering a choice: The day is to be <span class="gemarra-regular">either entirely for God, </span>in accordance with the one verse, <span class="gemarra-regular">or entirely for you, </span>as per the other verse; <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Yehoshua holds </span>that it is possible to fulfill both verses: <span class="gemarra-regular">Split </span>the day into two, <span class="gemarra-regular">half of it for God and half of it for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you. </span>
§ Since the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mentions the verse from Nehemiah, the Gemara poses the following question: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of: “Send portions <span class="gemarra-regular">to him for whom nothing is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prepared” </span>(Nehemiah 8:10)?<span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Ḥisda said: </span>Send to one who does not have food of his own prepared for Shabbat that follows the Festival because <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not prepare a joining of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cooked foods </span>and must therefore rely on others. <span class="gemarra-regular">Some say</span> that he said the following: It is necessary to provide food for <span class="gemarra-regular">one who did not have </span>an opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prepare a joining of cooked foods </span>on the eve of the Festival; <span class="gemarra-regular">but one who had </span>an opportunity <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prepare a joining of cooked foods and did not prepare </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">is negligent, </span>and there is no obligation to care for him.
The Gemara poses another question with regard to the same verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">“F</span><span class="gemarra-regular">or the joy of the Lord is your</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> strength”? Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Eliezer, son of Rabbi Shimon: The Holy One, Blessed be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> He, said to the Jewish people: My children, borrow on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> My </span>account, <span class="gemarra-regular">and sanctify the sanctity of the day </span>of Shabbat and the Festivals with wine, <span class="gemarra-regular">and trust in Me</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and I will repa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> this debt.
Apropos the statement attributed to Rabbi Yoḥanan in the name of Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Shimon, the Gemara cites another statement that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥ</span><span class="gemarra-regular">anan said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer, son of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon: One who wants his properties to be preserved </span>and protected from ruin should <span class="gemarra-regular">plant an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ede</span><span class="gemarra-italic">r</span> tree <span class="gemarra-regular">among </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is stated: “The Lord on high </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is mighty [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">adir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Psalms 93:4). Due to the similarity of the words <span class="it-text">eder</span> and <span class="it-text">adir</span>, this is understood to mean that the <span class="it-text">eder</span> tree bestows permanence.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eder</span> tree will preserve one’s property, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>implied by <span class="gemarra-regular">its name, as people say: What is </span>alluded to in the name of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eder</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Its name hints <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">endures for many generations [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">darei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. This is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A field that contains an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eder</span> tree <span class="gemarra-regular">will be neither stolen nor forcibly removed </span>from one’s possession, as the <span class="it-text">eder</span> serves as a clear indication of its owner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and its fruit is preserved, </span>as the unique odor of the <span class="it-text">eder</span> sap wards off insects. 
§ The Gemara returns to the previous issue: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Taḥlifa, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">brother </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravnai Ḥoza’a, taught: </span>

Daf 16a

<span class="gemarra-regular">A person’s entire livelihood is allocated to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him </span>during the period <span class="gemarra-regular">from Rosh HaShana to Yom Kippur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>During that time, as each individual is judged, it is decreed exactly how much money he will earn for all his expenditures of the coming year, <span class="gemarra-regular">except for expenditures for</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">Shabbatot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and expenditures for Festivals, and expenditures for </span>the school fees of <span class="gemarra-regular">his sons’ </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Torah</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> study. </span>In these areas, no exact amount is determined at the beginning of the year; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">if he reduced </span>the amount he spends for these purposes, <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>income <span class="gemarra-regular">is reduced </span>and he earns that much less money in that year, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if he increased</span> his expenditures in these areas, <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>income <span class="gemarra-regular">is increased </span>to ensure that he can cover the expense. Therefore, one may borrow for these purposes, since he is guaranteed to have enough income to cover whatever he spends for them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu said: What is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the verse </span>from which this dictum is derived? The source is: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Blow the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shofar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at the New Moon, at the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> concealed </span>time <span class="gemarra-regular">for our Festival day” </span>(Psalms 81:4). <span class="gemarra-regular">On </span><span class="gemarra-regular">which Festival is the new moon concealed? </span>You <span class="gemarra-regular">must say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is Rosh HaShana, </span>which occurs on the first of the month, when the moon is not yet visible, while the moon is visible during the other Festivals, which occur in the middle of the month. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> written </span>in the next verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For it is a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">statute [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥok</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] for Israel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a judgment of the God</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Jacob” </span>(Psalms 81:5).
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>may it <span class="gemarra-regular">be inferred that this </span>word <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">statute [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥok</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” is a term </span>relating <span class="gemarra-regular">to food? As it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is written: “And they ate their allotment [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥukkam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Pharaoh gave them” </span>(Genesis 47:22). <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra said: </span>One can learn that <span class="it-text">ḥok</span> is referring to food <span class="gemarra-regular">from here: “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">Feed me with my allotted [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥukki</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] bread” </span>(Proverbs 30:8).
<span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">They said about</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shammai the Elde</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">all his days he would </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eat in honor of Shabbat. </span>How so? If <span class="gemarra-regular">he found</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a choice animal, he </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">say: This is for Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">found another one choicer than it, he</span> would <span class="gemarra-regular">set aside the second </span>for Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">and eat the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> first. </span>He would eat the first to leave the better-quality animal for Shabbat, which continually rendered his eating an act of honoring Shabbat. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">However, Hillel the Elder had a different trait, that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> all his actions, </span>including those on a weekday, <span class="gemarra-regular">were for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the sake of Heaven, as it is stated: “Blessed be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Lord, day by day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> He bears our burden, our God who is our salvation; Selah” (Psalms 68:20), meaning that God gives a blessing for each and every day. <span class="gemarra-regular">That is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in more general terms: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: From the first </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the week, </span>Sunday, start preparing already <span class="gemarra-regular">for your Shabbat. And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Beit Hillel say: “Blessed be the Lord, day by day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.”</span>
§ Apropos the statements about honoring Shabbat, the Gemara cites another statement on the same topic. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: One who gives </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a gift to his friend need not inform him </span>that he has given it to him, and he need not concern himself that the recipient might not realize who gave it to him. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is stated: “And Moses did </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not know that the skin of his face was radiant” </span>(Exodus 34:29); Moses received this gift unawares. 
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to this. Isn’t it written: “Nevertheless, you must keep My <span class="it-text">Shabbatot</span>, for this is a sign between Me and you throughout your generations, <span class="gemarra-regular">that you may know that I am the Lord Who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sanctifies you” </span>(Exodus 31:13), which the Sages expounded as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Moses, I have a good gif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in My treasury, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its name is Shabbat, and I wish to give it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the Jewish people. Go and inform them </span>of this intention of Mine. <span class="gemarra-regular">And from here Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: One who gives </span>a gift of <span class="gemarra-regular">a piece of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bread to a child must inform his mother </span>of his actions, so that the child’s parents will be aware of the giver’s fond feelings for them, thereby enhancing friendly relations and companionship among Jews. This appears to be in direct contradiction to Rabbi Ḥama’s statement. 
The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, where one need not inform the recipient, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">referring to a gift that is likely to be revealed, </span>such as Moses’ shining face, which everyone would point out to him; <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, where one must inform the recipient, <span class="gemarra-regular">is referring to a gift that is not likely </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to be revealed </span>in the natural course of events. The Gemara challenges: Isn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat also a gift that is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">likely to be revealed, </span>as the Jews would eventually be instructed with regard to the time and nature of Shabbat? The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">its reward is not likely to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be revealed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, God told Moses to inform the Jews of the gift of Shabbat and its reward.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Master said </span>earlier that <span class="gemarra-regular">from here Rabban Shimon </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ben Gamliel said: One who gives a piece of bread </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to a child must inform his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What does he do to him; </span>how does he inform the child’s mother? <span class="gemarra-regular">He rubs oil on him and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">paints his eyes blue, </span>so that when the child arrives home his mother will ask him who did this to him and he will reply that it was a person who also gave him a piece of bread. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And nowadays, when we are concerned about witchcraft, </span>i.e., that painting the child’s eyes might have been performed as an act of sorcery, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>should one do? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: He rubs on </span>the child a little <span class="gemarra-regular">of that same type </span>of food that he put on the bread, such as butter or cheese, and this will cause the child’s mother to notice that he received a present.
The Gemara cites a further statement with regard to the gift of Shabbat to the Jewish people. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon ben Yoḥai: All </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzvot that the Holy </span><span class="gemarra-regular">One, Blessed be He, gave to the Jewish people, He </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gave to them in public [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">parhesya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> except for Shabbat, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">which he gave to them in private. As it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stated: “It is a sign between Me and the children </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Israel forever” </span>(Exodus 31:17), meaning that in a sense, it is a secret between God and the Jewish people. 
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that it was given in secret so that not everyone knew about it, <span class="gemarra-regular">the gentiles should not be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">punished for </span>not wanting to accept <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> they are liable to receive punishment for refusing to accept the other mitzvot of the Torah. The Gemara answers: The Holy One, Blessed be He, <span class="gemarra-regular">did inform them </span>of the concept of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, </span>but He <span class="gemarra-regular">did not inform them </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the reward </span>for the fulfillment of the mitzva. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>instead that <span class="gemarra-regular">He also informed </span>the gentiles of <span class="gemarra-regular">its </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reward, </span>but about the idea of the <span class="gemarra-regular">additional sou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> given to each person on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">He did not inform them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: The Holy One, Blessed be He, gives a person</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an additional soul on Shabbat eve, and at the conclusion</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Shabbat removes it from him, as it is stated</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: “He ceased from work and was refreshed [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vayinafash</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Exodus 31:17). Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish expounds the verse as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since he ceased from work, </span>and now Shabbat has concluded and his additional soul is removed from him, <span class="gemarra-regular">woe [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>for the additional <span class="gemarra-regular">soul [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nefesh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">lost.</span>
It was taught in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may prepare a cooked dish on a Festival eve </span>and rely on it for Shabbat for the joining of cooked foods. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: They taught </span>that the joining of cooked foods allows one to cook on a Festival for Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>when it is made from <span class="gemarra-regular">a cooked dish; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">however, </span>if it is composed of <span class="gemarra-regular">bread </span>alone, <span class="gemarra-regular">no, </span>this is not sufficient. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">bread that </span>makes it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>fit for this purpose? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we require something that accompanies </span>bread, <span class="gemarra-regular">and bread does not accompany </span>itself, the following difficulty arises: <span class="gemarra-regular">Porridge also does not accompany </span>bread, as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Zeir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: Those foolish Babylonians eat bread with bread, </span>referring to their custom of eating bread with porridge. This shows that porridge is no better accompaniment to bread than bread itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Neḥumi bar Zekharya said in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the name of Abaye: One may establish an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> porridge. Rather, </span>one must say as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">We require something</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is not routine, </span>so that it will be clear that one is setting it aside for the purpose of an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and bread is routine, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">porridge is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not routine. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>a different version of this discussion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: They taught </span>that a joining of cooked foods allows one to cook on a Festival for Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>when it is made from <span class="gemarra-regular">a cooked dish; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">however, </span>if it is composed of <span class="gemarra-regular">bread, no, </span>that is not sufficient. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">If we say that we require something that is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not routine, and bread is routine, </span>the following difficulty arises: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t porridge not </span>particularly <span class="gemarra-regular">routine? And </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Neḥumi bar Zekharya said in the name of Abaye: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">One may not establish an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with porridge. Rather, </span>one should say as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">We require something that accompanies </span>bread, <span class="gemarra-regular">and bread does not accompany </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and porridge, too, does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not accompany </span>bread, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Zeira said: Those foolish Babylonians</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> eat bread with bread, </span>from which it is clear that like bread, porridge does not accompany bread and consequently cannot constitute an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">lentils that </span>remain <span class="gemarra-regular">at the bottom </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of a po</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> on the eve of a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may rely on them for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">joining of cooked foods</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Although they were not prepared with this purpose in mind, they are nevertheless considered a cooked dish. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> applies only </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">there is an olive-bulk </span>of lentils in total. Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Yehuda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">fat </span>of meat and the like <span class="gemarra-regular">that is on a knife, one may scrape it </span>off the knife <span class="gemarra-regular">and rely on it for the joining of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cooked foods; and this applies only </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">there is an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> olive-bulk </span>of fat in total.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Asi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: Small salted fis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> that a gentile then cooked <span class="gemarra-regular">are not considered the cooked food </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of gentile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> because cooking does not prepare them to be food any more than they already were, as they can be eaten in their salted state. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: And</span> even <span class="gemarra-regular">if a gentile roasted them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a Jew may <span class="gemarra-regular">rely on them for the joining of cooked foods, </span>as they are not considered the cooked food of a gentile and are indeed already edible. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">gentile </span><span class="gemarra-regular">made them </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">fish fried with oil and flour [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kasa</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">deharsena</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is prohibited </span>to eat them. In this case they are considered the cooked food of a gentile, since his actions have made them into noteworthy food.
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is obvious </span>that this is the case; it need not be taught. The Gemara answers: The justification for teaching it is <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say </span>that

Daf 16b

the <span class="gemarra-regular">fish fat, </span>which one is permitted to eat even if cooked by gentiles, is the <span class="gemarra-regular">essential element. </span>Therefore, he <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the flour </span>is the <span class="gemarra-regular">essential </span><span class="gemarra-regular">element, </span>and the gentile has created a new and significant dish, which is consequently prohibited.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">A joining of cooked foods requires an olive-bulk </span>of food. <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: Is it enough to have <span class="gemarra-regular">one olive-bulk for all of </span>the household members who are relying on this <span class="it-text">eiruv</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">or perhaps</span> must there be a separate <span class="gemarra-regular">olive-bulk for each and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> every one </span>in the household? <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Abba said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: A joining of cooked</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> foods requires an olive-bulk, whether </span>it is cooked <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a single </span>person <span class="gemarra-regular">or for one hundred </span>people.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ate </span>the joining of cooked foods that he prepared, <span class="gemarra-regular">or</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if it was lost, he may not </span>rely <span class="gemarra-regular">on it</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">cook with the initial </span>intent to cook for Shabbat; but if <span class="gemarra-regular">he left any part of </span>the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span>, he may <span class="gemarra-regular">rely on it </span>to cook <span class="gemarra-regular">for Shabbat. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any part of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it? Doesn’t it </span>mean <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is valid <span class="gemarra-regular">although </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there is not an olive-bulk? </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the phrase: Any part of it, means <span class="gemarra-regular">that there is </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">an olive-bulk </span>left.
The Gemara attempts to bring another proof. <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">cooked dish </span>that is required for a joining of cooked foods may <span class="gemarra-regular">be roasted, or even pickled, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">well-boiled, or boiled </span>in the regular manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>may even be <span class="gemarra-regular">Spanish soft </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sea fish [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">koleyas</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ha’ispenin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> upon which one poured </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hot </span>water <span class="gemarra-regular">on the eve of the Festival, </span>rendering it cooked. With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">its beginning and end, </span>meaning its required size <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span> and after it has been reduced by being partially lost or partially eaten, the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>required <span class="gemarra-regular">measure. What, is it not </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">has no </span>required <span class="gemarra-regular">measure at all, </span>not even a minimum one? The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it means <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does not have a maximum measure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but it does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">have a minimum measure, </span>namely an olive-bulk.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: A joining </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of cooked foods </span><span class="gemarra-regular">requires</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> knowledge</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning that one must be aware of the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for it to be effective. The Gemara comments: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we require </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge of the one who prepares </span>the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span>; the question is: Do <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">require </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">knowledge of the one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for whom </span>the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is prepared</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or do we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not require </span>it?
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear</span> a proof from the following testimonies: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel’s fathe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> would <span class="gemarra-regular">prepare an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">entire </span>city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Neharde’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">prepare </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">entire </span>city of <span class="gemarra-regular">Tiberias</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">announce: </span>Anyone <span class="gemarra-regular">who did </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not prepare a joining of cooked foods </span>for himself should <span class="gemarra-regular">come and rely on mine. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And up </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to how much </span>may one rely on it, i.e., how far may one be from such an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> and still rely upon it? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Neḥumi bar Zekharya said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Abaye: </span>One may be <span class="gemarra-regular">as far </span>away <span class="gemarra-regular">as the Shabbat limit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
The Gemara relates: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the blind person who would </span><span class="gemarra-regular">present </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mishnayot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before Mar Shmuel, </span>the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">observed that he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was sad. </span>Mar Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Why are you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sad? He said to him: </span>Because <span class="gemarra-regular">I did not prepare </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a joining of cooked foods </span>before the Festival. Mar Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Then <span class="gemarra-regular">rely on mine. In the </span>following <span class="gemarra-regular">year, he </span>once again <span class="gemarra-regular">observed that he was sad. He </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Why are you sad? He said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: </span>Because <span class="gemarra-regular">I did not prepare a joining of cooked </span><span class="gemarra-regular">foods. </span>Mar Shmuel <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">you are </span>consistently <span class="gemarra-regular">negligen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> in this regard. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">for the entire world</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., anyone else but you, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted</span> to rely on my <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> if they forgot to prepare one, but <span class="gemarra-regular">for you </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to do so, as I did not intend to include such negligent people as yourself in my <span class="it-text">eiruv</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival occurs on Shabbat eve, one may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prepare an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> on that day, <span class="gemarra-regular">neither a joining of</span> Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">boundaries [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">teḥumin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] nor a joining of courtyards</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥatzerot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>for Shabbat. If one did not prepare these before the Festival, he may not do so on the Festival itself. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>On a Festival that occurs on a Friday, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may prepare </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">a joining of courtyards, but not </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a joining of </span>Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">boundaries. </span>His reasoning is as follows: There is a distinction between the two types of <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">because you may prohibit him from a matter that is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited to him, </span>e.g., venturing beyond the Shabbat limit, which is prohibited on a Festival as well as Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">but you may not prohibit him from a matter that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted to him, </span>e.g., carrying from one domain to another, which is permitted on a Festival. Therefore, on a Festival, one may not prepare a joining of Shabbat boundaries in order to render it permitted to venture beyond the boundary on the Shabbat following the Festival. However, one may prepare a joining of courtyards on the Festival in order to render it permitted to carry from one domain to another on the Shabbat following the Festival.
<span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagreed as to the conclusive ruling. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who said that it is prohibited to prepare both types of <span class="it-text">eiruvin</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Shmuel said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, and it is permitted to prepare a joining of courtyards on a Festival. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: Is stating that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">a leniency or a stringency? </span>The Gemara wonders at this query: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he stated it as a leniency. </span>The Gemara explains: The question was asked <span class="gemarra-regular">because Rabbi Elazar sent </span>a message from Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Diaspora: </span>This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">not as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you teach </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in Babylonia, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">permits</span> one to prepare a joining of courtyards on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis prohibit </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the opinions should be reversed, so that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibits </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis permit </span>it. Therefore, the question arose: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the conclusive ruling for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it lenient or stringent?
The Gemara attempts to cite a proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that Rav Taḥlifa bar Avdim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> performed an action in accordance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with the opinion of Shmuel, </span>who ruled that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rav said </span>in anger about this: <span class="gemarra-regular">The first </span>public <span class="gemarra-regular">ruling of this young Torah scholar is </span>bringing about <span class="gemarra-regular">corruption</span> of the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
