The Gemara analyzes this statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if you say </span>that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said it as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a leniency, this </span>explains <span class="gemarra-regular">the corruption </span>of the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> involved, as Rav was angered by a young scholar who relied on his own judgment to issue a lenient ruling on a disputed issue. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, if you say </span>that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi meant it <span class="gemarra-regular">as a stringency, what corruption </span>of the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is there </span>in the young scholar’s ruling? 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since it corrupts </span>the behavior of <span class="gemarra-regular">the masses, </span>as, if they refrain from preparing a joining of courtyards on the Festival although it is permitted to do so, they might mistakenly carry from one domain to another on Shabbat, 

Daf 17a

<span class="gemarra-regular">this is the corruption </span>that might result from a ruling that renders it prohibited to prepare an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> the day before. Therefore, this cannot serve as proof of the conclusive ruling. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">to prohibi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> one from preparing either type of <span class="it-text">eiruv</span>. One may not prepare an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> either for courtyards or for boundaries, as the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with Rabbi Elazar’s version of the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival that occurs </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat, Beit Shammai say: One must recite </span>an <span class="it-text">Amida</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">prayer </span>that includes <span class="gemarra-regular">eight </span>blessings, inserting two additional blessings between the standard opening three and concluding three. As for the two middle blessings, <span class="gemarra-regular">one recites </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">for Shabbat as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an independent </span>blessing <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>a second <span class="gemarra-regular">for the Festival as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an independent </span>blessing. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: One must pray </span>an <span class="it-text">Amida</span> comprising only <span class="gemarra-regular">seven blessings, </span>i.e., the three opening ones, the three concluding ones, and one in between. <span class="gemarra-regular">One begins </span>the middle blessing <span class="gemarra-regular">with Shabbat and concludes </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">with Shabbat, and he recites </span>a passage referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sanctity of the day </span>of the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">in the middle. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: He even concludes </span>this blessing with mention of both Shabbat and the Festival, saying: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who sanctifies </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, the Jewish people, and the seasons</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">A </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before Ravina </span>with a slightly different reading: He concludes the blessing with: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sanctifies the Jewish people, Shabbat, and the seasons. </span>Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>that <span class="it-text">tanna</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that to say that the Jewish</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> people sanctify Shabbat? Isn’t Shabbat already sanctified </span>from the six days of Creation? Every seventh day is automatically Shabbat, without the need for any declaration on the part of the Jewish people. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>amend it and <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who sanctifies Shabbat, the Jewish people, and the seasons, </span>as the Jewish people indeed sanctify the New Moon and the Festival days. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> with regard to the conclusion of the blessing <span class="gemarra-regular">is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">and as </span>the difficulty was <span class="gemarra-regular">resolved </span>by <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat that occurs on a New Moo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>one of <span class="gemarra-regular">the intermediate days of a Festival, </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">the evening, morning, and afternoon prayers, one prays </span>in his usual manner, reciting <span class="gemarra-regular">seven </span>blessings in the <span class="it-text">Amida</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and recites</span> a passage <span class="gemarra-regular">pertaining to the event </span>of the day, i.e.: May there rise and come [<span class="it-text">ya’aleh</span> <span class="it-text">veyavo</span>], <span class="gemarra-regular">during</span> the blessing of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Temple service,</span> known as <span class="it-text">retze</span>; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if he did not recite </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is required to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">return </span>to the beginning of the <span class="it-text">Amida</span> prayer and repeat it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer </span>disagrees and <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>This passage is recited <span class="gemarra-regular">during </span>the blessing of <span class="gemarra-regular">thanksgiving,</span> known as <span class="it-text">modim</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> additional prayer one begins </span>the fourth blessing, the special blessing for the additional service, <span class="gemarra-regular">with Shabbat, and concludes </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shabbat, and recites </span>a passage pertaining to <span class="gemarra-regular">the sanctity of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the day </span>of the New Moon or the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the middle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yoḥanan ben Beroka, </span>disagree and <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Wherever </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">required to </span>recite <span class="gemarra-regular">seve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> blessings, whether in the evening, morning, or afternoon prayers, <span class="gemarra-regular">he begins </span>the fourth blessing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat and concludes </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">with Shabbat, and recites </span>a passage referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the sanctity of the day </span>of the New Moon or the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">in the middle. Rav Huna said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">that pair </span>of scholars; rather, it is in accordance with the opinion of the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>, that in the evening, morning, and afternoon prayers one recites the usual seven blessings and recites a passage pertaining to the event of the day during the blessing of the Temple service. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥiyya bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ashi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">a person </span>forgot to place an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> before a Festival occurring on Thursday and Friday in the Diaspora, he may act as follows: He may <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">the joining of </span>Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">boundaries</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on </span>the first <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival day for the next, </span>i.e., on the first Festival day for the second Festival day kept in the Diaspora, based on a doubt as to which day is the real day of the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stipulat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> as follows: If today is in fact the Festival, then tomorrow is a weekday, on which I may walk as far as I wish in all directions; and if today is a weekday and tomorrow is the Festival, I hereby place an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for the joining of Shabbat boundaries for tomorrow. On the following day he makes a similar stipulation with the same <span class="it-text">eiruv</span>, so that he will have an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for Shabbat.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: A person may place </span>an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">the joining of cooked foods on </span>the first <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival day </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for the next </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">and stipulate </span>as follows: If today is a weekday and tomorrow is the Festival, this is my joining of cooked foods, so that I may rely on it to cook tomorrow for Shabbat; and if today is in fact the Festival and tomorrow is a weekday, I may cook tomorrow as on a regular weekday. 
The Gemara comments: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who said </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">the joining of </span>Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">boundaries, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>would he permit one to act in this manner concerning an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">the joining of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cooked foods. </span>On the other hand, <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who said </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">the joining of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cooked foods </span>spoke only with regard to the joining of cooked foods; <span class="gemarra-regular">however, </span>as for an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">the joining</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">boundaries, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permitted. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this difference? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span> they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permit <span class="gemarra-regular">the acquisition of residence on</span> a day of <span class="gemarra-regular">rest</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> even in a case of uncertainty. However, with regard to an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for the joining of cooked foods, since it is merely symbolic, it is permitted for the sake of the honor of Shabbat. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not bake</span> bread <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival day for the next, </span>i.e., on the first Festival day for the second Festival day kept in the Diaspora. Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">actually, they said </span>the following established <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A woman may fill an entire pot </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">meat </span>to cook on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">although she requires </span><span class="gemarra-regular">only one piece </span>for that day, and all the remainder will be for the following day. Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">a baker may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fill </span>an entire <span class="gemarra-regular">barre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with water </span>in order to heat it up <span class="gemarra-regular">although he requires only a jug </span>of hot water. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to baking, he may bake onl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that which he requires </span>for that day.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Elazar says: A woman may fill the entire ove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> with <span class="gemarra-regular">bread, </span>although she does not intend to use it all on that day, <span class="gemarra-regular">because bread bakes wel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the oven is full. </span>A full oven has less empty space and is therefore hotter; consequently, filling the oven with bread serves not only to provide bread for the next day but also to improve the bread to be eaten that same day. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">A </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who did not prepare </span>an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">the joining </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of cooked foods, </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">he prohibited </span>from cooking for Shabbat and <span class="gemarra-regular">his flour is </span>likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited, </span>meaning that none of his food may be prepared for Shabbat? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">he is prohibited </span>from performing this type of labor, <span class="gemarra-regular">but</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his flour is not prohibited.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">practical </span>halakhic <span class="gemarra-regular">difference </span>that emerges from this question? The Gemara explains: There is a difference with respect to whether or not he must <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer</span> ownership of <span class="gemarra-regular">his flour to others. If you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is prohibited and his flour is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited, he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> must transfe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his flour to others </span>so that they are able to bake for him if they so desire. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if you say </span>that only <span class="gemarra-regular">he is prohibited but </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his flour is not prohibited, he need not transfer his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">flour to others, </span>as they may bake for him even if the flour is not theirs. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What, </span>then, is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>?
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> did not prepare </span>an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">the joining of cooked</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> food</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> on a Festival eve <span class="gemarra-regular">may neither bake, nor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cook, nor insulate </span>food on the Festival for Shabbat that occurs on the following day, <span class="gemarra-regular">neither for himself nor for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">others, and others may neither bake nor cook for him. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">he do </span>so that he will have food to eat on Shabbat? <span class="gemarra-regular">He </span>must <span class="gemarra-regular">transfer his flour to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">others, and they may </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">bake and cook for him. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from here, </span>from the fact that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that he must transfer his flour to others, that <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited and his flour is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. </span>The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from here </span>that this is the case.
Another <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who transgressed </span>this prohibition <span class="gemarra-regular">and bake</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> on a Festival for Shabbat without having placed an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for the joining of cooked foods on the eve of the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Is it permitted to partake of his bread and his cooking? The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution to this question from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">did not prepare </span>an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">the joining of cooked </span><span class="gemarra-regular">foods, what </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">he do </span>so that he will have food to eat on Shabbat? <span class="gemarra-regular">He must transfer his flour </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to others, and they may </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">bake and cook for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him. </span>

Daf 17b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is so </span>that if one baked without having placed an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for the joining of cooked foods, it is permitted to eat the bread, <span class="gemarra-regular">let </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> simply <span class="gemarra-regular">teach: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who transgressed </span>the prohibition <span class="gemarra-regular">and baked</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is permitted </span>to eat the bread. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda bar Mattana said: </span>There is no proof from here, as the <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is teaching a remedy </span>involving acting in<span class="gemarra-regular"> a permitted </span>manner, and <span class="gemarra-regular">is not teaching a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> remedy </span>involving <span class="gemarra-regular">a prohibited </span>act. The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> did not want to teach that it is also possible to solve the problem in this proscribed manner. 
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution from a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who prepared </span>an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for <span class="gemarra-regular">the joining of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cooked foods </span>on a Festival eve <span class="gemarra-regular">may bake and cook </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and insulate </span>food on the Festival for Shabbat that occurs on the following day, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if he wants to eat </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiru</span><span class="gemarra-italic">v</span> on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has permission </span>to do so. But if <span class="gemarra-regular">he ate it </span>on the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">before he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> baked </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">before he insulated, he may neither bake, nor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cook, nor insulate, neither for himself nor for others, </span>and likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">others may neither bake nor cook for him. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>even without an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span>, one in this situation <span class="gemarra-regular">may cook for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Festival </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if he left over </span>part of what he cooked, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has left </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">over for Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, provided that he does not employ artifice </span>to circumvent the prohibition by saying that he is cooking a large amount for guests on the Festival, when in fact he has Shabbat in mind. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he employed artifice </span>to circumvent the prohibition, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibite</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to eat the food, by decree of the Sages. This indicates that one who cooks on a Festival for Shabbat in a prohibited manner may not eat the food.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: </span>This is no proof, as <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">speak of </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">artifice, </span>and a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">artifice is different, as the Sages were more stringent with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to </span>one who employs artifice <span class="gemarra-regular">than </span>with regard to one who <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally </span>cooks on a Festival for Shabbat. One who purposely transgresses is aware of his sin; therefore, he might repent and desist from his prohibited behavior, thereby preventing others from learning from his actions. However, one who employs artifice to circumvent a prohibition thinks that he is acting in a permitted manner. He is therefore likely to continue his practice. Furthermore, people might emulate him, and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of preparing an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> might be forgotten.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said </span>that there is another reason to reject the proof from this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion is <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥananya and in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥananya says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: One may not bake </span>bread on a Festival for Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he prepared an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> for the joining of cooked foods on the eve of the Festival specifically <span class="gemarra-regular">with bread</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; and one may not cook </span>any type of dish <span class="gemarra-regular">unless</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he prepared an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with a cooked dish; and one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not insulate </span>food <span class="gemarra-regular">unless there was hot </span>food <span class="gemarra-regular">insulated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the eve of the Festival. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: One may prepare an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> for the joining of cooked foods <span class="gemarra-regular">with one cooked dish and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> use it for all his needs, </span>i.e., baking, cooking, and insulating. Since Ḥananya’s opinion in accordance with the opinion of Beit Shammai is strict in this case, it may be assumed that he is stringent after the fact as well, and therefore the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> provides no proof. 
The Gemara offers yet another suggestion. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned</span> in amishna: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who </span>transgressed a rabbinic prohibition and <span class="gemarra-regular">tithed his produce on Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if he did so <span class="gemarra-regular">unwittingly, he may eat </span>of it; if he acted <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally, he may not eat </span>of it. This indicates that one may not derive benefit from a transgression that he committed intentionally. The Gemara rejects this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he has other produce </span>and therefore does not greatly suffer as a result. However, the Sages may have been more lenient with one who did not make an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for the joining of cooked food and consequently has nothing to eat.
The Gemara poses another resolution: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a different source: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who immerses</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his vessels on Shabbat, </span>an activity that the Sages prohibited because it is akin to repairing a vessel, if he did so <span class="gemarra-regular">unwittingly, he may use them; </span>however, if he did so <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally, he may not use them. </span>This shows that the product of an action performed in a prohibited manner is prohibited. 
The Gemara rejects this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he has other vessels </span>and is not forced to use these ones. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> possible </span>for him to manage <span class="gemarra-regular">by borrowin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> vessels from others. But if one failed to set aside an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for the joining of cooked foods, perhaps the Sages allowed him to eat the food he cooked on the Festival for Shabbat since it is difficult to obtain food from others on Shabbat.
The Gemara suggests another proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>that which was taught in the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who cooks on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if he did so <span class="gemarra-regular">unwittingly, he may eat </span>the food that he cooked; but if he cooked it <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally, he may not eat </span>it. This demonstrates that one who purposely violated a prohibition may not benefit from his prohibited action. The Gemara rejects this argument: There is no proof from here; the <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibition of Shabbat </span>desecration <span class="gemarra-regular">is different</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since it entails <span class="it-text">karet</span> and execution by a court. The same stringency might not necessarily apply to cooking on a Festival for the sake of the next day, and therefore the question raised above remains unresolved. 
§ It is stated in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say </span>that for the purpose of the joining of cooked foods one must prepare <span class="gemarra-regular">two cooked dishes, </span>whereas Beit Hillel say that one dish suffices. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, who taught</span> in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shammai and Beit Hillel agree that two dishes are necessary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. With regard to what do they disagree? </span>They disagree <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to </span>a fried <span class="gemarra-regular">fish and the egg on it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as Beit Shammai say: Two </span>proper <span class="gemarra-regular">dishes </span>are required, and this fish is considered only a single dish; <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Hillel say: One dish </span>of this kind is viewed as two dishes and is therefore suitable for an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> for the joining of cooked foods. <span class="gemarra-regular">And they </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">agree that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if one sliced </span>a cooked <span class="gemarra-regular">egg and placed </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">inside</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the fish, or if he mashed leeks [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kaflotot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> placed </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">inside the fish, they are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">two dishes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">our </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">and in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hille</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> that one dish suffices.
The mishna states that if <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ate </span>the food prepared before the Festival as an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">it was lost, he may not </span>rely <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">cook </span>with the initial intent to cook for Shabbat. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: We have a tradition </span>that if <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>prepared a proper <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">began </span>kneading <span class="gemarra-regular">his doug</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> on a Festival for Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>in the meantime <span class="gemarra-regular">his</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was eaten</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he may finish </span>baking the bread. Since he had begun in a permitted manner, he is allowed to complete the process and bake the bread. 
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">occurs </span>directly <span class="gemarra-regular">after Shabbat, </span>i.e., on a Sunday, and one wishes to behave in a proper manner and purify himself and his vessels in honor of the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One must immerse</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> everything before Shabbat, and Beit Hillel say: Vessels </span>must be immersed <span class="gemarra-regular">before Shabbat, but a person </span>may immerse himself even <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel both <span class="gemarra-regular">agree that one may bring </span>ritually impure <span class="gemarra-regular">water into contact</span> with ritually pure water <span class="gemarra-regular">in stone vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to purify </span>the water. Impure water can be purified if it is placed into a vessel that does not contract ritual impurity, such as a stone vessel, and then lowered with the vessel into a ritual bath. The water becomes purified when it comes into contact with the water of the ritual bath. Although this is not considered proper immersion, water may nevertheless be purified in this manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, one may not immers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the impure water in a ritually impure vessel in order to purify the vessel at the same time. Likewise, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may immerse </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">principle to another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one group to another, </span>as will be explained in the Gemara. 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">In</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> any event, everyone agrees, </span>i.e., both Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel agree, that one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not </span>immerse <span class="gemarra-regular">a vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on Shabbat. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reaso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that one may not do so? Which type of prohibited labor does it involve? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree </span>issued by the Sages as a preventive measure, 

Daf 18a

<span class="gemarra-regular">lest one </span>come to <span class="gemarra-regular">pick up </span>the vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">in his hand and carry it four cubit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the public domain </span>to a ritual bath. <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>Rabba: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one has a pit </span>full of water of a ritual bath <span class="gemarra-regular">in his courtyard, </span>so that this decree should not apply, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to say? </span>Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>The Sages issued <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree </span>against immersing vessels even in <span class="gemarra-regular">a pit </span>of water <span class="gemarra-regular">in one’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to a pit </span>situated <span class="gemarra-regular">in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> public domain.</span>
Abaye posed another challenge: This works out <span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to a Festival, </span>when there is no prohibition against carrying from one domain to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say? </span>Rabba replied: The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">issued a decree </span>that it is prohibited to immerse a vessel on <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival, due</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the prohibition against immersing it <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat. </span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And do we issue a decree</span> in such a case? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel both <span class="gemarra-regular">agree</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that one may bring </span>ritually impure <span class="gemarra-regular">water into contact </span>with ritually pure water <span class="gemarra-regular">in stone vessels in order to purify</span> the water. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, one may not immerse </span>the impure water in a ritually impure vessel in order to purify the vessel at the same time. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is so</span> that such a decree was issued, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">decree</span> here that <span class="gemarra-regular">bringing </span>ritually impure water <span class="gemarra-regular">into contact </span>with ritually pure water is prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">immersin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> a ritually impure vessel in a ritual bath. 
The Gemara rejects this challenge: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how can <span class="gemarra-regular">you understand </span>that there is substance to this question? <span class="gemarra-regular">If</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he has </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">good, </span>ritually pure, <span class="gemarra-regular">water </span>to drink, <span class="gemarra-regular">why</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do I </span>need <span class="gemarra-regular">to bring this </span>ritually impure water <span class="gemarra-regular">into</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> contact </span>with the ritually pure water? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one must say <span class="gemarra-regular">that he does not have </span>suitable drinking water, <span class="gemarra-regular">and since</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he does not have </span>other water, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span>particularly <span class="gemarra-regular">careful</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> about </span>this water, so that it not become impure. Therefore, perforce, this must be an exceptional case, as the water became impure despite the precautions that were taken; and the Sages did not apply their decrees to unusual cases.
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection </span>from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may draw water </span>from a spring or a ritual bath on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">with a </span>ritually <span class="gemarra-regular">impure pail</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>the pail becomes ritually <span class="gemarra-regular">pure </span>because while being filled with water, the bucket is completely immersed in the ritual bath. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is so </span>that the Sages issued such a decree, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">decree </span>here that it is prohibited to draw water on Festival with a ritually impure pail <span class="gemarra-regular">lest one come to immerse </span>the pail <span class="gemarra-regular">by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> itself. </span>Rabba answered: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is different there; since it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted for him </span>to immerse the pail <span class="gemarra-regular">only by drawin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> water with it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he remembers </span>that it is prohibited to immerse a vessel by itself, and therefore there is no reason to issue a decree. 
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">raised </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an objection </span>from a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, in which it was taught: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a vessel that was rendered ritually </span><span class="gemarra-regular">impure on the eve of a Festival, one may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">immerse it on the Festival; </span>however, if it became impure <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may immerse it on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival. And if it is so </span>that the Sages issued such a decree, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">decree </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is prohibited to immerse a vessel that became impure on <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival due to </span>the prohibition against immersing a vessel that became impure on the <span class="gemarra-regular">eve of a Festival. </span>Rabba answered: Contracting ritual <span class="gemarra-regular">impurity on a Festival, </span>when all are ritually pure, <span class="gemarra-regular">is an uncommon occurrence, and </span>the general principle is that in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncommon occurrence, the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Sages did not issue a decree </span>as a preventive measure. 
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">raised </span>yet another <span class="gemarra-regular">objection </span>from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a vessel that was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rendered </span>ritually <span class="gemarra-regular">impure by a primary source of impurity, one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not immerse it on a Festival. </span>However, if it was rendered impure only <span class="gemarra-regular">by a derivative source of impurity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning that the vessel came into contact with an object that was rendered impure by a primary source of impurity, so that the object has the status of first-degree ritual impurity and confers upon the vessel the status of second-degree ritual impurity, a type of impurity that applies to vessels only by rabbinic decree; in such a case, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may immerse </span>the vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is so </span>that the Sages issued such a decree, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">decree </span>here that it is prohibited to immerse <span class="gemarra-regular">this, </span>a vessel rendered impure by a derivative source of impurity, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the prohibition to immerse <span class="gemarra-regular">that, </span>a vessel rendered impure by a primary source of impurity.
Rabba replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do you find </span>a case where people are particular about purifying a vessel that contracted ritual impurity from <span class="gemarra-regular">a derivative </span><span class="gemarra-regular">source of impurity? </span>It is only in one situation, namely, <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to priests, </span>since they eat <span class="it-text">teruma</span>, and <span class="it-text">teruma</span> contracts ritual impurity even from a vessel that came into contact with only a derivative source of impurity. An ordinary person, who eats non-consecrated produce, does not go to the trouble of purifying such a vessel, since regular produce contracts ritual impurity only from a vessel that came into contact with a primary source of impurity, but not from a vessel that came into contact with a derivative source of impurity. And as for priests, the general principle is that <span class="gemarra-regular">priests are vigilant; </span>they are careful not to allow their vessels to become impure. Therefore, impurity in the case of priests is considered a rare occurrence, with regard to which the Sages did not issue a decree.
The Gemara further suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a different proof, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥiyya bar Ashi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: A menstruating </span><span class="gemarra-regular">woman who has no </span>ritually pure <span class="gemarra-regular">clothes </span>to wear after she immerses herself in a ritual bath to purify herself, as all her clothes had become impure, and it is Shabbat or a Festival, when she is unable to immerse them, <span class="gemarra-regular">may employ an artifice </span>to circumvent the prohibition <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">immers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> herself <span class="gemarra-regular">in her clothes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> She is permitted to purify herself, and when she immerses herself while wearing her garments, they become purified at the same time. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is so </span>that the Sages issued such a decree, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">decree </span>that it is prohibited for the woman to immerse herself in her clothes <span class="gemarra-regular">lest she come</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to immerse </span>the clothes by <span class="gemarra-regular">themselves. </span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is different</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there; since it is permitted for her </span>to immerse the clothes <span class="gemarra-regular">only by </span>wearing them as <span class="gemarra-regular">garments</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> she </span><span class="gemarra-regular">remembers </span>that it is prohibited to immerse them by themselves and will not come to violate this prohibition.
Apropos Rabba’s view that one may not immerse a vessel on Shabbat lest he come to carry it four cubits in the public domain, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said </span>that it is prohibited to immerse a vessel on Shabbat for a different reason: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree </span>issued by the Sages as a preventive measure <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">wringing. </span>After immersing certain items, such as clothes, one might come to wring them, and this is prohibited on Shabbat and Festivals as a subcategory of the biblically prohibited labor of threshing.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rav Yosef: This works out <span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that are fit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for wringing, </span>such as clothes, but with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that are not fit for wringing, what is there to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say? </span>Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to him: The Sages issued <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">decree </span>against <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>vessels, which cannot be wrung, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">those </span>vessels, which can be wrung. Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">raised </span>against Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">all of these objections </span>that he had raised against Rabba, in an attempt to prove that the Sages did not issue such a decree, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">answered him </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as we answered </span>in the name of Rabba.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Beivai said </span>a different reason: The prohibition against immersing a vessel on a Festival is <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree </span>issued by the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">lest one </span>come to <span class="gemarra-regular">dela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> the immersion of his impure vessels. Were the Sages to permit him to immerse vessels on a Festival, he might delay immersing all of his impure vessels until the Festival, when he has more free time; and were he to leave ritually impure vessels in his possession for a lengthy period, he might come to defile items that must be kept ritually pure, such as <span class="it-text">teruma</span>. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">It</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Beivai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a vessel that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> became ritually impure on the eve of a Festival, one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not immerse it on a Festival, </span>due to <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> decree lest he </span>come to <span class="gemarra-regular">delay </span>and keep impure vessels in his home in order to immerse them on the Festival. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>yet a different reason: It is prohibited to immerse a vessel on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">because it looks as if he is repairing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Since the vessel was previously unfit for use, and the act of immersion renders it usable, this is similar to the repair of a vessel, which is Torah law proscribes on Shabbat and Festivals. The Gemara challenges this understanding: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, a person </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">likewise </span>be prohibited to immerse himself, because it looks as if he is repairing himself through purification. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person</span> undergoing immersion <span class="gemarra-regular">looks as if he is cooling </span>himself. Since it is not clearly evident that he is immersing in order to purify himself, as he might be bathing for his pleasure, there is no reason to prohibit the immersion.
The Gemara challenges this explanation: This works out <span class="gemarra-regular">well</span> in a case where he immerses himself in <span class="gemarra-regular">good, </span>clean <span class="gemarra-regular">water, </span>in which it would be a pleasure to bathe; but if he immerses himself in <span class="gemarra-regular">bad, </span>murky <span class="gemarra-regular">water, </span>as the water of a ritual bath is not always sufficiently clean, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to say? Rav Naḥman bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yitzḥak said: </span>Even in that case, his actions do not prove that his intention is to purify himself, as <span class="gemarra-regular">sometimes a person comes </span>home

Daf 18b

<span class="gemarra-regular">on a hot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> day and washes </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">even in </span>putrid <span class="gemarra-regular">water </span>in which flax <span class="gemarra-regular">was soaked, </span>because the heat has made him so uncomfortable.
The Gemara raises another objection: This works out <span class="gemarra-regular">well in the summer</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> season; </span>however, <span class="gemarra-regular">in the rainy season, </span>when people do not usually immerse themselves in water in order to cool off, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to say? Rav Naḥman bar Yitz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">ḥak said: Sometimes a person comes </span>home <span class="gemarra-regular">from the field</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> soiled with mud and excrement and washes </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">even in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the rainy season. </span>
The Gemara continues with another objection: This works out <span class="gemarra-regular">well </span>and explains why it is permitted for one to immerse himself <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shabbat, </span>when it is permitted to wash, and therefore it can be argued that it is not clearly evident that he is immersing in order to purify himself; but <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yom Kippur, </span>when all bathing apart from ritual immersion is prohibited, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> His actions prove that his intention is to purify himself, and this should be prohibited because it looks as though he is repairing himself through purification.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>It is impossible to prohibit immersion on Yom Kippur alone, as <span class="gemarra-regular">is there anythin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that is permitted on Shabbat and </span>the very same act is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>as labor <span class="gemarra-regular">on Yom </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Kippur? </span>In fact, the prohibition against labor is more stringent on Shabbat than on Yom Kippur. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, since it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permitted on Shabbat, it is also permitted on Yom Kippur. </span>The Sages did not issue decrees with regard to Yom Kippur that would make it more stringent than Shabbat. Therefore, since they allowed a person to immerse on Shabbat because it looks as if he is doing so for pleasure, to escape the heat or to remove dirt, and not necessarily in order to purify himself, they permitted it on Yom Kippur as well, even though it is evident in that situation that his immersion is for the purpose of achieving purity. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Does Rava accept </span>the principle of: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is concerned </span>about pain <span class="gemarra-regular">in his teeth may not sip </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vinegar through the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> on Shabbat in order to alleviate his toothache; <span class="gemarra-regular">however, he may dip </span>his food in vinegar <span class="gemarra-regular">in his </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">manner </span>during the meal and eat it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and if he is healed </span>by the vinegar, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">healed. And we raised a contradiction to this </span>mishna from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not sip </span>vinegar <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>immediately <span class="gemarra-regular">spit </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">out, </span>as this is clearly done for medicinal purposes; <span class="gemarra-regular">however, one may sip </span>the vinegar <span class="gemarra-regular">and swallow </span>it, since it looks as though he is drinking it. This indicates that there is a permitted way to use vinegar even without dipping his food into it. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Abaye said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Also when we learned </span>this ruling in <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mishna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> learned </span>it with regard to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sips and spits </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">out</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rava said: Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that the mishna prohibits sipping vinegar even in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">one sips and swallows </span>it, it is still <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult: Here, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> permits sipping vinegar <span class="gemarra-regular">before</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dipping </span>one’s food in it, as he appears to be doing so for pleasure. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the mishna prohibits sipping the vinegar <span class="gemarra-regular">after dipping </span>his food in it, when it is clear that one is doing so for medicinal purposes only. 
The Gemara completes its question: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>that Rava accepts the principle of: Since, <span class="gemarra-regular">let him </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: Sinc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is permitted </span>to sip vinegar <span class="gemarra-regular">before dipping</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, it is also permitted </span>to do so <span class="gemarra-regular">after dipping. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava retracted that </span>statement with regard to vinegar and accepted Abaye’s resolution of the difficulty, along with the principle of: Since. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where </span>can it be determined <span class="gemarra-regular">that he retracted tha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> teaching? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps he retracted this </span>statement with regard to immersion in a ritual bath on Yom Kippur. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This cannot enter your mind </span>that he retracted his view in that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">All </span>who are <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated in immersion</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> immerse in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">their </span>usual <span class="gemarra-regular">manner, both on the Ninth of Av and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on Yom Kippur, </span>even though it is prohibited to wash on these days. Rava would certainly have aligned his opinion with the explicit ruling of a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel both <span class="gemarra-regular">agree that one may bring </span>ritually impure <span class="gemarra-regular">water </span><span class="gemarra-regular">into contact </span>with ritually pure water <span class="gemarra-regular">in stone vessels </span>in order to purify the water. However, one may not immerse the impure water. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of the mishna’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">However, one may not immerse </span>the impure water? <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: One may not immerse </span>an impure <span class="gemarra-regular">vessel on account of its wate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to purify it on a Festival. </span>The Sages allowed impure water to be purified through contact with ritually pure water only in a stone vessel or in another vessel that does not contract impurity, but not in an impure vessel that would itself become purified through this immersion.
The Gemara asks: If that is its meaning, in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is the mishna? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span>with that of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> As it is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not immerse an </span>impure <span class="gemarra-regular">vessel on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> account of its water </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to purify </span>the vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one may not bring </span>impure <span class="gemarra-regular">water into contact </span>with pure water <span class="gemarra-regular">in a stone vessel </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to purify</span> the water; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: One may immerse </span>an impure <span class="gemarra-regular">vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on account of its water </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to purify </span>the vessel, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one may bring </span>impure <span class="gemarra-regular">water into contact </span>with pure water <span class="gemarra-regular">in a stone vessel </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to purify</span> the water. 
If so, in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion is the mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, then the ruling with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">bringing </span>impure <span class="gemarra-regular">water into contact </span>with pure water in a stone vessel is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi prohibits doing so, whereas the mishna permits it; and <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>then the ruling with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">immersion</span> of an impure vessel on account of its water is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> the Rabbis permit this, while the mishna, as explained by Shmuel, prohibits it.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">If</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you wish, say </span>that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi; and <span class="gemarra-regular">if you wish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, say </span>instead that it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis. </span>How so? <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi and explain that the <span class="gemarra-regular">first clause of </span>that <span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the first part of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s statement in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, deals with <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; </span>it is in that case that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi prohibits immersing an impure vessel on account of its water, but bringing impure water into contact with pure water in a stone vessel would be permitted. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the latter clause, </span>which extends the prohibition to bringing impure water into contact with pure water, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the more stringent case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat. And the entire mishna </span>is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>when it is permitted to purify impure water by bringing it into contact with pure water in a stone vessel. 

Daf 19a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>and on a Festival one is permitted even to immerse an impure vessel on account of its water in order to purify the vessel. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the entire mishna </span>is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to Shabbat, </span>when it is prohibited to immerse an impure vessel, but it is permitted to purify impure water by bringing it into contact with pure water in a stone vessel.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a vessel that became ritually impure on the eve</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a Festival, one may not immerse it during twilight</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a time period of doubtful status whether it is a weekday or a Festival, due to the possibility of violating the prohibition against immersing vessels on a Festival. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon Shezuri says: Even on a weekday</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one may not immers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> an impure vessel during twilight <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>the vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">requires sunset. </span>After an impure vessel is immersed, it remains ritually impure for certain purposes until the sun has set and the stars have come out. If one immerses an impure vessel during the twilight period, thenowing to the uncertainty as to whether it is day or night, he must wait another full day, until the next sunset, before using the vessel. It is therefore preferable not to put oneself in a situation where one might come to use a vessel before its purification process has been completed. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not require sunset? </span>It is clear that this is required. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: I found the Sages of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">school of Rav sitting and saying </span>with regard to this issue that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree about </span>whether or not to accept the principle that one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">intention is evident from his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">actions. And what are the circumstances </span>of this dispute? They are, <span class="gemarra-regular">for example, </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one was holding a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vessel in his hand and running along at </span>the time of <span class="gemarra-regular">twilight to immerse it.</span>
This <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>i.e., the Rabbis, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he is running along </span>indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">he knows that </span>the vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">requires sunset. </span>If he arrives at the ritual bath late, he will realize that he must wait another day, and there is no concern that he might come to use the vessel on the same day. Consequently, it is prohibited to immerse the vessel during twilight on the eve of a Festival, as, since it may already be night and he will be unable to use the vessel until the next evening, immersing the vessel would be considered to be preparing something on a Festival for a weekday, which is prohibited. However, it is permitted to immerse a vessel during twilight on an ordinary weekday evening.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> this <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rabbi Shimon Shezuri, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">he is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> running due to his work </span>that he has not finished on time, and not necessarily because he knows that the purification of his vessel requires sunset. He believes that he may use the vessel immediately upon immersion; therefore, the Sages decreed that one should never immerse vessels during twilight.
Rava continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And I said to them: With regard to</span> the principle that one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">intention is evident from his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> actions, everyone agrees </span>that this is accepted. <span class="gemarra-regular">Where they disagree</span> is, <span class="gemarra-regular">for example, </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>a vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">became</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> impure through </span>contact with a creeping animal <span class="gemarra-regular">less than a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lentil-bul</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> in size, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the vessel’s owner <span class="gemarra-regular">came before the Sages to ask </span>whether a vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">impure through </span>contact with <span class="gemarra-regular">less than a lentil-bulk or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not. One Sage, </span>Rabbi Shimon Shezuri, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does not know this </span>matter that a creeping animal smaller than a lentil-bulk does not impart impurity, it stands to reason that <span class="gemarra-regular">he also does not know </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">sunset; </span>therefore, there is reason to prohibit him from immersing vessels during twilight even on a weekday. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Sage, </span>the Rabbis, who permit such immersion on a weekday, <span class="gemarra-regular">hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to the size of a creeping animal that <span class="gemarra-regular">he does </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not know, but </span>the requirement of <span class="gemarra-regular">sunset he does know, </span>as it is stated explicitly in the Torah.
It was taught in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may immerse </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">principle</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to another </span>and from one group to another. The Gemara attempts to clarify the meaning of this statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">How </span>does one immerse <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">principle</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> One who wishes to make his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> winepress, </span>meaning to immerse and purify vessels for the sake of his winepress, <span class="gemarra-regular">in addition to </span>the purification of <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>ritually impure <span class="gemarra-regular">pitcher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> may do so. In other words, if at first he merely intended to immerse his impure pitcher, but subsequently changed his mind and decided to use it for his winepress, and he wishes to immerse the pitcher a second time for the sake of the winepress, it is permitted to do so. 
Similarly, one who wishes to make <span class="gemarra-regular">his pitcher in addition</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>the purification of his vessels for the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">his winepress may do </span>so. That is to say, if he originally intended to use the pitcher for his winepress, and after immersing it he decided not to use it for that purpose, and now he wishes to immerse his pitcher a second time, it is permitted to do so. Since the second immersion does not purify the vessel or fulfill any obligation, it is not considered a proper immersion and is not prohibited on a Festival.
Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">how </span>does one immerse <span class="gemarra-regular">from one group to another? </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">was</span> planning to <span class="gemarra-regular">eat </span>the Paschal offering <span class="gemarra-regular">with this group, </span>and he immersed himself or his ritually impure vessels for that purpose; and now he has reconsidered <span class="gemarra-regular">and wishes to eat</span> the offering <span class="gemarra-regular">with a different group, </span>and he wants to immerse himself or his vessels a second time for the second group, in such a case <span class="gemarra-regular">he has permission </span>to do so even on a Festival, for the same reason: Since this immersion is not obligatory, it is not viewed as an immersion at all.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One may bring</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> peace-offerings </span>on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">but one may not place</span> his <span class="gemarra-regular">hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as this is considered using animals, which is prohibited on a Festival by rabbinic decree. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, one may not </span>bring <span class="gemarra-regular">burnt-offerings, </span>apart from the obligatory daily and additional offerings of the day, because burnt-offerings are consumed entirely on the altar and not by people, and slaughter is permitted on a Festival only for the purpose of human consumption. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">One may bring </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">peace-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">offerings</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">burnt-offerings</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and one may </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">hands on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">to Festival peace</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-offerings, </span>an obligation of the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">with respect to placing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hands </span>on them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and to burnt-offerings of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">appearance</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which must be brought over the course of the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">with respect to sacrificing </span>them. As <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai hold </span>that the verse <span class="gemarra-regular">“You shall observe [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">vaḥaggotem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] it as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival to the Lord </span>seven days in the year” (Leviticus 23:41) indicates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival </span><span class="gemarra-regular">peace-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">offerings [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥagiga</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], yes, </span>they may be sacrificed even on a Festival day, but <span class="gemarra-regular">burnt-offerings</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of appearance, no, </span>they may not. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hold: “To the Lord” </span>means that <span class="gemarra-regular">anything </span>brought <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>an offering <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Lord </span>may be sacrificed throughout the seven days of the holiday, even on the actual Festival day.
