<span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">vow</span>-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">and gift-offerings, </span>which are not part of the obligations of the day, <span class="gemarra-regular">all agree, </span>even Beit Hillel, that they <span class="gemarra-regular">may not be sacrificed on a Festival. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And likewise, Rav Adda bar Ahava said: Vow</span>-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gift-offerings may not be sacrificed on a Festival. </span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>against Ulla’s statement from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Beit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shammai and Beit Hillel did not disagree with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a burnt-offering that is not </span>part of the requirements <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Festival, </span>such as a vow-offering or a gift-offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">that it may not be sacrificed on a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival, or with regard to peace-offerings that are </span>part <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Festival </span>obligations, such as Festival peace-offerings or peace-offerings of rejoicing, <span class="gemarra-regular">that they may be sacrificed on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a Festival, </span>as the Festival is their designated time, and if one fails to bring them then he will be unable to sacrifice them later. 
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">did they disagree? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">burnt-offering that is </span>part <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Festival </span>requirements, such as the burnt-offering of appearance, <span class="gemarra-regular">and with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">peace-offerings that are not </span>part <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Festival </span>obligations, such as vow-offerings and gift-offerings. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Beit Shammai </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: He may not bring </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He may bring </span>them. This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> contradicts Ulla’s opinion that all agree that vow-offerings and gift-offerings may not be sacrificed on a Festival. 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Resolve </span>the contradiction by emending the text, <span class="gemarra-regular">and say </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as follows</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Beit Shammai </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel did not disagree with regard to burnt-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">offerings and peace-offerings that are not </span>part of the requirements <span class="gemarra-regular">of the Festival, </span>such as vow-offerings and gift-offerings, <span class="gemarra-regular">that they are </span>certainly <span class="gemarra-regular">not sacrificed on a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, or with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to peace-offerings that are </span>part <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Festival </span>obligations, such as Festival peace-offerings or peace-offerings of rejoicing, <span class="gemarra-regular">that they may be sacrificed on a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival. With regard to what did they disagree? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a burnt-offering that is </span>part <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Festival </span>requirements, such as the burnt-offering of appearance, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Beit Shammai say: He may not bring </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Beit Hillel say: He may bring </span>it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: </span>There were never any grounds for objection from the outset, as <span class="gemarra-regular">have you removed </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the world? </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the subject of a dispute among <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar’s opinion was not unanimously accepted. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">peace-offerings that come on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> account of a Festival on the Festival, </span>e.g., Festival peace-offerings or peace-offerings of rejoicing, <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: One places </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">hands on them on the eve of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Festival and slaughters them on the Festival, and Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Hillel say: One places </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">hands on them on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival </span>itself <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughters them on the Festival. </span>

Daf 19b

<span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">vow</span>-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">and gift-offerings, all agree </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not be sacrificed on </span>the actual <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as stated by Ulla and Rav Adda bar Ahava.
§ The Gemara comments that in this matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’</span><span class="gemarra-italic">im</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are like those </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who also disagreed about the same issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not bring a thanks-offerin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Matzot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to the leavened bread </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it, </span>as a thanks-offering must be accompanied by a meal-offering of forty loaves, ten of which are leavened bread, which may not be eaten on Passover. <span class="gemarra-regular">Nor </span>may one bring this offering <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shavuot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because it is a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival, </span>on which one may not bring any offering, even one that is eaten, if it is not part of the Festival obligations. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, a person may bring his thanks</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-offering on the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: But it says: “On the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Matzot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shavuot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and on the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” </span>(Deuteronomy 16:16), to teach: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any </span>offering <span class="gemarra-regular">that comes on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Matzot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may come on the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shavuot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and on the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and any </span>offering <span class="gemarra-regular">that does not come on the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Matzot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not come on the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shavuot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: A person may bring his thanks-offering on the festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukko</span><span class="gemarra-italic">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and fulfill with it his obligation </span>to bring peace-offerings of <span class="gemarra-regular">rejoicing. </span>One fulfills the mitzva to rejoice on a Festival by eating the meat of offerings, and this obligation can be fulfilled with the meat of a thanks-offering. <span class="gemarra-regular">But he does not fulfill </span>with it the obligation to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival </span>peace-<span class="gemarra-regular">offering. </span>
The Gemara analyzes the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited above. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Master </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not bring a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thanks-offering on the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Matzot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">leavened bread </span>included <span class="gemarra-regular">with it. </span>The Gemara expresses surprise: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that one may not bring this offering on Passover, as it contains leavened bread. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda, son of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yitzḥak, said, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel bar Abba </span>who said: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is not discussing Passover itself; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with </span>a thanks-offering sacrificed on <span class="gemarra-regular">the fourteenth </span>of Nisan, i.e., on Passover eve, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>this <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not bring consecrated </span>offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">to a situation </span>where the time that they may be eaten is restricted, thereby increasing <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>likelihood of <span class="gemarra-regular">disqualification</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Although it is permitted to eat leavened bread until the sixth hour of the fourteenth of Nisan, one may not bring a thanks-offering on Passover eve. The reason is that a thanks-offering may usually be eaten for one full day and the following night, and if it is brought on the eve of Passover, the time available before disqualification is reduced.
It was further taught in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Nor </span>may one bring a thanks-offering <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shavuot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because it is a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival. </span>The Gemara explains: This <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">vow</span>-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">and gift-offerings may not be sacrificed on a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">However</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, a person may bring his thanks-offering on the festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">When? If we say </span>he may bring it <span class="gemarra-regular">on the Festival day </span>of <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">itself, </span>this is difficult, <span class="gemarra-regular">as didn’t you say: Nor</span> may one bring a thanks-offering <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shavuot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is a Festival, </span>indicating that a thanks-offering may not be brought on an actual Festival day? The same should apply to <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it means that one may bring it <span class="gemarra-regular">on the intermediate days of the Festival.</span>
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> further taught that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: But it says: “On the festival </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Matzot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, on the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shavuot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” </span>to teach: <span class="gemarra-regular">Any </span>offering <span class="gemarra-regular">that comes on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Matzot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may come on the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Matzot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and on the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and any </span>offering <span class="gemarra-regular">that does not come on the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Matzot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not come on the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shavuot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>This seems to indicate that thanks-offerings may not be brought on any Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira </span><span class="gemarra-regular">strongly objects to this: Now, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">we may cho</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> kindling wood on the intermediate days of the Festival for the sake of the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it necessary </span>to state that it is permitted to sacrifice <span class="gemarra-regular">vow</span>-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">and gift-offerings</span> on the intermediate Festival days? How can it be suggested that Rabbi Shimon prohibits bringing thanks-offerings on the intermediate days of the festival of <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span>?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: With</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to sacrificing </span>these offerings on the intermediate days of a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees that it is permitted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> When</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they disagree, </span>it is not with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of a Festival but with respect <span class="gemarra-regular">to determining when one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is liable for </span>violating the prohibition: <span class="gemarra-regular">You must not delay</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>If one vows to bring an offering but fails to fulfill his pledge, how much time must pass before he transgresses the prohibition: “You shall not delay to pay it” (Deuteronomy 23:22)?
<span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-regular">first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Merciful One states three Festivals </span>in the Torah, <span class="gemarra-regular">even not in their </span>proper <span class="gemarra-regular">order, </span>meaning not in accordance with the yearly cycle found in the Torah: Passover, <span class="it-text">Shavuot</span>, <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span>. As soon as three Festivals have passed from the day a person took his vow, if he has yet to bring his offering, he has transgressed the prohibition against delaying. Therefore, the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> advises a person who vowed to bring a thanks-offering to do so on <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span>, even if it is the first Festival after his vow, and even though it is not the first Festival listed by the Torah. If he fails to do so, he will have to make a special trip to Jerusalem in order to sacrifice the offering, as he will not be able to sacrifice it on Passover due to the leavened bread it contains, or on <span class="it-text">Shavuot</span> because it does not have intermediate Festival days. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">But Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shimon holds </span>that if three Festivals have passed <span class="gemarra-regular">in their</span> proper <span class="gemarra-regular">order, yes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> he has violated the prohibition against delaying; but if they have passed <span class="gemarra-regular">not in their </span>proper <span class="gemarra-regular">order, </span>he has <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>violated the prohibition. If, for example, one vowed to bring an offering between Passover and <span class="it-text">Shavuot</span>, he may put off bringing the offering until <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span> of the following year, and therefore he would not be required to travel an extra time to Jerusalem specifically for this purpose.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> further taught that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: A person</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may bring his thanks-offering on the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">When? If we say </span>that he means <span class="gemarra-regular">on the intermediate days of the Festival, this is </span>identical to the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tann</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>he must be referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">the Festival </span><span class="gemarra-regular">day </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">vow</span>-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">and gift-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">offerings may be sacrificed on a Festival.</span>
The Gemara asks: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is different </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that he cited it </span>specifically as an example of a Festival? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, </span>and this ruling too is related to the prohibition against delaying. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>The verse did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have to <span class="gemarra-regular">say “the festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,” of which the </span>immediately preceding <span class="gemarra-regular">verse was speaking; </span>it was only necessary to add the other Festivals. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>“the festival of <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span>” <span class="gemarra-regular">stated</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">to say that this </span>Festival, i.e., <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">must be the last one </span>with regard to the prohibition against delaying; one transgresses the prohibition only if the three Festivals have passed in their proper order, so that <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span> is the last of the three.
However, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, son of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Shimon, says: </span>It comes <span class="gemarra-regular">to say that this </span>Festival is what <span class="gemarra-regular">causes </span>a person to be late in fulfilling his vow. In his view, the prohibition against delaying does not depend on the number of Festivals. Rather, it means that by the time of <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span>, the last Festival according to the yearly cycle found in the Torah, one must have brought all of his vow-offerings of that year. Even one who vowed to bring an offering just before <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span> must bring his offering before the Festival ends. 
It is taught in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: A person may bring his thanks-offering on the festival of <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and fulfill with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it his obligation </span>to bring peace-offerings of <span class="gemarra-regular">rejoicing</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but he does not fulfill </span>with it the obligation to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival </span>peace-<span class="gemarra-regular">offering. </span>The Gemara expresses surprise: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that one does not fulfill his obligation to bring a Festival peace-offering with his thanks-offering. The Festival peace-offering <span class="gemarra-regular">is an obligatory matter, </span>as everyone is obligated to bring this offering, and the principle is that <span class="gemarra-regular">anything that is an obligatory matte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> must come only </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from that which is non-sacred, </span>meaning that one cannot bring an obligatory offering from an animal that has already been consecrated for another purpose. It follows that one cannot discharge his obligation to bring a Festival peace-offering with a thanks-offering, as he is already obligated to bring the latter and has consecrated the animal for this purpose.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in order to teach <span class="gemarra-regular">that even if one specified </span>at the time of his vow that he is consecrating the animal as a thanks-offering on condition that it may be used as a Festival peace-offering as well, he nevertheless does not fulfill his obligation with it.
This teaching is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>the question <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Shimon ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Lakish</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> asked of Rabbi Yoḥanan: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who</span> vows and <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>It is incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon me </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a thanks-offering, and I will </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">fulfill </span>my obligation to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival </span>peace-<span class="gemarra-regular">offering with it; </span>or if he says: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am a nazirite, </span>

Daf 20a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and I will shave </span>my head, meaning I will purchase the nazirite offerings that are brought when a nazirite shaves himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">with second-tithe money, </span>which I am obligated in any case to bring to Jerusalem, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Rabbi Yoḥanan <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>With regard to the thanks-offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has vowed </span>and must bring the offering, but <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not fulfill </span>his obligation of the Festival peace-offering with it, as the latter offering must be brought from unconsecrated animals. Similarly, one who took the vow of naziriteship is <span class="gemarra-regular">a nazirite, but he may not shav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> his head and bring nazirite offerings purchased with second-tithe money.
In relation to the previous case, in which one makes a conditional statement and only part of his statement is accepted, the Gemara relates a somewhat similar incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">A certain man said to </span>those tending to him, in the form of a will: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give four hundred </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zuz</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to so-and-so, and let him marr</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> my</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> daughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Pappa said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">four hundred </span><span class="it-text">zuz</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> takes, but </span>as for the benefactor’s <span class="gemarra-regular">daughter, if he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wishes, he may marry </span>her, and <span class="gemarra-regular">if he wishes, he</span> need <span class="gemarra-regular">not marry </span>her. 
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span>is solely <span class="gemarra-regular">that he said </span>it in this manner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Give him </span>the money <span class="gemarra-regular">and let him</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> marry </span>my daughter, mentioning the gift before the condition. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, if </span>he specified the condition first, by <span class="gemarra-regular">saying: Let </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him marry </span>my daughter <span class="gemarra-regular">and give him </span>the money, in that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">if he marries </span>her, <span class="gemarra-regular">he takes </span>the money, but <span class="gemarra-regular">if he does not marry </span>her, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> take </span>it. 
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Mareima</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sat and stated this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> with regard to one who attaches a condition to his vow to bring a thanks-offering <span class="gemarra-regular">in his own name, </span>without attributing it to the Sage who stated it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Mareimar: You teach this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in this manner, </span>without attribution, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">we teach it </span>in the form of a question that <span class="gemarra-regular">Reish Lakish asked of Rabbi Yoḥanan.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">A </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Abba: </span>The verse concerning the burnt-offering that Aaron was commanded to sacrifice for the inauguration of the Tabernacle: <span class="gemarra-regular">“And he brought the burnt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-offering and sacrificed it according to regulation” </span>(Leviticus 9:16), indicates that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of an obligatory burnt-offering is <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to the regulation </span>governing <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift burnt-offering. </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches with regard to an obligatory burnt-offering </span>that it too <span class="gemarra-regular">requires </span>the person bringing the offering to <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">hands </span>on the head of the animal to be sacrificed. 
Rabbi Yitzḥak <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span>: He <span class="gemarra-regular">who told you </span>that this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> requires an explicit biblical source, in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose</span> opinion did he say this? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shammai, who do not learn </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">obligatory peace</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-offerings from </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">gift peace-offerings </span>by way of an analogy [<span class="it-text">binyan</span> <span class="it-text">av</span>], as they distinguish between the two with regard to the requirement of placing hands on the peace-offerings brought on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">As, if </span>it were the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel, since they learn </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">obligatory peace-offerings from </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">gift peace-offerings</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>there being no distinction between the two categories, then <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> obligatory burnt-offering should also not require a </span>special <span class="gemarra-regular">verse</span> to teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>they can <span class="gemarra-regular">learn </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">from</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing <span class="gemarra-regular">a gift burnt-offering </span>by means of an analogy. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> where </span>may it be shown that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Hillel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> learn </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">obligatory peace-offerings from </span>those of <span class="gemarra-regular">gift peace</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-offerings? Perhaps </span>they do not learn the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of obligatory peace-offerings from those of gift peace-offerings. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">learn </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing obligatory peace-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing <span class="gemarra-regular">an obligatory burnt-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>Just as an obligatory burnt-offering requires the one bringing the offering to place his hands on the animal to be sacrificed, so too do obligatory peace-offerings. <span class="gemarra-regular">And an obligatory burnt-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> itself requires</span> an explicit <span class="gemarra-regular">verse </span>from which to derive this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, and perhaps the verse cited above is the source: “And he brought the burnt-offering and sacrificed it according to regulation.”
The Gemara challenges this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>about obligatory peace-offerings such <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>Beit Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">do not learn </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing them <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applying to <span class="gemarra-regular">gift peace-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">offerings? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>gift peace-offerings are more <span class="gemarra-regular">common, </span>and perhaps a different <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies to them. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">they should also not learn </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing obligatory peace-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applying to <span class="gemarra-regular">an obligatory burnt-offering, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the latter is <span class="gemarra-regular">entirely burnt, </span>unlike peace-offerings.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing obligatory peace-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">is derived from between </span>the two of <span class="gemarra-regular">them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Torah explicitly states that one must place hands on the heads of both obligatory burnt-offerings and gift peace-offerings. It is possible to extend the same obligation to obligatory peace-offerings by combining the two sources, as follows: If one says that an obligatory burnt-offering is different from an obligatory peace-offering because it is entirely burnt, gift peace-offerings prove that this is not the critical factor; and if one counters that gift peace-offerings are different from obligatory peace-offerings because they are common, an obligatory burnt-offering proves that this is not crucial. Therefore, there is no proof from here with regard to Beit Hillel’s position, as they too might learn the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing an obligatory burnt-offering from the verse: “And he brought the burnt-offering and sacrificed it according to regulation.”
The Gemara raises a question with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> itself: <span class="gemarra-regular">And do Beit Shammai hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">obligatory </span><span class="gemarra-regular">peace-offerings do not require placing of hands </span>on the head of the animal? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei said: Beit Shammai and Beit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Hillel did not disagree with regard to the placing of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> itself that it is required </span>in the case of obligatory peace-offerings. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">did they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> disagree? </span>They disagreed with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that states that <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately </span>following <span class="gemarra-regular">placing hands </span>on the head of an offering is its <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> As Beit Shammai say: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not necessary </span>to be particular in this regard, and the ceremony of placing hands on the animal’s head may be performed even on the eve of the Festival, long before the animal is slaughtered. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary, </span>and therefore one who brings an offering on a Festival must place his hands on the animal’s head on the Festival itself.
The Gemara answers: The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>what he said <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is taught </span>in a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, said: Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shammai and Beit Hillel did not disagree with regard to</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">immediately </span>following <span class="gemarra-regular">placing hands </span>on the head of an offering is its <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter, that it is necessary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. With regard to what, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">did they disagree? </span>They disagreed with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the placing of hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> itself </span>on the head of obligatory peace-offerings. <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not necessary, and Beit Hillel say: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ The Gemara returns to the basic dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">There was an incident involving Hillel the Elder</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who brought his burnt-offering to the </span>Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in order to place </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">hands on </span>the animal’s head <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival. The students of Shammai the Elder</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gathered around him </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What is the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nature of this animal </span>that you are bringing? Hillel, being humble and meek, did not want to quarrel with them in the Temple and therefore concealed the truth from them for the sake of peace. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: It</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is a female, and I have brought it as a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> peace-offering, </span>as burnt-offerings are always male. <span class="gemarra-regular">He swung</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its tail for them </span>so that they would not be able to properly discern whether the animal was male or female, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they departed. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">On</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that day, </span>when the incident became known, suggesting that even Hillel had accepted Shammai’s view, <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai gained the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> upper hand over Beit Hillel, and they sought to establish</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> in this regard <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with their </span>opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">But a certain Elder of the disciples of Shammai </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Elder was there</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Bava ben But</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> was <span class="gemarra-regular">his name, who knew that </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel </span>in this matter. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he sent </span>for

Daf 20b

<span class="gemarra-regular">and brought all the </span>high-quality <span class="gemarra-regular">sheep </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Kedar that </span>were <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Jerusalem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and he stood them </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the </span>Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and said: Anyone who wishes to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> place </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">hands </span>on the head of an animal should <span class="gemarra-regular">come and place </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">hands </span>there. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">day Beit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Hillel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gained the upper hand </span>over Beit Shammai, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they established the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with their </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">and there was no one there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who disputed the matter in any way.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>some time later <span class="gemarra-regular">there was another incident involving a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">certain disciple from among the disciples of Beit Hillel who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">brought his burnt-offering to the </span>Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard in order </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to place </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">hands on </span>the animal’s head on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">A certain disciple from among the disciples of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai found him </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this placing of hands</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Why do you place your hands on the animal’s head and thereby violate the statement of Beit Shammai? <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to him: What is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">this silence</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Why do you not stay silent, as the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> was not established in accordance with their opinion? <span class="gemarra-regular">He silenced him with a rebuke, and he, </span>Beit Shammai’s disciple, <span class="gemarra-regular">departed </span>quietly.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Therefore, </span>it is clear from here that <span class="gemarra-regular">a Torah scholar whose colleague says something </span>reprimanding or insulting <span class="gemarra-regular">to him </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">not answer back </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">something more than</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his colleague had said to him, </span>to avoid adding fuel to the fire, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>in the above story <span class="gemarra-regular">the one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to </span>the other: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is this placing of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hands? and </span>the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">responded to </span>the former using the same language: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is this silence?</span>
§ With regard to the dispute concerning the sacrifice of burnt-offerings of appearance on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel said to Beit Shammai: Just as in a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> place where it is prohibited </span>to slaughter <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">a common person [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">hedyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> e.g., on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted </span>to slaughter offerings in the Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Most High, </span>such as the daily and additional offerings, then so too, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a place where it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted </span>to slaughter <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">a common</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> person, </span>e.g., on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> right that </span>it should be <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Most High? </span>This argument should include burnt-offerings of appearance as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai said to them: </span>This is no proof. <span class="gemarra-regular">Vow</span>-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">and gift-offerings prove </span>that this reasoning is not valid, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to slaughter an animal on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">for a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">common</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> person </span>to eat, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited</span> to slaughter vow-offerings and gift-offerings on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the sake of <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Most High.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them: If vow</span>-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">and gift-offerings </span>may not be slaughtered on a Festival, that is <span class="gemarra-regular">because they do not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have a fixed time </span>and there is no obligation to sacrifice them on a Festival in particular, but can <span class="gemarra-regular">you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a burnt-offering of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> appearance, which has a fixed time, </span>the Festival itself? <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shammai said to them: It too has no fixed time</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as we learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who did not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bring </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival offering on the first Festival </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">of</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may bring </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">throughout the entire Festival, including the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> last Festival </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>on the Eighth Day of Assembly, as that day is regarded as part of <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span> for this purpose. This shows that a burnt-offering of appearance need not be brought at a fixed time on the Festival either. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel said to them: </span>Although a burnt-offering of appearance need not be sacrificed on a particular day of the Festival, nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">it too has a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fixed time, </span>albeit a lengthier one. <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">If the </span>entire <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival passed and he did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not bring his Festival-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he is not accountable</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for it. </span>That is to say, he is not required to bring another offering, as the mitzva has already passed. This indicates that the offering is limited specifically to the Festival days, unlike vow-offerings and gift-offerings, which may be brought at any time.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai said to </span>Beit Hillel in support of their own position: <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t it already</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stated </span>in the verse: “Only that which every soul must eat, that alone may be done <span class="gemarra-regular">for you” </span>(Exodus 12:16), which indicates that for you may food be prepared, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not for the Most High</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Beit Hillel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: But wasn’t it already stated </span>in the verse: “You shall observe it as a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Lord” </span>(Leviticus 23:41), which teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">Anything </span>sacrificed <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Lord </span>may be sacrificed? <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, what </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states “for you”? </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you, but not for gentiles</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for you, but not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for dogs. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abba Shau</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> stated </span>the same disagreement <span class="gemarra-regular">in a different formulation, </span>that Beit Hillel said to Beit Shammai as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in a place where your stove is closed, </span>i.e., on Shabbat, when a person may not cook for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">your Master’s stove is open, </span>as it is permitted to light a fire on the altar and sacrifice offerings upon it, so too, <span class="gemarra-regular">in a place where your stove </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is open, </span>i.e., on a Festival, when one may cook food that he will eat, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it not right </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that your Master’s stove </span>should be <span class="gemarra-regular">open</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">likewise </span>stands <span class="gemarra-regular">to reason that your table should not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be full while your Master’s table, </span>the altar, remains <span class="gemarra-regular">empty.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what do </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> and Abba Shaul <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree </span>in their different versions of Beit Hillel’s statement? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">One Sage, </span>Abba Shaul, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that according to Beit Hillel, even <span class="gemarra-regular">vow</span>-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">and gift-offerings may be sacrificed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival, </span>and therefore Beit Shammai could not cite as proof the fact that they may not be sacrificed, as they claim in the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one Sage, </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the first <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that according to Beit Hillel, vow-offerings and gift-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">may not be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sacrificed on a Festival, </span>and therefore Beit Shammai could adduce this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in support of their opinion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">According to the statement of the one who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">vow</span>-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">and gift-offerings may not be sacrificed on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival, you </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">not say that by Torah law </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they are </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">fit </span>to be sacrificed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that it was <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages who issued a decree about them </span>that they should not be sacrificed on a Festival as <span class="gemarra-regular">a preventive measure, lest one delay </span>sacrificing them until the Festival, when it is more convenient for him to bring them to the Temple, and thereby transgress the prohibition against delaying the fulfillment of one’s pledge.
This is not the reason; <span class="gemarra-regular">rather, </span>according to this opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are not fit </span>to be sacrificed on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span><span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah law. As the two loave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> brought on the festival of <span class="it-text">Shavuot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">are an obligation of </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">day, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there is no </span>reason <span class="gemarra-regular">to issue a decree </span>about them <span class="gemarra-regular">lest one </span>come to <span class="gemarra-regular">delay </span>their offering, since they may be brought only on that Festival, and yet their baking and preparation <span class="gemarra-regular">override neither Shabbat nor the Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> According to this view, anything that need not be performed on the Festival itself may not be done on the Festival. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised </span><span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to the statement of the one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">vow</span>-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">and gift-offerings may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be sacrificed on a Festival, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">one transgressed and slaughtered </span>those vow-offerings and gift-offerings on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: He sprinkles the blood </span>of these offerings on the altar <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to allow the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">meat to be eaten </span>on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Huna, </span>however, <span class="gemarra-regular">said: He sprinkles the blood in order to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> burn the sacrificial parts </span>of the animal, including the fats and other portions that are brought upon the altar, <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the evening. </span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the opinion of Rava and that of Rabba bar Rav Huna, since both agree that the blood is sprinkled? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is </span>a practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>in a case where <span class="gemarra-regular">the meat became </span>ritually <span class="gemarra-regular">impure or was lost</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. According to Rava, </span>who holds that the blood is sprinkled in order to permit the meat to be eaten, by rabbinic decree <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not sprinkl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> the blood, as this sprinkling is not required for the Festival. On the other hand, <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabba bar Rav Huna, </span>who holds that the blood is sprinkled in order to burn the sacrificial parts upon the altar in the evening, <span class="gemarra-regular">he does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sprinkle </span>the blood, even though it does not enable him to eat the meat.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to the opinion of Rabba bar Rav Huna from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the lambs of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Shavuot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the two lambs sacrificed as peace-offerings that accompany the two loaves of bread brought on that Festival, if <span class="gemarra-regular">one slaughtered </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them not for their </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">purpose, </span>i.e., at the time of slaughter his intent was to slaughter them as a different offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he slaughtered them </span>not at their proper time, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether before their time or after their </span><span class="gemarra-regular">time, </span>the offerings themselves are valid, although the community has not fulfilled its obligation. What is to be done with them? <span class="gemarra-regular">The blood </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">be sprinkle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the meat </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">be eaten. And if </span>the day he slaughtered the lambs <span class="gemarra-regular">was Shabbat, </span>on which cooking or roasting the meat is prohibited, then since the sprinkling of the blood serves no purpose, neither with regard to their mitzva nor for any other matter, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not sprinkle </span>the blood. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">he sprinkled </span>the blood, 

Daf 21a

the offering <span class="gemarra-regular">is accepted on condition </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>he <span class="gemarra-regular">burn the sacrificial parts </span>that are brought upon the altar <span class="gemarra-regular">in the evenin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> and not during the day. The wording of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> indicates that if the meat may not be eaten on that day, then only <span class="gemarra-regular">if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">sprinkled </span>the blood, i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">after the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fact, yes, </span>it is permitted; however, he may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sprinkle it <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Granted, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava</span> it works out <span class="gemarra-regular">well, but according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Rav Huna, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult. </span>The Gemara comments: Indeed, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult. And if you wish, say </span>instead: <span class="gemarra-regular">A rabbinic decree concerning Shabbat is different from a rabbinic</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> decree concerning a Festival, </span>as the Sages were more stringent with regard to Shabbat than with regard to Festivals.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Avya the Elder raised </span>the following <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma </span><span class="gemarra-regular">before Rav Huna: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal </span>is owned in partnership, <span class="gemarra-regular">half of it </span>belonging <span class="gemarra-regular">to a gentile and half of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it to a Jew, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to slaughtering it on a Festival? </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: It is permitted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Rav Avya <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And what is </span>the difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that of <span class="gemarra-regular">vow</span>-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">and gift-offerings? </span>Vow-offerings and gift-offerings are similar to jointly owned animals, as part of the animal is sacrificed upon the altar while the other part is eaten by the owner and the priest. Why, then, is it not similarly permitted to slaughter them on a Festival? Seeking to distract Rav Avya so that he need not answer his question, Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Look, <span class="gemarra-regular">a raven flie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in the sky. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">When </span>Rav Avya <span class="gemarra-regular">left, Rabba, son</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of </span>Rav Huna, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>his father: <span class="gemarra-regular">Was this not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Avya the Elder, whom Master would recommend to </span>us, saying <span class="gemarra-regular">that he is a great man? </span>If so, why did you treat him in that manner and evade his question? Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What should I have</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> done for him? Today I am </span>in a state best described by the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Let me lean against the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stout trunks</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> let me couch among the apple trees” </span>(Song of Songs 2:5), meaning I am worn out and exhausted from all the communal responsibility that has fallen upon me, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he asked me </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">something that requires reasoning</span> and careful examination, and therefore I could not provide an immediate answer.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">is the reason? </span>The Gemara explains the difference between a jointly owned animal and a vow-offering or gift-offering: A jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">animal, half of </span>which belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to a gentile and half to a Jew, may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be slaughtered on a Festival, as it is impossible to</span> obtain <span class="gemarra-regular">an olive-bulk of meat without slaughtering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If a Jew wishes to eat even a small portion of meat, he has no alternative but to slaughter an entire animal, even though he will not use all of it. Therefore, it does not matter if part of the animal belongs to a gentile. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, it is prohibited to slaughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> vow</span>-offerings <span class="gemarra-regular">and gift-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">offerings</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a Festival, </span>because in this case there is no real joint ownership of the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">priests, when they receive </span>their portions of the meat of the offering, and similarly, when Israelites partake of the offering, <span class="gemarra-regular">they receive </span>their portions <span class="gemarra-regular">from the table</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the Most High. </span>In other words, the entire offering belongs to God, and those who partake of it are considered guests at His table; and as stated above, one may not slaughter an animal on a Festival for the sake of God.
In continuation of the previous discussion, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: A </span>jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">animal, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">half of </span>which belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to a gentile and half to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew, may be slaughtered on a Festival because it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is impossible to </span>obtain <span class="gemarra-regular">an olive-bulk of meat without </span><span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtering. </span>However, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">dough, half </span>of which belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to a gentil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and half to a Jew, it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prohibited to bake i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a Festival, as it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is possible for him to divide it </span>in half <span class="gemarra-regular">during</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the kneading </span>and bake only the part that belongs to the Jew. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥana bar Ḥanilai raised an objection</span> from the following mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Dough </span>for bread that is meant <span class="gemarra-regular">for dogs, when </span>it is of such quality that even <span class="gemarra-regular">shepherds eat of it, </span>is considered like regular bread. Accordingly, one <span class="gemarra-regular">is obligated </span>to separate <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalla</span> from such dough, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one </span>may use it to <span class="gemarra-regular">establish an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., a joining of courtyards and a joining of Shabbat boundaries, <span class="gemarra-regular">and to establish a merging of alleyways, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one recites a blessing </span>before and after eating <span class="gemarra-regular">it, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one invites </span>those with whom he ate to recite Grace after Meals after eating <span class="gemarra-regular">it, and it may be baked</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a Festival, </span>like all foods fit for human consumption, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a person fulfills his obligation </span>to eat <span class="it-text">matza</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span> the first night of <span class="gemarra-regular">Passover with it </span>if it has not leavened. 
With regard to the allowance to bake this dough, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And why </span>may it be baked on a Festival? <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t it possible to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> divide it during the kneading, </span>so that he bakes only the portion to be eaten by people and leaves aside the part given to dogs? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Dough </span>for bread meant for <span class="gemarra-regular">dogs is different, since it is possible</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to appease them with a carcass. </span>It is possible that one of his animals will die, and he will feed the carcass to the dogs, in which case all of the dough will be eaten by people.
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Does Rav Ḥisda accept </span>the principle of <span class="gemarra-regular">since</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., that since it is possible that the situation may change, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is not determined based on the current circumstances? <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t it stated </span>that the <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagreed about the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing one <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>intentionally <span class="gemarra-regular">bakes on a Festival </span>day <span class="gemarra-regular">for a weekday</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥisda said: He is flogged </span>for desecrating the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba said: He is not flogged. </span>
The Gemara explains the two opinions: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he is flogged </span>because he holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">guests happen to </span>visit <span class="gemarra-regular">him, </span>whatever he bakes <span class="gemarra-regular">will be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fit for him </span>on the Festival itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">now too, </span>although guests have not yet arrived, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him. </span>According to that logic, baking would not be considered a full-fledged transgression, and one cannot be forewarned about it and does not receive lashes. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba, </span>however, <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He is not flogged, </span>as he holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">we do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>the principle of: <span class="gemarra-regular">Since. </span>As Rav Ḥisda himself does not accept the principle of since, how can it be used to resolve a difficulty raised against him? 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the Gemara retracts its previous answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">Do not say </span>that dough for dogs is different, <span class="gemarra-regular">since it is possible </span>that one of his animals will die and he will appease the dogs with the carcass. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the reference here is to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he has a carcass </span>ready, so that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is certainly possible to appease them with the carcass. </span>Consequently, when the shepherds bake the dough, it is highly likely that they will consume it all themselves.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">They</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> raised a dilemma before Rav Huna: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span> Jewish <span class="gemarra-regular">residents of a village [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">baga</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> upon whom </span>the authorities <span class="gemarra-regular">imposed </span>the obligation to supply <span class="gemarra-regular">flour </span>and bread <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span>gentile <span class="gemarra-regular">military troop</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> serving in the area, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">baking it on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival? </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>them: <span class="gemarra-regular">We examine </span>the matter: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>those villagers can <span class="gemarra-regular">give bread </span>from the soldiers’ quota <span class="gemarra-regular">to a child and </span>the soldiers <span class="gemarra-regular">are not particular </span>about it, then <span class="gemarra-regular">each and every one </span>of the loaves <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fit for </span>a Jewish <span class="gemarra-regular">child, and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted </span>to bake them. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>the soldiers do <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>allow anyone else to partake of their bread, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited </span>to bake the loaves for them on a Festival.
The Gemara challenges Rav Huna’s lenient ruling: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">There was an incident involving </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon the Timnite</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who did not come </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">night </span>of the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">to the study hall. In the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">morning, Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava found him </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: Why did you not come last night to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">study hall? He said to him: A military unit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on a search mission </span>[<span class="gemarra-italic">balleshet</span>] <span class="gemarra-regular">came to our city and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wanted to pillage the entire city. We slaughtered a calf </span>in order to placate them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and we fed them </span>with it <span class="gemarra-regular">and had them depart in peace.</span>
Rav Yehuda ben Bava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: I wonder if your gain, </span>that which you saved by preventing the soldiers from taking your possessions, <span class="gemarra-regular">was not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> outweighed by your loss, </span>the punishment for your desecration of the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">As the Torah states: </span>“Only that which every soul must eat, that alone may be done <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you” </span>(Exodus 12:16), which indicates that food may be prepared for you, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not for gentiles. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> why </span>did Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava say this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Wasn’t</span> some portion of the calf <span class="gemarra-regular">fit to be eaten by</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them? </span>The conclusion seems to be that even if a Jew may eat from an animal, it may not be slaughtered on a Festival for the sake of a gentile. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yosef said: </span>In that case it <span class="gemarra-regular">was a calf with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a condition that would cause it to die within twelve</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> months [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>which may not be eaten by Jews. The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t it </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">fit to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">be eaten by dogs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and it could be argued that it was slaughtered for the sake of dogs belonging to Jews?
The Gemara answers: The question of whether or not one may perform prohibited labor on a Festival for the sake of dogs <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>a dispute between <span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: It is written: <span class="gemarra-regular">“Only that which every</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> soul must eat, that alone may be done for you</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.” By inference, from that which is stated: “Every soul,” I</span> might <span class="gemarra-regular">derive </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">even the soul of an animal is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> included, similar to </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is stated: “And he that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> kills the soul of an animal shall pay it” </span>(Leviticus 24:18), indicating that the life force of an animal is also called a soul. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states </span>and emphasizes: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For you,” </span>

Daf 21b

indicating <span class="gemarra-regular">for you, but not for dogs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Akiva says: </span>When the verse states “every soul,” it comes to teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">even the soul of an animal is included</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. If so, what </span>is the meaning when <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> “for you”? </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">for you, but not for gentiles</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
