The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And what did you see </span>that led you <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> include dogs </span>among those on whose behalf one is permitted to perform a labor on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">and to exclude</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> gentiles? </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">I include dogs because </span>the responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">their sustenance is </span>incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you, </span>as one is obligated to feed the animals in his possession; <span class="gemarra-regular">and I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> exclude gentiles because </span>the responsibility for <span class="gemarra-regular">their sustenance is not</span> incumbent <span class="gemarra-regular">upon you.</span>
With regard to this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yosef: And according to Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who said</span> that the verse indicates: <span class="gemarra-regular">“For you,” but not for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dogs, how </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span>permitted to <span class="gemarra-regular">cast date stones to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">animal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a Festival? </span>Since date stones are not fit for human consumption, they should be considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, and therefore it should be prohibited to handle them.
Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: Since they are fit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for fuel, </span>they may be handled, and therefore they may also be given to animals. Abaye objected: This works out <span class="gemarra-regular">well in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">dry </span>date stones; but <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span> the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">moist ones, </span>which are not suited for fuel, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is there to say? He said to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: They are fit for a large fire, </span>which dries them out, after which they burn well.
Abaye raised another objection: This works out <span class="gemarra-regular">well</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival, </span>when it is permitted to fuel a fire, but <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, what is there to say? </span>Why should one be permitted to handle date stones on Shabbat? Rav Yosef answered: <span class="gemarra-regular">We</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> carry them along with bread</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> We place the date stones upon a loaf of bread and move them together with it. This is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel, as Shmuel said: A person may perform all his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> needs with bread</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> as long as the bread remains edible, he need not be concerned that he is treating the bread contemptuously.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> the ruling of Rav Huna that one is permitted to bake for gentiles on a Festival if they allow a Jew to eat of the bread <span class="gemarra-regular">differs from </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> As Rabbi Yehoshua ben</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Levi said: One may invite a gentile </span>for a meal <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he will certainly not cook for him on Shabbat, and it is permitted to give a gentile food that was prepared the day before. <span class="gemarra-regular">But one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not invite a gentile </span>for a meal <span class="gemarra-regular">on a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> this is prohibited as <span class="gemarra-regular">a preventive measure lest</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he </span>come to cook <span class="gemarra-regular">more for </span>the gentile’s <span class="gemarra-regular">sake</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>This indicates that Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi holds that one may not prepare more for a gentile, even if the meal is primarily meant for Jews.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: Even on Shabbat as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> well, </span>one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>invite a gentile for a meal <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the </span>wine <span class="gemarra-regular">remnants in the cups. </span>Once a gentile has drunk wine from a cup, whatever remains in the cup may not be used and is therefore considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. Therefore, a Jew may not host a gentile on Shabbat lest he come to handle the <span class="it-text">muktze</span> wine remnants on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, our </span>cups <span class="gemarra-regular">should also </span>be prohibited, as they too contain wine remnants that have no use whatsoever and should therefore be considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. The Gemara answers: The remnants in <span class="gemarra-regular">our </span>cups <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fit for chickens. </span>The Gemara objects: If so, the remnants in <span class="gemarra-regular">their </span>cups <span class="gemarra-regular">are also fit for chickens. </span>The Gemara rejects this argument: The remnants in <span class="gemarra-regular">their </span>cups are <span class="gemarra-regular">items </span>from which it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to derive any <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit </span>whatsoever; consequently, they may not be handled at all. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And let him move </span>what remains of the wine <span class="gemarra-regular">on account of the cup, </span>which is a vessel that may be handled, as the wine remnants should be considered nullified in relation to the cup. <span class="gemarra-regular">Didn’t </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rava say: One may move a coal pan [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kannuna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">on account of the ashe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that can be used to cover filth, <span class="gemarra-regular">even though there are broken pieces of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wood on it </span>that have no use? This indicates that one may move something that is <span class="it-text">muktze</span> along with something else that one is permitted to handle.
The Gemara rejects this argument: There is a difference between the two cases. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>the broken sticks <span class="gemarra-regular">are not items from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to derive any <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit </span>but are merely <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>what remains of the wine in the gentile’s cup <span class="gemarra-regular">is an item from which </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to derive any <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit, </span>and therefore the prohibition is more stringent.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa of Difti said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina: But let it be like a chamber pot for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">feces, </span>which may be removed from a room because it is repulsive. One should likewise be permitted to discard the remnants of these cups, since it is unseemly to leave them on the table. Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>If the cups contain such remnants, they may be removed, but may <span class="gemarra-regular">one make a chamber pot for feces </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The Sages ruled that one may not invite a gentile for a meal on Shabbat so as to avoid such complications.
In summary of this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>, the Gemara states that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span><span class="gemarra-regular">authorized</span> the Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Shmuel, </span>from the house of the Exilarch, to deliver a public lecture, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: One may invite a gentile </span>for a meal <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat, but one may not invite a gentile </span>for a meal <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">a preventive measure, lest</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he </span>come to cook <span class="gemarra-regular">more for his sake. </span>It is related about <span class="gemarra-regular">Mareimar and Mar Zutr</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">when a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">gentile would happen </span>to come <span class="gemarra-regular">to their </span>house <span class="gemarra-regular">on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival, they would say to him: If you are satisfie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>the food <span class="gemarra-regular">that we have prepared for ourselves, good</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; and if not, we will not go to </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">extra</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> trouble on your account.</span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: A person may not heat water </span>on a Festival in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>wash <span class="gemarra-regular">his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fee</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">unless it is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">drinking</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they hold that kindling a fire on a Festival is permitted only for the sake of preparing food, but not for washing. <span class="gemarra-regular">But Beit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Hillel permit </span>one to kindle a fire on a Festival even for washing. <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may kindle</span> a large <span class="gemarra-regular">fire and warm himself at </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a fire, who taught</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Is <span class="gemarra-regular">it a statement </span>accepted by <span class="gemarra-regular">all, </span>including Beit Shammai, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Shammai differentiate between benefit </span>affecting <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’s entire body and benefit </span>affecting <span class="gemarra-regular">a single limb, </span>so that they agree that kindling a fire to heat one’s entire body is similar to kindling a fire for food and is therefore permitted, while heating water to wash one’s feet remains prohibited? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps Beit Hillel taught</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it, but Beit Shammai do not differentiate </span>between the two cases, and they permit kindling a fire on a Festival only for the purpose of preparing food.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from an explicit <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: A person </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may not make a fire and warm himself at it, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">but Beit Hillel permit </span>it. It is clear from here that the latter clause of the mishna was taught only in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Gamliel was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stringent </span>about <span class="gemarra-regular">three things in accordance with the statement of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai: One may not insulate hot food on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival </span>for Shabbat <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>but rather one ought to do so on the eve of the Festival; <span class="gemarra-regular">and one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may not set up</span> a metal <span class="gemarra-regular">candelabrum </span>that fell <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival; and one may not bake thick </span><span class="gemarra-regular">loave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">but only thin ones, </span>due to the great effort entailed in preparing the former. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Gamliel said: From</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the days of my father’s household they would never</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bake thick loaves </span>on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">thin ones</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: What shall we do for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> your father’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">household</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">who were stringent with themselves</span> but <span class="gemarra-regular">lenient with all of the Jewish people, to </span>allow them to <span class="gemarra-regular">bake thick loaves and cakes baked on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">coals</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the mishna’s statement that Rabban Gamliel would not permit the insulation of hot water on a Festival <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? If </span>it is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he prepared a joining of cooked foods [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tavshilin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], what is the reason that Beit Shammai </span>prohibit it? <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>it speaks of a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not set aside an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tavshilin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, what is the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reason for </span>the lenient ruling of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel? Rav Huna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: Actually, </span>I will <span class="gemarra-regular">say to you </span>that the mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one did not prepare</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tavshilin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>but Beit Hillel hold that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages</span> nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted him </span>to prepare what he needs for <span class="gemarra-regular">his</span> basic <span class="gemarra-regular">sustenance. </span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Huna </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as Rav Huna said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who did not prepare an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tavshilin</span> on the eve of a Festival, others <span class="gemarra-regular">may bake one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> loaf </span>of bread <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, and cook one pot </span>of food <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, </span>

Daf 22a

<span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> kindle a lamp for him. They said in the name</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rabbi Yitzḥak: They may even roast a small</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fish for him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> That is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who did not prepare </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">tavshilin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>others <span class="gemarra-regular">may bake one loaf </span>of bread <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, and insulate one pot </span>of food <span class="gemarra-regular">for him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and kindle a lamp for him, and heat one </span>small <span class="gemarra-regular">jug [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kiton</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> of water <span class="gemarra-regular">for him. And some </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: They may even roast a small fish for him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: Actually, </span>one can say that the mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one prepared </span>an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> <span class="it-text">tavshilin</span>, and nevertheless, if he did not insulate hot food on the eve of the Festival for Shabbat he may not do so on the Festival itself, because <span class="gemarra-regular">insulating </span>hot food <span class="gemarra-regular">is different, as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is evident that he is acting with Shabbat in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> mind </span>and not for the Festival. Beit Shammai view this as a desecration of the sanctity of the Festival.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye raised an objection to</span> Rava’s opinion from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥananya says </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One may not bake </span>on a Festival for Shabbat that occurs on the following day <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he established a joining </span>of cooked foods <span class="gemarra-regular">with bread, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he may not cook </span>for Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he established a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">joining </span>of cooked foods <span class="gemarra-regular">with a cooked dish, and he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may not insulate </span>hot food for Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">had hot food insulated from the eve of the Festival. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>this indicates that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he had hot food insulated, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he may in any case act </span>in that manner and insulate hot food for Shabbat, even though <span class="gemarra-regular">it is evident </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that he is acting with Shabbat in mind. </span>This shows that even according to Ḥananya, who rules in accordance with the opinion of Beit Shammai, it is permitted to insulate hot food on a Festival for Shabbat.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Abaye said </span>that the mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he established a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> joining </span>of cooked foods <span class="gemarra-regular">for this, </span>meaning he baked and cooked before the Festival for the sake of an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he did not establish a joining </span>of cooked foods <span class="gemarra-regular">for this, </span>i.e., he did not insulate hot food for Shabbat on the Festival eve. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span> in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥananya, according to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai, </span>with Rabban Gamliel’s household being stringent upon themselves in this regard.
§ The mishna states that one of the three stringencies that Rabban Gamliel practiced in accordance with Beit Shammai was that on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not set up a candelabrum </span>that fell. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>prohibited act <span class="gemarra-regular">does one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">perform </span>when he sets a candelabrum upright? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥinnana bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Bisna said: Here, we are dealing with a candelabrum </span>composed <span class="gemarra-regular">of segment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> that come apart; it is prohibited to reassemble such a candelabrum <span class="gemarra-regular">because it looks like building. As </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>a prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">building </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to vessels, </span>and therefore the pieces of this candelabrum may not be reconnected, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">building with regard to vessels</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and there is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">dismantling with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to vessels. </span>One may therefore reattach the pieces of the candelabrum if they came apart.
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">happened to </span>come to <span class="gemarra-regular">the house </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Yehuda </span>on a Festival. Ulla’s <span class="gemarra-regular">servant stood</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and tilted the </span>oil <span class="gemarra-regular">lamp [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sheragga</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> diverting most of the oil to one side, with the intention of preventing the oil from reaching the wick so that the light would be extinguished more quickly. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda raised an objection</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Ulla </span>from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, in which it is taught: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who adds oil to a lam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable for </span>performing the prohibited labor of <span class="gemarra-regular">kindling </span>on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one who supplies himself </span>with oil <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>a lit lamp on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">is liable for </span>performing the prohibited labor of <span class="gemarra-regular">extinguishing, </span>as he causes the light to be extinguished more quickly. This indicates that any action, even an indirect one, that causes a lamp be extinguished earlier than it would have otherwise is considered extinguishing. Here too, by tilting the lamp, the servant extinguished a light on the Festival, which is prohibited. Ulla <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>You are indeed correct; the act was performed by my servant <span class="gemarra-regular">without</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> my knowledge</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
With regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing extinguishing on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: It is permitted</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to trim the end of a wic</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> that has become charcoal, so that it will burn better; this is not considered extinguishing.
With regard to this same issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">Abba bar Marta raised </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a dilemma before Abaye: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">extinguishing a lamp </span>that is burning in a room on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">for another matter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a euphemism for marital relations? Since it is prohibited to have relations in a room where a lamp is burning, may one extinguish a lamp for this purpose? Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>One may not extinguish it, as <span class="gemarra-regular">it is possible </span>to have relations <span class="gemarra-regular">in a different room. </span>
Abba bar Marta continued: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not have a different room, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>should he do? Abaye replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is possible to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">erect for oneself a partition </span>out of sheets and engage in relations on the other side of the partition. Abba bar Marta asked further: If he <span class="gemarra-regular">does not have </span>sheets <span class="gemarra-regular">to erect a partition, what </span>should he do? Abaye answered: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is possible to invert a vessel over </span>the lamp in order to hide the light. Abba bar Marta further inquired: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he does not have a vessel, what </span>should he do? Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It is prohibited; </span>one may not extinguish the lamp.
Abba bar Marta <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span>Abaye’s opinion from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not extinguish a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">piece of wood in order to save it </span>from being needlessly burned, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if </span>he extinguishes it <span class="gemarra-regular">so that the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">house or a pot not become smoky, it is permitted. </span>This shows that it is permitted to extinguish a fire on a Festival if it serves people’s needs. Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: That </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>who permits the performance of prohibited labors on a Festival for all of one’s needs and not only for the preparation of food; <span class="gemarra-regular">when I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">spoke, </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis, </span>who disagree.
Further on the topic of extinguishing, <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye raised a dilemma before Rabba: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to extinguishing a fire on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival? </span>He clarified his question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where there is danger to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">life, I have no dilemma, as </span>in that case <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted even on Shabbat. When I raised the dilemma</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it was with regard to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">involving </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> loss. What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">It is prohibited</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his </span>opinion from the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited above: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">extinguish a piece of wood in order to save it </span>from being needlessly burned, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if </span>he extinguishes it <span class="gemarra-regular">so</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that the house or a pot not become smoky, it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted. </span>This indicates that extinguishing a fire on a Festival is permitted even if only to prevent a small loss. Rabba replied: <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda; when I spoke, </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi raised a dilemma before Ameimar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">painting an ey</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> with a medicinal ointment <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival? </span>He elaborated on his question: <span class="gemarra-regular">Where there is a danger </span>to the eye, <span class="gemarra-regular">for example</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the illnesses called <span class="gemarra-italic">rira</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ditza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">dema</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-italic">dimata</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">kadaḥta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>or the <span class="gemarra-regular">beginning of an inflammation, I have</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> no dilemma, as </span>in such cases <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted </span>to apply an ointment <span class="gemarra-regular">even on Shabbat. When I raised the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dilemma, </span>it was with regard to less serious ailments, such as at the <span class="gemarra-regular">end of an inflammation, or </span>in order to <span class="gemarra-regular">brighten one’s eyesight. What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in such cases? Ameimar <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: It is prohibited</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
Rav Ashi <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection to him </span>from the same <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not extinguish a piece of wood </span>in order to save it from being needlessly burned, but if he extinguishes it so that the house or a pot not become smoky, it is permitted. This indicates that a prohibited labor is permitted on a Festival, if it is performed for the sake of a bodily need. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Ameimar <span class="gemarra-regular">answered him</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as we answered </span>before, that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda.
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar permitted painting an eye </span>for medicinal purposes <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shabbat by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile. Some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar himself painted </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">eye on Shabbat by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile. Rav Ashi said to Ameimar: What is your </span><span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning </span>in permitting this practice? You must rely upon that which <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla, son of Rav Ilai, said: All the needs</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of an ill person </span>whose life is not in danger <span class="gemarra-regular">are performed by means of a gentile on Shabbat. And</span> similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hamnuna said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any matter in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which there is no </span>life-threatening <span class="gemarra-regular">dange</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> but only potential illness, <span class="gemarra-regular">one says to the gentile </span>to perform the act, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the gentile <span class="gemarra-regular">performs </span>the act for him.
However, <span class="gemarra-regular">this applies </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the ill person, or any other Jew, <span class="gemarra-regular">does not assist </span>the gentile. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">the Master, </span>Ameimar, <span class="gemarra-regular">assists </span>the gentile while the ointment is being applied, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he closes and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> opens </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">eye, </span>thereby allowing the ointment to penetrate more deeply. Therefore, this should be prohibited. Ameimar <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Ashi: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is </span>also the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Zevid, who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> holds in accordance with your </span>opinion; he, too, raised the objection that it should be prohibited due to the fact that the Jew assists the gentile. <span class="gemarra-regular">And I </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">answered</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him: </span>The assistance provided by one who <span class="gemarra-regular">assists </span>another in performing a task that the other could essentially have performed himself <span class="gemarra-regular">is insubstantial</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Inasmuch as the action is primarily performed by the gentile, the minor assistance given by the Jew may be overlooked.
The Gemara further relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted painting an eye </span>with a medicinal ointment <span class="gemarra-regular">on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> second day of the festival of Rosh HaShana </span>if the eye is causing pain and requires treatment. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to Ameimar: But didn’t Rava say </span>that if a person <span class="gemarra-regular">died on the first day of a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, gentiles may attend to his </span>burial; if he died <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the second day of a Festival </span>observed in the Diaspora, <span class="gemarra-regular">Jews may attend to his </span>burial? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even on the second day of the festival of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rosh HaShana, </span>

Daf 22b

<span class="gemarra-regular">which is not so with regard to an egg. </span>With regard to an egg laid on a Festival, the two days of Rosh HaShana are considered one long day and a single period of sanctity. It was only in deference to the dead that the Sages were lenient with regard to burial on the second day of Rosh HaShana, but with regard to all other matters, the two days of Rosh HaShana are viewed as one day and are governed by the same <span class="it-text">halakha</span>.
Ameimar <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him: I hold in accordance with </span>the opinion of the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">of Neharde’a, who state </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to an egg </span>laid on the Festival and other matters, as there is no difference between the two days of Rosh HaShana and the two days of other Festivals. <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is your reasoning </span>that you are concerned? Is it that <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps they will extend </span>the month of <span class="gemarra-regular">Elul</span> and declare it a thirty-day month, which would mean that the second day of the Festival is the first of Tishrei, the true date of Rosh HaShana? But <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t Rav Ḥinnana bar Kahana say: From the days of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ezra and onward we have not found </span>that the month of <span class="gemarra-regular">Elul </span>was made <span class="gemarra-regular">a full, </span>thirty-day month, and therefore there is no cause for this concern.
§ It is taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not bake thick loaves </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">but only thin ones. The Sages taught </span>the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not bake </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thick bread on Passover</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it might become leavened before it has a chance to bake, <span class="gemarra-regular">whereas Beit Hillel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permit </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And how much </span>thickness renders a loaf <span class="gemarra-regular">thick </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bread </span>that is permitted by Beit Hillel? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: </span>It is up to a thickness of one <span class="gemarra-regular">handbreadth, as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we find likewise with regard to the shewbread </span>in the Temple, which must also be unleavened and which was one <span class="gemarra-regular">handbreadth </span>thick. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef strongly objects to this </span>argument of Rav Huna: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>this leniency <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span> the shewbread that is prepared by priests, who are <span class="gemarra-regular">vigilant</span> about the mitzvot and ensure that the dough is not leavened, would <span class="gemarra-regular">they say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>bread that is prepared by ordinary people, who are <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">vigilant? </span>Furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">if they said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span> the shewbread, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">well-kneaded [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">amela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bread, </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">they say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to bread that is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">well kneaded?</span>
Rav Yosef continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">If they stated </span>this leniency <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">dry wood, </span>which was used in the Temple, as it would burn well and bake the bread quickly, would <span class="gemarra-regular">they say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">moist wood</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is what most people use to heat their ovens? Furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">if they said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">hot oven </span>found in the Temple, would <span class="gemarra-regular">they say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>a standard <span class="gemarra-regular">oven, </span>which is typically <span class="gemarra-regular">cold </span>in comparison to that of the Temple? And lastly, <span class="gemarra-regular">if they said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the Temple’s <span class="gemarra-regular">metal oven, </span>which warms up quickly, would <span class="gemarra-regular">they say </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">earthenware oven </span>that most people use to bake their bread?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yirmeya bar Abba said: I asked </span><span class="gemarra-regular">my teacher in private, and who is </span>this teacher? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav. </span>Rav Yirmeya asked him: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">thick bread? </span>Rav explained that it means <span class="gemarra-regular">a large </span><span class="gemarra-regular">quantity </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">bread</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a large amount of dough prepared in a single session. The concern here is not that the bread might become leavened, but that its preparation involves unnecessary exertion on the Festival.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yirmeya bar Abba said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: I asked</span> this of <span class="gemarra-regular">my teacher in private; and who is </span>Rav’s teacher? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">our holy Rabb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span> Yehuda HaNasi. And he explained the matter as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of <span class="gemarra-regular">thick bread? </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">a large quantity </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">bread. And why do they call it thick bread? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is </span>greatly <span class="gemarra-regular">expanded at the </span>time of <span class="gemarra-regular">kneading </span>and therefore looks very thick. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, in the place </span><span class="gemarra-regular">where this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> of the mishna lived, <span class="gemarra-regular">a large quantity</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">bread was called thick bread.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, since </span>the prohibition here is <span class="gemarra-regular">because he exerts himself unnecessarily</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>did the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">specifically </span>with respect to <span class="gemarra-regular">Passover? </span>The same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> should apply <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">regard to the other Festivals as well. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, it is indeed so; </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is not limited to Passover. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> who taught this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">was dealing </span>at the time <span class="gemarra-regular">with the festival </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Passover</span> and therefore mentioned this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in relation to that Festival, even though it applies in equal fashion to the other Festivals. The Gemara comments that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: One may not bake a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> large quantity of bread on </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival, whereas Beit Hillel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permit </span>it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Rabban Gamliel <span class="gemarra-regular">also said three things as leniencies, </span>in opposition to the view of most of the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may sweep the room of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">couche</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> on a Festival, i.e., the dining room, where they would recline on couches to eat, as there is no concern that by sweeping the room one might come to fill in the holes and level the ground. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may place </span><span class="gemarra-regular">incense </span>consisting of fragrant herbs on burning coals in order to perfume one’s house <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival. And one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may prepare a whole kid </span>goat, meaning a kid goat roasted whole, with its entrails over its head, <span class="gemarra-regular">on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> night of Passover, </span>as was the custom when they roasted the Paschal lamb in the Temple. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prohibit </span>all three practices: It is prohibited to sweep lest one come to level the ground, it is prohibited to burn incense because it does not meet the criteria of permitted food preparation, and it is prohibited to eat a kid that was roasted whole on the night of Passover because it would appear as if he were eating consecrated food outside the Temple.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>with regard to incense applies only to a case where one wishes to burn the incense in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to perfume </span>his garments. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>if he burns the incense in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>enjoy the <span class="gemarra-regular">smell, all agree </span>that this is like other bodily pleasures, the satisfaction of which has the same status as food preparation, and it is therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted.</span>
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>against Rav Asi’s understanding of the mishna from the following <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not sweep the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> room of the couches on a Festival </span>lest he fill in holes and level the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the house</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rabban Gamliel they did sweep, </span>as they did not share this concern. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer bar Tzado</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: On </span><span class="gemarra-regular">many occasions I followed Father, </span>Rabbi Tzadok, <span class="gemarra-regular">into Rabban Gamliel’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s house, and </span>I observed that <span class="gemarra-regular">they would not </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">sweep the room of the couches on a Festival, but </span>rather they would do the following: <span class="gemarra-regular">They </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">sweep </span>the room <span class="gemarra-regular">on the eve of the Festival and spread sheets </span><span class="gemarra-regular">over it </span>so that it would not become dirty, and <span class="gemarra-regular">on the following day, when </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">guests entered, they removed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the sheets, and it turned out that the house was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cleaned on its own. </span>The other Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">If so, it is permitted to do so on Shabbat </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>and there is no dispute in that case. 
The <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> continues: Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not place incense </span>on burning coals <span class="gemarra-regular">on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival, but </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the house of Rabban Gamliel they did </span><span class="gemarra-regular">place </span>incense. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer bar Tzadok said: On many occasions </span><span class="gemarra-regular">I followed Father into Rabban Gamliel’s house, and </span>I noticed that <span class="gemarra-regular">they would not </span>actually <span class="gemarra-regular">place incense </span>on burning coals <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival, but </span>rather they would <span class="gemarra-regular">bring perforated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">coal pans [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ardaska’ot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> made of iron, filled them with </span>fragrant <span class="gemarra-regular">smoke on the eve of the Festival, and plugged </span><span class="gemarra-regular">their holes on the Festival eve </span>so that their fragrant smell would not escape. <span class="gemarra-regular">On the following day, when </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">guests entered, they opened the holes, </span>releasing the smell throughout the house, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it turned out that the house</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was perfumed on its own.</span>
The other Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If so, it is permitted</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to do so on Shabbat as well. </span>This shows that the issue was not the perfuming of clothes but rather the burning of incense for the smell in the house. It follows that the Sages prohibit the practice even when the incense is burned for the enjoyment of the smell, against the opinion of Rav Asi.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the Gemara retracts its previous statement and says that <span class="gemarra-regular">if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> this was stated, it was stated as follows: Rav Asi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said </span>that the <span class="gemarra-regular">dispute </span>with regard to incense applies only to a case where one burns the incense in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>enjoy the <span class="gemarra-regular">smell. However, </span>if he burns the incense in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to perfume </span>his garments, all agree that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">smokin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> fruit on a Festival with incense in order to enhance its aroma? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yirmeya bar Abba said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: It is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited, </span>as it is not included in the category of permitted food preparation. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel said: It is permitted. Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Huna said: It is prohibited because he extinguishes </span>some of the coals when he sprinkles the aromatic powder on them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said to him: And let the Master </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that it is prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">because he kindles </span>the coals, as afterward the fragrant spices cause the coals to burn even more strongly; why are you not concerned about this? Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Two prohibitions are indeed violated: <span class="gemarra-regular">Its beginning </span>involves <span class="gemarra-regular">extinguishing, and its end </span>involves <span class="gemarra-regular">kindling.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said: </span>Sprinkling the aromatic spices <span class="gemarra-regular">on the coals </span>themselves <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>for the aforementioned reasons. 

Daf 23a

However, placing them <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>a scalding fragment of <span class="gemarra-regular">earthenwar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted, </span>as there is no concern of extinguishing or kindling.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabba said: </span>Placing the spices <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>a hot piece of <span class="gemarra-regular">earthenware is also prohibited, because it produces</span> a new <span class="gemarra-regular">scent</span> in the earthenware, and one may not create new things on a Festival. The Gemara notes that similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yosef both said </span>the following: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is prohibited to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> overturn a cup </span>containing perfume <span class="gemarra-regular">onto silk garments on a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival. What is the reason </span>for this prohibition? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because it produces </span>a new <span class="gemarra-regular">scent </span>in the garment.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this case <span class="gemarra-regular">different from </span>the case discussed in the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may press </span>a piece of aromatic wood between his fingers <span class="gemarra-regular">and smell it, and one may </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">snip off </span>a piece of it in order to release its fragrance <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> smell it? </span>In those cases too he produces a scent. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, the scent exists in any case</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and he </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">adds to the fragrance, </span>as his pressing or snipping causes the smell to be stronger. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>on the other hand, where he overturns a cup of perfume on clothing, <span class="gemarra-regular">he produces </span>a new <span class="gemarra-regular">scent. Rava, </span>however, <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">even permitted </span>to sprinkle the aromatic spices <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">coal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> themselves, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as it is </span>permitted to place <span class="gemarra-regular">meat on coals </span>for roasting.
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Geviha from Bei </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Katil </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">taught at the entrance to the house of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Exilarch </span>that <span class="gemarra-italic">ketura</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted </span>on a Festival; but he did not add any further clarification. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: What is </span>the meaning of <span class="gemarra-italic">ketura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If </span>it means <span class="gemarra-regular">tying </span>[<span class="gemarra-italic">ketura</span>] ornamental knots <span class="gemarra-regular">by hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> this is the <span class="gemarra-regular">act of a craftsman </span>and is therefore certainly prohibited on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to burning </span>incense [<span class="it-text">ketoret</span>], this too is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited, as he extinguishes </span>some of the coals when he sprinkles the aromatic powder on them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said to him: Actually, </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to burning </span>incense, which is permitted, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as it is </span>permitted to place <span class="gemarra-regular">meat on coals </span>for roasting.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>a slightly different version of this story, in which <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>Rav Geviha: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of <span class="gemarra-italic">ketura</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it means <span class="gemarra-regular">tying </span>ornamental knots <span class="gemarra-regular">by hand, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the act of a craftsman, </span>which is prohibited. <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to burning </span>incense, this too is prohibited, <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he produces a </span>new <span class="gemarra-regular">scent. Rav Ashi said: I said </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> to Rav Geviha, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I said </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the name of a great man, </span>Rava, that <span class="gemarra-regular">actually </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to burning </span>incense, which is permitted, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>permitted to place <span class="gemarra-regular">meat on coals </span>for roasting. 
§ It is taught in the mishna that one of Rabban Gamliel’s three leniencies was that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may prepare a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whole [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mekulas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ki</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> goat, meaning a goat roasted whole, with its entrails over its head, on the night of Passover. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in this regard that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: Theodosius [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">Todos</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rome, </span>leader of the Jewish community there, <span class="gemarra-regular">instituted the custom for the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Roman </span>Jews <span class="gemarra-regular">to eat whole kids on the night of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Passover, </span>in commemoration of the practice followed in the Temple. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">sent </span>a message <span class="gemarra-regular">to him: Were you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not Theodosius</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> an important person, <span class="gemarra-regular">we would have decreed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ostracism upon you, as you are feeding the Jewish people </span><span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>food, which may be eaten only in and around the Temple itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">outside </span>the Temple. 
The Gemara expresses surprise: <span class="gemarra-regular">Can it enter your mind </span>that the Sages really meant that Theodosius was feeding the Jewish people <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>food outside the Temple? These goats are certainly not consecrated animals. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, say </span>that he was feeding the Jewish people something <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to consecrated </span>food, which people might mistake for a Paschal offering.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> There are <span class="gemarra-regular">three things </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Azary</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">permits and the Rabbis prohibit: His cow </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">go</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">ou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a decorative <span class="gemarra-regular">stra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">between its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> horns. </span>Rabbi Elazar holds that such a strap is considered an ornament for the cow rather than a burden, whereas the Sages view it as a burden.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may comb [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mekardin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an anima</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> with a fine comb <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival </span>in order to remove ticks and dirt from its hair; the Rabbis prohibit this due to a concern that he might thereby come to wound or bruise the animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may grind peppe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> needed on the Festival even <span class="gemarra-regular">in its </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">mill, </span>although this appears similar to a weekday labor.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: One may not comb an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">animal </span>to remove ticks and dirt from its hair <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival because </span>this certainly <span class="gemarra-regular">creates a wound, but one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may brush </span>it with a wooden comb, as its blunt teeth do not wound the animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Rabbis say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">One may not comb, nor may one even brush.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the mishna’s statement that Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya’s cow would go out on Shabbat with a strap between its horns, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that to say that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya had </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">one cow? But didn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t Rav say, and some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya would </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tith</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from his herds thirteen thousand calves each and every year, </span>which means that he had ten times that number of calves alone. Why, then, does the mishna speak of his cow? The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>: This cow <span class="gemarra-regular">was not his; rather, it was his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> neighbor’s. And because he did not protest her </span>conduct and tell her that it is prohibited to do so, the cow <span class="gemarra-regular">was called by his name </span>to his discredit, as if it were his. 
§ It is taught in the mishna that Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may comb an animal on a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">combing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and what is brushing? Combing </span>is performed with <span class="gemarra-regular">a small</span>-toothed comb <span class="gemarra-regular">and makes a wound; brushing </span>is done with <span class="gemarra-regular">a large</span>-toothed comb <span class="gemarra-regular">and does not make a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wound.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And there are three disputes with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">matter. Rabbi Yehuda holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an unintentional act, </span>a permitted action from which an unintended prohibited labor ensues on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited, </span>as in his opinion it is prohibited to perform an action that involves a prohibited labor on Shabbat even if one has a permitted action in mind and does not intend to perform the labor in question. Therefore, one may not comb an animal in a manner that will cause a wound, even unintentionally. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>he differentiates between the cases: Although he prohibits <span class="gemarra-regular">combing </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> small</span>-toothed comb that <span class="gemarra-regular">makes a wound, </span>he permits <span class="gemarra-regular">brushing</span> with <span class="gemarra-regular">a large</span>-toothed comb that <span class="gemarra-regular">does not make a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wound, and we do not issue a decree </span>and prohibit <span class="gemarra-regular">brushing due to combing, </span>as there is no concern that people will err and come to permit even combing in the prohibited manner. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis also</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hold in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda </span>with regard to the fundamental issue that <span class="gemarra-regular">an unintentional act is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prohibited. </span>However, they maintain that <span class="gemarra-regular">we issue a decree </span>and prohibit <span class="gemarra-regular">brushing due to combing. </span>On the other hand, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya holds in accordance with </span>the dissenting opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, who said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an unintentional act </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">both combing and brushing are permitted, </span>as even if the combing or brushing bruises the animal, there is no transgression of a prohibition, as there was certainly no intention to cause the animal a wound. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said, and some</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said </span>this teaching <span class="gemarra-regular">himself: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that an unintentional act is permitted on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya agrees with him. Rava said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Naḥman: And let the Master say </span>the opposite, that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, as the Rabbis agree with him. </span>Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Fundamentally <span class="gemarra-regular">I hold in accordance with</span> the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon; </span>I am merely adding <span class="gemarra-regular">another</span> reason for doing so, which is <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Elazar ben</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Azarya agrees with him. </span>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span>aforementioned <span class="gemarra-regular">pepper mil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> is a composite vessel, and each of its parts must be considered independently with respect to ritual impurity. It <span class="gemarra-regular">is susceptible to ritual impurity because of </span>each of the <span class="gemarra-regular">three vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of which it is comprised: It is susceptible to impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it is a wooden <span class="gemarra-regular">receptacle, </span>it is susceptible to impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a metal </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>it is susceptible to impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a sieve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> A Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">lower </span>section of the mill is susceptible to impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it is viewed as <span class="gemarra-regular">a receptacle, </span>since the ground pepper descends into it. <span class="gemarra-regular">The middle </span>section is susceptible to impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a sieve, </span>as it serves to filter the pepper. Finally, the <span class="gemarra-regular">upper </span>part, in which the pepper is actually ground, is susceptible to impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">a metal vessel. </span>Although it is not a receptacle, it is nevertheless susceptible to impurity, since it is made of metal.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A child’s </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wagon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> with which he plays and upon which he also sits, <span class="gemarra-regular">is susceptible to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ritual impurity </span>imparted by <span class="gemarra-regular">treading</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> It is considered a fixed seat of the child, so that if the child is a <span class="it-text">zav</span> and he sits on the wagon, it contracts the ritual impurity imparted by the treading of a <span class="it-text">zav</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this wagon <span class="gemarra-regular">may be handled on Shabbat, </span>as it is considered a vessel. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it may be dragged </span>on the ground on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">only upon cloth, </span>a stone pavement, or the like, as otherwise it would create a furrow when dragged, and one would be liable due to the prohibited labor of plowing.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yehuda says: </span>For this reason, <span class="gemarra-regular">no vessels may be dragged </span>on the ground on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">except for a wagon, </span>which is permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>its wheels do not make a furrow in the ground but merely <span class="gemarra-regular">press </span>the earth down. Since no earth is moved from its place, this is not considered digging or plowing on Shabbat. 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> It is taught in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> child’s wagon is susceptible to ritual impurity </span>imparted by <span class="gemarra-regular">treading. </span>Why? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because he leans on it. </span>The mishna also teaches that this wagon <span class="gemarra-regular">may be handled on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shabbat. </span>Why? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because it has the status of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a vessel, </span>and one may handle a vessel on Shabbat. 
The mishna further teaches that a child’s wagon <span class="gemarra-regular">may be dragged </span>on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">only upon cloth. </span>The Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Upon cloth, yes, </span>it is permitted; but directly <span class="gemarra-regular">on the ground, no, </span>it is not permitted. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because he creates a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">furrow</span> in the ground when he drags the wagon across it. The Gemara asks: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion is this mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">It</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: An unintentional act, </span>i.e., a permitted action from which an unintended prohibited labor ensues on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited, </span>even though the person performing it does not have the prohibited labor in mind.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As, if </span>it were in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, didn’t </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he say: An unintentional act is permitted, </span>since there was no intention to perform the prohibited action? <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned</span> explicitly in a mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: A person</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may drag a bed, a chair, or a bench </span>on the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">provided that he does not intend to make</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a furrow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Even if one forms a furrow unwittingly, he need one need not be concerned, as this was not his intention.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">say the latter clause </span>of the mishna as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: No vessels may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be dragged </span>on the ground <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat except for a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wagon, because it </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">presses </span>the earth down. This is not prohibited as plowing because it does not create a furrow. This indicates that a wagon may be dragged on the ground on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">because, yes, it presses </span>the earth down, <span class="gemarra-regular">but it does not make a furrow. </span>Since it has already been established that the first section of the mishna is also in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, and there it appears that a wagon dragged along the ground makes a furrow, Rabbi Yehuda seems to contradict himself. 
The Gemara answers: It must be explained that this is a dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span> who hold <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>but differ with regard to the content of that opinion. The first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> holds that even a wagon makes a furrow, whereas the other <span class="it-text">tanna</span> maintains in the name of Rabbi Yehuda that a wagon does not make a furrow.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">pond</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival </span>even with the intention of eating them, as this falls into the category of hunting, a type of labor that is not permitted on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">Nor may one place food before them, </span>as it is not his duty to feed them; rather, they maintain themselves by eating smaller fish or different types of algae that grow in the water.
<span class="gemarra-regular">However, one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may trap an animal or a bird from </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">enclosures</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">beivarim</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they are viewed as already captured, and therefore the action is not considered an act of hunting. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">place food before the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> as one does for other household animals.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Not all </span><span class="gemarra-regular">enclosures are identical </span>with respect to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of hunting. <span class="gemarra-regular">This is the principle: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>animal

Daf 24a
