inside such an enclosure <span class="gemarra-regular">whose trapping is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">inadequate, </span>meaning that the enclosure is large and contains hiding places so that it is still necessary to pursue and apprehend the animal, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited </span>for one to catch it; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>with regard to any animal <span class="gemarra-regular">whose trapping is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not inadequate, </span>as it is possible to seize it immediately without having to engage in further pursuit, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted </span>for one to catch it.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>the Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>from what is stated in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">From enclosures of animals and of birds, one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may not trap </span>animals or birds <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival, nor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may one place food before them. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult </span>due to a contradiction between the ruling with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">animal </span>in the mishna and the ruling with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>. This is similarly <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult </span>due to a contradiction between the ruling with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">birds </span>in the mishna and the ruling with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">birds </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>.
The Gemara resolves the first contradiction: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, </span>with regard to the contradiction between the ruling concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal </span>in the mishna and the ruling concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">this, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that prohibits trapping and feeding animals in the enclosures, is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>who holds that an animal trapped in an enclosure whose trapping is inadequate, i.e., it is still necessary to pursue and apprehend the animal, is not considered trapped, and therefore one may not trap it from the enclosure on a Festival. Whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">that, </span>the mishna that permits trapping and feeding the animals in the enclosures, is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>who maintain that an animal in an enclosure is considered trapped, and therefore removing it from there is not considered an act of hunting.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: One who </span>drives and <span class="gemarra-regular">traps</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a bird into a closet or a deer into a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> house is liable. </span>The Gemara infers from this: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is</span> only if he traps the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">into a house that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he is liable, but </span>if he traps it <span class="gemarra-regular">into an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> enclosure, </span>he is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>liable. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: </span>One is liable for trapping <span class="gemarra-regular">a bird into a closet, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>for trapping <span class="gemarra-regular">a deer into a garden, or into </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard, or into an enclosure. </span>This demonstrates that according to the Rabbis, an animal found inside an enclosure is regarded as already captured, whereas Rabbi Yehuda disagrees. From this it follows that Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis similarly disagree about catching an animal inside an enclosure and removing it from there on a Festival. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>concerning the contradiction between the ruling with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">birds </span>in the mishna and the ruling with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">birds </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>as all agree that they may not be caught, even in one’s house. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>contradiction is <span class="gemarra-regular">also not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">difficult, </span>because <span class="gemarra-regular">this, </span>the mishna that permits trapping, is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a roofed enclosure, </span>in which a bird is considered captured, and therefore there is no prohibition against apprehending it on a Festival, and <span class="gemarra-regular">that, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that prohibits trapping, is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">an unroofe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> enclosure, </span>in which a bird is not considered trapped and apprehending it is prohibited, that does not resolve the contradiction. 
The Gemara explains why the proposed resolution must be rejected: <span class="gemarra-regular">As</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a house, which is like a roofed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> enclosure, </span>there is no dispute. <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to both Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda and the Rabbis, a bird </span>trapped <span class="gemarra-regular">into a closet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, yes, </span>it is considered trapped, while a bird <span class="gemarra-regular">into a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> house, no, </span>it is not considered trapped. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Rav Huna said: Here, </span>in the mishna, according to which a bird in a house is not considered trapped, <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing with a free</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bird, </span>a sparrow, <span class="gemarra-regular">which does not accept authority. </span>That bird is not intimidated and evades capture even in a house. <span class="gemarra-regular">As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Why is it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> called a free </span>[<span class="gemarra-italic">dror</span>] <span class="gemarra-regular">bird</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Because it dwells</span> [<span class="gemarra-italic">dara</span>] <span class="gemarra-regular">in a house as it does in a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">field, </span>flittering from place to place. For this reason, it is not considered captured when it is inside a house. Therefore, the distinction between a roofed and an unroofed enclosure resolves the apparent contradiction between the mishna and the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>. 
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that you have arrived at this </span>understanding, that the difference between the rulings in the two sources is predicated on different circumstances and not on a tannaitic dispute, the apparent contradiction between the ruling with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal </span>in the mishna and the ruling with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">also not difficult. This, </span>the ruling in the mishna that permits apprehending the animal, is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a small enclosure, </span>in which the animal cannot evade its pursuers and requires no further trapping. <span class="gemarra-regular">That, </span>the ruling in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> that prohibits apprehending the animal, is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">a large enclosure, </span>from which the animal cannot escape, but it can still avoid being caught.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the circumstances </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a small enclosure, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">what are the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">circumstances </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">a large enclosure? Rav Ashi said: Any </span>enclosure <span class="gemarra-regular">where one can run after </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and reach it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in one stoo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">a small enclosure. And </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">other </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a large enclosure. Or perhaps, any </span>enclosure <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">has a series of corners </span>in which the animal could hide and evade capture is <span class="gemarra-regular">a large enclosure, and </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">other </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a small enclosure. Or perhaps, any </span>enclosure <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the shadows from the </span>different <span class="gemarra-regular">walls fall upon each other, </span>because the walls are close together, is <span class="gemarra-regular">a small enclosure</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">other, </span>a larger area where the walls are further apart, is <span class="gemarra-regular">a large enclosure.</span>
§ It was taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ben Gamliel says: Not all enclosures are identical. </span>If the animal is inadequately trapped in the enclosure, it is prohibited for one to catch it; whereas if it is adequately trapped, he is permitted to do so. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Shimon ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Gamliel. Abaye said to </span>Rav Yosef: If one rules that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is in accordance with his opinion, does that mean <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference </span>that the Rabbis <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> or perhaps there is no dispute and everyone accepts the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel?
Rav Yosef <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: And what difference is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there to you </span>whether or not the Rabbis disagree? In either case the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. Why then does it matter whether or not the issue was in dispute? Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him, </span>invoking a folk expression with regard to one who learns without reaching understanding: Is it simply <span class="gemarra-regular">learn the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lesson; </span>let <span class="gemarra-regular">it be </span>like <span class="gemarra-regular">a song</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> In other words, is it sufficient to simply parrot the halakhic ruling? Rather, it is necessary to examine the issue to understand it even if it does not yield a practical halakhic difference. 
It was further taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is the principle: Any </span>animal inside such an enclosure <span class="gemarra-regular">whose trapping is inadequate </span>may not be caught and removed from there on a Festival, whereas any animal whose trapping is not inadequate may be apprehended and removed from there. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances </span>of an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">whose trapping is inadequate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yosef said</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: Any </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to which one would say: Bring a trap so</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that we may catch it, </span>as the animal cannot be apprehended without the aid of a trap.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: But aren’t geese and chickens</span> that are loose in a courtyard creatures <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> which one would say: Bring a trap so that we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may catch it, </span>as they freely roam about and evade capture? <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who traps geese, chickens, or domestic dove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they are considered already trapped.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Rav Huna said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>There is a difference between the two cases: <span class="gemarra-regular">These, </span>the geese and chickens, <span class="gemarra-regular">enter their coop in the evening </span>and use it as their fixed dwelling place and are therefore considered trapped, <span class="gemarra-regular">while these </span>animals in the enclosure <span class="gemarra-regular">do not enter their</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> coop in the evening </span>and therefore flee from those trying to seize them.
The Gemara challenges this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">But don’t doves of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> dovecote and doves of a loft enter their coop in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the evening, and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who traps doves of a dovecote, doves of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> loft, or birds that are nesting in pitcher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">buildings is liable </span>for their capture, although they enter their coop in the evening? 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rabba </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Rav Huna said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>A distinction can be made as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">These, </span>the geese and chickens, <span class="gemarra-regular">enter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">their coop in the evening, and </span>providing them with <span class="gemarra-regular">their </span><span class="gemarra-regular">feed is your </span>responsibility. They are therefore accustomed to their owners and considered as trapped. <span class="gemarra-regular">Whereas these, </span>the doves of a dovecote and the other birds mentioned in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, admittedly <span class="gemarra-regular">enter their coop in the evening, but feeding them </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is not your </span>responsibility. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari said </span>an alternative distinction: <span class="gemarra-regular">These, </span>the doves of a dovecote, <span class="gemarra-regular">are likely </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to flee </span>from people, and therefore require trapping, <span class="gemarra-regular">while these, </span>the geese, chickens, and domestic doves, <span class="gemarra-regular">are not likely to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">flee </span>from them. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">All of them are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> also likely to flee </span>when being pursued, even chickens. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>meant to <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are likely</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to flee to their coop. </span>In other words, even when they reach their coop they do not remain still but continue in their attempts to escape, and are therefore not considered trapped. 
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <span class="gemarra-regular">traps for animals, birds, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">were set on the eve of a Festival, one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not take </span>anything <span class="gemarra-regular">from them on the Festival, unless</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he knows that </span>the animals found in the traps <span class="gemarra-regular">had</span> already <span class="gemarra-regular">been caught on the eve of the Festival. And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an incident </span>is related <span class="gemarra-regular">where a certain gentile brought fish</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to Rabban Gamliel, and </span>the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The fish <span class="gemarra-regular">are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted, but I do not wish to accept </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as I despise him.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara raises a question about the story involving Rabban Gamliel. Was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident </span>cited above <span class="gemarra-regular">to contradict </span>a previously stated <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? The mishna first teaches that one may not eat an animal caught on a Festival, and then relates an incident in which Rabban Gamliel ruled that this is permitted. The Gemara answers: The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete; </span>it is missing an important element, <span class="gemarra-regular">and it teaches the following: </span>Even in a case where it is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertain </span>whether or not the animal was <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>before the Festival, as it is unclear whether it was caught today or on the previous day, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabban Gamliel permits </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And an incident </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>related <span class="gemarra-regular">where a certain gentile brought fish to Rabban Gamliel, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The fish <span class="gemarra-regular">are permitted, but I </span><span class="gemarra-regular">do not wish to accept </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">from him. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Gamliel. Some teach this </span>halakhic ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught: </span>With regard to something about which <span class="gemarra-regular">an uncertainty </span>exists whether or not it was <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>before the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabban Gamliel permits </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua prohibits </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua. And </span>others <span class="gemarra-regular">teach it in reference to this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught: </span>

Daf 24b

<span class="gemarra-regular">One may slaughter </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>pens containing <span class="gemarra-regular">pool</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of drinking water <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival, but not from </span>those found caught in <span class="gemarra-regular">nets or </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">traps</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they may have been caught on the Festival itself. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Elazar says: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">he came and found </span>the nets and traps <span class="gemarra-regular">out of order on the eve of the Festival, </span>which indicates that an animal had been caught in them, then <span class="gemarra-regular">it is known that </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">were caught on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the eve of the Festival, and they are </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted. </span>However, if he checked the nets and traps shortly before the onset of the Festival and found them intact, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">came and found them out of order on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is known that </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">were</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> caught on the Festival, and they are </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited.</span>
The Gemara poses a question: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">itself </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult </span>because it contains an internal contradiction between its clauses: <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span> that if <span class="gemarra-regular">he came and found them out of order</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the eve of the Festival, it is known that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they were caught on the eve of the Festival. The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> reason </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that he came and found them out of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> order, but </span>if there is <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty, </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. </span>But <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>of that same <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">he came and found them out of order</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the Festival, it is known that they were caught</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the Festival. The reason </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">that he came and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> found them out of order, but </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty, </span>the assumption is that <span class="gemarra-regular">they were caught on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> eve of the Festival and are permitted. </span>
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is what </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: If he came and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">found them out of order on the eve of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival, it is known that they were caught on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eve of the Festival, and they are permitted. But </span>in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">uncertainty, it is considered as if they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">were caught on the Festival, and they are prohibited</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar. </span>All these versions of Shmuel’s ruling are basically in agreement: In a case of uncertainty as to whether or not an item was prepared before the Festival, it is prohibited. 
§ It was stated in the mishna that Rabban Gamliel <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that the fish brought to him on the Festival by the gentile <span class="gemarra-regular">are permitted. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Permitted </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for wha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> purpose? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: They are permitted to be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> received </span>and moved, but they may not be eaten. <span class="gemarra-regular">Levi said: They are </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted to be eaten. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: A </span><span class="gemarra-regular">person should never prevent himself from </span>attending <span class="gemarra-regular">the study hall </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for even one moment, </span>and the proof is from this issue; <span class="gemarra-regular">as Levi and I were before Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">when he stated this </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. In the evening he said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">They are permitted to be eaten, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>following <span class="gemarra-regular">morning </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he said: They are permitted </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">to be received. I, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who was in the study hall </span>in the morning as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">retracted </span>what I said, and taught the matter in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s second opinion. <span class="gemarra-regular">Levi, who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was not in the study hall </span>in the morning, <span class="gemarra-regular">did </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not retract </span>his statement.
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile brought a gift [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">doron</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Jew </span>on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">even moist [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mefulamin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fis</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or produce from that </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">day, they are permitted. Granted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, according to the one who said they are permitted to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be received, it is well; </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is understandable. <span class="gemarra-regular">However</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, according to the one who said they are permitted to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be eaten, is produce from that </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">day permitted to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be eaten? </span>If it was picked from the tree on that day, it is subject to the prohibition of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. 
The Gemara responds with a counter-question: <span class="gemarra-regular">And according to your reasoning, is produce </span>picked <span class="gemarra-regular">on that</span> same <span class="gemarra-regular">day permitted to be moved? </span>Why, then, is it obvious to you that the produce is permitted to be received? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it must be explained that <span class="gemarra-regular">we are dealing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with fish whose </span>gills <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">re</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">produce that is preserved in greens, </span>not with produce that was actually picked on that day. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">is it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">called </span>produce <span class="gemarra-regular">of that </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">day? Because it is </span>fresh and <span class="gemarra-regular">similar to </span>produce picked <span class="gemarra-regular">on that </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">day. </span>Such produce is permitted not only to be moved, but even to be eaten. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> in this regard <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>as follows: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a gentile who brought a gift to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a Je</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if there is of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that species </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">attached </span>to a tree or the ground, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited </span>to be eaten, as it may be assumed that the gentile picked it that same day. <span class="gemarra-regular">And in the evening as well, </span>after the conclusion of the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited for </span>the period of <span class="gemarra-regular">time</span> needed <span class="gemarra-regular">for its preparation, </span>i.e., the period of time necessary to detach it from the tree or the ground, as one may not derive benefit from a prohibited labor that was performed on a Festival on behalf of a Jew. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if none</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of that species is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">attached </span>to the ground, then if the gift was brought from <span class="gemarra-regular">within the limit,</span> i.e., the distance one may travel on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted, </span>as no prohibited labor has been performed. 

Daf 25a

If, however, the gift was brought from <span class="gemarra-regular">outside the limit, it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited. And </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">that came </span>from outside the limit <span class="gemarra-regular">for one Jew is permitted to another Jew</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> No prohibition applies to the second recipient, as the gentile’s intention was not fulfilled. Since the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of limits is a rabbinic prohibition, the Sages decreed that the object is prohibited only to the one on behalf of whom it was brought, but not to others. 
§ The Gemara continues its discussion about trapping animals on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Huna said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">one dammed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a water channe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> that was used to irrigate a field <span class="gemarra-regular">on the eve of a Festival, and the following day</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he arose and found fish in it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> they are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted. </span>These fish presumably arrived with the water before the Festival and were unable to escape, as the channel had been obstructed. Therefore, the fish are considered as having been prepared before the Festival.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: From </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">statement</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of our teacher, </span>Rav, <span class="gemarra-regular">we learn </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an undomesticated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">animal that nested in an orchard </span>near one’s house <span class="gemarra-regular">does not require </span>special <span class="gemarra-regular">designation </span>but is considered prepared. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥman said </span>in response to this conclusion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Our colleague, </span>Rav Ḥisda, <span class="gemarra-regular">has fallen upon a great </span>matter, i.e., an issue that is not at all straightforward but is the subject of various disagreements. <span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>a slightly different version of this statement, that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Rav Huna said: From</span> this <span class="gemarra-regular">statement of our teacher, </span>Rav, <span class="gemarra-regular">we learn </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">an undomesticated animal that nested in an orchard does not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">require </span>special <span class="gemarra-regular">designation, </span>and with regard to this statement, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥman said </span>that Rabba, <span class="gemarra-regular">son of our colleague, </span>Rav Huna, <span class="gemarra-regular">has fallen upon a great </span>matter. Rav Huna was a contemporary of Rav Naḥman’s, and they were both students of Rav; consequently, Rav Naḥman referred to Rav Huna as his colleague and called Rabba the son of his colleague.
Rav Naḥman explains the difference between the cases: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case where the undomesticated animal nested in an orchard, the person <span class="gemarra-regular">performed no </span><span class="gemarra-regular">action </span>at all, as the animal came of its own accord, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case where he dammed the water channel, <span class="gemarra-regular">he performed an action </span>when he blocked the water from leaving the channel. 
Rav Naḥman concludes his challenge: <span class="gemarra-regular">And does </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">not require </span>further <span class="gemarra-regular">designation? Isn’t it taugh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> explicitly in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">An undomesticated animal that nested in an orchard requires designation. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">a free bird</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one is required </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to tie its wings so that it will not be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mistaken for its mother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., so that he not take a different bird, such as its mother, in its place. <span class="gemarra-regular">And this </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">a testimony that was reported </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Shemaya and Avtalyon. </span>The Gemara comments: Indeed, this is <span class="gemarra-regular">a conclusive refutation </span>of the Sages who drew an inference from Rav’s statement.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Does </span>an undomesticated animal in an orchard really <span class="gemarra-regular">require designation? But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Beit Shammai and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel concede </span>with regard to doves and the like <span class="gemarra-regular">that one had designated </span>on the eve of a Festival when they were <span class="gemarra-regular">inside the nest, and </span>on the Festival itself <span class="gemarra-regular">he found </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">in front of the nest, that </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">are prohibited, </span>as these doves might not be the same ones that he had designated but rather others that came from somewhere else? <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to doves of a dovecote, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">doves of a loft</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and birds nesting in pitchers </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or in a building. However, geese, chicken, domestic doves, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an undomesticated animal that nested in an orchard are permitted </span>in all cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they do not require designation </span>in advance. In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a free bird, one is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">required to tie its wings so that it is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mistaken for its mother.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">those </span>birds <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>wings <span class="gemarra-regular">were tied </span>as a sign, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">those that were shaken </span>in advance in order to designate them for the Festival, if they were <span class="gemarra-regular">in cisterns, in houses, in trenches, or in caves, they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are permitted </span>on the Festival. However, if they were <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">trees, they are prohibited, lest one climb up </span>the tree <span class="gemarra-regular">and detach </span>something from it, which is prohibited. <span class="gemarra-regular">And those </span>birds <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>wings <span class="gemarra-regular">were tied </span>by another, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">those </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that were shake</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> by another <span class="gemarra-regular">are prohibited in all places</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>even not on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">stealing. </span>Tying or shaking is considered an act of acquisition, and therefore others may not take them. In any case, this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> clearly states that an undomesticated animal that nested in an orchard does not require designation.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥman said: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which teaches that an animal nesting in an orchard is permitted even without designation, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to it, </span>a young animal that cannot escape; whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which states that designation is required, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to its mother, </span>which is larger and can escape. The Gemara asks: But is mere <span class="gemarra-regular">designation </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sufficient for its mother? </span>Doesn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">it require complete capture, </span>as it is an undomesticated animal? 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">both this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one are referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to it, </span>a young animal that is unable to escape, and the difference between them is as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which does not require designation, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a garden </span>situated <span class="gemarra-regular">near </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the city, </span>so that one knows precisely where the animal is located and he can take it at any time. <span class="gemarra-regular">T</span><span class="gemarra-regular">hat </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>, which requires designation, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">garden that is not </span>located <span class="gemarra-regular">nearby. </span>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">in dange</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of dying, in which case its meat would be prohibited as the animal had not been properly slaughtered, and one wishes to slaughter it in the hope that it will be found fit for eating and he will be spared a loss, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not slaughter </span>it on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">unless there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">time in the day </span>for him <span class="gemarra-regular">to eat</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an olive-bulk of roasted mea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>the animal, so that it is possible to say that he slaughtered the animal for the sake of the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: </span>There need not be enough time for him to roast it; rather, it is sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if there is only time to eat <span class="gemarra-regular">an olive-bulk of raw </span>meat <span class="gemarra-regular">from the place where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is slaughtered, </span>i.e., from its neck, without going to the trouble of removing its hide and roasting it.
If <span class="gemarra-regular">one slaughtered </span>an animal on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">in the field</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not bring it </span>to his house <span class="gemarra-regular">on a pol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a set of poles </span>carried by two people, as this appears similar to a weekday activity. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>he must alter his usual weekday manner of performing this action <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bring </span>it in <span class="gemarra-regular">by hand, limb by limb. </span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Abba </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The mitzva of <span class="gemarra-regular">flaying and cutting </span>the animal into pieces is mentioned in the Torah with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">burnt-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and the same is true for butchers. </span>That is to say, we learn from the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of the burnt offering that a butcher should first remove the hide and cut the animal into pieces. <span class="gemarra-regular">From here the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Torah taught </span>proper <span class="gemarra-regular">etiquette</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that a person should not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eat meat before flaying and cutting </span>the animal into pieces. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>new <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>Rami bar Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching us? If we say </span>that he wishes <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude</span> the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Huna, </span>there is a difficulty, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Huna said: An animal, while alive, retains its presumptive</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> status of </span>being subject to the <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibition </span>against eating a limb from a living creature, and it retains that status after slaughter <span class="gemarra-regular">until it becomes known to you how it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was slaughtered. </span>As long as it has not yet been clarified that the animal was slaughtered properly, it is presumed to be prohibited. 
However, once the animal has been <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered </span>properly, <span class="gemarra-regular">it retains its presumptive status</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of being permitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> until it becomes known to you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">how it became a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>an animal suffering from a wound or illness that would cause it to die within twelve months, which is prohibited to be eaten even after ritual slaughter. There is no need to conduct a special examination of the animal to determine if it had a defect or illness, as it is presumed to be permitted. Even if a defect is found, this does not necessarily render the animal a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>, as one can say that it appeared only after the animal was slaughtered. 
One might have understood from Rami bar Abba’s statement that he disagrees with Rav Huna and requires that the animal be examined. However, this is difficult, as <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t we learn </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna? As we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Akiva says: </span>It is sufficient <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if there is only time to eat <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">olive-bulk of raw </span>meat <span class="gemarra-regular">from the place where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is slaughtered. What, is it not </span>referring to meat <span class="gemarra-regular">from the actual place where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is slaughtered, </span>from which it follows that one need not remove the hide or examine the animal?
The Gemara rejects this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>the mishna can be understood as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">From the place where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughters its food, </span>i.e., from its intestines, where digestion takes place. The hide must still be removed and the animal must be examined before it can be eaten. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya teach: From </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the actual place where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is slaughtered? Rather, </span>the Gemara rejects the previous explanation and says that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Abba</span>

Daf 25b

merely <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us</span> proper <span class="gemarra-regular">etiquette, </span>even though no prohibition is involved.
§ The Sages teach proper manners unconnected to any prohibition, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">not ea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> garlic or onions </span>from the side of <span class="gemarra-regular">its head, </span>i.e., its roots, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>rather <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the side of <span class="gemarra-regular">its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> leaves</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And if he did eat </span>in that manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>gives the appearance of being <span class="gemarra-regular">a glutton. Similarly, a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> person </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">not drink his cup </span>of wine all <span class="gemarra-regular">at</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> once, and if he did drink </span>in this manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span> gives the appearance of being <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span>greedy <span class="gemarra-regular">drinker. The Sages</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in this regard: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who drinks his cup </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">at once is a </span>greedy <span class="gemarra-regular">drinker; </span>if he does so <span class="gemarra-regular">in two </span>swallows, this is proper <span class="gemarra-regular">etiquette; </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>swallows, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">of haughty spirit, </span>as he presents himself as overly delicate and refined.
Apropos the previous discussion, the Gemara notes that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Abba </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">said: The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sea squill</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a plant from the lily family whose roots project deep into the ground, will <span class="gemarra-regular">cut of</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span> <span class="gemarra-regular">the feet of the wicked </span>in the future on the Day of Judgment. It was customary to plant sea squill on the edges of fields as boundary markers because their roots grow straight down without spreading out. Those who overstepped boundaries and infringed upon their neighbor’s property should have heeded the markers and desisted. 
Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">young tree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will cut</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> off the feet of butcher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and those who have </span><span class="gemarra-regular">relations with menstruating women. </span>After a tree is planted, one must wait three years before eating its fruit. This should serve as a lesson for those butchers who hasten to eat of the animal’s meat before removing its hide, and for those who have relations with their menstruating wives and do not wait for them to achieve ritual purification. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">The lupine [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">turmus</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> an extremely bitter legume that is edible only after an extensive process, <span class="gemarra-regular">will cut of</span><span class="gemarra-regular">f </span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the feet of the enemies of the Jewish people, </span>a euphemism for the Jewish people themselves. <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is stated</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: “And the children of Israel continued to do evil in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the eyes of the Lord, and served the Baalim and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Ashtaroth, and the gods of Aram and the gods</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Zidon and the gods of Moab and the gods</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the children of Ammon and the gods of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Philistines, and they forsook the Lord and did not serve</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Him” </span>(Judges 10:6). 
<span class="gemarra-regular">By</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> inference from </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">which is stated: “And they forsook the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Lord,” do I not know that they did not serve</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Him? Rather, </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">does the verse state </span>the seemingly unnecessary words <span class="gemarra-regular">“and did not serve Him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">”? Rabbi Elazar said: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: My children did not treat Me even like this lupine</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, which, </span>because it is inedible as it is, must be <span class="gemarra-regular">cooked </span>in water <span class="gemarra-regular">seven times </span>in order to temper its bitter taste <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>is eventually made so sweet that <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> eats it as a dessert </span>after <span class="gemarra-regular">a meal. </span>They worshipped all seven types of idolatry listed in the verse, and even after I punished them for each and every one of them, they still refused to repent from their evil ways. Instead, they remained rebellious and did not serve Me.
The Gemara considers another aspect of the character of the Jewish people. <span class="gemarra-regular">It is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Meir: For what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> reason was the Torah give</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the Jewish people? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because they are impudent, </span>and Torah study will weaken and humble them. A Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">of the school of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael taught </span>the following with regard to the verse: <span class="gemarra-regular">“From His right hand went a fiery la</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them” </span>(Deuteronomy 33:2); <span class="gemarra-regular">The Holy One, Blessed be He, said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>Based on their nature and character, <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>people, the Jews, are <span class="gemarra-regular">fit to be given a fiery law, </span>a hard and scorching faith. <span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>a different version of this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The ways </span>and nature <span class="gemarra-regular">of these </span>people, the Jews, <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>like <span class="gemarra-regular">fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as, were it not for </span>the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah was given to the Jewish </span><span class="gemarra-regular">people, </span>whose study and observance restrains them, <span class="gemarra-regular">no nation or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tongue could withstand them. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And this is </span>the same as <span class="gemarra-regular">what Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: There are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">three impudent ones: The Jewish people among the nations; </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">dog among animals; </span>and the <span class="gemarra-regular">rooster among birds. And some </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say: Also </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">goat among small cattle. And some say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Also </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">caper bush among trees</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ It is taught in the mishna: If <span class="gemarra-regular">one slaughtered </span>an animal on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">in the field, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he may not bring it </span>to his house <span class="gemarra-regular">on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pole, </span>as this appears similar to a weekday activity. <span class="gemarra-regular">The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: A <span class="gemarra-regular">blind person may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not go out </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">with his cane</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">nor a shepherd with his satchel. And one may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">go out on a chair </span>borne on poles by other people, <span class="gemarra-regular">neither a man nor a woman. </span>All of these are considered weekday activities, the performance of which would display disrespect for the Festival. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi send </span>the following <span class="it-text">halakha</span> from Eretz Yisrael: <span class="gemarra-regular">There was an old man </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in our neighborhood who would go out </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">in his litter [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">gelodki</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and they came and asked </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, </span>the preeminent authority of the time, whether this was permitted. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>to them: <span class="gemarra-regular">If many </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">need </span>the man to come and lecture them on Torah matters, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted </span>to transport him to the study hall in that manner. 
Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">our Sages relied on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Aḥi Shakkaya, who said: I </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">brought </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the town of <span class="gemarra-regular">Hinei </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the town of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shilei and from Shilei </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Hinei </span>on a chair of this kind. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Naḥman </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Yitzḥak said: I </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">brought Mar Shmuel </span>on such a seat on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">from the sun into the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">shade and from the shade into the sun. </span>All of these incidents indicate that it is in fact permitted to use such a chair on a Festival. The Gemara answers: These cases pose no difficulty, <span class="gemarra-regular">as there, it is in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accordance with the reason that </span>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <span class="gemarra-regular">stated:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> If many </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">need him, it is permitted. </span>However, one who is not needed by the public may not go out in such a chair. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥama bar Adda, emissary of </span>the talmudic academies in <span class="gemarra-regular">Zion, </span>who would regularly travel back and forth from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia: <span class="gemarra-regular">When you go up there, </span>to Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">take a roundabout </span>route, i.e., do not travel by the shortest path; <span class="gemarra-regular">and go to the Ladder of Tyre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and go to Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi, </span>who lives in Tyre, <span class="gemarra-regular">and raise </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">dilemma before him: What</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do you say with regard to a chair </span>borne on poles; may one go out in such a chair on a Festival? 
<span class="gemarra-regular">By the time he arrived there, Rabbi Ya’akov bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Idi had </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">passed away. </span>However, <span class="gemarra-regular">when he went up </span>to Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">he found Rabbi Zerika </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him: What do you say with regard to a chair </span>borne on poles; what is your opinion on this topic? <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to him: Rabbi Ami said as follows: </span>It is permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">provided that he is not carried on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shoulders, </span>on the chair. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">Provided that he is not carried on the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> shoulders</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yosef, son of Rabba, said: </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">on poles [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">alunkei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> that are used to carry burdens on the shoulders of two people. This mode of transportation is highly conspicuous and has the appearance of a weekday activity, the performance of which displays disrespect for the Festival. Instead, the poles on which the chair is borne should be held in the bearers’ hands, so the seat will be closer to the ground and less noticeable.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so? But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> didn’t Rav Naḥman permit </span>his wife <span class="gemarra-regular">Yalta to go</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> out </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>a chair borne on <span class="gemarra-regular">poles</span> that rested on the shoulders of the bearers? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yalta is different, as she was afrai</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> of falling and therefore required this special arrangement. 
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ameimar and Mar Zutra would be carried </span>to their places in the study hall <span class="gemarra-regular">on the shoulders </span>of their students for the public lecture delivered <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival. </span>They would be carried in that manner <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">fear </span>of falling. <span class="gemarra-regular">And some say </span>the reason was <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the pushing of the crowd, </span>as these Sages were afraid of being crushed by the large number of people attending the lecture. 
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A male firstborn of cattle, sheep, or goats belonging to a Jew is sanctified from birth and must be given to a priest to be sacrificed on the altar in the Temple. If a firstborn animal acquired a physical blemish that disqualifies it from being sacrificed as an offering, it still must be given to a priest, but it may be redeemed, slaughtered, and eaten as non-sacred meat. If <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">firstbor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> animal <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into a cistern </span>on a Festival, and there is concern that it might die there, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: An expert </span>in these matters <span class="gemarra-regular">goes down </span>into the cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">and examines </span>the animal. 

Daf 26a

<span class="gemarra-regular">If it has </span>a permanent <span class="gemarra-regular">blemish, </span>owing to which it may be slaughtered and eaten, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may raise it </span>from the cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughter </span>it; <span class="gemarra-regular">but if </span>it does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have a blemish, or if its blemish is temporary, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may not slaughter </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>Even if it has a blemish, it is prohibited to slaughter it, as <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>firstborn animal <span class="gemarra-regular">whose blemish is not perceptible while it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is still day, </span>i.e., on the day before the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">among </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>prior to the Festival for use on the Festival.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">do </span>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">If we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree </span>about whether or not <span class="gemarra-regular">one may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> examine blemishes on a Festival, </span>such <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Yehuda holds</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may examine blemishes on a Festival, and Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shimon holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not examine blemishes on a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> if so, <span class="gemarra-regular">let them disagree </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> examining blemishes in general </span>on a Festival and not only with respect to the particular case of a firstborn that fell into a cistern.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">It was necessary</span> to teach the disagreement with regard to the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a firstborn that fell into a cistern</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> could enter your mind to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">because of </span>the matter of <span class="gemarra-regular">the suffering of living creatures, one should employ</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an artifice </span>to circumvent the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and raise </span>the animal from the cistern. This would be <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua, </span>who states elsewhere (37a) with regard to a different case that one may employ an artifice in order to rescue an animal that fell into a cistern on a Festival. Therefore, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon disagree even in the case of a firstborn that fell into a cistern. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so, </span>if the mishna mentions the case of a firstborn that fell into a cistern in order to teach that an artifice may not be employed to raise the animal from the cistern, the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">He may not slaughter </span>it, is inaccurate. Rather, it <span class="gemarra-regular">should have </span>stated: <span class="gemarra-regular">He may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> raise </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and slaughter </span>it. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this teaching <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">transgressed </span>the prohibition and already <span class="gemarra-regular">raised it, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">it could </span><span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind to say that he may </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it. </span>Therefore, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that even then he may not do so.
The Gemara expresses wonder at this answer: How could one think that <span class="gemarra-regular">he may </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter it? Isn’t </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">unblemished? </span>How could one imagine that it is permitted to slaughter a firstborn that is unblemished? The Gemara answers: This teaching <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary only </span>in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where it developed </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a blemish </span>after it fell. The Gemara challenges this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>how could one think that he may now slaughter the animal? <span class="gemarra-regular">Doesn’t </span>it fall into the category of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as it was not fit to be eaten on the eve of the Festival, since at that time it was still unblemished? In that case, it should remain in the category of <span class="it-text">muktze</span> for the duration of the Festival. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the mishna is speaking of a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">developed a temporary </span><span class="gemarra-regular">blemish, </span>one that might eventually heal, <span class="gemarra-regular">on the eve of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Festival, and now, </span>after falling, <span class="gemarra-regular">it has a permanent </span><span class="gemarra-regular">blemish. Lest you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">his mind was </span>set <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the animal as food already before the Festival due to the temporary blemish <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">he should </span>now be allowed to <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter it, </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that since it was not fit to be eaten before the Festival, it is not considered prepared for use on the Festival. Rather, it falls into the category of <span class="it-text">muktze</span> and may not be slaughtered.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an unblemished firstborn that fell into a cistern </span>on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi says: An expert </span>in these matters <span class="gemarra-regular">goes down </span>into the cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">and examines </span>the animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">If</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>now <span class="gemarra-regular">has a </span>permanent <span class="gemarra-regular">blemish </span>as a result of the fall, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">raise </span>it from the cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> slaughter </span>it; <span class="gemarra-regular">but if not, </span>then even if he proceeds to raise it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not slaughter </span>it, even if afterwards it develops a blemish. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him: </span>The Sages of earlier generations <span class="gemarra-regular">already said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not examin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> blemishes on a Festival. How </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so? </span>If <span class="gemarra-regular">a blemish came into being on the eve </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of a Festival, one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not examine it on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival </span>itself to see whether it is in fact of the type that permits the animal to be slaughtered. And if the <span class="gemarra-regular">blemish came into being</span>

Daf 26b

<span class="gemarra-regular">on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: It</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">among the </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>prior to the Festival for use on the Festival; therefore, even if it was examined by an expert, it may not be slaughtered. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">agree </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was born with its blemish, it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">among the </span>animals <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>for use on the Festival.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar Rav Huna taught</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> as follows: If a firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">was born with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its blemish, </span>experts may <span class="gemarra-regular">examine it on a Festival </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and if the blemish is found to be permanent, the animal may then be slaughtered. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him: Father would teac</span><span class="gemarra-regular">h</span> on this matter that <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he transgressed and examined it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is considered <span class="gemarra-regular">examined </span>after the fact, <span class="gemarra-regular">and you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">examine </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>even <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: It </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stands to reason </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabba bar Rav Huna from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">three parts</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which suggests that each part contains a novel <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. The first section states: If a firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">developed a blemish on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eve of a Festival one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not examine it on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival </span>itself, from which one can learn that <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>only <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>examine it; <span class="gemarra-regular">but after the fact, it seems well, </span>and the examination is valid.
The second section of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states: If <span class="gemarra-regular">it developed a blemish on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: It is not </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">among </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>prior to the Festival for use on the Festival. In other words, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span><span class="gemarra-regular">after the fact, no, </span>if the animal was examined by an expert, it may not be slaughtered and eaten. <span class="gemarra-regular">And then </span>in the third section <span class="gemarra-regular">it teaches: And </span>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">agree that if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">born with its blemish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">among </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>for use on the Festival. The fact that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> taught this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> as an independent clause indicates that <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as well, </span>the animal may be examined.
