The Gemara raises an objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t </span>it so that <span class="gemarra-regular">when Rav Oshaya came </span>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> came and brought the </span>following <span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in his hand: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Whether </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">developed a blemish on the eve of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Festival or it developed a blemish on </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Festival </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis say: It is not </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">among </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>for use on the Festival, so that even after the fact, if the animal was examined, it may not be slaughtered and eaten. According to this, the allowance granted in the case of a firstborn that was born with its blemish can be only after the fact, as argued by Rav Naḥman, and not <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, as maintained by Rabba bar Rav Huna. Why, then, does Abaye accept the opinion of the latter and not that of the former?
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if so, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> cited earlier, which presents these <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> differently, is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult. </span>The Gemara answers: This does not pose a problem, as <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>taught by <span class="gemarra-regular">Adda bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ukhmei, who </span>would often <span class="gemarra-regular">confuse </span>the opinions in the text <span class="gemarra-regular">and teach </span>an inaccurate version of the dispute; therefore, his version is unreliable. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: The mishna is also precise</span> in its wording according to the opinion that no blemish may be examined <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">As </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span>Even if the animal has a blemish, it is prohibited to slaughter it, since <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>firstborn animal <span class="gemarra-regular">whose blemish is not perceptible on the eve of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival </span>while it is still day <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">among </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>prior to the Festival for use on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">Whose blemish is not perceptible? If we say </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that its blemish is not perceptible at all, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious. Need it be said </span>that an animal whose blemish was not perceptible at all prior to the Festival is not considered prepared for use on the Festival?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>one must say that the animal had a perceptible blemish, but <span class="gemarra-regular">it was not shown to a Sage on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eve of the Festival </span>to determine <span class="gemarra-regular">whether it is a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permanent blemish or a temporary blemish. In any event, </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches: It is not </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">among </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>prior to the Festival for use on the Festival, which indicates that it is not considered prepared even after the fact. It follows that the allowance granted in the case of a firstborn that was born with its blemish is also only after the fact, but the blemish may not be examined <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from this </span>that this is so.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Hillel raised </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a dilemm</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before Rava: Is there </span>a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for half of Shabbat or is there no </span>prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for half of Shabbat? </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the circumstances </span>of this case? <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>an item <span class="gemarra-regular">was fit</span> for eating or for some other purpose <span class="gemarra-regular">at twilight </span>between Friday and Shabbat, it would then <span class="gemarra-regular">be fit </span>for the entire Shabbat. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if it was not fit </span>at twilight, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not fit </span>for the entire day, as anything considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span> at twilight remains so throughout Shabbat. How, then, could there be a case of an item that is considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span> for half of Shabbat?
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">No</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to raise this dilemma in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the item <span class="gemarra-regular">had </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">been fit </span>for use, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> then became disqualified </span>on Shabbat itself for some reason, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> then </span>once again <span class="gemarra-regular">became fit. </span>It is about such a case that Hillel asked: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>Hillel: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is </span>a prohibition of<span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span> for half of Shabbat, that is to say, once an item becomes disqualified for use on Shabbat, it retains that status for the rest of the day. 
Hillel <span class="gemarra-regular">raised an objection </span>from the previously cited <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that taught: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">agree that if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was born with its blemish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, it is </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">among </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>before the Festival for use on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">But why</span> should this be? <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span><span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn was fit at the outset </span>to be eaten <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">account of its mother, </span>as had its mother been slaughtered before giving birth to the firstborn, it would have been permitted to eat them both. This being the case, when the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">was born, it became disqualified, </span>since once a firstborn is born, it may not be eaten until it acquires a permanent blemish. And later, when <span class="gemarra-regular">he showed it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to a Sage, it </span>once again <span class="gemarra-regular">became permitted to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>This shows that although the animal had the status of <span class="it-text">muktze</span> for part of the day of the Festival, it did not retain that status for the entire day.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Safra </span>who said: Here, the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where judges were sitting there, </span>observing the firstborn as it was being born, and they immediately saw that it was blemished. Therefore, the animal never lost its permitted status even for a moment. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>that Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>the opposite <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Hillel: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is no </span>prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for half of Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that is to say, even if an item becomes disqualified for use on Shabbat, once it becomes fit again, it is no longer prohibited. The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say that </span>the previously cited <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon <span class="gemarra-regular">agree that if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was born with its blemish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, it is </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">among </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>before the Festival for use on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t this firstborn fit </span>to be eaten <span class="gemarra-regular">at the outse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on account of its mother; </span>and then when <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was born it became disqualified; </span>and then later, when <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">showed it to a Sage, it </span>once again <span class="gemarra-regular">became permitted </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him? </span>This indicates that for half of Shabbat there is no prohibition of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Safra </span>who said: This proof is inconclusive, as the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> may be referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where judges were sitting there </span>when the firstborn was born, and they immediately saw that it was blemished; therefore the animal never acquired the status of <span class="it-text">muktze</span> at all.
The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a proof from a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">was eating grapes and left </span>some over <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">took them up to the roof </span>to dry in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to make them </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">raisins, </span>or if he was eating <span class="gemarra-regular">figs and left </span>some over <span class="gemarra-regular">and took them up to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the roof </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to make them </span>into <span class="gemarra-regular">dried figs, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not eat from them </span>on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">designates them </span>as food to be eaten <span class="gemarra-regular">while it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">still day. </span>Otherwise, they are prohibited as <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And you </span>would <span class="gemarra-regular">find the same with regard to peaches, and quinces, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and all other types of fruit </span>that one left out to dry. It is prohibited to eat any of them on Shabbat due to the prohibition of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. 
The Gemara proceeds to clarify this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are the circumstances? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">If they are fit </span>to be eaten, as they have already dried, <span class="gemarra-regular">why does he require </span>prior <span class="gemarra-regular">designation? </span>Since he placed them there in order to eat them after they dried, they should be considered food that has been designated to be eaten. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if they are not fit </span>to be eaten, as they are yet not dry, even <span class="gemarra-regular">if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he designates them </span>the day before, <span class="gemarra-regular">what of it? </span>Of what use is such designation, seeing that the fruit is still unfit to be eaten?
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case where he could not ascend to the roof to examine them, and therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">he did </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not know whether they were fit or unfit, </span>so that his designation was conditional, there is a difficulty. <span class="gemarra-regular">As didn’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t Rav Kahana say: </span>If fruit had been <span class="gemarra-regular">set aside </span>for drying, and it <span class="gemarra-regular">dried </span>and became fit for eating before Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">but the owner did not know about it </span>before Shabbat but only on Shabbat, the fruit <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted, </span>since he removed it from his mind only for as long as it would be unfit for eating. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, is </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">were fit, and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">became disqualified, and then </span>once again <span class="gemarra-regular">became fit, </span>and therefore they have the status of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span> for half of Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">why do they require </span>prior <span class="gemarra-regular">designation? </span>The Gemara refutes this argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, what </span>then do you say, that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>in fact a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span> for half of Shabbat? In that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">if he designates them </span>the day before, <span class="gemarra-regular">what of it? </span>How does his designation permit that which is prohibited as <span class="it-text">muktze</span>? 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">were fit but not </span>completely <span class="gemarra-regular">fit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning <span class="gemarra-regular">that there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are people who eat </span>them in that state <span class="gemarra-regular">and there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">people who do not eat </span>them. Therefore, if <span class="gemarra-regular">he designated </span>them as food to be eaten, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">has revealed his intention </span>that he is included among those who do eat them; if <span class="gemarra-regular">he did not designate </span>them as food, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has not revealed his intention. </span>Therefore, no proof can be adduced from here.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said: Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution to the problem raised above <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> governing <span class="gemarra-regular">beans and lentils </span>cooked on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">As beans and lentils at the outset, </span>at twilight, when they are still raw and uncooked, <span class="gemarra-regular">are fit to be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">chewed </span>as they are and are therefore not in the category of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>; then, when <span class="gemarra-regular">he casts them into the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pot </span>to cook them, <span class="gemarra-regular">they become disqualified </span>because while they are being cooked they are fit neither to be chewed raw nor to be eaten cooked. 

Daf 27a

And then when <span class="gemarra-regular">their cooking is finished</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, they </span>once again <span class="gemarra-regular">become fit </span>for eating. This demonstrates that even food that had temporarily been set aside because it had become inedible does not remain prohibited for the entire day.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> according to your reasoning </span>that foods are temporarily considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span> while being cooked, <span class="gemarra-regular">cooked dishes in general </span>present <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for you </span>on Shabbat as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">As ordinary cooked dishes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in general are </span>still <span class="gemarra-regular">bubbling at twilight </span>and not yet edible, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">we partake of them </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> evening. </span>This demonstrates that although the food was considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span> at the critical moment of twilight, it is not prohibited for the duration of Shabbat.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it must be that <span class="gemarra-regular">we have no dilemma </span>with regard to a food <span class="gemarra-regular">whose completion, which </span>brings it to its finished and edible form, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>entirely <span class="gemarra-regular">in the hands of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a person, </span>e.g., beans and lentils. Such foods are certainly not considered as <span class="it-text">muktze</span> for all of Shabbat simply because they had become temporarily unfit for eating. <span class="gemarra-regular">Where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we have a dilemma </span>is with regard to an item <span class="gemarra-regular">whose completion is in the hands of Heaven, </span>such as figs and grapes, which dry by the heat of the sun. This dilemma remains unresolved.
§ The Gemara returns to the issue of permitting firstborn animals. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda Nesia had a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> firstborn </span>animal that acquired a blemish on a Festival, and he wished to serve it to priests staying at his house. <span class="gemarra-regular">He sent it to </span>be presented <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi Ami</span> for examination, and Rabbi Ami <span class="gemarra-regular">thought </span>that he should <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> examine it, </span>in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zerika said to him, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya: </span>The principle is that in cases of dispute between <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon, </span>the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>who in this case permits examination of the firstborn. Rabbi Yehuda Nesia <span class="gemarra-regular">then sent </span>the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>be presented <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi Yitzḥak </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Nappaḥa, </span>who likewise <span class="gemarra-regular">thought </span>that he should <span class="gemarra-regular">not examine it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Rabbi Yirmeya said to him, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zerika: </span>The principle is that in cases where <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon </span>disagree, the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>Rabbi Yirmeya: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">you did </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not allow the Sages to act in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon? He said to him: And you, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">what do you have? </span>Do you have a tradition that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon? Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as follows: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">is in accordance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon.</span>
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">a certain </span>unidentified <span class="gemarra-regular">person </span>in Babylonia <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> May it be His will that <span class="gemarra-regular">I merit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to go up there </span>to Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> learn </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">teaching from the mouth of its Master; </span>I will ask Rabbi Zeira himself for his opinion on this matter. <span class="gemarra-regular">When he went up there </span>to Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">he found Rabbi Zeira </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span>Did <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Master say </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon? </span>Rabbi Zeira <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: No, </span>that is not what I said; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">I said: It </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stands to reaso</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that this is so. It is reasonable to rule in accordance with Rabbi Shimon on this issue, although I do not have a definitive tradition to this effect. 
Rabbi Zeira explains: Why do I think so? <span class="gemarra-regular">From </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that it teaches in the mishna </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Any </span>firstborn animal <span class="gemarra-regular">whose blemish is not perceptible while it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is still day is not </span>considered to be <span class="gemarra-regular">among </span>the animals <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>prior to the Festival for use on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>the same ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">name of the Sages, </span>indicating that this is the majority opinion. One should therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from this that it stands</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to reason </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is ruled <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with</span> the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. 
The Gemara asks: In the final analysis, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>conclusion <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>reached <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>this matter? Whose opinion does the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> follow? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear, as </span>this matter <span class="gemarra-regular">hangs on great trees, </span>meaning it is the subject of a dispute among the early Sages. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yehoshua ben Levi said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei ben Shaul said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said in the name of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">holy community in Jerusalem: Rabbi Shimon </span>ben Menasya <span class="gemarra-regular">and his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">colleagues said </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir.</span>
The Gemara wonders at the wording of this report: How could the holy community in Jerusalem have reported that Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya and his colleagues <span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir? <span class="gemarra-regular">Aren’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t they much older than he? </span>Why, then, would they have reported a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in his name? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the holy community in Jerusalem said the following: Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya and his colleagues, who said that one may not examine blemishes on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">spoke in </span>accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">the opinion of Rabbi Meir. </span>
To which teaching of Rabbi Meir is the Gemara referring? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Bekhorot</span> 28a): If <span class="gemarra-regular">one slaughtered a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">firstborn </span>before it was shown to a Sage and deemed permitted, <span class="gemarra-regular">and afterward he showed its blemish </span>to a Sage, who confirmed that it was indeed a permanent blemish that permitted the animal to be slaughtered, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda permits </span>it, as it had been established that the animal was blemished. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Meir says: Since it was slaughtered without </span>the permission <span class="gemarra-regular">of an expert</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is prohibited. Apparently Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Meir holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the examination of a firstborn is not </span>as simple a process <span class="gemarra-regular">as the examination of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since it involves more than a mere examination of the body of the animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">The examination of a firstborn </span>must be conducted <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the animal is <span class="gemarra-regular">alive</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> examination of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span> may be performed even <span class="gemarra-regular">after slaughtering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And from this </span>Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya and his colleagues inferred that <span class="gemarra-regular">the examination</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tereifa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which consists merely of clarifying the facts of the animal’s physical state, may be done <span class="gemarra-regular">even on a Festival. </span>On the other hand, <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>more stringent <span class="gemarra-regular">examination of a firstborn, </span>which can be likened to the rendering of a judgment, a process with principles of its own, must be performed <span class="gemarra-regular">on the eve of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said</span> to Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in that mishna, Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">disagree </span>about whether or not one may <span class="gemarra-regular">examine blemishes </span>on a Festival? That was not their dispute; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">they disagree with regard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>the question of whether or not there is a <span class="gemarra-regular">penalty </span>for one who acted improperly. <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rabba bar bar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥana said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>If the blemish was <span class="gemarra-regular">in the eyelids, </span>e.g., if a fissure developed there that disqualifies the animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone, </span>including Rabbi Meir, <span class="gemarra-regular">agrees </span>that the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited, because </span>such a blemish <span class="gemarra-regular">changes </span>its appearance after the slaughter. It is possible that after slaughter what was a temporary blemish will then look like a permanent one, and the animal will incorrectly be permitted retroactively.
<span class="gemarra-regular">When they disagree </span>is in a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">blemishes in the body, </span>e.g., if an ear had been cut off or a foreleg broken, which are prominent blemishes whose appearance does not change after death. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir holds that we issue a decre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">blemishes in the body </span>are prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">due to blemishes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the eye, and Rabbi Yehuda holds that we do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not issue </span>such a <span class="gemarra-regular">decree.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: </span>The wording of <span class="gemarra-regular">the mishna </span>in tractate <span class="it-text">Bekhorot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is also precise </span>according to this explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it teaches </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: Since</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it was slaughtered without </span>the permission of <span class="gemarra-regular">an expert </span>who confirmed that this is a permanent blemish, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. Learn from this </span>that this is <span class="gemarra-regular">a penalty </span>that Rabbi Meir <span class="gemarra-regular">imposes </span>and nothing else. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <span class="gemarra-regular">learn</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from this </span>that this is the correct understanding of the mishna.
§ The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Ami of Vardin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> was <span class="gemarra-regular">the examiner of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> firstborns in the household of the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Nasi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. On Festivals he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> would not examine </span>firstborn blemishes. <span class="gemarra-regular">They came and told Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ami </span>about this. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: He does well</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not to examine </span>them. The Gemara raises an objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that so? But didn’t Rabbi Ami himself examine </span>firstborns for blemishes on a Festival? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ami would examine </span>the blemishes of firstborns, it was <span class="gemarra-regular">on the day before </span>the Festival that <span class="gemarra-regular">he would examine </span>them, to see whether the blemishes were permanent or temporary. 

Daf 27b

<span class="gemarra-regular">And on the Festival </span>itself <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> would as</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span> only <span class="gemarra-regular">how the incident occurred, </span>meaning that he would investigate the cause of the blemish, <span class="gemarra-regular">as in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">where a certain man </span>who was a priest <span class="gemarra-regular">brought a firstborn before Rava, </span>close to <span class="gemarra-regular">nightfall on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival eve. Rava was sitting and washing </span>the hair on <span class="gemarra-regular">his head. He raised his eyes and saw </span>the firstborn’s <span class="gemarra-regular">blemish. He </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the owner of the firstborn: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go now, and come </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">tomorrow. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">When he came </span>back <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">following day, </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: How did the incident </span>that caused the blemish <span class="gemarra-regular">occur? </span>The owner <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">Barley </span>grains <span class="gemarra-regular">were scattered on one side of a fence </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of thorns, while </span>the firstborn <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>standing <span class="gemarra-regular">on the other </span><span class="gemarra-regular">side. When it wanted to eat, it stuck its head </span><span class="gemarra-regular">through the fence and a thorn cut its lip. </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>the owner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps you caused </span>the blemish by deliberately placing the barley on the other side of the fence? <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to him: No. </span>
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And from where do you say that causing </span>a blemish to an offering <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited? As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: It is written with regard to offerings: <span class="gemarra-regular">“</span><span class="gemarra-regular">There must not be </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">blemish in it” </span>(Leviticus 22:21). <span class="gemarra-regular">I have only </span>an explicit prohibition <span class="gemarra-regular">that it may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have a blemish; from where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not cause </span>a blemish <span class="gemarra-regular">to it by means of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> something else, </span>e.g., <span class="gemarra-regular">that he does not bring dough</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or a dried fig and place it on its ear</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so that a dog will com</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and take it, </span>thereby biting off part of the animal’s ear and leaving it blemished? Therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states “any blemish.” It </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says “blemish” and it says “any blemish”; </span>the word “any” comes to teach that one may not cause a blemish.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal that died, one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not move </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it from its place </span>on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>such <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">incident </span>once occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">and they asked Rabbi Tarfon about it. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>on that same occasion they also asked him <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>had been separated from dough and then <span class="gemarra-regular">became</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ritually impure </span>on a Festival. Such <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> is not fit to be eaten by anyone, nor may it be used in any other manner, e.g., as animal feed or as fuel for a fire, on that day. Rabbi Tarfon <span class="gemarra-regular">entered the study hall and inquired </span>about these matters, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: One </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not move</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them from their </span><span class="gemarra-regular">place</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let us say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned the unattributed </span>mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shabbat</span> 156b) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon says: One </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">cut up gourds for an animal </span>on Shabbat so that it can eat them more easily, and similarly, one may cut up <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span>unslaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">animal carcass for dogs. Rabbi Yehuda </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: If it was not an animal carcass </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the eve of Shabbat, </span>but rather it died on Shabbat itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited. </span>Since Rabbi Yehuda distinguishes between an animal that died on Shabbat and one that died before Shabbat, it would appear that Rabbi Shimon holds that one may move an animal carcass and feed it to dogs even if it died on Shabbat. Accordingly, the mishna that prohibits moving an animal that died on a Festival seems to conflict with Rabbi Shimon’s opinion. 
The Gemara rejects this argument: The mishna can be understood <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">concedes in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">animals that </span>were entirely healthy at twilight but <span class="gemarra-regular">died </span>on the Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">that they are prohibited. </span>Since they were healthy at twilight, the owner had no intention at that point in time of feeding them to dogs, and they are therefore prohibited as <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, on the other hand, is referring to an animal that had been sick on the previous day; since the owner knew that it was close to death, he had in mind to feed it to his dogs after it died.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>works out <span class="gemarra-regular">well according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar Ameimar </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rava, who said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon </span><span class="gemarra-regular">concedes in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">animals that died </span>on the Festival without having been mortally sick the day before <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they are prohibited </span>on the Festival due to <span class="it-text">muktze</span>; according to this opinion, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">well. However, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar, son of Rav Yosef, in the name</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rava, who said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon was in disagreemen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">animals that died </span>suddenly, and he holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are permitted, what is there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to say? </span>The unattributed mishna appears to contradict this opinion.
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Ze’iri explained it </span>as follows: The mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a sacred animal </span>that died; since it is sacred property, one may not derive benefit from it, and therefore one may not give it to dogs. The Gemara comments: The language of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is also precise </span>according to this interpretation, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it teaches: </span>They asked Rabbi Tarfon <span class="gemarra-regular">about</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it and about </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that became ritually impure, </span>from which it may be inferred: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is sacred</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, so too, </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">animal </span>mentioned here is one <span class="gemarra-regular">that was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sacred, </span>rather than a non-sacred animal.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>according to this explanation, <span class="gemarra-regular">the reason </span>that the animal may not be moved <span class="gemarra-regular">is that </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">was sacred; but </span>if it was <span class="gemarra-regular">a non-sacred </span>animal that died, it would be <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to move it. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>works out <span class="gemarra-regular">well according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar, son of Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yosef, in the name of Rava, who said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon was in disagreement even in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">animals </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that died, </span>and he holds that <span class="gemarra-regular">they are permitted; </span>according to this opinion, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">well, </span>as one can say that the mishna, which indicates that one may move an animal that died on a Festival, is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, according to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Mar bar Ameimar in the name of Rava, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon concedes in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">animals that died that they are prohibited, what is there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to say? </span>The mishna is in accordance with neither Rabbi Shimon nor Rabbi Yehuda. 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a case where the animal was <span class="gemarra-regular">in danger </span>of dying the day before, and the owner had in mind to feed it to his dogs after it died, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">all agree </span>with regard to the ruling. Therefore, according to Rabbi Shimon, an allowance is granted to move the animal if it was a non-sacred animal and it had been in danger prior to the Festival; and if the animal was sacred, even he agrees that it is prohibited, as it may not be fed to dogs. 
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">registe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> to have a portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of an animal</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a Festival </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>since it is prohibited to divide up an animal into portions for different people, as this is similar to conducting business, a weekday activity, on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">But one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">registe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">on the eve of the Festival, and </span>then those who registered for the animal may <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter and divide </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them </span>on the Festival itself in accordance with the agreement reached the day before. The next day, each pays the slaughterer according to his portion of the animal.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">One</span> may <span class="gemarra-regular">not register? Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: One</span> may <span class="gemarra-regular">not fix </span>a sum <span class="gemarra-regular">of money </span>and set a particular price for each portion <span class="gemarra-regular">of an animal on a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">Festiva</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> do </span>on a Festival to divide up the animal without fixing a price? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: He </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">bring two animals</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and stand them one next to the other and say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>Is <span class="gemarra-regular">this one equal </span>in value <span class="gemarra-regular">to the other </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one? </span>If the purchasers confirm that this is the case, then after the Festival they assess the value of the animal that is identical to the animal that had been slaughtered on the Festival, and in that way they establish the amount that each person must pay. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">This is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that states: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not say to another </span>on a Festival: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am hereby </span>in partnership <span class="gemarra-regular">with you </span>in this animal that you are about to slaughter <span class="gemarra-regular">for the value </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sela</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>or: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am hereby </span>in partnership <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you for two </span><span class="it-text">sela</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, he </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">say to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: I am hereby </span>in partnership <span class="gemarra-regular">with you for half </span>the animal, or <span class="gemarra-regular">for a third or a quarter, </span>without stipulating the value of that share, and after the Festival they may determine how much each share is worth. 

Daf 28a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: A person </span>selling meat on a Festival who wishes to know its weight in order to determine its price may not weigh it against regular weights in the ordinary weekday manner, but he may <span class="gemarra-regular">weigh </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">meat against </span>a <span class="gemarra-regular">vesse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or against </span>a <span class="gemarra-regular">cleaver [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">kofitz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> and then calculate the weight of the meat by weighing the vessel or cleaver later. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: One </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">look at the pans of a </span>balance <span class="gemarra-regular">scal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at all</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>meaning that they may not be used for weighing in any manner or for any other purpose.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of: One may not look at the pans of a scale <span class="gemarra-regular">at all? Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: Even </span>if one has meat and he wishes <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">protect it from mice, </span>he may not put it on a scale, since it would look as if he were weighing it. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Idi bar Avin said: And this </span>ruling applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the scale <span class="gemarra-regular">is hanging on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">rin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> used for balancing it. However, if the scale is hanging in such a manner that it is not fit for weighing, one may use it as he would use any other vessel.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: It is prohibited for an expert butcher to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> weigh meat </span>on a Festival even <span class="gemarra-regular">by hand </span>because he can arrive at its precise weight using this method, and so it is prohibited like weighing with a scale. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> likewise, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: It is prohibited</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for an expert butcher to weigh meat </span>on a Festival even <span class="gemarra-regular">in water</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Butchers would calculate the weight of a slab of meat by placing it into a tub of water and measuring the amount of water that it displaces with the help of markings on the container. Since this procedure enables the butcher to determine the precise weight of the meat, it may not be performed on a Festival. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: It is prohibited to make </span>a hole to serve as <span class="gemarra-regular">a handle in mea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> on a Festival, since this is a weekday act. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: But it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted </span>to make such a handle <span class="gemarra-regular">by hand, </span>rather than with a knife or some other implement, since this is an atypical manner of making a hole.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: It is permitted to make a sign</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on meat </span>even on a Festival, so that it not be mistaken for the meat of another person. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that which Rabba bar Rav Huna </span>would do when he sent meat by means of a messenger to his house; he would <span class="gemarra-regular">cut it into triangles </span>as a sign that the meat was his and it was fit to be eaten.
The Gemara relates an incident in connection to the basic <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Shimon, son</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, would <span class="gemarra-regular">weigh </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">portion against </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">portio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a Festival </span>in order to divide the meat between them. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion did they do so? This seems to be <span class="gemarra-regular">neither in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda nor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis </span>in the mishna. As, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, didn’t he say: A person </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">weigh meat against a vessel or against a cleaver, </span>from which it may be inferred: <span class="gemarra-regular">Against a vessel </span>or a cleaver, <span class="gemarra-regular">yes, </span>one may do so; but <span class="gemarra-regular">against anything </span><span class="gemarra-regular">else, no, </span>he may not. And <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, didn’t they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: One </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not look at the pans of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> scale at all?</span>
The Gemara explains: Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">acted in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua says: One may weigh </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">portion against </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">portion on a Festival. Rav Yosef said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua, since we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>tractate <span class="gemarra-italic">Bekhorot</span> (31a)<span class="gemarra-regular"> in accordance</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with his </span>opinion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">As we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> learned </span>there: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated animals that have become</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> disqualified </span>because of a blemish, all <span class="gemarra-regular">the benefit </span>that accrues <span class="gemarra-regular">from their </span>sale belongs <span class="gemarra-regular">to the </span>Temple treasury of <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated</span> property. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">weigh </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">portion </span>of meat <span class="gemarra-regular">against</span> another <span class="gemarra-regular">portion </span>of meat <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>the case of a <span class="gemarra-regular">firstbor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> that developed a blemish. Although the meat of a firstborn may not be sold by weight in the manner of non-sacred meat, one may weigh one portion against another portion in order to determine its price. This indicates that even in a case where it is prohibited to weigh an item in the ordinary manner, one may still weigh one portion of it against another portion.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: Perhaps that is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not so, </span>and the two cases are not similar. It is possible that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua stated </span>his opinion that one may weigh one portion against another <span class="gemarra-regular">only here, </span>on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the action does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>involve a show of <span class="gemarra-regular">degradation of sacred </span>items; <span class="gemarra-regular">but there, </span>in the case of a firstborn, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the weighing involves a display of <span class="gemarra-regular">degradation</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of sacred </span>items, perhaps he did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permit weighing of any kind. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>it is possible that <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis stated </span>their opinion that one may weigh one portion against another <span class="gemarra-regular">only there, </span>in the case of a firstborn, <span class="gemarra-regular">because it does not look </span><span class="gemarra-regular">like a weekday activity; but here, </span>on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it looks like a weekday activity</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> perhaps they would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>have permitted it. It is therefore possible that even the Rabbis would prohibit this action on a Festival.
With regard to the incident involving Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is this to say that they were particular</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with each other </span>with regard to such matters, to the extent that they had to weigh one portion against another so that their portions would be exactly equal? <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t </span>there the incident of <span class="gemarra-regular">the seven fish that were</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> brought to the house of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">and five</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of them were </span>later <span class="gemarra-regular">found in the house </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥiyya, </span>who had taken them from Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi; <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">was not particular</span> about this, as they treated each other like family?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Pappa said: Cast a person between </span><span class="gemarra-regular">them. </span>In other words, a third party must have been involved in the incident. How so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Either </span>the two who divided the meat between themselves were <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, or </span>else they were <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shimon, son of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">and bar Kappara. </span>Although these pairs of scholars were colleagues, they were exacting with each other in monetary matters. Consequently, they weighed one portion of meat against the other to ensure that they would each receive the same amount.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sharpe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">a knife on a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival </span>in the ordinary weekday manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, one </span>may do so in an unusual fashion, e.g., to <span class="gemarra-regular">run </span>one knife <span class="gemarra-regular">over another, </span>thereby sharpening the blade.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Huna said: They taught </span>that one may not sharpen a knife on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if he does so in the typical manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">with a stone </span>knife <span class="gemarra-regular">sharpener, but </span>if he does so <span class="gemarra-regular">with a wooden </span>knife <span class="gemarra-regular">sharpener, it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permitted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as this is an unusual way of sharpening knives. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which you said, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a stone </span>sharpener <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only where </span>one’s intention is <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sharpen </span>the knife, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if he merely means <span class="gemarra-regular">to remove</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the </span>accumulated <span class="gemarra-regular">fat </span>by scraping it off with the stone, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted. </span>This proves <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that with </span>a sharpener made <span class="gemarra-regular">of wood, even </span>if his intention is <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sharpen </span>the knife, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teach </span>the statement of Rav Yehuda as referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> latter clause </span>of Rav Huna’s statement, where he says: But if he uses a sharpener made <span class="gemarra-regular">of wood, it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted. Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">that which you said, </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">with a wooden </span>sharpener it <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted, we said </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only where </span>one’s intention is <span class="gemarra-regular">to remove its fat, but </span>if he does so in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to sharpen it, it is prohibited. </span>This proves <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that </span>with a sharpener made <span class="gemarra-regular">of stone</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, even </span>if he intended merely <span class="gemarra-regular">to remove its fat, it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is prohibited.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some teach </span>the statement of Rav Yehuda as referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the mishna </span>itself, which teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not sharpen</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a knife on a Festival. Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: They taught </span>that this is prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>where one’s intention is <span class="gemarra-regular">to sharpen </span>the knife, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if his aim is merely <span class="gemarra-regular">to remove its fat, it is permitted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>This proves <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that </span>running one knife <span class="gemarra-regular">over another</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted even </span>if his intention is <span class="gemarra-regular">to sharpen </span>the knife.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And some teach</span> the statement of Rav Yehuda as referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the latter</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> clause </span>of the mishna, which teaches: <span class="gemarra-regular">However, one </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">run </span>one knife <span class="gemarra-regular">over another. Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: They taught </span>this <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>where one’s intention is <span class="gemarra-regular">to remove its fat, but </span>if he does so <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sharpen it, it is prohibited. </span>This proves <span class="gemarra-regular">by inference that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with a sharpener, it is prohibited even to remove its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fat.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Who is the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> who holds <span class="gemarra-regular">that with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a sharpener it is </span>entirely <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited? Rav Ḥisda said: </span>This <span class="it-text">tanna</span> does <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>hold <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between a Festival and Shabbat is only </span>with regard to the preparation of <span class="gemarra-regular">food, </span>as it is permitted to perform labor for the purpose of food preparation on a Festival, but not on Shabbat; <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda permits </span><span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>actions that <span class="gemarra-regular">facilitate preparation of food </span>on a Festival, e.g., repairing utensils with which food is prepared on the Festival. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda: We teach in your name </span>that the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda. He</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to him: May it be </span>God’s <span class="gemarra-regular">will that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you teach in my name all outstanding matters like this</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>In other words, Rav Ḥisda was pleased that this teaching was attributed to him, as he too agreed with it.
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Neḥemya, son of Rav Yosef</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, said: I was </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">standing before Rava, and he was</span> 

Daf 28b

<span class="gemarra-regular">running a knife over the rim of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a baske</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And I said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him: </span>Is <span class="gemarra-regular">the Master doing </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to sharpen</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it or </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to remove its fat? And he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to me: To remove its fat. And I </span>nevertheless <span class="gemarra-regular">perceived his intention, that he did so </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sharpen it. </span>He concealed this from me, however, because <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds </span>that Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion is the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">but a </span>public <span class="gemarra-regular">ruling is not issued to that effect;</span> therefore he did not wish to permit the practice explicitly.
Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: I was standing before my</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Master </span>and teacher, Rabba, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he was running a knife</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> over the edge of a millstone </span>on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And I said to him: </span>Does <span class="gemarra-regular">the Master wish to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sharpen it, or </span>is he doing this in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> remove its fat? And he said to me: To remove</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its fat. And I perceived his intention, that he did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> so </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to sharpen it, but he holds: </span>This is the <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, but a </span>public <span class="gemarra-regular">ruling is not issued</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to that effect</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to showing a </span>slaughtering <span class="gemarra-regular">knife to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a Sag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a Festival </span>so that he may examine it for nicks and imperfections that would render it unfit to be used for slaughtering? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Mari, son of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Bizna, permitted </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">whereas the Rabbis prohibited </span>it, as this is somewhat similar to a weekday activity. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yosef said: A Torah scholar may examine </span>a knife <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">himself </span>in his own home <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">lend it to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">others, </span>who may also slaughter with it. Since the examination is not performed in public, it does not appear similar to a weekday activity. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yosef said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a knife that became blunt </span>without being nicked, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted to sharpen it on a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And this applies </span>only if the knife still <span class="gemarra-regular">cuts, </span>albeit <span class="gemarra-regular">with difficulty</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so that when he sharpens it he is seen not as making a new utensil but merely as improving an old one. However, if the knife no longer cuts at all, it is prohibited to sharpen it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥisda taught, and some say </span>it was <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef </span>who taught: <span class="gemarra-regular">A knife that became nicked </span>on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span>roasting <span class="gemarra-regular">skewer [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shappud</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that was crushed </span>on a Festival and its point broke off, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the sweeping of </span>the coals in <span class="gemarra-regular">an oven and a stove on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival </span>to prepare them for baking, with regard to all of these <span class="gemarra-regular">we have arrived at the dispute between Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda and the Rabbis. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between a Festival and Shabbat is only</span> with regard to the <span class="gemarra-regular">preparation of food. Rabbi Yehuda permits</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even </span>actions that <span class="gemarra-regular">facilitate preparation of foo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> on a Festival.
The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span> for prohibiting actions that facilitate food preparation? <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-regular">verse states: </span>“Save that which every person must eat, <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> alone may be done for you” </span>(Exodus 12:16), from which it may be inferred: <span class="gemarra-regular">“That” </span>may be done on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>actions that <span class="gemarra-regular">facilitate it. And Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda </span>adduces proof for his view from the fact that <span class="gemarra-regular">the verse states: “For you,” </span>indicating: <span class="gemarra-regular">For you, for all</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> your needs, </span>and that which facilitates food preparation is also a need.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, is it not written “for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you”? </span>What does he learn from this phrase? The Gemara answers: That <span class="it-text">tanna</span> could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>phrase comes to teach: <span class="gemarra-regular">For you, but not for gentiles. </span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>according to <span class="gemarra-regular">the other </span><span class="it-text">tanna</span>, Rabbi Yehuda, <span class="gemarra-regular">too, isn’t it written: “</span><span class="gemarra-regular">That,” </span>which indicates a limitation? The Gemara explains that Rabbi Yehuda could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: </span>The limiting word <span class="gemarra-regular">“that</span><span class="gemarra-regular">” is written, and </span>the expansive phrase <span class="gemarra-regular">“for you,” </span>indicating all your needs, <span class="gemarra-regular">is written </span>as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult </span>and no contradiction is involved. One can say that <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>actions that <span class="gemarra-regular">facilitate </span>food preparation <span class="gemarra-regular">that can be performed on the eve of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival; </span>the Torah prohibits these on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>actions that <span class="gemarra-regular">facilitate </span>food preparation <span class="gemarra-regular">that cannot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> be performed on the eve of the Festival. </span>The latter may be performed even on the Festival itself, as they too are part of the preparation of food, similar to cooking.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>With regard to a roasting <span class="gemarra-regular">skewer that became bent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is prohibited to repair it on a Festival. </span>The Gemara asks: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious; </span>it is clear that one may not fix a utensil on a Festival. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to a particular case: <span class="gemarra-regular">Although </span>the skewer <span class="gemarra-regular">can be straightened</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by hand </span>and no special tool is needed for this task, it is nevertheless prohibited.
