<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a skewer upon which one roasted meat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is prohibited to move it on a Festival, </span>as it has already served its purpose on the Festival, and it is not fit for any other use. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Adda</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bar Ahava said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Malkiyu said: He </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">pull</span> the skewer <span class="gemarra-regular">out and place it in a corner </span>so that it will not endanger anyone, as it could if it were left in the middle of the house. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said: And this </span>ruling applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">where</span> the skewer <span class="gemarra-regular">has an olive-bulk of meat on it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> in such a case he may move the skewer on account of the meat and drag it into the corner in an unusual manner. However, if it does not have an olive-bulk of meat on it, he may not move it at all. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: Although it does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not have </span>an olive-bulk of <span class="gemarra-regular">meat on it, it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted to move it </span>in the regular manner and place it in a corner, <span class="gemarra-regular">just as in </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a thorn </span>lying <span class="gemarra-regular">in the public domain. </span>For the sake of public safety, it is permitted to remove such a thorn by moving it in increments, each less than four cubits. The same applies to this skewer; since it might harm someone where it is, it may be moved to a corner.
Apropos Rav Malkiyu, to whom only a few <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> are attributed, the Gemara mentions that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥinnana, son of Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ika, said: </span>The <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a skewer </span>that had been used for roasting meat but no longer has an olive-bulk of meat on it, that it may be moved to a corner; and likewise, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">maidservants, </span>that even if a woman brought one hundred maidservants into the marriage as her dowry, her husband may nevertheless compel her to perform some sort of work so that her boredom not bring her to sin (<span class="it-text">Ketubot</span> 61b); <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span> finally, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">follicles, </span>that if a girl has two hair follicles in her pubic region, even if there are no hairs growing from them, she is considered to have reached majority and may perform <span class="it-text">ḥalitza</span>; these three <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> were all stated by <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Malkiyu.</span>
However, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">a forelock, </span>that a Jew who cuts the hair of a Samaritan must stop before he reaches his forelock at a distance of three fingerbreadths on every side, as the Samaritans would grow their forelocks for idolatry, and the Jew must not appear as if he were dressing the forelock for idolatrous purposes; and likewise, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">burnt ashes, </span>that one may not place them on a wound, as it looks like a tattoo; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>finally, the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">cheese </span>made by a gentile, that it is forbidden because gentiles smooth the surface of their cheese with lard; these three <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> were all stated by a different Sage named <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Malkiya.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Pappa said </span>a different principle: The teachings mentioned above that relate to <span class="gemarra-regular">a mishna or a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">baraita</span> were stated by <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Malkiya, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-italic">halakhot</span> that are not related to a mishna or <span class="it-text">baraita</span> were taught by <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Malkiyu. And your</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> mnemonic </span>to remember this <span class="gemarra-regular">is: The mishna is a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">queen </span>[<span class="gemarra-italic">malketa</span>]; the comments that are referring to a mishna were made by Rav Malkiya, whose name is similar to the Aramaic term for queen. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is</span> the practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>Rav Ḥinnana and Rav Pappa? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is </span>a practical difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between them </span>with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">maidservants. </span>According to Rav Ḥinnana, this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> was stated by Rav Malkiyu, whereas Rav Pappa holds that it was taught by Rav Malkiya, since it is referring to a dispute in a mishna. 
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A person </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not say to a butcher </span>on a Festival: <span class="gemarra-regular">Weigh for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">a dinar’s worth of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">meat, </span>since if he mentions a sum of money, it looks like a commercial transaction. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>the butcher may <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter </span>an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">and apportion it </span>among his customers without stipulating a price.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What </span>should one <span class="gemarra-regular">do </span>if he wishes to take part of an animal on a Festival, but is barred from mentioning its price? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">As</span>

Daf 29a

<span class="gemarra-regular">they would </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say in Sura: </span>Give me that cut of meat called <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tart</span><span class="gemarra-italic">a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or half a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tarta</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>without naming a price. <span class="gemarra-regular">In Neresh they would say </span>in reference to those same portions: <span class="gemarra-regular">A part or half a part. In Pumbedita </span><span class="gemarra-regular">they would say: An </span><span class="gemarra-italic">uzya</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or half an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">uzya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. In </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Nehar Pekod and in Mata Meḥasya they would say: </span>Give me <span class="gemarra-regular">a quarter or half a quarter, </span>thereby establishing the size of the portion without mentioning its price.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One <span class="gemarra-regular">person </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">sa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to another </span>on a Festival: <span class="gemarra-regular">Fill this vessel for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">me</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and I will return its contents or reimburse you after the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>he may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>ask him to fill the vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">in a </span>particular <span class="gemarra-regular">measure. Rabbi Yehuda says: If it was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a measuring utensil, he may not fill it. </span>There was <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving Abba </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Shau</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">ben </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Botnit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a Sage who was also a grocer, <span class="gemarra-regular">who would fill his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> measures on the eve of a Festival and give them</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">customers on the Festival. </span>In this way he would know exactly how much he had given each person, without conducting any measurements on the Festival itself. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abba Shaul, </span>a Sage distinct from Abba Shaul ben Botnit, <span class="gemarra-regular">says: He would do this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">even on </span>the intermediate days of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival because of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the clarity of the measures, </span>i.e., in order to clarify precisely how much must be given to each customer, since the measurement is more precise once the foam of the liquid being measured has subsided. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Even on a weekday </span>it is proper to <span class="gemarra-regular">do so, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">because of the draining of the measures. </span>This method allows all the liquid to drain fully out of the seller’s measuring utensil so that the amount is exact. 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">But not in a measure? Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: But not with a vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> designated for measuring; however, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">be used for measuring </span>but has yet to be used for this purpose, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">fill it. </span>According to this, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda comes to </span>disagree and <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not fill even a vessel that </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">be</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> used for measuring.</span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yehuda is stringent with regard to the joy of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Festival </span>in that he prohibits the use of any sort of measuring utensil, <span class="gemarra-regular">while the Rabbis are lenient. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we hear them </span>state <span class="gemarra-regular">the opposite, as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in an earlier mishna (28a) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: A person </span>selling meat on a Festival may <span class="gemarra-regular">weigh </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">meat against a vessel or against a cleaver, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis say: One </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not look at the pans </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of a </span>balance <span class="gemarra-regular">scale at all? Apparently, </span>here, the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda is lenient, while the </span>opinion of the <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis is stringent. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a contradiction between </span>the one statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda and </span>the other statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>as well as <span class="gemarra-regular">a contradiction between </span>the one statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis and </span>the other statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbis.</span>
The Gemara answers: With regard to the contradiction <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the one teaching of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda and </span>the other teaching of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. There, </span>where he is lenient, he is dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">that cannot be used</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for measuring </span>on a regular basis at all, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">here</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>he is referring to a vessel that <span class="gemarra-regular">can be used</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for measuring, </span>and therefore he is stringent even if the vessel has not yet actually been used in this capacity.
With regard to the contradiction <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>the one statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis and </span>the other statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">also not difficult</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. There, he is acting in a weekday manner, </span>and consequently they prohibit the weighing, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">here, he is not acting</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in a weekday manner, </span>as the vessel is not a measuring utensil, and consequently they permit him to use it. This completes the Gemara’s discussion of Shmuel’s explanation of the mishna. 
The Gemara offers a second explanation of the mishna. Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said: What is </span>the meaning of the phrase: <span class="gemarra-regular">But not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> by measure? </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">that he </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not mention to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him the name of the measure. </span>For example, he may not say: Fill for me one <span class="it-text">kav</span>, or two <span class="it-text">kav</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, he </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">fill a vessel </span>even if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">designated for measuring. And Rabbi Yehuda comes to say: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not fill a vessel designated for measuring, </span>even if he does not stipulate a particular measure. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, with regard to the joy of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Festival, Rabbi Yehuda is stringent, and the Rabbis are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lenient. But didn’t we hear them </span>state <span class="gemarra-regular">the opposite, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in an earlier mishna (28a) that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yehuda says: A person </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">weigh meat against a vessel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or against a cleaver, and the Rabbis </span>prohibit this and <span class="gemarra-regular">say: One </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not look at the pans of a </span>balance <span class="gemarra-regular">scale at all? Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda is lenient, while </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis are stringent. </span>Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is a contradiction between</span> one statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda and </span>the other statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>and there is also <span class="gemarra-regular">a contradiction between </span>one statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis and </span>the other statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbis.</span>
The Gemara answers: With regard to the contradiction <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>one teaching of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda and</span> the other teaching of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. There, </span>with regard to weighing meat against a vessel, he is dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">that is not designated </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for measuring, </span>and therefore he is lenient, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>he is referring to a vessel that <span class="gemarra-regular">is designated for measuring, </span>with regard to which he is stringent. With regard to the contradiction <span class="gemarra-regular">between </span>one statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis and </span>the other statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>this is <span class="gemarra-regular">also not difficult. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">There, he is acting in a weekday manner, </span>and consequently they prohibit the weighing, whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">here, he is not acting </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in a weekday manner, as people are accustomed to offer </span>their friends <span class="gemarra-regular">wine in a measuring utensil and drink. </span>Since the use of such a vessel is not exclusive to commercial transactions, the Rabbis permitted it here as well. 
§ The mishna recounted <span class="gemarra-regular">an incident involving Abba Shaul ben Botnit, </span>a Sage who was also a grocer, who would fill his measures on the eve of a Festival and give them to his customers on the Festival. A <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">He would do this even on </span>the intermediate days of <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival, in order to </span>prevent <span class="gemarra-regular">dereliction </span>of Torah study in <span class="gemarra-regular">the study hall. </span>Since he wanted to spend most of his day in the study hall and not have to interrupt his study to carry out measurements, he would measure for his customers at night, when it was not a time of study. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: Abba Shaul ben Botnit <span class="gemarra-regular">collected three hundred earthenware jugs of wine, </span>to which he thought he was not entitled <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the clarity of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the measures</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as he thought that he had unfairly profited from the foam at the top of the liquid he measured. <span class="gemarra-regular">And his colleagues, </span>similarly God-fearing grocers, <span class="gemarra-regular">collecte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> three hundred earthenware jugs of oil, </span>which they thought were not rightly theirs <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the draining of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">measures; </span>they were concerned that because they had measured for their customers using their own vessels, they might not have drained the entire measure from their containers into the customers’ vessels. <span class="gemarra-regular">And they brought </span>these jugs of wine and oil <span class="gemarra-regular">to Jerusalem before the </span>Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">treasurers, </span>as they did not want to benefit from possibly stolen goods. 
The treasurers <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: You </span><span class="gemarra-regular">need not do this, </span>as all buyers take into account the foam and what is left in the sellers’ vessels and pay with this in mind. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said to them: </span>Just like the buyers give up their claim to it, <span class="gemarra-regular">we too do not wish </span>to benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from this, </span>even if strictly speaking it is not considered stolen property.
The treasurers <span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Since you are </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">stringent with yourselves, use </span>the wine and oil <span class="gemarra-regular">for communal needs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If one <span class="gemarra-regular">stole and does not know </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from who</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he stole, he </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">use </span>the stolen items <span class="gemarra-regular">for communal needs, </span>thereby repaying all of the Jewish people. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What are </span>communal needs? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>He should finance the digging of <span class="gemarra-regular">cisterns, ditches, and caves</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>for storing water for travelers. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda authorized Rabbana Ukva </span>to give a public lecture, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he taught </span>the following: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not measure barle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and place </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">before</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his animal on a Festival, but he </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">cut out</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">koder</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> a hole in the pile of grain by means of a vessel of one <span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and place </span>the barley <span class="gemarra-regular">before his animal, and he need</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not be concerned </span>about the measuring this entails, as he does not transgress the prohibition against using a measuring utensil if he is not particular about measuring precisely. <span class="gemarra-regular">And a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> baker </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">measure spice</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and put them in his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pot, so as not to spoil his dish, </span>since if he puts in too much he will ruin the food.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yirmeya bar Abba said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">A woman </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">measure flour on a Festival and put </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it into her dough in order to separate </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalla</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> generously</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>because if she knows the exact amount of dough she can separate the proper amount of <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>It <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited, </span>as she can estimate the amount that must be set aside as <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span>. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t </span>a Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">of the school of Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teach </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> stating that this <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted? </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: Now that </span>it is known that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited and </span>a Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">of the school of Shmuel taught </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that it <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted, </span>

Daf 29b

it is reasonable to conclude that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel came to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teach us the practical </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Knowing that a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> permits the practice, Shmuel found it necessary to state that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is otherwise. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One</span> may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sift <span class="gemarra-regular">flour a second time on a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as this involves unnecessary extra effort. <span class="gemarra-regular">They said in the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> name of Rabbi Papeyyas and Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira: One</span> may sift flour <span class="gemarra-regular">a second time</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> However, they </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">agree that if a pebble or a wood chip fell</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> into </span>the flour after it had been sifted the previous day, one may sift it <span class="gemarra-regular">a second time </span>in order to remove the items.
<span class="gemarra-regular">A </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before Ravina: One </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>sift <span class="gemarra-regular">flour a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> second time on a Festival, but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">a pebbl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or a wood chip fell </span>into the flour after the first sifting, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">remove it with his hand. </span>Ravina <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: All the more so </span>is the latter procedure <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited, as it is similar to </span>the prohibited labor of <span class="gemarra-regular">selecting. </span>It is therefore preferable to sift the flour with a sieve, and the unwanted items will thereby be removed. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava bar Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Huna the Short taught at the entrance to Neharde’a: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>may sift <span class="gemarra-regular">flour a second time on a Festival. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said to </span>the students standing before him: <span class="gemarra-regular">Go </span><span class="gemarra-regular">out and say to Abba, </span>i.e., to Rava bar Rav Huna, as Rava is a shortened form of Rav Abba: <span class="gemarra-regular">Your good has been removed and cast upon thorns, </span>meaning that your teachings are not needed. <span class="gemarra-regular">Go out and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">see how many sieves circulat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in Neharde’a, </span>as all the women already know that this is permitted.
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef’s wife was </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">sifting flour </span>in an unusual manner <span class="gemarra-regular">on the reverse </span>side <span class="gemarra-regular">of a sieve. He said to her: Look, I want</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> good-quality bread</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> hinting that she need not invert the sieve but may sift the flour in her regular fashion. The Gemara likewise relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi’s wif</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was </span>once <span class="gemarra-regular">sifting flour onto a table, </span>rather than into a bowl in the usual manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">of ours, </span>my wife, is <span class="gemarra-regular">the daughter of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rami bar Ḥama, and Rami bar Ḥama is a master </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>good <span class="gemarra-regular">deeds </span>who is meticulous in his performance of mitzvot. <span class="gemarra-regular">Had </span>my wife <span class="gemarra-regular">not observed </span>this practice <span class="gemarra-regular">in her </span><span class="gemarra-regular">father’s house, she would not have acted </span>in this manner. Therefore, one can learn the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in practice from her actions.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A person </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">go </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a grocer </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">whom he is accustomed </span>to buy <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say to him: Give me eggs and nuts of </span>such-and-such <span class="gemarra-regular">a number, as it is the manner of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a homeowner to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">coun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> this way <span class="gemarra-regular">in his </span>own <span class="gemarra-regular">house</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Counting eggs or nuts is not considered a commercial activity, as people regularly mention the number of eggs and nuts that they need. 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person </span>may <span class="gemarra-regular">go </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">to a shepherd </span>with <span class="gemarra-regular">whom </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he is accustomed </span>to deal <span class="gemarra-regular">and say to him: Give </span><span class="gemarra-regular">me one kid, or one lamb. </span>Similarly, one may go on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">to a butcher </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">whom he is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">accustomed </span>to buy <span class="gemarra-regular">and say to him: Give me one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">foreleg </span>of an animal, <span class="gemarra-regular">or one thigh. </span>Likewise, one may approach <span class="gemarra-regular">one who deals in fattened </span>fowl from <span class="gemarra-regular">whom he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is accustomed </span>to buy <span class="gemarra-regular">and say to him: Give me </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one dove or one pigeon. </span>He may also visit <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">baker </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">whom he is accustomed </span>to buy <span class="gemarra-regular">and say </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him: Give me one loaf or one cake </span><span class="gemarra-regular">[</span><span class="gemarra-italic">g</span><span class="gemarra-italic">eluska</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one may go on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">to a grocer </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">whom he is accustomed </span>to buy <span class="gemarra-regular">and say to him: Give me twenty eggs, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or fifty nuts, </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">ten peaches, or five pomegranates, or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="gemarra-italic">etrog</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, provided that he does not mention any measure. </span>In other words, he must not specify a unit of measurement, e.g., a <span class="it-text">kav</span>; rather, he must state a number, which is not the usual manner of making a purchase. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: </span>This is permitted, <span class="gemarra-regular">provided that he does not mention the amount of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">purchase</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning that he must not mention the sum of money that he is spending, but rather he must take what he needs and after the Festival they will calculate how much he owes.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> brings wine </span><span class="gemarra-regular">jug</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">place to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">place </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may not bring </span>a large number of <span class="gemarra-regular">them in a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">basket or in a tub </span>in the usual weekday manner on a Festival, as this is disrespectful of the Festival; <span class="gemarra-regular">but he may bring </span>one or two barrels <span class="gemarra-regular">on his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">shoulder or </span>carry them <span class="gemarra-regular">in front of himself. Similarly, one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who brings </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stra</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> for kindling or for feeding animals <span class="gemarra-regular">may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not place the tub behind him </span>while carrying it, as this is the usual weekday manner; <span class="gemarra-regular">but he may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">transport it </span>in front of him <span class="gemarra-regular">in his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in an unusual fashion. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may begin </span>taking straw for kindling 

Daf 30a

<span class="gemarra-regular">from the pile of straw, </span>although he did not designate the pile for this purpose the day before; <span class="gemarra-regular">but one may not </span>begin to take from <span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wood in the </span>wood <span class="gemarra-regular">storage, </span>a small yard behind the house where people store various items that they do not intend to use in the near future.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> A <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If it is impossible to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">modify </span>the manner in which one carries a vessel, whether due to the vessel or due to time constraints, <span class="gemarra-regular">it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted </span>to act in the typical weekday manner.
The Gemara relates that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava instituted </span>the following <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>his city, <span class="gemarra-regular">Meḥoza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span> One <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>usually <span class="gemarra-regular">carries</span> his burden <span class="gemarra-regular">with difficult</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span> on a weekday <span class="gemarra-regular">should </span>modify his habit on a Festival and <span class="gemarra-regular">carry it on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pitchfork. </span>One <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>usually<span class="gemarra-regular"> carries it on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pitchfork should carry it on a carrying pol</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> held by two people on their shoulders. One <span class="gemarra-regular">who carries it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on a carrying pole </span>held by two people on their shoulders <span class="gemarra-regular">should carry it </span>on a carrying pole <span class="gemarra-regular">in his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hands, </span>although he is not thereby making it easier for himself. One <span class="gemarra-regular">who carries </span>burdens on a carrying pole <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">his hands should spread a scarf [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">sudara</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> over it. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And if it is not possibl</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to make these modifications due to time constraints, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted </span>to proceed in the usual manner, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the Master said above: If it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is impossible to modify, it is permitted.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥanan</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bar Rava said to Rav Ashi: The Sages said: As</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> much as it is possible to modify </span>the weekday manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">one should modify on a Festival. </span>A question was asked of Rav Ashi: <span class="gemarra-regular">But don’t those women fill </span><span class="gemarra-regular">their jug</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with water on a Festival without modifying, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we say nothing to them </span>by way of protest; why do we not instruct them to alter their usual manner? 
<span class="gemarra-regular">He</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to him: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is not possible</span> for them to fill their jugs any other way. <span class="gemarra-regular">How</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> should they act? </span>She <span class="gemarra-regular">who </span>is accustomed to <span class="gemarra-regular">filling a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> large jug, should </span>she instead <span class="gemarra-regular">fill a small jug</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> Won’t this mean that <span class="gemarra-regular">she increases </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">walking, </span>since she has to make more than one trip to bring home more than one jug, and she will thereby perform unnecessary labor on the Festival? 
If one were to suggest the opposite, <span class="gemarra-regular">that one who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fills a small jug should fill a large jug, </span>won’t this mean that <span class="gemarra-regular">she increases </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">load? </span>Furthermore, if one were to suggest that <span class="gemarra-regular">she should cover </span>the jug <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a wooden <span class="gemarra-regular">cover, sometimes </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">fall</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and she </span><span class="gemarra-regular">might come to bring it </span>by hand, in the manner of a burden. <span class="gemarra-regular">Should she tie </span>the cover to the jug, the rope might <span class="gemarra-regular">occasionally break, and she might come </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to tie it, </span>a prohibited labor. Finally, <span class="gemarra-regular">should she </span><span class="gemarra-regular">spread a scarf over it, </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">occasionally </span>falls off and <span class="gemarra-regular">becomes soaked in water</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and she might come to </span>transgress the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">squeezing. Therefore, it is not possible </span>to make a modification, and those women may act in the regular manner.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava bar Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Ḥanin said to Abaye: We learned </span>in a mishna: The Rabbis decreed that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not clap, nor strik</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> a hand on his thigh, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor dance </span>on a Festival, lest he come to repair musical instruments. <span class="gemarra-regular">But nowadays we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">see that </span>women <span class="gemarra-regular">do so, and </span>yet <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say anything to them.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">He said </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to him: And according to your reasoning, </span>how do you explain <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>which <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: A person should not sit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">at the entrance </span>to an alleyway, next to <span class="gemarra-regular">the side </span><span class="gemarra-regular">post </span>that has been placed at the edge of an alleyway in order for it to be considered a private domain, as <span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps an object </span>will <span class="gemarra-regular">roll </span>away <span class="gemarra-regular">from him </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and he will come to carry it four cubit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the public domain, </span>thereby transgressing a biblical prohibition? <span class="gemarra-regular">But don</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t these women take their jugs, and go, and sit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> at the entrance to an alleyway</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and we do</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not say anything to them?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the accepted principle is: <span class="gemarra-regular">Leave </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">Jews</span> alone; <span class="gemarra-regular">it is better that they be unwitting sinners </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and not be intentional sinners</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If people engage in a certain behavior that cannot be corrected, it is better not to reprove them, as they are likely to continue regardless of the reproof, and then they will be sinning intentionally. It is therefore preferable for them to be unaware that they are violating a prohibition and remain merely unwitting sinners. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, too, </span>with regard to clapping and dancing, <span class="gemarra-regular">leave</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">Jews </span>alone; <span class="gemarra-regular">it is better that they be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">unwitting sinners and not be intentional sinners.</span>
The Gemara comments: There were those who understood that <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">applies only to rabbinic </span>prohibitions <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>not to <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah </span>prohibitions, with regard to which the transgressors must be reprimanded. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, this is not so; </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">no different</span> whether the prohibition is <span class="gemarra-regular">by Torah </span>law <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>whether it is <span class="gemarra-regular">by rabbinic </span>law, <span class="gemarra-regular">we do not say anything </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to them. </span>For example, on the eve of Yom Kippur, there is an obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>one begin the fast while it is still day, before sunset, as <span class="gemarra-regular">the extension of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yom Kippur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> During this time, one must observe all the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>. This mitzva of extending Yom Kippur <span class="gemarra-regular">is by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Torah </span>law, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>yet people <span class="gemarra-regular">eat and drink until darkness</span> falls <span class="gemarra-regular">but we do not say anything to them, </span>as we know they will pay no attention.
It is taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may begin </span>taking straw <span class="gemarra-regular">from the pile of straw. Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Kahana said: That is to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may begin </span>removing items <span class="gemarra-regular">from a storeroom </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Although the items in this storeroom are designated for other purposes, it is not assumed that one put them out of his mind. If so, in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion is this mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, who is not </span>of the opinion that there is a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-regular">set-aside [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. </span>According to him, on Shabbat and Festivals it is not prohibited to handle items that one has removed from his mind.
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say the latter clause </span>of the same mishna as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">But not wood in the </span>wood <span class="gemarra-regular">storage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">we have come to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda, who is </span>of the opinion that there is a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, we are dealing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with </span>wood of <span class="gemarra-regular">cedars and firs</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which are expensive and used only in the construction of important buildings, not for kindling; the wood storage is therefore considered <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to </span>potential <span class="gemarra-regular">monetary loss. </span>With regard to an item that one removes from his mind due to the financial loss he might suffer were he to use it, but not due to any prohibition involved, <span class="gemarra-regular">even Rabbi Shimon concedes </span>that it may not be handled due to the prohibition of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">There are </span>those <span class="gemarra-regular">who taught </span>the statement of Rav Kahana as referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to the latter clause</span> of the mishna, as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">But not wood from the</span> wood <span class="gemarra-regular">storage </span>area. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana said: That is to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not begin </span>removing items <span class="gemarra-regular">from a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">storeroom </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If so, in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion is the mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who is </span>maintains that there is a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">Say the first </span><span class="gemarra-regular">clause </span>of the mishna, which states that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may begin </span>taking <span class="gemarra-regular">from the pile of straw</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> have come to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, who is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>of the opinion that there is a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the first clause of the mishna, it is dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with straw </span>that has rotted <span class="gemarra-regular">and become rancid. </span>Since it is no longer fit as animal fodder, even Rabbi Yehuda concedes that it will be used for kindling and is not <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t rancid straw fit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for clay </span>in the making of bricks; why can one assume that it will be used as fuel? The Gemara answers: The mishna is referring to straw <span class="gemarra-regular">that has thorns</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which cannot be kneaded into clay. It will certainly be used only for kindling. 

Daf 30b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not take wood from a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span> on any Festival, not only on the festival of <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span>, because this is considered dismantling, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>one may take <span class="gemarra-regular">from near it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara poses a question with regard to the mishna: In <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this case <span class="gemarra-regular">different? </span>Why did the mishna teach that <span class="gemarra-regular">from the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span> itself one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>remove wood? It is because <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">dismantles a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">tent</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> which is a prohibited labor. But if so, if one takes wood <span class="gemarra-regular">from near it, too, </span>doesn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">dismantle </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a tent? </span>Why, then, does the mishna permit him to do so?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: What is </span>the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">Near </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it? </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">near the walls. </span>Wood placed near the walls may be removed because it is not part of the <span class="it-text">sukka</span> itself; the walls themselves may not be removed. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Menashya said: Even </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the wood <span class="gemarra-regular">is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">near the walls </span>but is part of the roof of the <span class="it-text">sukka</span> itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">when that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">was taught, it was </span>with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to bundle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> of reeds that are not considered part of the roof of the <span class="it-text">sukka</span>, as they have not been untied. Therefore, one may remove them.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef taught </span>the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">before Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yoḥanan: One may not take wood from the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span> itself <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">from the nearby </span>wood. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shimon permits</span> one to take wood from the <span class="it-text">sukka</span> as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> all <span class="gemarra-regular">agree, </span>even Rabbi Shimon, that with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to the</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span> that was built for the <span class="gemarra-regular">festival </span>of<span class="it-text">Sukkot</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">during</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Festival it is prohibited </span>to remove wood from it. <span class="gemarra-regular">But if </span>at the outset <span class="gemarra-regular">one stipulated </span>a condition <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to it </span>allowing him to use it for other purposes, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">all according to his stipulation. </span>
The Gemara questions this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon permit </span>one to take wood from the <span class="it-text">sukka</span> itself? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t one dismantling a tent, </span>which is a prohibited labor? The Gemara answers that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Yitzḥak said: Here, we are dealing with a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span> that has already <span class="gemarra-regular">collapsed. </span>Therefore, the only potential concern is <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, not dismantling. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shimon </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as he is not </span>of the opinion that there is a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If a wick in oil was lit before Shabbat, and it went out on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">the remainder of the oil in a lam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a bowl is prohibited </span>for use, as it is <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Shimon permits </span>one to use it. Consequently, Rabbi Shimon also permits one to take wood from the <span class="it-text">sukka</span>.
The Gemara rejects this claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it comparable? There, </span>in the case of oil in a lamp, <span class="gemarra-regular">a person sits and anticipate</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> when his lamp </span><span class="gemarra-regular">will be extinguished. </span>It is clear to him that it will be extinguished, and he can safely assume that a certain amount of oil will remain in the lamp or the bowl. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>however, can it be said that <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> person sits and anticipates when his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will fall? </span>He cannot know ahead of time that his <span class="it-text">sukka</span> will collapse. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: Here, we are dealing with a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span> that is <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sturdy</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as from yesterday, </span>the Festival eve, <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">had his mind on it. </span>He thought it might collapse, and therefore he did not remove the possibility of using its wood from his mind.
§ The above <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states: <span class="gemarra-regular">All agree with regard to the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span> that was built for the <span class="gemarra-regular">festival </span>of <span class="it-text">Sukkot</span>, that <span class="gemarra-regular">during </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Festival it is prohibited </span>to remove wood from it, <span class="gemarra-regular">but if one stipulated </span>a condition <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">all according to his condition. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is a condition effective with </span>regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">it?</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Rav Sheshet say </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the name of Rabbi Akiva: From where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that the wood of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to be used for any other use <span class="gemarra-regular">all seven </span>days of the Festival? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is stated: “The festival </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the Lord</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> seven days” </span>(Leviticus 23:34). <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught </span>in a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in explanation of this that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says: From </span><span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>is it derived <span class="gemarra-regular">that just as the name of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Heaven takes effect upon the Festival peace-offering, so too</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, does the name of Heaven take effect upon the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? The verse states: “The festival of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Sukkot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to the Lord</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, seven days” </span>(Leviticus 23:34), from which it is learned: <span class="gemarra-regular">Just as the Festival </span>offering is consecrated <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Lord, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so too, the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span> is consecrated <span class="gemarra-regular">to the Lord. </span>Since the wood of the <span class="it-text">sukka</span> is compared to consecrated objects, how may one stipulate a condition with regard to it?
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Menashya, son of Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, said: </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause, </span>where the stipulation is mentioned, <span class="gemarra-regular">we have arrived at </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a regular </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>a hut used throughout the year, not specifically for the Festival. With regard to such a <span class="it-text">sukka</span>, one may stipulate to use the wood as he wishes; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of mitzva, </span>used for the Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">a condition</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not effective with regard to it. </span>
The Gemara asks a question from a different angle: <span class="gemarra-regular">And is </span>a condition <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>effective for <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of mitzva? But isn’t it taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>: In the case of a <span class="it-text">sukka</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">one roofed in accordance with its </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and decorated it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with embroidered </span>clothes <span class="gemarra-regular">and with patterned sheets, and hung on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it nuts, almonds, peaches, pomegranates, and vines [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">parkilei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> grapes </span>and glass containers filled with <span class="gemarra-regular">wine, oil, and flour, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wreaths of ears of corn </span>for decoration, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is prohibited</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to derive benefit </span>from any of these <span class="gemarra-regular">until the conclusion</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of the last Festival day. But if one stipulated </span>a condition <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to them </span>whereby he allows himself to use them, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">all according to his condition</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> This shows that conditions are effective even with regard to a <span class="it-text">sukka</span> of mitzva.
The Gemara answers based on the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and Rava, who both say </span>that this is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one says: I am not removing </span>myself <span class="gemarra-regular">from them throughout twilight. </span>In other words, he announces from the outset that he will not set them aside as <span class="it-text">sukka</span> decorations, but rather he will use them for other purposes as well. In that case, <span class="gemarra-regular">no sanctity devolves upon</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> them </span>at all, and he may therefore use them throughout the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>as for the actual <span class="gemarra-regular">wood of a</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">sukka</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sanctity devolves upon it </span>through the very construction of the <span class="it-text">sukka</span>, and <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>has therefore been <span class="gemarra-regular">set aside </span>from use <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>the entire <span class="gemarra-regular">seven </span>days.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>way is it <span class="gemarra-regular">different </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from that which was stated </span>with regard to a different <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: In the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">separated seven </span><span class="gemarra-italic">etrogi</span><span class="gemarra-italic">m</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span>each of <span class="gemarra-regular">the seven </span>Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">days, </span>one for each day, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: He fulfills </span>his obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">through each </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and every one </span>of them when he recites the blessing over the <span class="it-text">lulav</span> and <span class="it-text">etrog</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>if he so desires <span class="gemarra-regular">he may eat it immediately </span>after the blessing. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Asi said: He fulfills </span>his obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">through each one, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he may eat it the following day, </span>as it retains its sanctity for the duration of that entire day. In any case, all agree that the sanctity of each <span class="it-text">etrog</span> does not extend to the following day. If so, why does the sanctity of the <span class="it-text">sukka</span> extend through all seven days?
The Gemara answers: There is a difference between an <span class="it-text">etrog</span> and a <span class="it-text">sukka</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>with regard to an <span class="it-text">etrog</span>, the <span class="gemarra-regular">nights are divide</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from the days, </span>as the mitzva of <span class="it-text">etrog</span> applies only during the day and not at night. This means that <span class="gemarra-regular">each and every day is its</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> own mitzva, </span>and therefore an item that is sanctified for one day is not necessarily sanctified for the following day. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>with regard to a <span class="it-text">sukka</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">nights</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are not divided from the days, </span>as the mitzva of <span class="it-text">sukka</span> applies at night as well, <span class="gemarra-regular">all </span>seven <span class="gemarra-regular">days are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> considered as one long day. </span>Throughout the Festival, there is no moment during which the sanctity of <span class="it-text">sukka</span> leaves the wood; it leaves only at the conclusion of the Festival. 

Daf 31a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One may bring wood </span>chopped from a tree the previous day <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>an unfenced <span class="gemarra-regular">field, </span>but only <span class="gemarra-regular">from that which has been gathered </span>into a pile before the Festival for the purpose of using it for kindling. However, scattered wood is <span class="it-text">muktze</span> and may not be handled. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>if one brings wood <span class="gemarra-regular">from a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">karpef</span> used for storage, he may bring <span class="gemarra-regular">even from the scattered </span>wood, as it is considered a guarded courtyard rather than a field, and one does not remove even scattered items from his mind if they are stored inside such an enclosure. The mishna explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">karpef</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> It is <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>enclosure <span class="gemarra-regular">that is near a city, </span>but if it is far from a city, it is considered a field; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: Any </span>fenced place <span class="gemarra-regular">into which one </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">enter </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">with a key </span>is a <span class="it-text">karpef</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>if it is located at a distance from a city, provided that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">within the Shabbat limit.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: One may not bring </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wood except from </span>the wood that was <span class="gemarra-regular">gathered in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">karpef</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn</span> in the mishna: And <span class="gemarra-regular">from a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">karpef</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, even from scattered</span> wood? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna </span>follows <span class="gemarra-regular">an individual </span>opinion. 
One may not rely on it, as is clear from a different source that the majority view is otherwise, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Beit Shammai and Beit</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Hillel did not disagree with regard to </span>wood <span class="gemarra-regular">scattered in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fields that one may not bring </span>it on a Festival to one’s house for kindling, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor with regard to</span> wood <span class="gemarra-regular">gathered in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">karpef</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that one may bring </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what did they disagree? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to scattered </span>wood <span class="gemarra-regular">in a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">karpef</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and gathered </span>wood <span class="gemarra-regular">in fields, as Beit Shammai say: He may not bring</span> it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel say: He may bring </span>it. Although the lenient opinion with regard to gathered wood in a field is attributed to Beit Hillel, this is only according to the minority view of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar. However, most Sages disagree and say that one may not bring wood from a field at all, even according to Beit Hillel.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">reed leaves and vine leaves</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> although they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are gathered </span>together <span class="gemarra-regular">and placed </span>in the same spot, <span class="gemarra-regular">since</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> if a wind comes it will scatter them, </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">are</span> already <span class="gemarra-regular">considered scattered and are </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. </span>Given that they are likely to be scattered in the wind, one does not intend to use them. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">if one placed a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> vessel on them the day before </span>to prevent their being scattered in the wind, <span class="gemarra-regular">it seems well </span>and is permitted. 
The mishna discussed the question: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">karpef</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>Rabbi Yehuda states that it is any enclosure that is near a city, while in Rabbi Yosei’s opinion it is any fenced place into which one can enter only with a key, provided that it is within the Shabbat limit of a city. <span class="gemarra-regular">A dilemma was raised before </span>the Sages: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">speaking? </span>Does Rabbi Yehuda mean to say that a <span class="it-text">karpef</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">any </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">that is near a city</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> provided that it has </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a key, </span>otherwise it is not a <span class="it-text">karpef</span> at all; <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Yosei comes to say: Since it has a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">key, even </span>if it is not near a city, as long as it is <span class="gemarra-regular">within the Shabbat limit </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>considered a <span class="it-text">karpe</span><span class="it-text">f</span>? According to this understanding, Rabbi Yosei’s view is more lenient than that of Rabbi Yehuda. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps this is what </span>Rabbi Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Any </span>enclosure <span class="gemarra-regular">that is near a city</span> is a <span class="it-text">karpef</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">whether it has a key or does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not have a key, and Rabbi Yosei comes to say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>With regard to the distance, it is a <span class="it-text">karpef</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">even</span> if it is not near a city, provided that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">within the Shabbat limit, but specifically if it has</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a key. However, if it does not have a key</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, even </span>if it is <span class="gemarra-regular">near a city </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">also</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>considered a <span class="it-text">karpef</span>. According to this understanding, the opinion of Rabbi Yosei is not necessarily the more lenient one; rather, for him the defining issue is whether or not there is a key, regardless of distance. 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear from </span>the fact <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught </span>in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Any </span>place <span class="gemarra-regular">into which one enters with a key, even </span><span class="gemarra-regular">within the Shabbat limit, </span>and he does not say: If one enters, but rather: Any place into which one enters, it shows that the key is not the determining factor. One may <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from this </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei stated two </span>conditions <span class="gemarra-regular">as leniencies. </span>In other words, he is not more stringent than Rabbi Yehuda in any situation; he is lenient in all cases. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from here </span>that this is the case. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Salla said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yirmeya said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yosei as a leniency; </span>Rabbi Yosei should be understood in this manner, and one should rule accordingly. 
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not chop wood </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">neither from beams</span> intended for construction <span class="gemarra-regular">nor from a beam that broke on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a Festival, </span>although it no longer serves any purpose. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one may not chop </span>wood on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">neither with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an ax, nor with a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">saw</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">nor with a</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">sickle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as these are clearly craftsman’s tools used on weekdays. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, one may </span>chop only <span class="gemarra-regular">with a cleaver</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>Using this tool differs greatly from the weekday manner in which wood is chopped. 

Daf 31b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara wonders at the wording of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t you say in the first clause </span>of the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not chop </span>beams <span class="gemarra-regular">at all</span> on a Festival, ostensibly due to the extra effort involved? Why, then, does the mishna later define how one may chop, and even permit the use of a cleaver? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and is teaching the following: One may not chop </span>wood <span class="gemarra-regular">from the pile of beams </span>intended for construction, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a beam that broke on the Festival </span>itself, as it is considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, one may chop </span>wood <span class="gemarra-regular">from a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">beam that broke on the eve of the Festival, </span>since it has presumably been designated as firewood.
Yet even <span class="gemarra-regular">when one chop</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> such a beam, it must not be done in the weekday manner; an adjustment must be made. Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not chop </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">neither with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an ax</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor with a saw, nor with a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sickle, but with a cleaver. </span>The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>opinion, which is in accordance with the opinion of Shmuel, <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not chop</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> wood, neither from the pile of beams nor from the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> beam that broke on the Festival </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not considered prepared.</span>
