It is taught in the mishna that even when it is permitted to chop wood on a Festival, one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>do so <span class="gemarra-regular">with an ax. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥinnana bar Shelemya said in the name of Rav: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">They taught </span>this prohibition <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>with regard to a case where one chops <span class="gemarra-regular">with its female </span>side, i.e., the broad side of the ax, as was normally done. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if one chops <span class="gemarra-regular">with its male </span>side, i.e., the narrow side, this <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted </span>because it is an unusual manner of chopping. 
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">It </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that one may do so in this unusual fashion, as <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in the mishna that it is permitted to chop <span class="gemarra-regular">with a cleaver, </span>and chopping with the narrow side of an ax is similar to chopping with a cleaver. The Gemara explains: It was necessary to teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say: This applies only</span> to <span class="gemarra-regular">a cleaver, </span>as it is narrow on both sides, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>with regard to a tool that is <span class="gemarra-regular">an ax</span> on one side <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>like <span class="gemarra-regular">a cleaver </span>on the other, one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Since this side, </span>that which is like an ax, <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited, the other, side, </span>which is like a cleaver, should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. </span>Rav therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches </span><span class="gemarra-regular">us </span>that the cleaver side is in fact permitted. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">some teach this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> in relation <span class="gemarra-regular">to the latter clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, with a cleaver. Rav Ḥinnana bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shelemya said in the name of Rav: They taught </span>that it is permitted to chop wood on a Festival from a beam that was broken the day before, as stated previously, when one does so <span class="gemarra-regular">only with its male </span>side; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if he chops <span class="gemarra-regular">with its female </span>side, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited. </span>The Gemara challenges: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious. </span>Didn’t <span class="gemarra-regular">we </span><span class="gemarra-regular">learn </span>in the mishna that one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>use <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ax? </span>The Gemara answers: It was necessary to teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">lest you say: This </span>prohibition <span class="gemarra-regular">applies </span>only to <span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ax, but </span>with regard to a utensil that is both <span class="gemarra-regular">an ax and a cleaver</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., that is broad on one side and narrow on the other, one might <span class="gemarra-regular">say: Since this side, </span>the narrower one, <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the other, </span>broader <span class="gemarra-regular">side </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>be <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted. </span>Rav therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that they did not permit one side due to the other. 
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a house that is filled with produce </span>and locked on all sides, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a hole </span><span class="gemarra-regular">forme</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in one of its walls or its roof, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may remove</span> produce <span class="gemarra-regular">through the place of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hole</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The produce is not considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, even though one cannot reach it without the existence of the hole. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may even make a hole </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and take </span>produce through that opening. 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara wonders at Rabbi Meir’s statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>does he permit one to make a hole in order to remove the produce <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">Isn’t </span>one who does so <span class="gemarra-regular">dismantling</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a tent, </span>thereby performing a biblically prohibited labor? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥumi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bar Adda said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>Here, it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to bricks </span>placed <span class="gemarra-regular">one on top of the other [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">aveira</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">delivni</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> but not cemented together. This is not considered a building at all. The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? But didn’t Rav Naḥman say: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">these</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bricks </span><span class="gemarra-regular">remainin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">g</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from a building, it is permitted to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">handle them on Shabbat, since they are fit to sit </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on; </span>however, if <span class="gemarra-regular">one arranged them </span>in rows, one on top of the other, <span class="gemarra-regular">he has certainly set them aside </span>from his intentions? This indicates that even bricks placed on top of one another without being cemented together are nonetheless considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said: </span>Rabbi Meir was referring to a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">On a Festival they said </span>that one may do so, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>allow it <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat </span>even in such a manner, and Rav Naḥman was speaking of Shabbat. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">was also taught </span>explicitly in the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir says: One may even make a hole </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and remove </span>the produce from inside; <span class="gemarra-regular">they said </span>this with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival, but not</span> with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">fastenings </span>made of knotted ropes <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>are attached <span class="gemarra-regular">to the groun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> and that serve as closures for doors of cellars and caves, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> untie </span>the knot, <span class="gemarra-regular">but one may not unrave</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> the rope itself into its constituent fibers <span class="gemarra-regular">nor cut </span>the rope. This constitutes the prohibited labor of dismantling the cellar or cave on Shabbat. With regard to fastenings <span class="gemarra-regular">that are on </span>the doors of <span class="gemarra-regular">vessels</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> e.g., cupboards, it is permitted to <span class="gemarra-regular">untie, or unravel, or cut </span>them if necessary, <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat and </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival, </span>as the prohibition against dismantling does not apply to vessels. 
The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises an objection </span>to this from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">fastenings that </span>are attached <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the ground, </span>which are on doors, <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat one may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">untie </span>the rope <span class="gemarra-regular">but not unravel or cut </span>it. Although it is permitted to do so by Torah law, the Sages prohibited it. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival, one may untie </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or unravel or cut </span>it, as this is not prohibited even by rabbinic law. This appears to contradict the opinion of Shmuel, who does not differentiate between Shabbat and Festivals. 
Shmuel could respond: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Meir, who said: One may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> even make a hole and remove </span>produce <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, whereas</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the Rabbis disagree with him </span>and prohibit it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and I</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> spoke in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And do the Rabbis disagree with him </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to </span>doors <span class="gemarra-regular">sealed to the ground? But isn’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Rabbis concede to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Meir with regard to </span>doors <span class="gemarra-regular">sealed to the ground</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that one may untie </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat but not unravel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or cut </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">while on a Festival one may untie</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> or unravel or cut </span>them? 

Daf 32a

The Gemara responds: It was <span class="gemarra-regular">he, </span>Shmuel, <span class="gemarra-regular">who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> spoke in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">fastenings that are to the ground, </span>e.g., those on doors, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may untie </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">but not unravel or cut </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat and </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival. And </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">those </span>fastenings <span class="gemarra-regular">of a vessel, on Shabbat one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may untie </span>them, <span class="gemarra-regular">but one may not unravel or cut </span>them; <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival one may untie, or unravel, or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cut </span>them. 
The Gemara challenges further: <span class="gemarra-regular">You have </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">answered the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> first clause </span>of Shmuel’s statement, with regard to fastenings attached to the ground, e.g., those on doors, by finding a <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who permits untying them, as does Shmuel. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, the latter clause </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">difficult </span>because the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states that one may not unravel even ropes of vessels on Shabbat, whereas Shmuel permits unraveling in all cases. 
The Gemara answers: In accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span>opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">is this</span> <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">It is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Neḥemya, </span>whose opinion is a minority view, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: All vessels may be handled only in the manner </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of their </span>designated <span class="gemarra-regular">use. </span>Therefore, the rope may not be cut, not because it is prohibited to unravel it but because one may not handle a knife for this purpose, as the designated use of the knife is cutting food rather than rope. 
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>it is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Neḥemya, why </span>discuss <span class="gemarra-regular">particularly Shabbat? </span>The same <span class="it-text">halakha</span> should apply <span class="gemarra-regular">even on a Festival, </span>as there is no distinction between Shabbat and Festivals with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of handling items. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a distinction </span>according <span class="gemarra-regular">to Rabbi Neḥemya between a rabbinic decree</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Shabbat, </span>when a vessel may be moved only for its designated purpose, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a rabbinic decree of a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>when it may not be moved for any purpose, there is a problem. <span class="gemarra-regular">Does he differentiate </span>between them in this manner? 
<span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: On a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">one may kindle </span>fire <span class="gemarra-regular">with vessels, but one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not kindle </span>fire <span class="gemarra-regular">with shards of vessels, </span>as they are <span class="it-text">muktze</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">And it is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may kindle </span>fire <span class="gemarra-regular">both with vessels and with shards </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of vessels. And it is taught </span>in yet <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may kindle </span>fire <span class="gemarra-regular">neither with vessels nor with shards</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of vessels. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this contradiction between the <span class="it-text">baraitot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is resolved </span>in the following manner: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult; this </span>first <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>who accepts the law of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. One may therefore kindle fire with vessels, as they are not <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, but not with shards of vessels, as they are <span class="it-text">muktze</span> and may not be handled. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>who does not accept the law of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. According to him, one may use shards of vessels as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>one that prohibits using even vessels that are intact is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Neḥemya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who allows vessels to be used only for their designated purpose. This indicates that Rabbi Neḥemya prohibits handling even whole vessels on Festivals as well. 
The Gemara replies: These are <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna’im</span> who both hold <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Neḥemya. </span>Two later <span class="it-text">tanna’im</span> disagreed with each other in reporting the opinion of Rabbi Neḥemya. Both agree that one may use vessels only for their designated purpose, but they disagree with regard to whether this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> applies only on Shabbat or on Festivals as well.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> On a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not hollow out </span>a piece of clay to form <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> into which he will place oil and a wick <span class="gemarra-regular">because he </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">creates a vessel. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not produce </span><span class="gemarra-regular">charcoa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> at all <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a Festival </span>because this is not labor for sustenance. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span> similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not cut the wick, </span>as this is considered mending a vessel. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span>If one requires a wick of a particular length, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may cut it</span> by burning it <span class="gemarra-regular">in a fire </span>but not by cutting it with a knife.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Who </span>is the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> who <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">hollowing out a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered creating <span class="gemarra-regular">a vessel, </span>even if it is not fired in a furnace? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said: It is Rabbi Meir, as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> with regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of ritual impurity: <span class="gemarra-regular">From when is an earthenware vessel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">susceptible to ritual impurity? </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">from when its work </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">completed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., when the clay has been made into the form of a vessel; this is <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehoshua says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">is fired in the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">furnace.</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: From where </span>do you conclude that this is the same opinion? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps Rabbi Meir stated </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">only there, </span>with regard to vessels, <span class="gemarra-regular">since they are fit to contain </span><span class="gemarra-regular">something. </span>Although they cannot hold liquids before being fired in a furnace, they can contain other items. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what </span>use <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this lamp <span class="gemarra-regular">fit? </span>The Gemara responds: It can be used <span class="gemarra-regular">to contain </span>small <span class="gemarra-regular">coins</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>the following version of the discussion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>The mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as we learned: </span><span class="gemarra-italic">Ḥaraniyyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pots [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ilpasin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> are unfinished earthenware pots made together with their covers. The covers are removed after they are fired in a furnace. They are <span class="gemarra-regular">pure </span>with regard to contracting the impurity <span class="gemarra-regular">of a tent over a corpse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as they do not have a receptacle. Earthenware vessels can contract impurity imparted by a corpse only if they have a hollow space that can contain something. But <span class="it-text">ḥaraniyyot</span> pots are rendered <span class="gemarra-regular">impure by the carrying of a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> even if the <span class="it-text">zav</span> moved them without actually touching them, as this impurity applies to any earthenware vessels that serve some purpose.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says: </span>These vessels are <span class="gemarra-regular">even pure</span> with regard to the impurity imparted by the <span class="gemarra-regular">carrying of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">zav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> because their labor is not completed; </span>therefore, they are not fully formed. This implies that when the pots are completed, they are considered full-fledged vessels, even before they have been fired in a furnace. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to him: Perhaps </span>it is not so, as it is possible to say that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, son</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rabbi Tzadok, stated </span>his opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">only there, </span>in the case of <span class="it-text">ḥaraniyyot</span> pots, <span class="gemarra-regular">since they are fit to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">contain something. But here, </span>in the case of a lamp, <span class="gemarra-regular">for what is </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">fit? </span>The Gemara replies: It is fit <span class="gemarra-regular">to contain </span>small <span class="gemarra-regular">coins.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: One may not hollow out a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lamp, and one may not create </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥaraniyyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pots on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel permits </span>creating <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥaraniyyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pots. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥaraniyyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda said: </span>They are pots <span class="gemarra-regular">of a city [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">iraniyyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]. </span>The Gemara again inquires: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of <span class="gemarra-italic">iraniyyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Abaye said: </span>It means <span class="gemarra-regular">villager</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s’ </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bowls </span>who will use even clay vessels that have not been fully formed or fired, as they are not particular with regard to half-finished utensils.
It is taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">produce charcoa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> on a Festival. The Gemara challenges: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that one may perform only labor for sustenance. <span class="gemarra-regular">For</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> what is </span>charcoal <span class="gemarra-regular">fit; </span>what purpose does it have for the sake of sustenance? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya taught: It is necessary</span> to teach this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">handing</span> the charcoal <span class="gemarra-regular">over to bathhouse attendants [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">olyarin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> who heat up the bathhouse <span class="gemarra-regular">for that day. </span>One might have thought that since charcoal is used for the sake of washing on a Festival, producing it should be permitted. 
The Gemara questions this: <span class="gemarra-regular">And on that day is it permitted </span>to heat up water for washing? The Sages decreed that one may not wash in a bathhouse on a Festival, even if the water was heated up the day before, and certainly it is prohibited if the water was heated on the Festival itself. The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">As Rava said </span>with regard to a different issue, this decree does not refer to actual washing but to entering a bathhouse merely in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to sweat, and </span>it was stated <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the enactment of the <span class="gemarra-regular">decree </span>against sweating in a bathhouse. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, too, </span>one can explain that the statement of Rabbi Ḥiyya is referring to a case where one entered <span class="gemarra-regular">to sweat, and </span>he entered at a time <span class="gemarra-regular">before </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">decree </span>was enacted.
It was taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not cut a wick into two, </span>but Rabbi Yehuda permits cutting it by means of fire. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is different </span>about cutting a wick with fire as opposed to with a knife, <span class="gemarra-regular">that one may not </span>cut a wick <span class="gemarra-regular">with a knife? </span>

Daf 32b

 Is it because <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">mends a vessel? </span>If so, when one cuts it <span class="gemarra-regular">in the fire, he is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">also preparing a vessel </span>for use. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya taught </span>in explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">He cuts it by fir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the mouth </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of two candles. </span>In other words, he does not simply cut a wick, but rather inserts a long wick into two lamps, which he subsequently lights in the middle. This indeed leads to the formation of two separate wicks, but only as a result of kindling two lamps. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Natan </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar Abba said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: One may </span><span class="gemarra-italic">moḥet</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wic</span><span class="gemarra-regular">k</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a Festival. </span>The term <span class="it-text">moḥet</span> was unknown, and the Gemara therefore asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is </span>the meaning of the word <span class="gemarra-italic">moḥet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? Rav Ḥanina bar Shelemya said in the name</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rav: To remove the dark</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> in other words, it is permitted to remove the burnt, charcoaled section to make the lamp shine more brightly.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Bar Kappara taught: Six matters were stated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to </span>the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-regular">a wick </span>on a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>of which <span class="gemarra-regular">are to be stringent and three</span> of which <span class="gemarra-regular">are to be lenient</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The three <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to be stringent </span>are: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not spin </span>or twist <span class="gemarra-regular">it </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on a Festival, and one may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> singe it in fire </span>before lighting it so that it will burn well, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one may not cut it into</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> two. </span>The three <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">to be lenient </span>are: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may crush it by hand, </span>as although it is prohibited to twist it into a wick, one may adjust its shape in an unusual manner; <span class="gemarra-regular">and one may soak it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in oil </span>so that it will later burn well; <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one may cut it by fire in the mouth of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">two candles</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ After citing one teaching in the name of Rav Natan bar Abba, the Gemara quotes a few more statements attributed to the same scholar. Since he is not mentioned often, Rav Natan’s teachings are arranged together, so that they can be remembered more easily. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Natan bar Abba said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: The wealthy </span>Jews <span class="gemarra-regular">of Babylonia will descend to Gehenna </span>because they do not have compassion on others. This is illustrated by incidents <span class="gemarra-regular">such as this: Shabbetai bar Marinu</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> happened</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to come to Babylonia. He requested </span>their participation in <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> business venture, </span>to lend him money and receive half the profits in return, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they did not give </span>it to <span class="gemarra-regular">him. </span>Furthermore, when he asked them <span class="gemarra-regular">to sustain him </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with food, they likewise refused to sustain him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">He said: These </span>wealthy people are not descendants of our forefathers, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they came from the mixed multitude, as it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is written: “And show you compassion</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and have compassion </span><span class="gemarra-regular">upon you, </span>and multiply you, as He has sworn to your fathers” (Deuteronomy 13:18), from which it is derived: <span class="gemarra-regular">Anyone who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has compassion </span>for God’s <span class="gemarra-regular">creatures, it is known that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he is of the descendants of Abraham, our father, and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> anyone who does not have compassion </span>for God’s <span class="gemarra-regular">creatures</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, it is known that he is not of the descendants</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Abraham, our father. </span>Since these wealthy Babylonians do not have compassion on people, clearly they are not descended from Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
This is another teaching that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Natan bar</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Abba said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: Whoever looks to the table</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of others </span>for his sustenance, <span class="gemarra-regular">the world is dark for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him. </span>Everything looks bleak and hopeless to him, <span class="gemarra-regular">for it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is stated: “He wanders abroad for bread: Where is it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? He knows the day of darkness is ready at his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hand” </span>(Job 15:23). <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: Even his life </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is no life, </span>as he receives no satisfaction from it.
In support of this last claim, the Gemara cites a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> in which <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages taught: </span>There are <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span>whose <span class="gemarra-regular">lives are not lives, and they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are as follows: One who looks to the table of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">others </span>for his sustenance; <span class="gemarra-regular">and one whose wife rules </span>over <span class="gemarra-regular">him; and one whose body is ruled by suffering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And some say: Even one who has only one robe. </span>Since he cannot wash it properly, he suffers from lice and dirt. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the first </span><span class="gemarra-italic">tanna</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>who did not include such a person, maintains: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is possible</span> for him <span class="gemarra-regular">to examine his clothes </span>and remove the lice, which would alleviate his suffering.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not break earthenware </span>on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not cut </span><span class="gemarra-regular">pape</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to roast salted </span>fish <span class="gemarra-regular">on it. </span>Earthenware shards or pieces of paper that have been soaked in water were placed on the metal surface or in the oven in which the fish was roasted, so that it would not be burned by the heat.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sweep ou</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> anything that has fallen into <span class="gemarra-regular">an ove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or stove </span>that interferes with the baking, such as plaster. <span class="gemarra-regular">But one may press down </span>and flatten any accumulated dust and ashes at the bottom of the oven, which might prevent it from lighting properly.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> draw two barrels together </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to place a pot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on them, </span>so that its contents will be cooked by a fire lit between the barrels. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prop a po</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> that does not stand straight <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a piece of wood, </span>in order to prevent it from falling. <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, with a door. And one may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lead an animal with a stick </span>in the public domain <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival; and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, permits </span>it.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the issue of breaking earthenware and cutting paper, the Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the reason </span>for this prohibition? <span class="gemarra-regular">Because one </span>is thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">preparing</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a vessel </span>for use.
It was taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not sweep out an oven or stove. Rabbi Ḥiyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bar Yosef taught before Rav Naḥman: And if it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not possible to bake unless one sweeps it out, it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is permitted. </span>The Gemara relates an incident with regard <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the wife of Rabbi Ḥiyya</span><span class="gemarra-regular">:</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> A part of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> brick fell into </span>her <span class="gemarra-regular">oven on a Festival, </span>preventing her from baking. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥiyya said to her: See, </span>you should know that <span class="gemarra-regular">I want good-quality bread. </span>He thereby stated that it would be impossible unless she removed the brick, making it permissible for her to do so. Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said to his attendant: Roast for me a duck </span>in an oven, <span class="gemarra-regular">and be careful not to singe </span>it. He thereby implied that the attendant may remove all impediments from the oven in order to fulfill this requirement because otherwise it would not be possible to cook without singeing.
In a related case, <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Rav Aḥa from Hutzal said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to us that the master, </span>Rav Ashi, allows his attendants <span class="gemarra-regular">to plaster </span>the mouth of <span class="gemarra-regular">the oven for hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival. </span>This was done in order to ensure that the roasted or cooked dish would be fully prepared. Why does this not constitute the prohibited labor of kneading on a Festival? <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to him: We rely on </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the bank of the Euphrates </span>River. We avoid the labor of kneading by taking sufficiently kneaded mud from the riverbank. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this applies only when one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wrappe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> or made some mark on the mud <span class="gemarra-regular">the day</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> before, </span>so that it not be <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said: And</span> as for kneading with <span class="gemarra-regular">ashes </span>for this purpose, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> since the labor of kneading does not apply to ashes.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> draw two barrels together </span>in order to place a pot on them. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman said: </span>With regard to large <span class="gemarra-regular">stones</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of a lavatory</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> upon which one sits to attend to his needs, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted to put them together</span> in the proper manner, so that they may be used <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival. Rabba raised an objection to Rav Naḥman</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>Wasn’t it taught that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not draw two</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> barrels together </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to place a pot on them</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>This seems to indicate that any arrangement resembling building is prohibited. <span class="gemarra-regular">He said to him: There, </span>with regard to barrels, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is different, because one makes a tent. </span>It is not the drawing of the barrels close together that is prohibited. Rather, the placement of the pot over them forms a kind of covering, which is similar to building a tent. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the Younger, </span>so called to distinguish him from the more famous <span class="it-text">amora</span> known as Rabba, <span class="gemarra-regular">said to Rav Ashi: However, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>that is <span class="gemarra-regular">so, </span>then if, <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival, one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> built </span>a solid <span class="gemarra-regular">bench [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">itztaba</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> without a gap below the seat, a situation in which <span class="gemarra-regular">one does not make</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a tent, so too, </span>will you say <span class="gemarra-regular">that it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted? He said to him: </span>The two cases are not comparable: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>with regard to a proper construction, such as a bench, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah prohibited </span>erecting <span class="gemarra-regular">a permanent construction, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">the Torah did not prohibit </span>erecting <span class="gemarra-regular">a temporary construction. The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Sages, </span>however, <span class="gemarra-regular">decreed against </span>creating <span class="gemarra-regular">a temporary construction </span>on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">due to a permanent construction. </span>However, <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>with regard to a lavatory, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the dignity </span>of the user, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages did not decree with regard to it. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said: </span>With Regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">this bonfire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in which the wood is arranged in the form of a house, if one arranges it <span class="gemarra-regular">from above to below</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is permitted, </span>as this is not the regular manner of building. However, if one prepares it in the usual fashion, <span class="gemarra-regular">from below to above, it is prohibited, </span>for this is considered building.

<span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, </span>if one wishes to place <span class="gemarra-regular">eggs </span>on the mouth of a hollow vessel or on a grill sitting above coals, he must first hold the vessel in his hands and put the eggs on it, and only afterward position them both on the coals. <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a po</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> placed on barrels, one must hold the pot above the barrels before placing them underneath it. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> similarly, </span>in the case of a collapsible <span class="gemarra-regular">bed, </span>whose legs and cover are separate pieces, one must first stretch the upper part, then add the legs. <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, </span>in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">barrels </span>positioned one on top of the other, the upper one must be held in place first and then the others added below.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prop a pot with a piece of wood, and similarly</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a door. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">door, </span>can this <span class="gemarra-regular">enter your mind? </span>Is it possible to prop a pot by means of a door? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, say </span>and correct the wording as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, </span>one may not prop <span class="gemarra-regular">a door </span>with a piece of wood. <span class="gemarra-regular">The</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Sages taught: One may not prop a pot with a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> piece of wood, and similarly a door, as wood is</span> to be used <span class="gemarra-regular">only for kindling</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> With regard to any use other than kindling, wood is considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Shimon, </span>who does not accept the prohibition of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">permits </span>it.
The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not lead an animal with a stick on a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, but Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, permits </span>it. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shall we say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar, son </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon, holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">his father</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Rabbi Shimon, <span class="gemarra-regular">who is not </span>of the opinion that there is a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and he therefore permits one to take any stick and lead an animal with it? The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>there is no issue of <span class="it-text">muktze</span> here at all, for in <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">even Rabbi Shimon concedes </span>to the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span> that this activity is prohibited, not due to <span class="it-text">muktze</span> but <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>one who does so <span class="gemarra-regular">looks like one who is going </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to the market [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥinga</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> in the manner of a weekday. On a Festival, one must therefore lead the animal in an unusual fashion. 
§ In a case where one takes <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bambo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">o</span> branch to use as a skewer, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span><span class="gemarra-regular">prohibits it </span>because it is <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, since it was not made into a vessel the day before, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rav Sheshet </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permits it. </span>The Gemara elaborates: In the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wet </span>branch, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited; </span>it is unfit for kindling and is therefore <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">When they disagree, </span>it is in the case <span class="gemarra-regular">of a dry </span>branch. <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibits </span>handling it, Rav Naḥman, could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to you: Wood is only for kindling, </span>but it is considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span> with regard to any other use. <span class="gemarra-regular">And the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">permits </span>handling it, Rav Sheshet, could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: </span>Since all wood is to be used for roasting, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is it to me to roast with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>when it is inserted into meat? <span class="gemarra-regular">What is it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to me to roast with its coals? </span>Just as it is permitted to burn the bamboo as coal, so it is permitted to use it as a skewer for cooking. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Some say </span>a different version of the explanation of this dispute: <span class="gemarra-regular">In the case </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of a dry </span>branch, <span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees </span>that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted; </span><span class="gemarra-regular">when they disagree, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">in the case of a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wet </span>one. <span class="gemarra-regular">The one </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibits </span>handling it does so because <span class="gemarra-regular">it is not fit for kindling. And the one </span>who <span class="gemarra-regular">permits </span>it could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: Isn’t </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for a large fire, </span>which will dry out the branch and enable it to burn as well? The Gemara concludes: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> is that <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dry </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">is permitted </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">a wet </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava taught: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">A woman may not enter a storehouse of wood </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to take from them a firebrand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a partly burnt piece of wood used for turning over the wood of the bonfire, because this piece of wood was not made into a vessel the day before and it is therefore <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">And a firebrand that broke may not be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">kindled on a Festival, for one may kindle </span>fire <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vessels but one may not kindle </span>fire <span class="gemarra-regular">with shards of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vessels, </span>and this firebrand was considered a vessel before it broke. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that to say that </span>in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava </span><span class="gemarra-regular">holds in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>of the opinion that there is a prohibition of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? But didn’t Rava say to his attendant: Roast </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a duck for me, and throw its innards </span>to the cat? According to Rabbi Yehuda, it is prohibited to give the innards to animals, as they were not prepared for this purpose the day before. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, since </span>the innards <span class="gemarra-regular">become rancid </span>when they were left, <span class="gemarra-regular">from yesterday</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the Festival eve, <span class="gemarra-regular">his mind was on them. </span>At that point in time, he already intended to give them to the cats in his house.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>On a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">a person may remove a sliver </span>from a pile of straw or from similar material <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is before </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to clean with it </span>between <span class="gemarra-regular">his teeth. And he may collect </span>straw <span class="gemarra-regular">from a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard and kindle </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">for anything in a courtyard is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared </span>for all purposes. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Rabbis say: He may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">collect </span>these materials only <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>things placed <span class="gemarra-regular">before him </span>in his house, as they are certainly prepared for all uses, <span class="gemarra-regular">and kindle </span>them. With regard to objects lying in his courtyard, however, as their collection takes great effort, he certainly did not have them in mind the day before, and they are therefore <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. 
The mishna states a different <span class="it-text">halakha</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may not produce fire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> neither from wood, </span>by rubbing one piece against another; <span class="gemarra-regular">nor from stones </span>knocked against each other; <span class="gemarra-regular">nor from </span>hot <span class="gemarra-regular">dirt; nor from tiles </span>struck against each other; <span class="gemarra-regular">nor from water </span>placed in round, glass vessels, which produces fire by focusing the rays of the sun. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not whiten tiles </span>with a burning-hot heat in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to roast upon them </span>afterward.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yehuda said:</span> 

Daf 33b

<span class="gemarra-regular">Animal fodder, </span>such as straw and reed branches, <span class="gemarra-regular">does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not have </span>any associated prohibition <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the preparing of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a vessel. </span>One may therefore trim it on Shabbat and use it as one wishes.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana raised an objection to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Yehuda </span>from the following <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may handle </span>wood of <span class="gemarra-regular">a spice tre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> on Shabbat in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> smell them and to wave them before a sick person</span> to fan him. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he may crush it </span>between his fingers to release its fragrance, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he may smell it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>However, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not cut it </span>from the branch in order to produce a moist spot on the branch that will emit a strong fragrance, so as <span class="gemarra-regular">to smell it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">; and if he did cut it, he is exempt </span>from punishment according to Torah law, <span class="gemarra-regular">but it is prohibited </span>to do so. If he intends <span class="gemarra-regular">to clean his teeth with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it, he may not cut it, and if he did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cut it, he is liable </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering</span> for transgressing a prohibited labor on Shabbat. This indicates that although some wood of a spice tree was used as animal fodder, it is nevertheless prohibited to cut it. This appears to contradict Rav Yehuda. 
Rav Yehuda <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Kahana: <span class="gemarra-regular">Now, </span>even the statement <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt but prohibite</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> poses <span class="gemarra-regular">a difficulty to my </span>opinion, and it is not reasonable. <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it required </span>to say the opposite, i.e., <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">-offering? </span>This teaching cannot be understood at face value; <span class="gemarra-regular">rather</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>it must be understood as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">When that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">was taught, </span>it was referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">hard </span>pieces of wood such as beams, with regard to which there is a concern that one might perform a prohibited labor. The Gemara questions this: And can <span class="gemarra-regular">hard </span>branches <span class="gemarra-regular">be crushed </span>by hand? 
The Gemara replies: The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is incomplete and is teaching </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the following: </span>With regard to wood of a spice tree, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">crush it and smell it </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">cut i</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and smell</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it. In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement said? With regard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to soft </span>pieces of wood, <span class="gemarra-regular">but with regard to hard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ones, one may not cut them. And if he did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cut it he is exempt, but it is prohibited </span>to do so. If he intended <span class="gemarra-regular">to clean his teeth </span><span class="gemarra-regular">with it, he may not cut it, and if he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">did cut it, he is liable </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-</span><span class="gemarra-regular">offering. </span>
Similarly, it <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may cut it and smell it, and </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">another </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not cut it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to smell it. Rabbi Zeira said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: </span>This <span class="gemarra-regular">is not difficult. </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case, when it is permitted, it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to soft </span>wood. In <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, where the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> prohibits it, it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to har</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> pieces of wood.
With regard to the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov strongly</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> objects to this: With hard ones, why not? </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span> way <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>this case <span class="gemarra-regular">different from that which we learned</span> in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may break a barrel </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to eat dried figs from it, provided that he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">intend to make a vessel, </span>and he may use the barrel afterward. Breaking off wood in order to smell it is certainly not more of a prohibited labor than breaking a barrel. <span class="gemarra-regular">And furthermore, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bar Rav Adda and Ravin bar Rav Adda, who both</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: When we were at the house of Rav Yehuda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, he would break and give us many sticks </span>of wood of a spice tree, although <span class="gemarra-regular">they were </span>hard enough to be <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for handles of axes and hatches. </span>
The Gemara answers: This <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not difficult; this </span>case is in accordance with the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case follows <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis. As</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>On Shabbat or a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">a person may take a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> sliver </span>of wood <span class="gemarra-regular">from before him to clean his teeth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with it, and the Rabbis say: One may take </span>a toothpick <span class="gemarra-regular">only from an animal’s trough; </span>since it is fit for animal fodder, it is considered prepared for all purposes. <span class="gemarra-regular">And they agree that he may not pluck it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. And if he did pluck it to clean his teeth</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with it </span>or <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>use it as a key and <span class="gemarra-regular">open a door with it, </span>if he did so <span class="gemarra-regular">unwittingly</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on Shabbat, he is liable </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>If he did so <span class="gemarra-regular">intentionally on a Festival, he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">receives the forty </span>lashes administered to one who desecrates the Festival by performing labor. These are <span class="gemarra-regular">the words of Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Eliezer. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: Both this and this, </span>whether one did so on Shabbat or a Festival, even if he plucked it by hand to use it as a key, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">only due to a rabbinic </span><span class="gemarra-regular">decree</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Therefore, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, who states there </span>that one who plucks a toothpick on Shabbat unwittingly in order to make a vessel such as a key is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>to bring <span class="gemarra-regular">a sin-offering, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case of one who cuts a sliver of wood in order to smell it, he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt, but it is prohibited. </span>However, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis who state there, </span>in the case of plucking a toothpick, that he is <span class="gemarra-regular">exempt but it is prohibited, </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>when one cuts a sliver of wood for purposes of smelling, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer not accept this </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we learne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may break a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> barre</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to eat dried figs from it, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">provided that he does not </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">intend to make a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vessel? </span>This shows that if one does not intend to make a vessel, it is permitted <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>; whereas Rabbi Eliezer maintains that he is exempt, but it is prohibited. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said: When that </span><span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught, </span>its lenient ruling was <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a vessel </span><span class="gemarra-regular">patched with pitch [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mustaki</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning a vessel that had previously been broken and its pieces glued together with pitch. If one breaks it for his own needs, he does not smash a complete vessel, and he is therefore not considered to have fashioned a vessel.
§ It is taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one may collect </span>straw <span class="gemarra-regular">from the courtyard </span>on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught: One may collect </span>materials <span class="gemarra-regular">from a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">courtyar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and kindle </span>a fire because <span class="gemarra-regular">everything in a courtyard</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared, provided he does not arrange it in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> piles, and Rabbi Shimon permits </span>it even in such a manner. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what do they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> disagree; </span>what is the basis of their dispute? <span class="gemarra-regular">One Sage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., the Rabbis, who are stringent, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds: It looks</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as though he is collecting for tomorrow and another day</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and it is therefore prohibited, so that one will not be suspected of preparing from a Festival to a weekday. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one Sage, </span>Rabbi Shimon, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds: His pot proves his</span> intention. When onlookers see that he is using the straw for cooking, they will not suspect him of preparing for after the Festival.
§ It is taught in the mishna that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not produce </span>new <span class="gemarra-regular">fire</span> on a Festival in any manner. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is the reason </span>for this? The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> create</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> something new <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival. </span>This is similar to an act of creation, and it is therefore prohibited.
§ The mishna states that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not whiten tile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> by heating them, in order to roast food on them. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What does one </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">do; </span>since his intention is to prepare food, how does this differ from any other manner of roasting? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba bar bar Ḥana said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: Here we are dealing with new tiles, </span>and it is prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>

Daf 34a

<span class="gemarra-regular">it is necessary to test </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> to ensure that they do not burst when heated. If they are heated for the first time on a Festival, he will be thereby testing them, which is a prohibited labor. <span class="gemarra-regular">And some say: Because it is necessary to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> harden them </span>by overheating them the first time to make them fit for use, which is considered preparing a vessel for use and is prohibited on a Festival. 
In relation to the above, the Gemara cites the following teaching: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">there: </span>If one <span class="gemarra-regular">trampled </span>fowl with his foot, <span class="gemarra-regular">or threw it </span>against a <span class="gemarra-regular">wall, or if an animal crushe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it, </span>and it is <span class="gemarra-regular">twitching </span>but cannot stand; <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the animal <span class="gemarra-regular">waited</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>i.e., remained alive, <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span>of the injury <span class="gemarra-regular">until </span>the same <span class="gemarra-regular">time </span>twenty-four hours later, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered it, it is kosher, </span>provided no other defect is found in it that would have caused it to die within twelve months, which would render it a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar bar Yannai said in the name of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Elazar ben Antigonus: It requires examination </span>after slaughtering, to make sure it does not have a defect. 
In relation to the same issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yirmeya inquired</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Rabbi Zeira: What is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> slaughtering it on a Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Do we assume on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a Festival </span>that it has <span class="gemarra-regular">a flaw or not? </span>In other words, may one rely on the assumption that a typical chicken has no defect? Or perhaps, since there is concern with regard to this particular bird and it requires examination, one should refrain from slaughtering it lest it turn out to be a <span class="it-text">tereifa</span>. If so, he will have performed labor for no purpose. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">He said to him </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">We </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">learned </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not whiten tile</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in order to <span class="gemarra-regular">roast on them. And we discussed it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: What does he </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">do? And Rabba bar bar Ḥana</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Here we are dealing with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> new tiles, </span>and the Sages prohibited heating them <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>one first <span class="gemarra-regular">needs to test them, </span>and they might crack when heated. If they were heated for the first time on a Festival and cracked, it would show that they were unfit for use, in which case heating them would have been an unnecessary labor. This indicates that one may not take a chance on a Festival with regard to something that might be flawed, and therefore a possible <span class="it-text">tereifa</span> should be similarly prohibited. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">He said to him: </span>This is no proof; <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>that the reason for <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is necessary to harden the</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> in order to make them into proper vessels. Therefore, there is no connection between making a vessel and conducting an examination. Consequently, there is no reason to prohibit the slaughter of such a chicken on a Festival. 
It <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: It is possible for several people to perform a single act of cooking on Shabbat, and all will be liable. How so? <span class="gemarra-regular">One brings the fire, and one brings the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">wood, and one places the pot </span>on the stove, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one brings the water </span>for the pot, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one puts </span><span class="gemarra-regular">spices into </span>the food, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one stir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> the pot; <span class="gemarra-regular">they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are all liable </span>for cooking. The Gemara wonders at this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’t it taught </span>in a different <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">the last one is liable and all </span>the rest <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt? </span>The Gemara responds: This <span class="gemarra-regular">is not difficult. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>case, where all are liable, is referring to a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">in which he brought fire at the outset, </span>and therefore each of them performed part of the act of cooking; <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case, where only the last one is liable, is referring to a situation <span class="gemarra-regular">in which he brought fire </span><span class="gemarra-regular">at the end. </span>In that case, none of the earlier people performed any aspect of cooking at all, as the labor of cooking begins only from when fire is brought. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Granted, all of them performed an action</span> that constitutes a prohibited labor, and they are therefore partners in a prohibited act and the desecration of Shabbat. <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">one who places the pot </span>on the stove, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>prohibited labor <span class="gemarra-regular">has he performed? Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: Here we are dealing with a new pot, and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">due to whitening tiles they applied </span>the same prohibition to <span class="gemarra-regular">it. </span>This means that one is not liable for cooking the food in the pot but for strengthening the pot itself, as is the case with heating tiles.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages </span><span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">New ovens and stove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">similar to all vessels that </span>may be <span class="gemarra-regular">carried in a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard </span>on a Festival, as one can place items on them. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, one may not anoint them with oil, nor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">rub them with a rag, nor cool them with cold </span>liquids to prevent them from overheating, as all these actions are considered preparing the vessel for use, which may not be done on a Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span>one did so <span class="gemarra-regular">in order to bake </span>in the oven on the Festival itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">this is permitted.</span>
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>: During a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may scald the head and the feet </span>of a slaughtered animal with hot water in order to remove the hairs from them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and one may singe them in fire </span>for this purpose, <span class="gemarra-regular">but one may not smear them with clay</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor earth, nor lime </span>in order to remove the hairs because this involves great effort, and it appears as though he is processing the skin. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not shear </span>those hairs <span class="gemarra-regular">with scissors, </span>as it appears as though he is performing the labor of shearing in an effort to obtain the hairs themselves.
