Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> trim </span>the top of the leaves connected to <span class="gemarra-regular">the vegetable</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with its </span>special <span class="gemarra-regular">shears</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but one may prepare </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kunda</span><span class="gemarra-italic">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span><span class="gemarra-italic">akaviyot</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>bitter vegetables that can be eaten only after extensive cooking, although this involves great effort. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may kindle </span>fire <span class="gemarra-regular">and bake in a large baker’s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> oven [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">purnei</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and one may heat water in an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">antikhi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>a kind of large urn, <span class="gemarra-regular">but one may not bake</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in a new baker’s ove</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lest it break. </span>If the oven cracks when heated because it was not properly made, one will have performed unnecessary work on a Festival. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught</span> similarly in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not blow </span>a fire <span class="gemarra-regular">with bellows</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> because this is the manner of a weekday activity, <span class="gemarra-regular">but one may blow </span>a fire <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a tube, </span>in an unusual manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mend a skewer nor sharpen it. The Sages </span>further <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not break a reed </span>in order to make a kind of skewer upon which <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> roast salted </span>fish, <span class="gemarra-regular">but one may crack a nut </span>covered <span class="gemarra-regular">with a rag</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and there is no concern lest</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it tear, </span>for even if this occurs, no prohibited labor has been performed.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Eliezer further </span><span class="gemarra-regular">state</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> the following leniency: <span class="gemarra-regular">A person may stand over </span>objects in <span class="gemarra-regular">storage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> such as produce that he has for some reason previously set aside from use, 

Daf 34b

<span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat eve during the Sabbatical Year</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> during which no tithes are separated, which means one may take fruit on the following day without the need for any corrective measure, <span class="gemarra-regular">and say: From here, </span>from these fruits, <span class="gemarra-regular">I will </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eat tomorrow. And the Rabbis say: </span>He may not eat <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he mark</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> the pile of fruit the day before <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">says: From here to there </span>I will take.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">We</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> learned </span>in a mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">there: Children who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">figs </span>for themselves in a field <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat </span><span class="gemarra-regular">ev</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> in order to eat them on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they forgot and did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not separate tithes, </span>not only are they prohibited from eating them on Shabbat, for eating on Shabbat is always considered a fixed meal that obligates the produce in tithes, but even <span class="gemarra-regular">after the conclusion of Shabbat, they may not eat</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> until they have separated tithes. And we also learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who transfers figs in his courtyard in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> order to </span>make them into <span class="gemarra-regular">dry </span>figs, <span class="gemarra-regular">his children and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the members of his household may </span>in the meantime <span class="gemarra-regular">partake</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of them </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a casual </span>manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they are exempt</span> from tithes. The fact that the fruit has reached his courtyard, as opposed to his house, is not enough to cause it to be liable for tithing.
Based on these two sources, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava inquired of Rav Naḥman: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in terms of <span class="gemarra-regular">whether</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it establish</span>es an obligation <span class="gemarra-regular">to tithe </span>food that has been <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span> on Shabbat? Specifically, in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">an</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> item whose labor has not been completed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span>does the fact that the food is <span class="it-text">muktze</span> on Shabbat give it the status of completely prepared food, or not? <span class="gemarra-regular">Do we</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">since it is written: “And call Shabbat a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> delight” </span>(Isaiah 58:13), this implies that any food one eats on Shabbat is considered a delight and not a casual meal, and therefore Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">establishes </span>an obligation to tithe, as if the food were fully completed and fit to be eaten as a fixed meal, <span class="gemarra-regular">even for an </span><span class="gemarra-regular">item that has not </span>had its <span class="gemarra-regular">labor completed? Or perhaps </span>Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">establishes </span>an obligation to tithe <span class="gemarra-regular">an item whose labor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is completed, </span>but regarding <span class="gemarra-regular">an item whose labor is not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">completed it does not establish </span>an obligation to tithe? 
Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rava: <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat establishes </span>the obligation for tithes, <span class="gemarra-regular">both </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">an item whose work</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is completed and things whose work is not completed. </span>Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Naḥman and challenged: <span class="gemarra-regular">But say </span>that the law of <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat </span>should be <span class="gemarra-regular">similar </span>to that of <span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard: Just as a courtyard establishes </span>food placed inside it as a fixed meal with regard to tithes <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">the work on an item is completed, so too,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shabbat </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">establish only an item whose work is completed</span> as liable for tithing. Rav Naḥman <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rava: I did not say this based on my own logic, which can be countered by logic of your own. Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">we have it as an ordered teaching that Shabbat establishes </span><span class="gemarra-regular">both things whose work is completed and things whose work </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is not completed. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra, son </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rav Naḥman, said: We, too, have learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Eliezer further stated </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a person may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">stand over </span>objects in the <span class="gemarra-regular">storage </span>area <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat eve </span><span class="gemarra-regular">during the Sabbatical Year </span>and say: I will eat from here and here. <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason is that </span>it is fruit of the <span class="gemarra-regular">Sabbatical Year, </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">which </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not obligated to </span>separate <span class="gemarra-regular">tithes. However, if </span>it occurred <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the other years of the Sabbatical </span>cycle, <span class="gemarra-regular">so too, </span>you will say that it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to eat them without separating tithes. <span class="gemarra-regular">What is the reason </span>for this? <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not because Shabbat establishes </span>them with regard to tithes, and consequently they not be eaten until tithes have been separated? 
The Gemara refutes this: This is no proof, for <span class="gemarra-regular">there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is different: Since he said: From here I will</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> eat tomorrow, he has </span>immediately <span class="gemarra-regular">established for himself </span>a meal <span class="gemarra-regular">with them, </span>by stating his intention to eat the food as it is. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, why </span>does the mishna mention <span class="gemarra-regular">particularly Shabbat? Even </span>if one said so <span class="gemarra-regular">on a weekday </span>the same should <span class="gemarra-regular">also </span>apply. Since he has set them aside for his meal, they are considered finished and are liable to tithes. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>comes to <span class="gemarra-regular">teach us </span>the following: One should not conclude <span class="gemarra-regular">that untithed produce </span>is inherently <span class="it-text">muktze</span> because one may not separate the tithes and eat it; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is</span> considered <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared with regard to Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in that if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one transgressed </span>the words of the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">and corrected it</span> by separating the tithes, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">corrected</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 

Daf 35a

The Gemara challenges: How can one say that the very decision to partake of the fruit establishes it as fixed with regard to tithes? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it </span>true that even if one declared his intention to eat it the following day, it can nevertheless be assumed that <span class="gemarra-regular">the remaining </span>fruit <span class="gemarra-regular">is restored </span>to the pile? <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we have heard </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">said: Anywhere that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> its leftovers are restored, it is not established </span>with regard to liability for tithes at all.
This is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna in tractate <span class="it-text">Ma’asrot</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who removes olives from a vat [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">ma’atan</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]</span> where they are temporarily stored before being pressed <span class="gemarra-regular">may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">dip </span>them <span class="gemarra-regular">one by one in salt and eat </span>without tithing them first, since he is eating them one at a time. Although he is eating them with salt, it is not considered a fixed meal. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he dipped </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and placed </span>several olives <span class="gemarra-regular">before him, </span>such as <span class="gemarra-regular">ten, </span>they are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>in tithes. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: </span>One who eats <span class="gemarra-regular">from a ritually pure vat is liable </span>to separate tithes; one who eats <span class="gemarra-regular">from a ritually impure vat is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">exempt because he returns the surplus </span>to the vat.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And we discussed it: What is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the first clause </span>of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">and what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is different </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause; </span>why is the issue of purity relevant to this case? <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Abbahu </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: The first case </span>is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a ritually pure vat </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and a ritually impure person</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who transfers his impurity to the olives he touches. <span class="gemarra-regular">He may not return </span>the olives to the vat because he would thereby render all the remaining olives ritually impure. Therefore, from the outset he takes only the amount he wishes to eat. This is enough to consider it a fixed meal, and he must tithe them.
However, <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter clause </span>is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a ritually </span><span class="gemarra-regular">impure vat and a person </span>who is <span class="gemarra-regular">ritually impure, who </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may return </span>the olives to the vat, as the olives it contains are already ritually impure. He is not particular to take the exact amount he wants to eat, since he knows he may return the remaining olives, and they are therefore not considered fixed for tithes. For the purposes of this discussion, it can be seen from here that Rabbi Eliezer maintains that whenever one may restore the food, it is not considered fixed until its work is complete. 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">The mishna also </span>deals <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span> food that is <span class="gemarra-regular">pure and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a ritually impure person, who may not return them </span>to the vat. The Gemara challenges this answer: <span class="gemarra-regular">But aren’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t they already returned? </span>This is not a case where a person takes all the fruit and replaces what remains after his meal; rather, he takes the amount he explicitly designated the day before, while the rest remains in place. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: </span>The previous explanation is to be rejected, and it should be understood as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, you said? </span>There is no difficulty according to his approach. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer </span>conforms <span class="gemarra-regular">to his </span>standard line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as he said </span>that the separation of <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> itself <span class="gemarra-regular">establishe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> the work of fruit as completed, so that one may not eat it even in a casual manner without first separating the other tithes. <span class="gemarra-regular">And, all the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">more so, Shabbat </span>itself establishes food as fixed with regard to tithes, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Fruits from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">which </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has been separated before their work was completed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Eliezer prohibits eating from them </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a casual </span>manner without separating the rest of the tithes, as the <span class="it-text">teruma</span> establishes the food as fixed; <span class="gemarra-regular">but the Rabbis permit </span>it.
The Gemara suggests a different answer to Rava’s question as to whether Shabbat establishes an obligation to tithe food whose labor is incomplete: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a resolution <span class="gemarra-regular">from the latter clause </span>of the mishna, which states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the Rabbis say: </span>Even in the Sabbatical Year, when <span class="it-text">teruma</span> and tithes are not separated from fruit, a declaration from the day before is not enough to render the food prepared for Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless one marks </span>the fruit he is preparing <span class="gemarra-regular">and says </span>explicitly: <span class="gemarra-regular">From here</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to there. </span>The Gemara infers from this: <span class="gemarra-regular">The reason </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is that the eve of Shabbat </span>during <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sabbatical Year </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is not fit for tithes; but during </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">other years </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the Sabbatical </span>cycle, which <span class="gemarra-regular">are fit for </span>and obligated in <span class="gemarra-regular">tithes, </span>the fruits <span class="gemarra-regular">are prohibited. What is the reason? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Is it not because Shabbat </span>itself <span class="gemarra-regular">establishes </span>them as fixed? If this is the view of the Rabbis, one may not reject it in favor of a minority opinion such as Rabbi Eliezer’s. 
The Gemara refutes this: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this is no proof; <span class="gemarra-regular">there it is different. Since he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: From here to there I will eat tomorrow, he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">has </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">established </span>his meal, and the reason is not due to Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">If so, why discuss </span>particularly <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat; even on a weekday as well </span>the same law applies? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">This </span>comes to <span class="gemarra-regular">teach us, </span>as stated above, <span class="gemarra-regular">that untithed produce </span>is not fundamentally <span class="it-text">muktze</span> because it is prohibited to remove the dues and tithes on Shabbat; rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">prepared with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in that if one transgressed </span>the words of the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">and tithed it, it is tithed.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And we raise a contradiction </span>from a different source, in which it is taught: <span class="gemarra-regular">If one was eating from a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cluste</span><span class="gemarra-regular">r</span> of grapes, whose work is not completed, as grapes are designated for juice extraction, <span class="gemarra-regular">and came in from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a garden</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> where one may eat fruit in a casual manner without separating tithes, <span class="gemarra-regular">to a courtyard, Rabbi Eliezer </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: He may finish </span>eating the cluster, as the courtyard itself does not establish the fruit with regard to tithes, if their work was not completed beforehand. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He may not finish. </span>He maintains that a courtyard does establish the fruit as fixed for tithes, even if their work has not been completed. 
Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it grew dark on </span>Friday evening, <span class="gemarra-regular">the night of Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>while one was eating the cluster, and eating on Shabbat is considered a fixed meal, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer says: He </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may finish, </span>as not even Shabbat establishes fruit as fixed if its work was not completed. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yehoshua says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He may not finish. </span>He holds that Shabbat does indeed establish fruit as fixed for tithes even if its work has not been completed. This indicates that Rabbi Eliezer maintains that Shabbat does not establish food with regard to tithes, whereas the mishna here indicates that he agrees that the beginning of Shabbat does establish them as fixed. 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, the reason is as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> he taught </span>explicitly that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Natan says: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that when Rabbi Eliezer said: He may finish, </span>he meant that <span class="gemarra-regular">he may finish in the courtyard </span>itself; <span class="gemarra-regular">but rather</span> he meant: <span class="gemarra-regular">He may exit the courtyard and finish</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> And </span>similarly, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not that when Rabbi Eliezer said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: He may finish, </span>he meant that <span class="gemarra-regular">he may finish on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shabbat </span>itself; <span class="gemarra-regular">but rather, </span>he meant  that <span class="gemarra-regular">he may wait until the conclusion</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of Shabbat and finish. </span>If so, this source does not contradict the mishna here. 
With regard to the halakhic ruling in this case, <span class="gemarra-regular">when Ravin came</span> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yoḥanan said: Whether </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat; or </span>with regard to the separation of <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> from fruit; <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard </span>into which the fruit is brought; <span class="gemarra-regular">or </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a transaction</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>cases, if one sold the fruits, <span class="gemarra-regular">they establish </span>a requirement for tithes <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">items whose labor is completed</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>
The Gemara notes that each of these details teaches a novel <span class="it-text">halakha</span>. How so? <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat </span>comes <span class="gemarra-regular">to exclude </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Hillel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who gathers fruits from one place to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> another </span>in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to rea</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> them, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the day </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sanctified upon them, </span>i.e., Shabbat commenced, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Hillel prohibits </span>the food from the gatherer <span class="gemarra-regular">himself. </span>In other words, Hillel alone prohibits eating the fruit in that case until its tithes have been separated, for he believes that the beginning of Shabbat itself causes the fruit to be considered completed. Rabbi Yoḥanan teaches that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in this case is not in accordance with the opinion of Hillel. 

Daf 35b

In addition, it was necessary for Rabbi Yoḥanan to teach the law that <span class="gemarra-regular">a courtyard </span>does not establish fruit for tithes unless its work is completed, <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">exclude </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Ya’akov. As we learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who was transporting figs in his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard to make them into dried figs, his children and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the members of his household may eat from them </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a casual </span>manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and they are exempt from tithes. And </span>a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is taught in that regard: Rabbi Ya’akov</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> obligates </span>him, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">exempts </span>him.
With regard to the law that the separation of <span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span> does not establish fruit as fixed for tithes, this comes <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">exclude </span>the opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Eliezer. As we learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Fruits from which </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> had been separated before </span><span class="gemarra-regular">their work was completed, Rabbi Eliezer prohibits eating from them </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">a casual </span>manner, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the Rabbis permit </span>it.
With regard to the statement that <span class="gemarra-regular">a transaction </span>does not fix fruit for tithes, this is <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who acquires fig</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">am</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ha’aretz</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in a place where most people</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> press </span>and dry their figs in order to make them into cakes, the work of the figs is not completed before this stage, and <span class="gemarra-regular">he may </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">partake of them</span> in <span class="gemarra-regular">a casual </span>manner. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>when their work is completed, <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>need only <span class="gemarra-regular">tithe them as doubtfully tithed produce, </span>in accordance with the law with regard to all produce bought from an uneducated person.
The Gemara comments: One can <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from </span>this <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">three </span><span class="it-text">halakhot</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Learn from here </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a transaction establishes </span>produce as fixed <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an item whose work is completed, </span>but if its work has not been completed, even selling it does not obligate it in tithes. <span class="gemarra-regular">And learn from here </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">most </span>people who are in the category of <span class="gemarra-italic">am</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ha’aretz</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> separate</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tithes, </span>and therefore one need only separate tithes as doubtfully tithed produce, rather than definitively untithed produce. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one can <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from here </span>another law: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may tithe doubtfully tithed</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> produc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> purchased <span class="gemarra-regular">from an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">am</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">ha’aretz</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, even with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to something whose work is not completed. </span>
Rabbi Yoḥanan rules in accordance with this opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> exclude that which we learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> exchanges fruit</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with his friend, </span>which is considered a commercial transaction, if their intention was for <span class="gemarra-regular">this one to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eat and that one to eat, </span>or for <span class="gemarra-regular">this one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to make them into dried fruit and for that one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to make them into dried fruit, </span>they are both <span class="gemarra-regular">obligated </span>in tithes. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span>however, <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span>The one who took the fruits in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to eat is obligated, </span>as for him their labor is completed, but the one who intended <span class="gemarra-regular">to make them into dried fruit is exempt </span>and may partake of the fruit in a casual manner, as for him their work has not yet been completed. Rabbi Yoḥanan rules in opposition to the first <span class="it-text">tanna</span>. He maintains that the transaction itself does not make the fruit liable to tithes unless its work has been completed. 

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">One may lower produce, </span>which had been laid out on a roof to dry, into the house <span class="gemarra-regular">through a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">skyligh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival, </span>in order to prevent it from becoming ruined in the rain. Although it is a strenuous activity, it is permitted do to so on a Festival in order to prevent a financial loss; <span class="gemarra-regular">however, </span>one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>do so <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat. And one may cover </span><span class="gemarra-regular">produc</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> inside a building <span class="gemarra-regular">with cloths </span>to prevent damage <span class="gemarra-regular">due </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to a leak </span>in the ceiling over it, <span class="gemarra-regular">and similarly </span>one may cover <span class="gemarra-regular">jugs of wine and jugs of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">oi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> for the same reason. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may place a vessel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> beneath a leak </span>in order to catch the water <span class="gemarra-regular">on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shabbat, </span>to prevent it from dirtying the house.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara discusses the first word of the mishna from a linguistic standpoint. <span class="gemarra-regular">It</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was said: Rav Yehuda and Rav Natan </span>recited differing versions of the mishna’s opening word, which is in all versions a verb meaning to lower. <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">taught</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">mashilin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as in the text of this mishna, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">one taught </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mashḥilin</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">The one who teaches </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mashilin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not mistaken, and the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one who teaches </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mashḥilin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not mistaken, </span>as support can be found for both versions. He elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">The one who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> teaches </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mashilin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not mistaken, as it is written: “For</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> your olives will fall [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">yishal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]” </span>(Deuteronomy 28:40). <span class="it-text">Mashilin</span> would therefore mean: To cause to fall. <span class="gemarra-regular">And he who teaches </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mashḥilin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not mistaken, as we learned </span>the following cases in a mishna that lists blemishes that invalidate an animal for sacrifice: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shaḥul</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kasul</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> The mishna explains these terms: <span class="gemarra-italic">Shaḥul</span> is referring to an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">whose </span><span class="gemarra-regular">thigh is dislocated, </span>i.e., it has slipped out of place; <span class="gemarra-italic">kasul</span> is referring to an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">one of whose</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> thighs is higher than the other. </span>This shows that the root <span class="it-text">sh-ḥ-l-</span> is referring to something that has slipped down from its place. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said </span>that there are other possible variations of this word as well. <span class="gemarra-regular">One who teaches </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mashirin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not mistaken, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and one who teaches </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mashḥirin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not mistaken, and one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who teaches </span><span class="gemarra-italic">manshirin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not mistaken.</span>
He elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who teaches </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mashirin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not mistaken, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yishmael says: A</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nazirite may not wash </span>the hair of <span class="gemarra-regular">his head with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> clay </span>as a kind of shampoo, <span class="gemarra-regular">because it causes hair</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to fall off [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">mashir</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>and a nazirite is prohibited to remove the hairs of his head. This shows that <span class="it-text">mashir</span> indicates causing something to fall. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one who teaches </span><span class="gemarra-italic">mashḥirin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">not mistaken, as we learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">sheḥor</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>a type of razor, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">barber’s scissors, even if </span>their blades <span class="gemarra-regular">are detached, are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">subject to ritual impurity. </span>The fact that a razor is called <span class="it-text">sheḥor</span> implies that the root <span class="it-text">sh-ḥ-r</span> indicates causing to fall down.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And one who teaches </span><span class="gemarra-italic">manshirin</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not mistaken </span>either, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> whose clothes fell down [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nashru</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] into water </span>on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">may</span> continue to <span class="gemarra-regular">walk in them </span>while they dry of their own accord, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he need not be concerned </span>that people might suspect him of having washed them on Shabbat. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>another support can be found <span class="gemarra-regular">from that which we learne</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> in the following mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is gleaning [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">leket</span><span class="gemarra-regular">], </span>which must be left for the poor as commanded in Leviticus 19:9? <span class="gemarra-regular">That which falls [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">nosher</span><span class="gemarra-regular">] during reaping. </span>These sources show that the root <span class="it-text">n-sh-r</span> means: To fall down, and <span class="it-text">manshirin</span> would consequently mean: To cause to fall down.
§ The Gemara discusses the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">one may lower produce through </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a skylight on a Festival. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Up to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">how much </span>produce may be lowered in this manner? At what point is it considered to be too strenuous an activity to be performed on the Festival? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Zeira said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi said, and some say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Asi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">like that which </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in a mishna with regard to a different case: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may clear out four or five sack</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> hay or grain </span>from a room on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">due to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> visitors, </span>to clear a place for them to sit, <span class="gemarra-regular">or</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> due to suspension of </span>study in <span class="gemarra-regular">the study hall, </span>i.e., to make room there for more people, who would not be able to study Torah otherwise. Here too, only four or five sacks’ worth of produce may be lowered from the roof. 
The Gemara raises an objection to the comparison of the two cases. <span class="gemarra-regular">But perhaps there it is different, since there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the matter of preventing <span class="gemarra-regular">suspension of </span>study in <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">study hall </span>or of providing hospitality to guests, i.e., moving those items is permitted in order to facilitate a mitzva. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, where there is no suspension of </span>study in <span class="gemarra-regular">the study hall, </span>i.e., no facilitation of any mitzva, they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permit one to move such a large amount. <span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively: There, this is the reasoning that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">four or five sacks are permitted: Because Shabbat is severe </span>in people’s eyes <span class="gemarra-regular">and they will not come to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">belittle it; but </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival, which is </span>regarded more <span class="gemarra-regular">lightly and which </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">might come to belittle, </span>one may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>move the items <span class="gemarra-regular">at all</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>a claim can be made <span class="gemarra-regular">from the other perspective: There, this is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the reasoning </span>that it is permitted to carry only four or five sacks: <span class="gemarra-regular">Because there is no monetary loss </span>involved. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, where there is monetary loss </span>if the produce is not moved, one may carry <span class="gemarra-regular">even a larger amoun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> than four or five sacks. 

Daf 36a

The Gemara poses another question with regard to the same issue. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned elsewhere, </span>at the end of the mishna cited above concerning clearing out sacks for guests and study: <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span> one <span class="gemarra-regular">may not </span>clear out <span class="gemarra-regular">a storeroom. And Shmuel said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: What is </span>the meaning of: <span class="gemarra-regular">But not a storeroom? </span>It means: <span class="gemarra-regular">But one may not finish </span>clearing out <span class="gemarra-regular">the entire</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> storeroom </span>while clearing out the sacks, exposing the floor of the storeroom. The reason this is prohibited is <span class="gemarra-regular">lest </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he come to level out depression</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> in the dirt floor of the storeroom, which would constitute a biblically prohibited labor. <span class="gemarra-regular">What would be </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>with regard to lowering the produce from the roof on a Festival to prevent its ruin in the rain? Is it prohibited also in this case to remove all of it and thereby expose the floor of the roof? 
The Gemara specifies the possible arguments: Perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">it is there, on Shabbat, that it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is prohibited, because </span>punishment for Shabbat desecration is <span class="gemarra-regular">severe, but</span> on <span class="gemarra-regular">a Festival, which </span>has a <span class="gemarra-regular">lighter </span>punishment for desecration, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is acceptable. Or perhaps </span>it can be argued to the contrary: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of the sacks on Shabbat, even though <span class="gemarra-regular">there is suspension of </span>study in <span class="gemarra-regular">the study hall, </span>i.e., the clearing out facilitates a mitzva, <span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that they did <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permit exposing the floor. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>in the case of lowering produce on a Festival to prevent its ruin, <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is no suspension </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>study in <span class="gemarra-regular">the study hall, </span>i.e., clearing out the produce does not facilitate any mitzva, is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>prohibited?
The Gemara poses a further question. <span class="gemarra-regular">And here we learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lower produce through a skylight on a Festival, and Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Naḥman said: They taught </span>this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only with regard to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the same roof, </span>i.e., only if the skylight is in the same roof where the produce is located, <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>to carry the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">roof to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">roof </span>in order to lower it through a skylight in the second roof is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permitted. This would involve too much exertion to be permitted on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>this ruling <span class="gemarra-regular">is also taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">carry from </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">roof to </span>another <span class="gemarra-regular">roof, even when </span>the two <span class="gemarra-regular">roofs are on the same leve</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> and there is no extra effort of lifting or lowering the produce while transporting it between the roofs. 
The question arises: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of moving sacks on Shabbat for guests or for study, <span class="gemarra-regular">what</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? May the sacks be moved from one roof or house to another for this purpose? Perhaps <span class="gemarra-regular">all</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the more so </span>they may not be moved on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>because Shabbat is more <span class="gemarra-regular">severe </span>than a Festival? <span class="gemarra-regular">Or </span><span class="gemarra-regular">perhaps </span>it can be argued to the contrary: <span class="gemarra-regular">It is here</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>with regard to a Festival, <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to transfer from one roof to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">because a Festival </span>is regarded <span class="gemarra-regular">lightly </span>by people <span class="gemarra-regular">and they might </span>consequently <span class="gemarra-regular">come to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> belittle it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">;</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> but </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, which is severe </span>in people’s eyes <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">they will not come to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> belittle it, it is acceptable </span>to transfer even from one house to another. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>it may be argued: <span class="gemarra-regular">If here, </span>in the case of clearing produce from the roof, <span class="gemarra-regular">when there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>the issue of the <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">produce, you</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say </span>he may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>transfer from one roof to another, then <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>in the case of moving sacks on Shabbat for guests or study, <span class="gemarra-regular">when there is no </span>issue of <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of produce, </span>is it <span class="gemarra-regular">not all the more </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>prohibited?
The Gemara presents yet another dilemma: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span>with regard to bringing produce into one’s house from the roof, <span class="gemarra-regular">we learned </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If there is no skylight from the roof to the house, necessitating another method of moving the produce out of the rain, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lower them by </span>means of <span class="gemarra-regular">a rope through the windows</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, nor may he take them down by way of ladders</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. There, </span>with regard to moving sacks on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is</span> the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? May they be moved by ropes or using a ladder? Perhaps it is only <span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case of moving produce out of the rain <span class="gemarra-regular">on a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival, that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited, </span>because produce left on a roof <span class="gemarra-regular">does not </span>entail <span class="gemarra-regular">suspension of </span>a mitzva such as study in <span class="gemarra-regular">the study hall; but </span>on <span class="gemarra-regular">Shabbat, when there </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>the possibility that leaving the sacks in their current location will lead to <span class="gemarra-regular">suspension of </span>study in <span class="gemarra-regular">the study </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hall, it is acceptable </span>to remove them even via windows and ladders. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Or perhaps </span>it can be argued to the contrary: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>in the case of the produce on the roof, <span class="gemarra-regular">when</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> there is </span>the issue of the <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, you say </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>permitted. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>in the case of clearing out sacks on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">where there is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">no </span>issue of the <span class="gemarra-regular">loss of produce, </span>should it <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">all the more so </span>be prohibited to lower them via windows and ladders? No resolution was found, so the dilemma <span class="gemarra-regular">shall stand </span>unresolved.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may cover produce </span>with cloths to prevent damage due to a leak. <span class="gemarra-regular">Ulla said: And even a row </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of bricks </span>that might be ruined by the rain may be covered to prevent damage. Although the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in the mishna mentions produce, it is not limited to that case, but extends to any item liable to be spoiled. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak said: </span>It applies only to an item like <span class="gemarra-regular">produce, which is fit </span>for use on the Festival, but not to items such as bricks, which are designated for building and are not fit for use on the Festival. The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yitzḥak follows </span>his line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning </span>in this regard, <span class="gemarra-regular">as Rabbi Yitzḥak said: A vessel,</span> even if it is of the type that may be handled on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">may be handled </span>on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>if it is going to be used <span class="gemarra-regular">for something that may</span> itself <span class="gemarra-regular">be handled on Shabbat, </span>but not for the sake of set-aside [<span class="it-text">muktze</span>] objects. Since the bricks are <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, one may not handle cloths to cover the bricks.
The Gemara attempts to find a proof for this view: <span class="gemarra-regular">We</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may cover produce with cloths</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which seems to imply: <span class="gemarra-regular">Produce, yes, </span>because it may be handled on the Festival, but <span class="it-text">muktze</span> items such as <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> row of bricks, no. </span>The Gemara rejects this argument: This is no proof, as it is possible that <span class="gemarra-regular">the same</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is true even </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">a row of bricks, </span>i.e., that they may be covered. But <span class="gemarra-regular">since </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">taught in the first clause </span>of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">lower produce, </span>and there it is referring specifically to produce, as bricks may not be handled at all and surely not lowered from the roof, <span class="gemarra-regular">he taught also in the latter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">clause: One may cover produce. </span>The example of produce was chosen to parallel the first clause in the mishna, not in order to imply exclusion of bricks. 
The Gemara offers a different proof. <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly </span>one may cover <span class="gemarra-regular">jugs of wine and jugs of oil </span>due to a leak in the ceiling. This choice of examples seems to indicate that one may cover only things that are fit for use on the Festival, as opposed to objects such as bricks, which are <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. The Gemara rejects this proof: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what are we dealing here? With </span>jugs that contain wine and oil <span class="gemarra-regular">that are untithed, </span>which are not fit for Festival use and are therefore <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. And the same would be true for bricks.
The Gemara goes further: <span class="gemarra-regular">So, too, it is </span>in fact more <span class="gemarra-regular">reasonable </span>that this is the case, <span class="gemarra-regular">as if it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> enters your mind </span>that the mishna is referring to <span class="gemarra-regular">jugs</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of wine and jugs of oil </span>containing <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>liquids, <span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> already <span class="gemarra-regular">teach in the first clause </span>of this part of the mishna that it is permitted to cover <span class="gemarra-regular">produce? </span>What new information would be added by specifying jugs as well? 
The Gemara rejects this assertion. It is possible that the mishna is referring specifically to jugs containing permitted liquids. Nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">it was necessary for </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> to add the example of <span class="gemarra-regular">jugs of wine and jugs of oil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as <span class="gemarra-regular">it could enter your mind to say </span>that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">were concerned over a substantial loss, </span>such as of produce, which can be ruined by drops of rain that leak on it. But <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a minor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">loss, </span>such as drops of rain falling into a wine jug or an oil jug, <span class="gemarra-regular">they were not concerned</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and they did not permit covering them. The mishna therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> us </span>that those may be covered as well.
The Gemara raises objections against Rabbi Yitzḥak’s view: <span class="gemarra-regular">We learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may place a vessel beneath a leak on</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Shabbat. </span>It is permitted, then, to bring a bucket for the purpose of containing the water leaking into the house, although that water is ostensibly not fit for drinking and is therefore <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. The Gemara rejects this objection: The case in the mishna is of <span class="gemarra-regular">leakage </span>of water <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>is in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">fi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> to be drunk, at least by animals, and is consequently fit for Festival use. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another objection from a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> may spread a mat over bricks on Shabbat </span>to protect against rain. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> explicitly permits covering bricks, which Rabbi Yitzḥak prohibited. The Gemara rejects this argument: This <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to bricks <span class="gemarra-regular">that were left over from building </span>and are no longer designated for use in building, and <span class="gemarra-regular">which are </span>consequently <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for </span>use on the Festival by <span class="gemarra-regular">sitting on </span>them. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>another objection. It was taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may spread a mat </span><span class="gemarra-regular">over stone</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on Shabbat, </span>although stones are <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. The Gemara responds: That <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is speaking not of ordinary stones but <span class="gemarra-regular">of rounded </span>[<span class="gemarra-italic">mekurzalot</span>] <span class="gemarra-regular">stones, which </span>are <span class="gemarra-regular">fit for</span> use in personal hygiene <span class="gemarra-regular">in the lavatory </span>on Shabbat, and are therefore not <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>an objection from a different source. <span class="gemarra-regular">One may spread a mat over a beehiv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on Shabbat </span>to protect it from the elements, <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the sun due to the sun, and in the rain </span><span class="gemarra-regular">due to the rain, provided he does not have the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">intent to trap </span>the bees inside by covering the hive, as trapping is prohibited on Shabbat. A beehive and its bees are not fit for Shabbat use, yet it is permitted to handle a mat in order to cover the hive. The Gemara rejects this: <span class="gemarra-regular">There, too, </span>the reference is to an item that is fit for Shabbat use, as it is discussing a hive <span class="gemarra-regular">when there is honey </span>in it, which can be eaten on Shabbat. It is therefore permitted to handle the mat for the sake of the honey.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ukva from Meishan said to Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ashi: </span>This explanation works out <span class="gemarra-regular">well with </span>regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">summer, when there is honey, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">in the rainy season, </span>when there is no honey in beehives, <span class="gemarra-regular">what can be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said? </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> explicitly mentioned the two phrases in the sun and in the rain. The Gemara answers: This <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is necessary only for those two honeycombs </span>left in the beehive in the winter to sustain the bees. The Gemara questions this: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are those two honeycombs </span>not <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>as they have clearly been left for the sake of the bees, and not to be used by humans? The Gemara replies: <span class="gemarra-regular">With what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">are we dealing here? </span>This is a case <span class="gemarra-regular">when </span>the beekeeper <span class="gemarra-regular">had in mind </span>before the Festival that he was going to take them from the bees and eat <span class="gemarra-regular">them </span>himself. 
The Gemara raises an objection to this interpretation. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if he did not have in mind </span>to take <span class="gemarra-regular">them </span>for himself, <span class="gemarra-regular">what </span>would be the <span class="it-text">halakha</span>? Wouldn’t it be <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to spread a mat over the hive? If so, when the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> goes on to specify that sometimes it is prohibited to cover the hive, <span class="gemarra-regular">rather than </span><span class="gemarra-regular">teaching: As long as he does not have the intent </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to trap </span>the bees, introducing a totally new factor into the discussion, <span class="gemarra-regular">let it make a distinction within the case</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> itself </span>by saying: <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">is this statement </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said, </span>that the beehive may be covered? <span class="gemarra-regular">When he had </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in mind </span>beforehand to take the honeycombs; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> did not have in mind </span>to take <span class="gemarra-regular">them, it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prohibited. </span>
The Gemara responds: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is what </span>the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is saying: Even </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if he had in mind </span>to take the honeycombs, so that there is no problem of the hive’s being <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, it is still permitted to cover it <span class="gemarra-regular">provided he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">does not have intent to trap </span>the bees. 
The Gemara raises a further objection against this interpretation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">In what </span>manner <span class="gemarra-regular">did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you establish </span>and explain this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>? <span class="gemarra-regular">In accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> who, </span>in disagreement with Rabbi Shimon, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span> apply. But now <span class="gemarra-regular">say the latter clause </span>of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Provided he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not have the intent to trap. </span>This indicates that even though the bees may be trapped in the process of covering, it is permitted if this was not his intention. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">we have come to </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon, </span>who, in disagreement with Rabbi Yehuda, <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">An unintentional act is permitted </span>even though it leads inadvertently to a prohibited result. This interpretation of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is internally conflicted, half in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda and half in accordance with Rabbi Shimon. 
The Gemara rejects this argument. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>how can <span class="gemarra-regular">you understand </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> follows the view <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Shimon </span>at all? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Abaye and Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> both say: Rabbi Shimon concedes </span>that even an unintentional act is prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>a case of: <span class="gemarra-regular">Cut off its head</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and will it not die</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> In this case the person covering the hive with a mat inevitably traps the bees, even if he does not have intent to do so, and this act should be prohibited even by Rabbi Shimon. 
Rather, <span class="gemarra-regular">actually </span><span class="gemarra-regular">all of </span>the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and with what </span>case <span class="gemarra-regular">are we dealing here? </span>With a beehive <span class="gemarra-regular">that has windows, </span>i.e., small openings, besides the main opening on top, so that some of the windows remain uncovered and covering the hive does not inevitably trap the bees. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>should <span class="gemarra-regular">not say, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Yehuda: Provided he does not have intent </span><span class="gemarra-regular">to trap </span>the bees, which would imply that the deciding factor is the intention of the one who covers them, 

Daf 36b

<span class="gemarra-regular">but rather </span><span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>the following: <span class="gemarra-regular">Provided he does not make it a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">trap </span>as he covers it, i.e., as long as he takes care not to cover all the openings. The Gemara questions this: But it is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that it is prohibited to directly trap bees on Shabbat; why would the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> mention it? The Gemara responds: It does inform us of something that is not obvious: <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say: </span>An animal <span class="gemarra-regular">whose type is </span>generally <span class="gemarra-regular">trapped </span>and hunted by people for some purpose is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to be trapped on Shabbat, whereas an animal <span class="gemarra-regular">whose type is not </span>generally <span class="gemarra-regular">trapped, </span>such as a bee, is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to be trapped even <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, as this is not considered to be the normal manner of hunting. The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that one may not in fact trap bees.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi said </span>a different elucidation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is it taught </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">In the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> summer, and: In the rainy season? </span>No, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is taught</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: In the sun due to the sun and in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the rain due to the rain. </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> speaks not of the summer and the rainy season, but <span class="gemarra-regular">of the </span>spring <span class="gemarra-regular">days of Nisan and the </span>autumn <span class="gemarra-regular">days of Tishrei, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">when there is </span>sometimes <span class="gemarra-regular">sun and there is </span>sometimes <span class="gemarra-regular">rain,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>when <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>also <span class="gemarra-regular">honey </span>in the hive. It is possible, then, that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> permits covering the hive during these seasons because of the honey that is in it, as initially proposed.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may place a vessel beneath a leak</span> in order to catch the water <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat. </span>A Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">If the vessel became full </span>with the leaking water, <span class="gemarra-regular">he may pour out </span>its contents, place the vessel back under the leak, <span class="gemarra-regular">and repeat </span>the entire process if necessary, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>he need <span class="gemarra-regular">not refrain </span>from doing so.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s millhous</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> once <span class="gemarra-regular">developed a leak </span>on Shabbat. Abaye was concerned about the potential damage to the millstones, which were made partly of clay and which would become ruined from the leaking water, and he did not have enough buckets to catch all the water without emptying and refilling them. But the water was unfit for drinking and was therefore <span class="it-text">muktze</span> and could not be removed. Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">came before </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> to ask him how to proceed. Rabba <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him: Go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">bring your bed into </span>the millhouse, <span class="gemarra-regular">so</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>the dirty water <span class="gemarra-regular">will be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">like a container</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of excrement, </span>which, despite being <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, may be removed from one’s presence due to its repulsive nature, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">remove </span>the water. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye sat </span>and examined the matter <span class="gemarra-regular">and posed a difficulty: And may one initiate </span>a situation of <span class="gemarra-regular">a container of excrement</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., may one intentionally place any repulsive matter into a situation which will bother him and will then have to be removed, <span class="gemarra-italic">ab</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">initio</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? In the meantime, </span>as he was deliberating the issue, <span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye’s millhouse collapsed. He said: I had</span> this <span class="gemarra-regular">coming to me for having gone against the words</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of my master</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> Rabba, by not following his ruling unquestioningly.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: </span>With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a container of excremen</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and a container of urine, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is permitted to remove them </span>on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">to a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">garbage heap. And when he returns </span>the container to the house <span class="gemarra-regular">he must place water in it </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">return it, </span>for it is prohibited to carry these containers alone, as their foul odor makes them <span class="it-text">muktze</span> due to their repulsive nature. 
Some Sages at first <span class="gemarra-regular">understood</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>the wording of Shmuel’s statement that with regard to removing <span class="gemarra-regular">a container of excrement on account of the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> vessel, </span>i.e., along with its vessel: <span class="gemarra-regular">Yes, </span>this is permitted; but to remove the excrement <span class="gemarra-regular">by itself, </span>without a vessel containing it: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>this is prohibited. The Gemara counters this conclusion with the following story: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear that a certain </span>dead <span class="gemarra-regular">mouse was discovered in Rav </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ashi’s storeroom </span>for <span class="gemarra-regular">spices </span>[<span class="gemarra-italic">isparmekei</span>]. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said to them: Take hold of it by its tail </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and remove it. </span>This shows that repulsive matter may be removed even directly.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Any act for which one is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">liable due to a rabbinic decree </span>made to enhance the character of Shabbat as a day of <span class="gemarra-regular">rest [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shevut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]; </span>or if it is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">because it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">optional</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., it involves an aspect of a mitzva but is not a complete mitzva; or if it is notable <span class="gemarra-regular">because</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it is </span>a full-fledged <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzva, </span>if it is prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat, one is liable for it on a Festival</span> as well. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And these are </span>the acts prohibited by the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">shevut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: One may not climb a tree </span>on Shabbat, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor ride on an animal, nor swim in the water</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, nor clap </span>his hands together, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor clap </span>his hand on the <span class="gemarra-regular">thigh</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> nor dance. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">following </span>are acts that are prohibited on Shabbat and are notable <span class="gemarra-regular">because they are optional, </span>i.e., which involve an aspect of a mitzva but are not complete mitzvot: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not judge, nor betroth </span>a woman, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> perform </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalitza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which is done in lieu of levirate marriage, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor perform levirate marriage. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the following </span>are prohibited on Shabbat despite the fact that they are notable <span class="gemarra-regular">because of the </span>full-fledged <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> involved in them: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not consecrate, nor take a valuation</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> vow </span>(see Leviticus 27), <span class="gemarra-regular">nor consecrate </span>objects for use by the priests or the Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor separate </span><span class="gemarra-italic">teruma</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and tithe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from produce.
The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">spoke </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">all these </span>acts being prohibited even <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a Festival; all the more </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so </span>are they prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">on Shabbat. </span>The general principle is: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is no </span>difference <span class="gemarra-regular">between a Festival and Shabbat</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">except for </span>work involving preparation of <span class="gemarra-regular">food alone, </span>which is permitted on a Festival but prohibited on Shabbat.
