<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara clarifies the reasons for each of these <span class="it-text">halakhot</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not climb a tree. </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">decree </span>that was made <span class="gemarra-regular">lest one detach </span>branches or leaves as he climbs, thereby transgressing the prohibited labor of reaping. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Nor ride </span><span class="gemarra-regular">on an animal: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree </span>that was made <span class="gemarra-regular">lest one go beyond the </span>Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">limi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> on the animal. The Gemara asks: Can one then <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from here </span>that the prohibition against venturing beyond <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">limits, </span>which applies also to Festivals, <span class="gemarra-regular">is by Torah law? </span>If the prohibition with regard to the Shabbat limit were rabbinic, the Sages would not have reinforced it with the additional decree against riding an animal. It is known that this is a matter of dispute; in light of this explanation of the mishna it would be a proof that Shabbat boundaries are of Torah origin. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>give a different reason for the prohibition: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree </span>that was made <span class="gemarra-regular">lest</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> one cut off a branch </span>to use as a riding switch, and thereby perform the labor of reaping, which is prohibited by Torah law.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Nor swim in the water: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree </span>that was made <span class="gemarra-regular">lest one make a swimmer’s barrel, </span>i.e., an improvised flotation device used to teach beginners how to swim. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Nor clap </span>one’s hands together, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">clap his hand on the thigh, nor dance: </span>All of these are prohibited due to <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree </span>that was made <span class="gemarra-regular">lest one assemble put together a musical instrument </span>to accompany his clapping or dancing.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> following </span>are acts that are prohibited on Shabbat and are notable <span class="gemarra-regular">because they are optional, </span>i.e., which involve an aspect of a mitzva but are not complete mitzvot: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not judge. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one perform</span> a full-fledged <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzva </span>by acting as a judge in a court? Why is it categorized as optional rather than as a full-fledged mitzva? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the mishna to categorize it as optional, as it is speaking of a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span><span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>another person <span class="gemarra-regular">who is more </span>qualified <span class="gemarra-regular">than he. </span>Since the other person can judge even better, it is not considered an absolute mitzva for the first one to judge. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Nor betroth </span>a woman: The Gemara asks: Why is this categorized as optional, indicating that it is not a full-fledged mitzva? <span class="gemarra-regular">But</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> doesn’t one perform a </span>full-fledged <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzva </span>when he marries, as this enables him to fulfill the mitzva to be fruitful and multiply? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the mishna to categorize it as optional, 

Daf 37a

<span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>it is dealing with a case in which <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span>already <span class="gemarra-regular">has a wife and children, </span>so that he has already fulfilled the mitzva to be fruitful and multiply, and his betrothal of another woman is only an optional act. 
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">Nor perform </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalitza</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, nor perform levirate </span><span class="gemarra-regular">marriage: </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But doesn’t one perform a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> mitzva </span>through these acts? Why are they categorized as optional? The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>for the mishna to categorize them as optional, as it is speaking of a case <span class="gemarra-regular">when there is an older </span>brother. Since the general principle is that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>preferable way to carry out the <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzva is for the oldest </span>brother <span class="gemarra-regular">to perform </span><span class="gemarra-regular">levirate marriage</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the performance of levirate marriage by a younger brother is classified as optional. 
The Gemara clarifies the reason for the prohibition against judging, betrothing, etc., on Shabbat and Festivals: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in <span class="gemarra-regular">all these </span>cases, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is the reason </span>they may not be performed? It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree lest one write </span>down the proceedings of these acts in a document, such as the verdict of a judgment, the document of betrothal, a document testifying to the <span class="it-text">ḥalitza</span>, or a marriage contract in the case of levirate marriage.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And the following </span>are notable <span class="gemarra-regular">because of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>full-fledged <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzva </span>involved in them, yet are prohibited on Shabbat: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may not consecrate, nor take a valuation </span><span class="gemarra-regular">vow, nor consecrate </span>objects for use by the priests or the Temple. The Gemara explains: All these cases are prohibited because of <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree due to </span>their similarity to <span class="gemarra-regular">commerce</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> These acts, which all involve the transfer of ownership to the Temple treasury, resemble commerce, which is prohibited on a Festival.
§ It was taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And one may not separate </span><span class="gemarra-italic">terumot</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> tithes. </span>The Gemara asks: Is it not <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that this is so? In doing so one makes forbidden food usable, a form of repairing, which is a prohibited labor. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yosef taught: It is necessary </span>for the mishna to teach this <span class="gemarra-regular">only </span>to state that it is prohibited even to separate <span class="it-text">teruma</span> in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to give it to a priest</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the same day. </span>One could have thought that since he is separating the produce in order to give it to a priest it should be permitted like any other preparation of food; the mishna therefore states explicitly that it is prohibited.
The Gemara comments: <span class="gemarra-regular">And this applies only to produce</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> that </span>had the status of <span class="gemarra-regular">untithed produce, </span>and therefore was required to be tithed, <span class="gemarra-regular">the day before </span>the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, produce that became untithed now </span>on the Festival itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">such as dough </span>prepared on the Festival, which becomes untithed and requires <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> to be taken from it only after the dough is made: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">separating </span><span class="gemarra-italic">ḥalla</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">from it, one may separate </span>the <span class="it-text">ḥalla</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and give </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to a priest </span>even on a Festival.
The Gemara asks a question. When the mishna describes <span class="gemarra-regular">those </span>cases as notable <span class="gemarra-regular">because they are optional, </span>is this to say that to say that their prohibition is <span class="gemarra-regular">not because </span>of a <span class="gemarra-regular">rabbinic decree </span>to enhance the character of Shabbat as a day of <span class="gemarra-regular">rest [</span><span class="gemarra-italic">shevut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">]? </span>Likewise, with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">those </span>cases described as notable <span class="gemarra-regular">because they are mitzvot, </span>is this to say that their prohibition is <span class="gemarra-regular">not because of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shevut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? </span>The mishna, by referring only to the first of its three categories as <span class="it-text">shevut</span>, implies that the acts listed in the following categories do not involve <span class="it-text">shevut</span>. But this is not so; as the Gemara stated above, all these acts are prohibited by rabbinic decree to enhance the character of Shabbat and the Festival as days of rest. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yitzḥak said: </span>They are indeed all prohibited as <span class="it-text">shevut</span>. The mishna lists three types of <span class="it-text">shevut</span>: Those that involve no mitzva whatsoever, those that have a mitzva aspect to them, and those that constitute a full-fledged mitzva. And the <span class="it-text">tanna</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is speaking </span>and arranges his list employing the style of: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is no need, </span>i.e., he arranges the cases in order of increasing notability. First, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> no need </span>to state, i.e., it is most obvious, that <span class="gemarra-regular">plain </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shevut</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>which involves no mitzva at all, <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited, but even </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shevut</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of an optional act, </span>i.e., an act that is a minor mitzva, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">also prohibited. And there is no need </span>to state, i.e., it is obvious, that <span class="gemarra-italic">shevut</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of an optional act</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is prohibited, but even </span><span class="gemarra-italic">shevut</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of</span> a full-fledged <span class="gemarra-regular">mitzva</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is also prohibited. </span>
§ It was taught in the mishna: The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">spoke </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">all these </span>acts being prohibited even <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to a Festival; </span>all the more so are they prohibited on Shabbat. There is no difference between a Festival and Shabbat except for work involving food. The Gemara <span class="gemarra-regular">raises a contradiction </span>against this from an earlier mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">One may lower </span>produce from the roof into the house <span class="gemarra-regular">through a skylight </span>to prevent it from being spoiled by the rain <span class="gemarra-regular">on a Festival, but not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on Shabbat. </span>This shows that there is another difference between a Festival and Shabbat besides food preparation: Doing a strenuous activity to prevent a loss is permitted on a Festival but prohibited on Shabbat. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Yosef said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>mishna here, which does not include the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of lowering produce as an example of a difference between Shabbat and a Festival, is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>previous mishna that does cite it as a difference is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehoshua. </span>
Rav Yosef elaborates on his statement: <span class="gemarra-regular">As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: If a cow and her calf, which may not be slaughtered on the same day because of the biblical prohibition: “You shall not kill <span class="gemarra-regular">it and its offspring </span>both in one day” (Leviticus 22:28), <span class="gemarra-regular">fell into a pi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> on a Festival, and their owner wishes to take them out, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Eliezer</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> says: One may raise the first in order to slaughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it and </span>then <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter it, and </span>as for <span class="gemarra-regular">the second</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, he provides it sustenance in its place so that it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> will not die </span>in the pit. It is prohibited to undertake the strenuous task of raising an animal out of a pit except for the purpose of eating it on the Festival. Therefore, since one cannot slaughter both animals on the Festival, only one can be raised, while the other should be sustained in its place until after the Festival.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua, </span>however, <span class="gemarra-regular">says: One </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may raise the first with the intent of slaughtering it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>then change his mind and <span class="gemarra-regular">not slaughter it. Then </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he may go back and employ artifice </span>by deciding that he prefers to slaughter the second one, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he raises </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the second. </span>Having raised both animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">if he </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he may slaughter this </span>one; <span class="gemarra-regular">if he </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">desires he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">may slaughter that </span>one. Rav Yosef understands the argument between the two Sages as follows: Rabbi Yehoshua maintains that it is permitted to perform a strenuous activity on a Festival in order to prevent a loss, and therefore he may raise both animals, lest the one left behind die in the pit. Rabbi Eliezer, on the other hand, holds that one may not perform a strenuous activity to prevent a loss, so the second animal must be left in the pit even though it may die there. It may therefore be posited that the mishna that permits lowering produce on a Festival to prevent loss is in accordance with Rabbi Yehoshua’s opinion. Rabbi Eliezer would disagree with this leniency, and the principle that there is no difference between Shabbat and a Festival other than food preparation would remain intact. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said to </span>Rav Yosef: <span class="gemarra-regular">From where </span>do you know that this analysis of these Sages’ opinions is correct? <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps Rabbi Eliezer stated </span>his opinion that a strenuous activity to prevent monetary loss is prohibited on a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">only thus far, there </span>in the case of the animals in the pit, <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is possible to sustain </span>the second animal in the pit and keep it from dying. <span class="gemarra-regular">But here, </span>in the case of the produce on the roof, where there is <span class="gemarra-regular">no possibility </span>of preventing the loss <span class="gemarra-regular">through providing sustenance, </span>he would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>prohibit lowering the produce to save it from loss. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Alternatively, </span>one can propose an opposite argument: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehoshua stated </span>his opinion that a strenuous activity to prevent loss is permitted <span class="gemarra-regular">only thus far</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, there </span>in the case of the two animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it is possible to employ artifice </span>to raise the second animal, so that an observer might assume that that he was not acting to preserve his property, but wished to eat the first animal and subsequently changed his mind. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>in the case of the produce on the roof, <span class="gemarra-regular">where it is not possible to employ artifice</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it is clear that he is acting to salvage his produce, Rabbi Yehoshua would <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>be lenient. Therefore, Rav Yosef’s approach to resolving the contradiction has no support from this <span class="it-text">baraita</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, Rav Pappa said: </span>This resolution of the contradiction is to be rejected in favor of the following: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case follows the approach of <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Hillel. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">As we learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: </span>On a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not take out a child </span>who cannot walk, <span class="gemarra-regular">nor a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">lulav</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, nor a Torah scroll</span> into the public domain, as none of these are required for the preparation of food, <span class="gemarra-regular">and Beit Hillel permit </span>it. It is certainly prohibited to carry out any item into the public domain on Shabbat, yet Beit Hillel permit it on a Festival. Therefore, it may be posited that just as Beit Hillel allow carrying out items on a Festival but not on Shabbat, so would they permit moving the produce off the roof on a Festival but not on Shabbat. According to Beit Shammai, who forbid carrying items out on a Festival and on Shabbat equally, moving the produce from the roof would also be equally prohibited, and the principle that there is no difference between Shabbat and a Festival other than food preparation would remain intact. 
The Gemara at first refutes this explanation: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps that is not so, </span>as it is possible that <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai stated </span>their opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">only thus far, there </span>with regard to the prohibition against <span class="gemarra-regular">transferring </span>objects from one domain to another, <span class="gemarra-regular">but not </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">moving </span>objects, such as produce, from place to place in the house. The Gemara rejects this claim: <span class="gemarra-regular">Is that to say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">moving is not </span>performed <span class="gemarra-regular">for the sake of taking out </span>to the public domain? The decree against moving items unnecessarily, i.e., not for use on Shabbat or a Festival, was enacted due to a concern that one might take objects into the public domain. Rav Pappa’s explanation that it is only Beit Shammai who would prohibit lowering the produce from the roof therefore stands.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The status of <span class="gemarra-regular">animals and vessels </span>on Festivals <span class="gemarra-regular">is as the feet of </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">owner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> meaning that one’s animals and vessels are governed by his own travel limitations on Shabbat and Festivals. In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who delivers his animal to his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">so</span><span class="gemarra-regular">n</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">or</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to a shepherd </span>before the Festival to care for it, <span class="gemarra-regular">these are as the feet of the owner, </span>rather than those of the son or the shepherd.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Vessels that </span>have been inherited by several brothers and have not been divided among them but are still owned jointly, if they <span class="gemarra-regular">are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> designated for </span>the use of <span class="gemarra-regular">one of the brother</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">in the house </span>and the other brothers have no part in them, <span class="gemarra-regular">these are as his feet</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> and they are subject to his travel limitations. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>as for those <span class="gemarra-regular">that are not designated </span>for any particular brother, <span class="gemarra-regular">these are </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as a place where </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">may </span>all <span class="gemarra-regular">go. </span>They are limited by the travel limitations of every one of the brothers, as when one brother made a joining of Shabbat boundaries [<span class="it-text">eiruv</span> <span class="it-text">teḥumin</span>] and the others did not.
<span class="gemarra-regular">One who borrows a vessel from another on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eve of a Festival, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the feet of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the borrower </span>rather than the owner, as when the Festival began the vessel established its place of rest in possession of the borrower. However, if he borrowed it <span class="gemarra-regular">on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival </span>itself, it is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the feet of the lender, </span>since at the start of the Festival its place of rest was established in the possession of its owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">And</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> similarly, a woman who borrowed spices from another </span>to put in a dish, <span class="gemarra-regular">or water and sal</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t</span> to put in <span class="gemarra-regular">her dough, these </span>foods, i.e., the dish and the dough, which contain ingredients belonging to both parties, <span class="gemarra-regular">are</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as the feet of both of them; </span>they are limited by the travel limitations of both parties. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yehuda exempts </span>one from travel limitations <span class="gemarra-regular">in the </span>case of <span class="gemarra-regular">water, because it </span>has <span class="gemarra-regular">no substance </span>in the mixture and therefore is not considered connected to the original owner.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asserts: <span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-regular">mishna</span>

Daf 37b

is <span class="gemarra-regular">not in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dosa. As it is taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dosa says, and some say Abba Shaul </span><span class="gemarra-regular">says: One who purchases an animal from another on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eve of a Festival, even if he did not deliver </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it to him until the Festival </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the feet of the purchaser. And one who delivers his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">animal to a shepherd, even if he did not deliver </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it to him until the Festival </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the feet of the shepherd. </span>The mishna, on the other hand, teaches that an animal delivered to a shepherd remains as the feet of the owner, therefore apparently contradicting Rabbi Dosa.
The Gemara rejects the assertion that this is a contradiction. <span class="gemarra-regular">You </span>can <span class="gemarra-regular">even say</span> that the mishna is in accordance with <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dosa, and</span> it is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. Here, </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, it is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a town that has only <span class="gemarra-regular">one shepherd. </span>In that case the owner knows with certainty beforehand that he will be delivering his animal to this shepherd over the course of the Festival, and therefore the animal’s place of rest is established as being identical to that of the shepherd. <span class="gemarra-regular">There, </span>however, the mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a town where there are <span class="gemarra-regular">two shepherds. </span>Since the issue of which of them will receive this animal is undetermined when the Festival begins, the animal remains as the feet of its owner.The Gemara strengthens this assertion that the mishna is dealing with a case where there are two shepherds: The language of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">is also precise </span>in accordance with this interpretation, <span class="gemarra-regular">as it teaches: To his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">son or to a shepherd</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> suggesting that initially he did know to whom he would give the animal. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <span class="gemarra-regular">learn from this </span>that this is so. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabba </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bar bar Ḥana said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dosa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that animals given to a shepherd are as the feet of the shepherd. The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And did Rabbi Yoḥanan</span> actually <span class="gemarra-regular">say this? But didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say </span>a general principle that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span> always <span class="gemarra-regular">follows an unattributed </span>statement in <span class="gemarra-regular">a mishna? And we learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Animals</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and vessels are as the feet of the owner. </span>One who delivers his animal to his son or to a shepherd, it is as the feet of the owner. 
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">did we not establish </span>that the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> of Rabbi Dosa is dealing with a different case than the mishna, that <span class="gemarra-regular">here </span>in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> it is dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a town with <span class="gemarra-regular">one shepherd, </span>whereas <span class="gemarra-regular">there </span>in the mishna it is dealing <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a town with <span class="gemarra-regular">two shepherds? </span>There is consequently no contradiction between establishing the halakha both in accordance with Rabbi Dosa and in accordance with the mishna.
§ <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">who borrowed one</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rob</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in partnership </span>from a third party, <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>person in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to go to the study hall with it </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">morning and that </span>person in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to enter</span> a wedding <span class="gemarra-regular">feast with it </span>in the <span class="gemarra-regular">evening, </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span><span class="gemarra-regular">one made a joining </span>of Shabbat boundaries [<span class="it-text">eiruv</span> <span class="it-text">teḥumin</span>] <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> himself to the north </span>in order to reach his destination, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">made an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for himself to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the south </span>in order to reach his destination, <span class="gemarra-regular">the one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who made an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for himself to the north may </span><span class="gemarra-regular">walk </span>with the robe only <span class="gemarra-regular">to the north </span>as far <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>it is permitted for <span class="gemarra-regular">the feet of the one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who made an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for himself to the south, </span>i.e., he may go north only as far as the other borrower may go.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">the one who made </span><span class="gemarra-regular">an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for himself to the south may walk </span>with the robe <span class="gemarra-regular">to the south </span>only as far <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span>is permitted for the <span class="gemarra-regular">feet of the one who made an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for himself to the north, </span>as the robe is as the feet of both borrowers and may go only as far as both of them may walk. If each of them placed his <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> at a distance of one thousand cubits from their house, to the north and south respectively, they may each walk, without the robe, three thousand cubits from their regular dwelling-place, one partner toward the north and the other partner toward the south. The three thousand cubits are comprised of the thousand cubits from the house to the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> plus another two thousand, the standard Shabbat limit, from the location of the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span>. The one whose <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> is in the north may not wear the robe farther than one thousand cubits north of his house, as he would then be going beyond the farthest extent of the other’s Shabbat limit, and vice versa for the one whose <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> is in the south. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> made </span>their respective <span class="gemarra-regular">limits </span>end <span class="gemarra-regular">in the center</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> i.e., if one placed his <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> two thousand cubits from the house to the south, so that the house is his farthest limit to the north, and the other placed his <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> two thousand cubits to the north of the house, the house being his farthest limit to the south, <span class="gemarra-regular">then each </span>of them <span class="gemarra-regular">may not move </span>the robe <span class="gemarra-regular">from its place </span>at all.
The Gemara records a dispute between <span class="it-text">amora’im</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">It </span><span class="gemarra-regular">was said: </span>In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">two </span>people <span class="gemarra-regular">who purchased</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a barrel </span>of wine <span class="gemarra-regular">or an animal in partnershi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> before a Festival, in order to divide the contents of the barrel or the meat of the animal between them on the Festival itself, what is the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> if the two people have different Shabbat limits? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">barrel is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> permitted </span>to each of them, and each may take his portion on the Festival and transfer it within his respective Shabbat limit, which is also applicable to Festivals; <span class="gemarra-regular">but </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">animal is prohibited, </span>and each portion of it may be transferred only within the limits that are shared by both purchasers. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel said: </span>The <span class="gemarra-regular">barrel is also prohibited </span>to be transferred beyond the limits shared by both people.
The Gemara questions the opinion of Rav, who distinguished between the case of the barrel and that of the animal. <span class="gemarra-regular">What does Rav hold? If he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is</span> retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation, </span>so that after the division of the barrel it becomes clarified retroactively which portion belonged to which partner, and the Festival place of rest for each portion is established at the start of the Festival in accordance with the person who will later become its owner, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even</span> the <span class="gemarra-regular">animal should be permitted. And if he holds </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation, </span>so that at the start of the Festival both portions of the animal belong jointly to both of them and may therefore be transferred only within the limits shared by both people, then <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">barrel should be prohibited. </span>
The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, </span>the explanation for Rav is that <span class="gemarra-regular">he holds there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation, </span>and the reason Rav was stringent in the case of the animal is that <span class="gemarra-regular">an animal is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> different, as </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">limits absorb from each other</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> A live animal cannot be divided into two parts for ownership; each part of its body depends on and is nourished by the other. Consequently, even if the designation of the respective portions takes place retroactively, each portion continues to draw from the other part, so that at the time of division the two portions are once again mixed together. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Kahana and Rav Asi said to Rav: </span>If that is your rationale, this indicates that the Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">were not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">concerned about the prohibition of </span><span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it is not assumed that each of them removed the portion of his partner from his mind, thereby prohibiting it from his own use, and yet <span class="gemarra-regular">they were concerned about the prohibition </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of </span>Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">limits. </span>Isn’t this illogical? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav was silent</span> and offered no response.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What</span> conclusion <span class="gemarra-regular">was </span>reached <span class="gemarra-regular">about </span>this issue? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Hoshaya said: </span>In general, <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation, </span>and they can therefore each transport their portions of both the barrel and the animal to their respective places. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: There is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> no </span>retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation, </span>and therefore they may not move their portions of either the barrel or the animal except within the limits shared by both of them. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And does Rabbi Hoshaya </span>really <span class="gemarra-regular">hold there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation? But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna: If there is <span class="gemarra-regular">a corpse in a house that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> has many entrances, all </span>the entrances <span class="gemarra-regular">are ritually impure, </span>i.e., everything situated in the space of the entrance becomes impure, even in the part that lies beyond a closed door, separating it from the corpse. Since any of the entrances might be used to remove the corpse, and none are designated for that purpose, all are rendered impure. However, <span class="gemarra-regular">if one of them was </span>subsequently <span class="gemarra-regular">opened, </span>then the space of <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>particular entrance <span class="gemarra-regular">is impure, while all the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> others are pure, </span>as it is assumed that that the corpse will be removed by way of the open door. Even if none of the entrances was actually open, if <span class="gemarra-regular">one </span>merely <span class="gemarra-regular">intended to remove </span>the corpse <span class="gemarra-regular">through </span>a particular <span class="gemarra-regular">one of </span>the entrances <span class="gemarra-regular">or through a window that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is </span>at least <span class="gemarra-regular">four by four </span>handbreadths in size, this intention of his <span class="gemarra-regular">saves all the </span>other <span class="gemarra-regular">entrances </span>from impurity.
The details of this last <span class="it-text">halakha</span> are disputed by <span class="it-text">tanna</span><span class="it-text">’im</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">Beit Shammai say: And this </span>applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">if he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> had this intention before the dead person died, </span>so that at the time of death it was known which entrance would be used. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Beit Hillel say: </span>It applies <span class="gemarra-regular">even</span> if he had this intention only <span class="gemarra-regular">after the dead person</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> died. </span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And it is stated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with regard to this </span>mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Hoshaya said: </span>When Beit Hillel said that the other entrances are pure even if one thought of removing the corpse via a particular entrance only after the person died, they meant only <span class="gemarra-regular">to purify</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the entrances from that point and onward; </span>from the moment of his intention there is no more impurity in the other entrances. From this the Gemara infers: <span class="gemarra-regular">From here and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> onward: Yes, </span>the other entrances are saved from impurity, but <span class="gemarra-regular">retroactively: No. </span>Whatever was in the doorways before this intent was formulated has already contracted ritual impurity and this cannot be reversed retroactively by one’s subsequent thoughts. This indicates that the principle of retroactive designation is not accepted by Rabbi Hoshaya.
The Gemara resolves this contradiction in the following manner: <span class="gemarra-regular">Reverse </span>the presentation of their opinions given above, and say: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Hoshaya said: There is no </span>retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation, and Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yoḥanan said: There is </span>retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation.</span>
The Gemara questions this resolution: <span class="gemarra-regular">And does Rabbi Yoḥanan </span>really <span class="gemarra-regular">accept </span>the principle of retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation? But didn’t Rav Asi say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yoḥanan said: Brothers who divided </span>property received as an inheritance <span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">purchasers </span>from each other, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>as purchasers of land <span class="gemarra-regular">they must return </span>the portions <span class="gemarra-regular">to each other </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the Jubilee </span>year, at which point they may redistribute the property? This demonstrates that Rabbi Yoḥanan does not hold that it is retroactively established that each brother’s portion was designated for him directly upon their father’s death, but rather it is considered that all the land was joint property until the brothers traded or bought their respective portions from each other. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> you should say: When does Rabbi Yoḥanan not accept </span>the principle of retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation? </span>Only <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>regard to matters that are <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah law, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">he does hold </span>of retroactive designation <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>regard to matters of <span class="gemarra-regular">rabbinic law, </span>such as the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of Shabbat limits; this would account for the discrepancy. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">But does he accept </span>retroactive designation <span class="gemarra-regular">in </span>matters of <span class="gemarra-regular">rabbinic law? Didn’t </span>the Sage <span class="gemarra-regular">Ayo teach </span>otherwise in regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> of joining of Shabbat boundaries [<span class="it-text">eiruv</span> <span class="it-text">teḥumin</span>]? As it was taught in a mishna: One who has heard that a rabbi will be coming to a place near his town to deliver a lesson on Shabbat, but is unsure where the lecture will take place, may place two <span class="it-text">eiruvin</span> on Shabbat eve in two different directions, while stipulating that only the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> on the side where the rabbi will teach will take effect. Furthermore, if he hears that two rabbis will be coming to two different locations, he may place two <span class="it-text">eiruvin</span> and stipulate that he will decide on Shabbat which rabbi he prefers, and consequently which of the two <span class="it-text">eiruvin</span> will take effect. 
Ayo taught in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda </span>disagreed with this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> and <span class="gemarra-regular">said: A person may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">make a stipulation with regard to two </span>contradictory <span class="gemarra-regular">things at </span><span class="gemarra-regular">once, </span>and therefore if two Sages will be arriving, his condition is of no effect. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>it is true that in the first case, where he knows that a rabbi is coming but does not know from which direction, he may place two <span class="it-text">eiruvin</span> and stipulate that <span class="gemarra-regular">if the rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">comes from the east his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the east </span>will take effect, and if the rabbi comes <span class="gemarra-regular">from the west</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, his </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the west </span>will take effect. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>in the second case, when two rabbis come to the two locations, one of them arriving <span class="gemarra-regular">here and </span>the other arriving <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>and one wants to place two <span class="it-text">eiruvin</span> and decide on Shabbat which of the two lecture he will attend, this he may <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>do; that would require the identity of the functional <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> to be determined retroactively, and one’s place of rest must be determined when Shabbat begins. 

Daf 38a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">we discussed </span>the following difficulty <span class="gemarra-regular">with regard to this </span>teaching of Ayo: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>about the case where two rabbis are coming to the two locations, one <span class="gemarra-regular">here and </span>the other <span class="gemarra-regular">there, </span>and one places two <span class="it-text">eiruvin</span>, planning to decide on Shabbat which lecture he will attend? Why did Rabbi Yehuda state that this may not be done? It is because he held that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>But if so, in the first case <span class="gemarra-regular">as well, </span>where only one rabbi comes, but the location of his lecture was not known before Shabbat, and one placed <span class="it-text">eiruvin</span> in the <span class="gemarra-regular">east and </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">west, </span>we should say that neither is effective because the rabbi’s location will not be known until Shabbat, and <span class="gemarra-regular">there is no </span>retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi Yoḥanan said </span>in explanation: This first case is referring to a situation in which the <span class="gemarra-regular">rabbi had already </span><span class="gemarra-regular">arrive</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> before the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> was placed, but the one placing the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> does not know the rabbi’s location. Therefore, it had already been determined which of the two <span class="it-text">eiruvin</span> would be effective, although it was not yet known to him when Shabbat began. <span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not accept </span>the principle of retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation </span>even in matters of rabbinic law, as he states that if the rabbi were to arrive after the <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> was placed, it would not be effective retroactively.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the Gemara rejects this approach and states: <span class="gemarra-regular">Actually, do not reverse </span>the views of Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Hoshaya; it is indeed Rabbi Hoshaya, also known as Rabbi Oshaya, who accepts retroactive designation, and Rabbi Yoḥanan who rejects it. As for Rabbi Oshaya’s statement with regard to the entrances to a house that contains a corpse, the following answer may be offered: <span class="gemarra-regular">And when does Rabbi Oshaya not hold </span>of the principle of retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation? </span>With regard to matters of <span class="gemarra-regular">Torah</span> law, such as the ritual impurity of the dead. <span class="gemarra-regular">But with regard to </span>matters of <span class="gemarra-regular">rabbinic </span>law, such as Shabbat limits and the placement of <span class="it-text">eiruvin</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">he does accept</span> this principle.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Mar Zutra taught in </span>a public <span class="gemarra-regular">lesson: </span>The <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Oshaya </span>with regard to retroactive designation.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said: An ox of a fattener</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> one whose occupation is to fatten oxen in order to sell them for their meat, <span class="gemarra-regular">is as the feet of all</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> people. </span>It is as the feet of the one who acquires the animal on the Festival, even if the buyer is from another city, as the fattener’s intention when the Festival begins is that the ox belong to whoever buys it. But <span class="gemarra-regular">an ox of a shepherd</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> who raises oxen for himself but occasionally sells them to his neighbors or acquaintances, <span class="gemarra-regular">is as the feet of </span>the people of <span class="gemarra-regular">that city, </span>as his intention when the Festival begins is that he might sell the animal to someone in town, but not to someone from out of town.
§ The mishna states: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> borrows a vessel from another on the eve of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Festival</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is as the feet of the borrower. The Gemara asks: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious </span>that this is the case, as the place of rest of the vessel has already been established in the possession of the borrower. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one did not deliver </span>the vessel <span class="gemarra-regular">to him until the Festival </span>itself. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say: </span>Since the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">did not establish it in </span>the borrower’s <span class="gemarra-regular">possession </span>before the Festival began, it should remain as the feet of the lender, the mishna therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that it is not so, but it is as the feet of the borrower. 
The Gemara comments: Interpreted in this manner, the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">supports </span>a statement of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan, as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who borrows a vessel from another</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> on the eve of a Festival, even if he did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not give it to him until the Festival </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is as the feet of the borrower.</span>
§ It is taught in the mishna: If one borrowed <span class="gemarra-regular">on the Festival </span>itself, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> as the feet of the lender. </span>The Gemara again wonders: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">obvious. </span>The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">necessary </span>to state this <span class="it-text">halakha</span> in a case where this borrower <span class="gemarra-regular">is accustomed to borrowing </span>such items <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span>this lender. <span class="gemarra-regular">Lest you say </span>that since it is a regular occurrence for this loan to take place, the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">establishes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> it in his possession </span>ahead of time, and it should therefore be considered as though the object’s place of rest is established as the feet of the borrower, the mishna therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>that it is not so, as the lender <span class="gemarra-regular">certainly says </span>to himself: <span class="gemarra-regular">Perhaps he will find</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> someone else </span>this time, <span class="gemarra-regular">and he will go and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">borrow from him. </span>Consequently, the lender does not transfer possession of the object to the borrower until the latter takes it, and it may be carried only where the lender may go.
§ It is taught in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">And similarly, a woman who borrowed </span>spices <span class="gemarra-regular">from another </span>to put in a dish, or water and salt to put in her dough, these are as the feet of both of them. The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">When Rabbi Abb</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> ascended </span>from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, <span class="gemarra-regular">he said: May </span><span class="gemarra-regular">it be </span>God’s <span class="gemarra-regular">will that I say a statement </span>of <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">that will be accepte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> by my listeners in Eretz Yisrael, so that I will not be put to shame. <span class="gemarra-regular">When he ascended, </span>he found <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan, Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ḥanina bar Pappi, and Rabbi Zeira, and some say </span>he found <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abbahu, Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, and Rabbi Yitzḥak </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Nappaḥa, and </span>they <span class="gemarra-regular">were sitting and saying </span>in a discussion of the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Why </span>is this the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> with regard to dough? <span class="gemarra-regular">But let </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">water and salt be </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">nullifie</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> in the dough, </span>and the status of the dough should follow its flour rather than its minor ingredients, such as water and salt. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Abba said to them: </span>

Daf 38b

<span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one’s single <span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of wheat became mingle</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> with ten </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of another</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’s wheat, </span>shall <span class="gemarra-regular">the latter eat </span>all eleven <span class="it-text">kav</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> rejoice? </span>One does not allow his property to become nullified into someone else’s property. The same applies to water and salt in dough. The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">laughed at him. </span><span class="gemarra-regular">He said to them: </span>Did <span class="gemarra-regular">I take your cloak</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> from you that you are putting me to shame? <span class="gemarra-regular">They again</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> laughed at him.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Oshaya said: They did well to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> laugh at him. </span>They were correct that the two cases are dissimilar, as they reasoned as follows: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different</span> about a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat </span>belonging to one person that became mingled <span class="gemarra-regular">with barley </span>of another, that Rabbi Abba <span class="gemarra-regular">did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not say </span>this case <span class="gemarra-regular">to them </span>as an example? He specifically chose an example of wheat mingling with other wheat and not that case of barley <span class="gemarra-regular">because that is </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">type </span>mingled <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>something <span class="gemarra-regular">that is not its </span>same <span class="gemarra-regular">type</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>The principle is: <span class="gemarra-regular">A type </span>of food mixed <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span> a large amount of food <span class="gemarra-regular">not </span>of its own <span class="gemarra-regular">type</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> becomes nullified, </span>and this principle applies even when the two foods belong to two different people. If so, the same may be said when <span class="gemarra-regular">wheat </span>of one individual is mixed <span class="gemarra-regular">with wheat </span>of another <span class="gemarra-regular">as well. Although, according to Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Yehuda, </span>an item mingled with another item of the same type <span class="gemarra-regular">is not nullified, according to the Rabbis </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">is certainly nullified.</span>
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Safra said </span>to Rabbi Oshaya: <span class="gemarra-regular">Moses! </span>This is a term of reverence for the leader of the generation. Have you in fact <span class="gemarra-regular">spoken wel</span><span class="gemarra-regular">l</span> in defending those who scoffed at Rabbi Abba? <span class="gemarra-regular">But, did </span>those Sages who scoffed <span class="gemarra-regular">not hear </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>teaching <span class="gemarra-regular">that Rabbi Ḥiyya of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Ketosfa’a in the name of Rav: One who removes</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> pebble</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from another’s </span>wheat <span class="gemarra-regular">granary is obligated </span>to reimburse him for the loss he has caused and <span class="gemarra-regular">pay </span><span class="gemarra-regular">him the value of wheat </span>according to the weight of those stones. The latter could have sold those pebbles along with his wheat, as there is always some refuse mixed in with the wheat that is weighed and sold along with it. Therefore, the removal of the pebbles has caused the owner of the granary a monetary loss. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Apparently, </span>he must compensate him because <span class="gemarra-regular">he </span><span class="gemarra-regular">has reduced his measur</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> of wheat. Despite the fact that the pebbles themselves are worthless, we do not say that the pebbles were nullified in the wheat and that consequently there is no loss involved in their removal. <span class="gemarra-regular">Here, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">too, </span>in the case of one who borrows water and salt, which are not worthless, all the more so may we say that <span class="gemarra-regular">one has reduced his measure, </span>and he must compensate the lender; it cannot be said that they are nullified in the dough and that they are no longer taken into account regarding the Shabbat limit.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye </span>objected to the comparison to the case with the pebbles in the wheat, and <span class="gemarra-regular">said to </span>Rav Safra: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>does <span class="gemarra-regular">the master not differentiate</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> between money that has claimants, </span>such as in the case of the pebbles removed from the granary in which the owner seeks compensation and therefore there is no nullification, <span class="gemarra-regular">and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> money that does not have claimants, </span>as in the case of water and salt, where the owner lent them to the borrower and does not demand them back for now? In the latter case it is possible for these ingredients to be considered nullified. 
Rav Safra <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">And according to your reasoning</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> that one must distinguish between money that has claimants and money that does not, how would you account for <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>teaching: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥisda said: </span>According to Rabbi Yehuda, who maintains that an item can be nullified only when mixed with an item of a different type but not of the same type, flesh of an unslaughtered <span class="gemarra-regular">animal carcas</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> can be nullified in </span>a larger quantity of meat of <span class="gemarra-regular">a slaughtered </span>animal. Although carcass meat generally imparts impurity, if someone touches the mixture of the two meats he does not become ritually impure, as the carcass meat is considered a different type from the slaughtered animal, and is therefore nullified. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>meat from <span class="gemarra-regular">a slaughtered </span>animal <span class="gemarra-regular">cannot attain the status of carcass</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>and it is therefore viewed as a different type. 
The Gemara continues to cite Rav Ḥisda’s statement: However, if meat of a slaughtered animal became mingled with a larger quantity of pieces of animal carcass, the meat of the <span class="gemarra-regular">slaughtered</span> animal <span class="gemarra-regular">is not nullified by the carcass, as it is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> possible for a carcass to attain the status of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> slaughtered </span>animal. This means that it can lose its ability to transmit ritual impurity, as if a carcass becomes spoiled to the extent that it is no longer edible, it loses its impure status. The fact that the carcass meat has the potential ability to attain the status of slaughtered meat renders the two meats as the same type, and according to Rabbi Yehuda the smaller amount of slaughtered meat would not be nullified in the larger amount of carcass meat. The entirety of the mixture would not be considered carcass meat, but would retain its status of intermingled carcass and slaughtered meat. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Here, too</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>will you say <span class="gemarra-regular">that if </span>the carcass <span class="gemarra-regular">has owners </span>other than the owner of the slaughtered meat, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not nullified </span>in the slaughtered meat? <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>Yes, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is indeed so, but isn’t it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> taught: Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri said: Ownerless objects acquire residence</span> for Shabbat in their location, and anyone who finds them on Shabbat may move them two thousand cubits in all directions but not beyond that, as <span class="gemarra-regular">although they have no</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> owner, it is as though they have an owner? </span>This shows that even property that has no claimants, like the salt and water in this mishna, has its own independent Shabbat limits, which do not become nullified when mixed with items that have a different Shabbat limit.
Abaye <span class="gemarra-regular">said to</span> Rav Safra: <span class="gemarra-regular">Are you comparing </span>a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> involving <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibitions, </span>i.e., ritual law, <span class="gemarra-regular">to monetary </span>law? An object subject to <span class="gemarra-regular">a prohibition, </span>such as a prohibited food, <span class="gemarra-regular">can be </span><span class="gemarra-regular">nullified, </span>whereas one’s <span class="gemarra-regular">money cannot be nullified. </span>
Therefore, the initial question remains: Why isn’t the small amount of salt and water in the dough, which is subject to the ritual restriction of Shabbat limits, nullified in the rest of the dough, in the manner of nullification of all other ritual prohibitions? <span class="gemarra-regular">And what is the reason </span>that the water and salt are not nullified in the dough? 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">a decree </span>that the Sages made, <span class="gemarra-regular">lest </span>a woman <span class="gemarra-regular">make dough in partnership </span>with her neighbors. Indeed, in the case of the mishna, the small amount she received from her neighbor should be nullified in the dough. However, on another occasion, several friends or neighbors might decide to pool ingredients and prepare bread in partnership, in which case the bread is certainly bound by the Shabbat limits of all the parties combined. In order to prevent confusion between making dough in partnership and making it with borrowed ingredients, the Sages made a decree that the dough in both cases be subject to the same limitations.
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava said </span>a different reason: <span class="gemarra-regular">Spices are made</span> in order <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>add <span class="gemarra-regular">tast</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> to food, and <span class="gemarra-regular">taste</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not nullified, </span>even if the amount of actual substance is minute. Nullification indicates that a small amount of food may be considered insignificant and therefore null and void, but if an ingredient is added with the specific intent that its taste be noticed, there can be no nullification. 

Daf 39a

<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Ashi said </span>a different explanation as to why the spices, water, and salt are not subject to nullification: It is <span class="gemarra-regular">because </span>any one of these ingredients <span class="gemarra-regular">is an object whose prohibition is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">temporary, </span>as the prohibition against their being taken out of the Shabbat limits lapses once the Festival has passed, <span class="gemarra-regular">and </span>the general principle is that <span class="gemarra-regular">anything whose prohibition is temporar</span><span class="gemarra-regular">y</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> cannot become nullified, even </span>by one part <span class="gemarra-regular">in one thousand</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
§ It is taught in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda exempts </span>one from travel limitations <span class="gemarra-regular">in</span> the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">water. </span>The Gemara asks: Does this mean to imply that <span class="gemarra-regular">water, yes</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> it is exempted by Rabbi Yehuda, but <span class="gemarra-regular">salt, no, </span>it is not? <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn</span><span class="gemarra-regular">’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yehuda says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Water and salt are </span>both <span class="gemarra-regular">nullified, whether in a dough </span><span class="gemarra-regular">or in a pot </span>of cooked food. The Gemara answers: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. </span>In <span class="gemarra-regular">this </span>case of the mishna, the reference is to <span class="gemarra-regular">salt of Sodom, </span>which is quite coarse and does not blend in easily with the dough, and, being noticeable in the final product, is not nullified. In <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, the reference is <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span> a type of fine salt known as <span class="gemarra-italic">isterokani</span><span class="gemarra-italic">t</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">salt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> Consequently, it is not noticeable in the final product and can be nullified.
The mishna states that according to Rabbi Yehuda water mixed into dough, and presumably into a cooked dish as well, is considered nullified. The Gemara challenges this: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t it taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Yehuda says: Water and salt are nullified in dough but </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not in a pot, due to its sauce. </span>The pot, unlike bread, ends up with liquid in it, so the borrowed water is still recognizable. The Gemara replies: This is <span class="gemarra-regular">not difficult. This </span>case of the mishna, where Rabbi Yehuda says that the water is nullified in the cooked food, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a thick </span>dish that has no liquid sauce. <span class="gemarra-regular">That </span>case of the <span class="it-text">baraita</span>, in which Rabbi Yehuda said the water is not nullified, is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> thin </span>dish with liquid sauce. 
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">A</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> coal </span>that one borrowed from another on the Festival is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the feet of the owner, </span>and it may be carried on the Festival to any place where its owner may walk. Since it has substance, it is associated with its owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">But a flame </span>that one lit from another’s flame may be taken <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> as it has no substance. This essential difference between a coal and a flame has additional halakhic ramifications: If one uses <span class="gemarra-regular">a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> coal of consecrated property </span>for a non-consecrated purpose, he is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse </span>of consecrated property, since it has substance. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if one uses a consecrated <span class="gemarra-regular">flame, </span>although according to rabbinic law <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not </span>derive <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit </span>from it <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, if one did benefit from it, <span class="gemarra-regular">he is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not </span>liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misuse, </span>since it does not have substance. Similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">one who takes out a coal </span>from a private domain <span class="gemarra-regular">to the public domain </span>on Shabbat is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable </span>for the prohibited labor of carrying, but one who takes out <span class="gemarra-regular">a flame is exempt.</span>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (<span class="it-text">Beitza</span> 4:7): <span class="gemarra-regular">Five things were stated with regard to a coal, </span>in relation to the practical halakhic differences between a coal and a flame: <span class="gemarra-regular">(1) Coal is as the feet of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the owner </span>with regard to its Festival resting place, <span class="gemarra-regular">whereas a flame </span>may be carried <span class="gemarra-regular">anywhere. (2) One </span>is liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misusing </span>property consecrated to the Temple <span class="gemarra-regular">with a consecrated</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> coal, whereas </span>with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">flame</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> according to rabbinic law <span class="gemarra-regular">one may not benefit </span>from it, <span class="gemarra-regular">but he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is not </span>liable for <span class="gemarra-regular">misusing </span>property consecrated to the Temple. <span class="gemarra-regular">(3) Coal </span>used for <span class="gemarra-regular">idol </span><span class="gemarra-regular">worshi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">p</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited </span>for one to benefit from it, <span class="gemarra-regular">whereas </span>from <span class="gemarra-regular">a flame </span>of this sort it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">permitte</span><span class="gemarra-regular">d</span> to benefit. <span class="gemarra-regular">(4) One </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who carries out a coal to the public domain is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">liable, whereas </span>one who carries out <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">flam</span><span class="gemarra-regular">e</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">is exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. (5) One who is prohibited by a vow </span>from deriving <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit from another is prohibited from </span>using <span class="gemarra-regular">his coal, but</span> he is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to derive benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from his </span><span class="gemarra-regular">flame</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
With regard to the <span class="it-text">halakhot</span> cited in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> above, the Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">What is different </span>in in the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">a flame </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">idol worship, that </span>one is <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>to use it even <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, as the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> uses the term permitted in that case; <span class="gemarra-regular">and what is different </span>in the case of a <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated </span>flame, in <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span>it is <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to be used <span class="it-text">ab</span> <span class="it-text">initio</span>, as the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> states: One may not benefit from it, but he is not liable for misuse? The Gemara explains: In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">idol worship, which</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is repulsive </span>to Jews <span class="gemarra-regular">and from which </span>Jewish <span class="gemarra-regular">people </span>inherently <span class="gemarra-regular">maintain separation, the Sages did not decree </span>additional restrictions <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> regard to it. </span>However, concerning <span class="gemarra-regular">consecrated property, which is not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> repulsive and from which people do not </span>inherently <span class="gemarra-regular">maintain separation</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in order to prevent its misuse, <span class="gemarra-regular">the Sages did</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> decree with regard to it </span>that it is prohibited to use the flame.
§ It is taught in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> that <span class="gemarra-regular">one who carries out a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> coal to the public domain </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">liable, whereas </span>one who carries out <span class="gemarra-regular">a flame is exempt. </span>The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But isn’t </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>in another <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> carries out a flame of any size </span>on Shabbat <span class="gemarra-regular">is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> liable? Rav Sheshet said: </span>The second <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one carried out </span>the flame along <span class="gemarra-regular">with</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a wooden chip. </span>Since the flame is attached to a physical object, it is considered significant.
The Gemara raises an objection: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if so, <span class="gemarra-regular">let it derive </span>that one is liable for carrying out in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">wooden chip, </span>and the presence of the flame is irrelevant. The Gemara responds: That <span class="it-text">baraita</span> speaks of a chip <span class="gemarra-regular">that</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> does not have the </span>minimum <span class="gemarra-regular">measure </span>that determines liability for carrying out, <span class="gemarra-regular">as we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shabbat</span> 89b): In the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who carries out wood </span>on Shabbat, the measure that determines liability is <span class="gemarra-regular">enough </span>wood <span class="gemarra-regular">to cook an egg </span>of the kind that is the <span class="gemarra-regular">easiest </span>to cook, which is the egg of a chicken. Because the chip is too small to cook an egg, one is not liable for carrying it out, but one is liable for carrying out the flame attached to it.
