<span class="gemarra-regular">Abaye said </span>a different scenario: The mishna is referring to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one smeared a vessel with oil</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and lit a fire on it, </span>and carried out that flame. The Gemara asks: If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">let it derive</span> that one is liable for carrying out in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">vessel </span>itself, and the flame is irrelevant. The Gemara replies: The mishna is referring <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>a fire lit in <span class="gemarra-regular">an earthenware </span>shard, not in a whole vessel. 
The Gemara challenges: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>nevertheless, <span class="gemarra-regular">let it derive </span>that one is liable for carrying <span class="gemarra-regular">due to </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">earthenware </span>shard itself. The Gemara answers: It deals <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>a shard <span class="gemarra-regular">that is not of </span>the minimum <span class="gemarra-regular">measure </span>that determines liability for carrying out, <span class="gemarra-regular">as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> we learned </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shabbat</span> 82a): The measure that determines liability for carrying out <span class="gemarra-regular">earthenware </span>is <span class="gemarra-regular">enough to place </span><span class="gemarra-regular">between one </span>window <span class="gemarra-regular">frame and another, </span>as small shards of earthenware were sometimes placed between window frames during construction. This is <span class="gemarra-regular">the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. </span>
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>if so, if one is liable for carrying it out whenever the flame is attached to an object of substance, <span class="gemarra-regular">that which we learned </span>in the mishna here: <span class="gemarra-regular">One who carries out a flame is exempt, </span>under <span class="gemarra-regular">what circumstances </span>can this case <span class="gemarra-regular">be found? </span>The Gemara answers: The mishna is speaking of a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">fanned </span>the fire <span class="gemarra-regular">with his hand </span>so that it spread <span class="gemarra-regular">into the public domain </span>without its being attached to any vessel.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern of an individual, </span>water drawn from it <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span><span class="gemarra-regular">as the feet of the individual </span>who owns the cistern, and the water may be carried only to those places where its owner is permitted to walk. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>water drawn from a cistern belonging jointly to all <span class="gemarra-regular">the people </span>dwelling in <span class="gemarra-regular">a particular town is as the feet of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">people of that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">town</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>water drawn from a cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">of those who come up </span>to Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">from </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Babylonia, </span>i.e., a public cistern, is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the feet </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of whoever fills </span>his vessel with its water; the water has no defined boundary of its own since it is made available to all. 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">Rava raised a contradiction to Rav Naḥman: We learned</span> in the mishna that the water of <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern of</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> an individual is as the feet of the individual; and</span> Rava <span class="gemarra-regular">raised a contradiction </span>from the <span class="it-text">Tosefta</span> (<span class="it-text">Beitza</span> 4:8): Water drawn from <span class="gemarra-regular">flowing </span><span class="gemarra-regular">river</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">and flowing springs are as</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the feet of all people. Rava said: With what </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are we dealing here </span>in the mishna? <span class="gemarra-regular">With </span>cisterns that contain <span class="gemarra-regular">collected </span>water, not flowing water. <span class="gemarra-regular">And it was also</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel said</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: </span>The mishna applies only <span class="gemarra-regular">to collected </span>water. 
§ The mishna states: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>water drawn from a cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">of those who come up </span>to Eretz Yisrael <span class="gemarra-regular">from Babylonia, </span>i.e., a public cistern, is <span class="gemarra-regular">as </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the feet of whoever fills </span>his vessel with its water. <span class="gemarra-regular">It was stated </span>that <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagreed with regard to this issue: In the case of one who <span class="gemarra-regular">filled </span>a vessel with water from a public cistern on behalf of <span class="gemarra-regular">another and gave </span>the water <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span>him, <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Naḥman </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The water is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the feet of the one </span><span class="gemarra-regular">for whom they were filled; Rav Sheshet said: </span>It is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the feet of the one who filled </span>it. 
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">With regard to what </span>principle <span class="gemarra-regular">do they disagree? </span>The Gemara explains: <span class="gemarra-regular">One Sage, </span>Rav Sheshet, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that a public <span class="gemarra-regular">cistern is ownerless, </span>and the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that one cannot take possession of ownerless property on behalf of someone else. Therefore, the water belongs to the one who drew it; it is as his feet, and this status does not change even if he subsequently gave it to anyone else. <span class="gemarra-regular">And one Sage, </span>Rav Naḥman, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that a public cistern <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>considered jointly owned <span class="gemarra-regular">by </span>all its <span class="gemarra-regular">partners, </span>namely, all of the Jewish people. Therefore, it is possible for one partner to draw water on behalf of another partner, and the drawn water immediately belongs to the person for whom it was drawn. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">Rava</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> raised a challenge to Rav Naḥman </span>from a mishna (<span class="it-text">Nedarim</span> 47b): One who says to another: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am hereby </span>prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">to you </span>by force of <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥerem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>a kind of vow of prohibition, as objects declared as <span class="it-text">ḥerem</span> are generally consecrated to the Temple, <span class="gemarra-regular">the one prohibited by the vow</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>the addressee, <span class="gemarra-regular">is prohibited </span>to derive benefit from the person who made the vow or from his property, as the point of the vow was to prohibit the addressee from deriving any benefit from the one who made the vow. 

Daf 39b

If he said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">You are hereby </span>prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">to me </span>by force of <span class="gemarra-italic">ḥerem</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the one making the vow is </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">prohibited </span>to derive benefit from the addressee or from his property. If he said to him: <span class="gemarra-regular">I am hereby </span>prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">to you </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">you to me </span>by force of <span class="it-text">ḥerem</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">they are both</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> prohibited </span>to benefit <span class="gemarra-regular">from one another. And they are permitted</span> to benefit from anything belonging <span class="gemarra-regular">to those who come up</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from Babylonia, </span>i.e., public property that is not owned by any person or group, <span class="gemarra-regular">but they are prohibited </span>to benefit from property that is jointly owned by the inhabitants <span class="gemarra-regular">of that city, </span>as both parties have a share in such items. 
That mishna provides examples: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the following are items of those coming up from Babylonia,</span> i.e., publicly owned items: <span class="gemarra-regular">The Temple Mount, the chambers</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, and the courtyards </span>on the Temple Mount, <span class="gemarra-regular">and a </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cistern </span>situated <span class="gemarra-regular">in the middle of the road. And these </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are </span>items jointly owned by the inhabitants <span class="gemarra-regular">of that city: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">The street, and the synagogue</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and the bathhouse</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
Rava, having cited the mishna in full, concludes his challenge to the opinion of Rav Naḥman: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">a cistern </span>of those who come up from Babylonia, a public cistern, <span class="gemarra-regular">is </span>owned jointly <span class="gemarra-regular">by partners, </span>i.e., by all Jews, <span class="gemarra-regular">why </span>should it be <span class="gemarra-regular">permitted </span>for the one who made the vow and the addressee to use it? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Nedarim</span> 45b): Two <span class="gemarra-regular">partners who took a vo</span><span class="gemarra-regular">w</span> not to derive <span class="gemarra-regular">benefit from one another are prohibited to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">enter </span>a joint <span class="gemarra-regular">courtyard </span>in which they both have a share. According to you, the same should apply to a cistern in which the two of them have a share, such as the cisterns of those who come up from Babylonia. 
Rav Naḥman answered: Indeed that is the case. <span class="gemarra-regular">So </span><span class="gemarra-regular">too, </span>they are prohibited <span class="gemarra-regular">to wash </span>themselves <span class="gemarra-regular">in a cistern</span> because when bathing one uses of all the water of the cistern, part of which belongs to the forbidden partner. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>when the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> says that a cistern of those who come up from Babylonia is permitted to both parties, <span class="gemarra-regular">with what are we dealing here? </span>The <span class="it-text">baraita</span> is referring only <span class="gemarra-regular">to filling </span>water from the cistern. This is permitted because it is considered that <span class="gemarra-regular">this one fills </span><span class="gemarra-regular">from his </span>portion, <span class="gemarra-regular">and that one fills from his </span>portion. The water that each of them draws is considered retroactively designated exclusively for him, so that the partner has no share in it at all.
The Gemara asks: <span class="gemarra-regular">And does Rav Naḥman hold </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">there is </span>retroactive <span class="gemarra-regular">designation? But didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna (<span class="it-text">Shekalim</span> 1:7): If <span class="gemarra-regular">brothers </span>divided up inherited property among themselves and subsequently joined their property again and became <span class="gemarra-regular">partners, they are obligated to </span>add <span class="gemarra-regular">a </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kalbon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> a small coin, to the obligatory half-shekel yearly Temple donation. The <span class="it-text">kalbon</span> covered both the cost to the Temple of exchanging half-shekels into larger coins and the depreciation of the donated coin. Although a whole shekel given by two partners does not need to be changed into a larger coin, the Sages imposed the same <span class="it-text">kalbon</span> fee on the partners as on everyone else. However, these partners <span class="gemarra-regular">are exempt</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> from </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">animal tithe</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> in accordance with the standard <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that people who own animals in partnership are exempt from the animal tithe. 
The quote from the mishna continues: <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>in a situation in which the brothers are <span class="gemarra-regular">liable for the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> animal tithe, </span>as when they have not yet divided up their inheritance, and all the deceased’s estate is therefore still considered a single unit and not a partnership, <span class="gemarra-regular">they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> are exempt from the </span><span class="gemarra-italic">kalbon</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>in accordance with the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> that a father who contributes a single shekel for his two dependent sons does not need to add the <span class="it-text">kalbon</span>.
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Anan </span><span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The Sages <span class="gemarra-regular">taught </span>that the inherited property is no longer considered a single unit after the brothers divided it and then rejoined in a partnership <span class="gemarra-regular">only when they divided </span><span class="gemarra-regular">kids against lambs or lambs against kids, </span>i.e., if one brother took kids and the other took a corresponding value of lambs. This kind of division is considered a commercial transaction, with one brother purchasing goats and paying for them with lambs and vice versa. Therefore, when they join their animals again as partners, it is considered an entirely new partnership. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">However, </span>if <span class="gemarra-regular">they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">divided kids against kids and lambs against lambs, </span>meaning that each brother took an equal portion of each of the items they inherited, one can <span class="gemarra-regular">say </span>of each brother’s portion: <span class="gemarra-regular">This is his portion </span>destined to <span class="gemarra-regular">reach him from</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> the first moment, </span>from the time of the death of the deceased. If the brothers form their partnership again, the inheritance becomes a single unit again, and they are therefore obligated in the animal tithe and exempt from the <span class="it-text">kalbon</span>. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">But Rav</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Naḥman said: Even if they divided kids against kids and</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> lambs against lambs, </span>one does <span class="gemarra-regular">not say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">this is</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his portion </span>destined to <span class="gemarra-regular">reach him from the first moment</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>This is because Rav Naḥman does not accept the principle of retroactive designation. Consequently, the resolution proposed previously for the issue of filling water from the cistern of those who come up from Babylonia is invalid.
The Gemara retracts its previous explanation of the disagreement between Rava and Rav Naḥman: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span><span class="gemarra-regular">everyone agrees </span>that a cistern of those who come up from Babylonia, i.e., a public cistern, <span class="gemarra-regular">is an ownerless </span><span class="gemarra-regular">cistern, but here they disagree over </span>a different issue: <span class="gemarra-regular">One </span><span class="gemarra-regular">who picks up a found article </span>intending to acquire it <span class="gemarra-regular">on behalf of his friend</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> One <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rav Naḥman, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that if one picks up a found object on behalf of his friend, his friend <span class="gemarra-regular">acquire</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> it through this act as though he had picked it up himself. The water of the ownerless cistern is like a found object. Therefore, if one draws water on behalf of another, the latter acquires it, and consequently the water is as his feet. <span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">Sage, </span>Rav Sheshet, <span class="gemarra-regular">holds </span>that when one picks up a found object for another, the latter <span class="gemarra-regular">does</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not acquire it. </span>Rather, it belongs to the one who actually picked it up, and consequently the water is as the feet of the one who draws it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to<span class="gemarra-regular">one who had produce in</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> a different city</span> beyond the Shabbat limit, <span class="gemarra-regular">and the residents</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> of that city </span>where the produce was located joined the Shabbat boundaries, enabling them to reach the owner’s home on the Festival,and they wish <span class="gemarra-regular">to bring him some of his produce, they may not </span><span class="gemarra-regular">bring </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">to him. </span>His produce is as his feet; since it is outside of his Shabbat limit, it may not be taken from its place. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, if </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">placed an </span><span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span> to enable travel to that city, the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">his produce is like his </span>status with regard to the Shabbat limit. People from that city who also placed an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> may bring the produce to him, since he himself may walk to the produce and take it. 

Daf 40a

With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who invited guests to</span> visit <span class="gemarra-regular">hi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">m</span> from a town beyond his Shabbat limit, and they joined the Shabbat boundaries to enable them to reach his house, <span class="gemarra-regular">they may not carry in their </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hands </span>back to their town any <span class="gemarra-regular">portions </span>they received from him as gifts. These portions are as the feet of the host, since they belonged to him on the eve of the Festival. This is true <span class="gemarra-regular">unless he transferred ownership </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of their portions to them on the eve of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Festival, </span>in which case the gifts may be carried wherever the recipients may walk.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <span class="gemarra-regular">It is stated </span>that <span class="it-text">amora’im</span> disagreed with regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who deposits produce with another </span>for safekeeping: In whose possession is the produce with regard to determining its place of rest over the Festival? <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span>They are <span class="gemarra-regular">as the feet of the one with whom they</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> were </span><span class="gemarra-regular">deposited</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel said: </span>They are <span class="gemarra-regular">as the</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> feet of the </span>object’s <span class="gemarra-regular">owner. </span>The Gemara suggests: <span class="gemarra-regular">Let</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> us say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav and Shmuel follow their </span>usual line of <span class="gemarra-regular">reasoning, as we learned </span>in a mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">If </span>one <span class="gemarra-regular">brought in </span>his produce or his ox to another’s courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">with </span>his <span class="gemarra-regular">permission, the owner of the courtyard </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is liable </span>for any damage caused to them. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">said: </span>The homeowner <span class="gemarra-regular">is never liable </span>for damages, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless the homeowner </span>explicitly <span class="gemarra-regular">accepts upon himself </span>the responsibility <span class="gemarra-regular">to </span><span class="gemarra-regular">watch </span>them. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And Rav Huna said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav said: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with the statement of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis, </span>who disagreed with Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, and <span class="gemarra-regular">that Shmuel</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said: The </span><span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. If so, <span class="gemarra-regular">let us say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav spoke </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis, </span>with the following reasoning: Just as when one gives permission to store something in his yard, that object is under his jurisdiction concerning monetary responsibility, so too, it is in his jurisdiction concerning the establishment of the Shabbat limit. <span class="gemarra-regular">And Shmuel spoke </span>here <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi: When a homeowner gives permission to store something in his yard, the object is not in his jurisdiction, whether with regard to monetary responsibility or with regard to the Shabbat limit.
The Gemara rejects the comparison: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said to you: I said </span>my statement in this case <span class="gemarra-regular">even in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi. For <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">stated </span>his <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">only there, </span>that an object brought into a courtyard is not considered in the possession of the homeowner with regard to monetary responsibility, <span class="gemarra-regular">because in </span>the <span class="gemarra-regular">ordinary </span>situation one who allows someone to bring items into his courtyard <span class="gemarra-regular">does not</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> accept upon himself </span>the responsibility of <span class="gemarra-regular">watching </span>them. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">here, </span>the homeowner <span class="gemarra-regular">has accepted upon himself </span>the responsibility <span class="gemarra-regular">of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">watching </span>the produce, and consequently it is as his feet. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And </span>similarly, <span class="gemarra-regular">Shmuel </span>could have <span class="gemarra-regular">said: I said </span>my statement here <span class="gemarra-regular">even </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbis, </span>as <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbis stated </span>their opinion <span class="gemarra-regular">only there, </span>maintaining that the objects are considered in the jurisdiction of the homeowner, <span class="gemarra-regular">because it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">is a person’s, </span>i.e., the owner’s, <span class="gemarra-regular">preference that his ox </span>or other object <span class="gemarra-regular">be established in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the jurisdiction of the owner of the courtyard, </span>so <span class="gemarra-regular">that </span><span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>his ox <span class="gemarra-regular">does damage </span>to the homeowner’s property the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">will not be liable. But here, is it </span><span class="gemarra-regular">a person’s preference for his produce to be in </span><span class="gemarra-regular">another’s jurisdiction </span>with regard to the establishment of its Shabbat limit? It is certainly inconvenient for him to have his produce out of his Shabbat limit. Consequently, the two disputes between Rav and Shmuel are not necessarily connected. 
The Gemara asks concerning Rav’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">We</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> learned </span>in the mishna: <span class="gemarra-regular">However, if </span>the owner <span class="gemarra-regular">placed an</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> the legal status of <span class="gemarra-regular">his produce is like</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> his </span>status. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if you say </span>that deposited produce is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the feet of the one with whom they were</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> deposited, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if </span>the owner of the produce <span class="gemarra-regular">placed an</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">eiruv</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, what of it? </span>The produce is under the jurisdiction of the people in the other town with whom it was deposited. It should be as their feet, not as the feet of the owner. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Huna said </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">the </span>Sages of the <span class="gemarra-regular">school of Rav said </span>in reply to this question: The mishna is dealing with a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where </span>the keeper <span class="gemarra-regular">designated a corner </span>of his house <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span> the owner, thereby revealing his intention that the produce not be considered in his own jurisdiction but rather in that of the owner. Consequently, it remains as the feet of the owner. 
The Gemara raises another challenge to Rav’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">Come </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">hear </span>a different proof from the mishna: With regard to <span class="gemarra-regular">one who invited guests to </span>visit <span class="gemarra-regular">him, they may not carry in their hands </span>any <span class="gemarra-regular">portions </span>they may have received back to their town, <span class="gemarra-regular">unless </span><span class="gemarra-regular">he transferred ownership of their portions to them on the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">eve of the Festival. And if you say </span>that the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> is that deposited items are <span class="gemarra-regular">as the feet of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the one with whom they were deposited, </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">if he</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> transferred ownership to them by means of another </span>person taking possession on their behalf, <span class="gemarra-regular">what of it? </span>The portions are in any event deposited in the house of the host, and they should be as his feet. The Gemara answers: <span class="gemarra-regular">Here too, since he transferred ownership to them by </span><span class="gemarra-regular">means of another </span>person, <span class="gemarra-regular">it is considered as </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who designated a corner for him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">,</span> so that the gifts are considered in the jurisdiction of the guests and may be carried wherever they may walk. 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>instead that the entire case of <span class="gemarra-regular">transferring ownership is different </span>because the host’s specific intention is to transfer possession of the portions entirely to his guests. This means that the guests have certainly established the place of rest of these portions in their own jurisdiction and that the portions are as their feet.
The Gemara relates: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥana</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> bar Ḥanila</span><span class="gemarra-regular">i</span> once <span class="gemarra-regular">hung meat on the bar of </span><span class="gemarra-regular">the door </span>of his host’s house, located outside his own town. He subsequently wondered if he was permitted to take the meat home with him, since he had made an <span class="it-text">eiruv</span> enabling him to walk from his home to his host’s home. <span class="gemarra-regular">He came before Rav Hun</span><span class="gemarra-regular">a</span> to ask his opinion. Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him: If you</span> yourself <span class="gemarra-regular">hung </span>the meat, <span class="gemarra-regular">go take it, but if </span>your hosts <span class="gemarra-regular">hung </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">for you, you may not take it</span><span class="gemarra-regular">. </span>
The Gemara questions this: <span class="gemarra-regular">And if he </span>himself <span class="gemarra-regular">hung </span>the meat, <span class="gemarra-regular">may he </span>indeed <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">But wasn’</span><span class="gemarra-regular">t Rav Huna </span>a student of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav, and Rav said</span> that when an object is deposited in one’s house it is <span class="gemarra-regular">as the feet of the one with whom it</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> was deposited, </span>which in this case is the host. The Gemara responds: Here <span class="gemarra-regular">it is different, </span>as Rav Ḥana bar Ḥanilai hung the meat on <span class="gemarra-regular">the bar of the </span>host’s <span class="gemarra-regular">door, </span>and this case <span class="gemarra-regular">is considered similar to </span>a case of <span class="gemarra-regular">one who designated a corner for him. </span>Since he was given a particular spot for the meat, it is considered his in all respects. 
The Gemara raises a further objection with regard to this incident: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Hillel said to Rav Ashi: And if they </span><span class="gemarra-regular">hung </span>the meat <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, may he </span>indeed <span class="gemarra-regular">not take </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t Shmuel say: An ox of a</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> fattener, </span>who fattens oxen in order to sell them for meat, <span class="gemarra-regular">is as the feet of all people, </span>i.e., it is as the feet of whoever buys it on the Festival. This shows that meat that is likely to be sold is not as the feet of its owner, but rather it follows the buyer, as the intention before the Festival is that it be for whoever happens to purchase it. Here too, the intention from the outset was that Rav Ḥana would take it over the course of the Festival. 
Furthermore, <span class="gemarra-regular">Ravina said to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rav Ashi: And if </span>the hosts <span class="gemarra-regular">hung </span>the meat <span class="gemarra-regular">for</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> him, may he </span>indeed <span class="gemarra-regular">not take </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">But didn’t</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> Rabba bar bar Ḥana say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The</span> <span class="gemarra-italic">halakha</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is in accordance with </span>the opinion of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi Dosa</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>that in a town that has only one shepherd, an animal that will be given to that shepherd over the course of the Festival is as the feet of the shepherd, since it is certain that the animal will be transferred to him. Here too, since the meat was put aside for Rav Ḥana, he should be permitted to take it with him. There is a further difficulty: <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ashi</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> said to Rav Kahana: And if they hung </span>the meat <span class="gemarra-regular">for him, may he </span>indeed <span class="gemarra-regular">not take </span>it? <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span><span class="gemarra-regular">didn’t we learn </span>in a mishna: The status of <span class="gemarra-regular">animals and vessels is as the feet of </span>their <span class="gemarra-regular">owner</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> The same should apply to meat that was hung for him; it should be as his feet. 
Because of all these questions, the Gemara reinterprets the case of Rav Ḥana. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, </span>the problem with the meat concerns a completely different matter, as the issue under consideration is not the establishment of its place of rest but the prohibition against eating meat that has been left unobserved, due to the concern that it might have been exchanged for prohibited meat. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rav Ḥana bar Ḥanilai is different </span>from the average person, <span class="gemarra-regular">as he is a great man and occupied with his</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> studies, and this is what </span>Rav Huna <span class="gemarra-regular">said to him</span><span class="gemarra-regular">: If you </span>yourself <span class="gemarra-regular">hung </span>it, in which case <span class="gemarra-regular">you </span>noticed some recognizable <span class="gemarra-regular">mark on </span>the meat <span class="gemarra-regular">and your attention was</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> not diverted from it, </span>the meat is not forbidden for having been left unobserved, and therefore you <span class="gemarra-regular">may go </span>and <span class="gemarra-regular">take </span>it. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, if </span>the hosts <span class="gemarra-regular">hung </span>it <span class="gemarra-regular">for </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you, you </span>thereby <span class="gemarra-regular">diverted your attention </span>from it, and they too did not pay careful attention to it after hanging it on your behalf. In that case, it is considered meat that has been left unobserved, <span class="gemarra-regular">and you may </span>therefore <span class="gemarra-regular">not take </span>it. 
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> On a Festival <span class="gemarra-regular">o</span><span class="gemarra-regular">ne may not water or slaughter desert </span>animals, which graze mainly outside the town, as they are considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. <span class="gemarra-regular">However, one may water and slaughter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">domesti</span><span class="gemarra-regular">c</span> animals. The mishna elaborates: <span class="gemarra-regular">These are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">domestic </span>animals: Those <span class="gemarra-regular">that sleep in the city </span>at night. <span class="gemarra-regular">Desert </span>animals are those <span class="gemarra-regular">that sleep in the pasture </span>and come into town only rarely. 
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: The mishna is coming to teach which animals are <span class="it-text">muktze</span> and consequently may not be slaughtered and eaten on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">Why, </span>then, <span class="gemarra-regular">do I </span>need the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">to</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> say: One may water and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">slaughter</span><span class="gemarra-regular">?</span> What does watering have to do with the topic at hand? The Gemara explains: The <span class="it-text">tanna</span> of the mishna <span class="gemarra-regular">teaches us </span>a practical <span class="gemarra-regular">matter incidentally: That a person should </span>first <span class="gemarra-regular">water his animal</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and </span>only <span class="gemarra-regular">afterward slaughter </span>it, <span class="gemarra-regular">due to the adhesion </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">skin </span>to the meat when this is not done. If one first waters the animal, it is easier to skin it after slaughtering it.
<span class="gemarra-regular">The Sages taught </span>in a <span class="it-text">baraita</span>: <span class="gemarra-regular">Which are desert </span>animals, <span class="gemarra-regular">and which are domestic ones? </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Desert </span>animals include <span class="gemarra-regular">all those that go out </span>to pasture <span class="gemarra-regular">at Passover </span>time <span class="gemarra-regular">and graze in the meadows </span>day and night <span class="gemarra-regular">and enter </span>the town again only <span class="gemarra-regular">at the first </span><span class="gemarra-regular">rainfall, </span>at the start of the rainy season. <span class="gemarra-regular">And these </span><span class="gemarra-regular">are domestic </span>animals: <span class="gemarra-regular">All that go out </span>in the morning <span class="gemarra-regular">and graze outside the </span>town’s <span class="gemarra-regular">boundary but come and </span><span class="gemarra-regular">sleep within the boundary </span>at night. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi <span class="gemarra-regular">says: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">Both these and those are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">domestic </span>animals and may be slaughtered on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">Rather, these are desert animals </span>that may not be slaughtered on the Festival: <span class="gemarra-regular">All those </span><span class="gemarra-regular">that go out and graze in the meadows and do </span><span class="gemarra-regular">not enter the settled area, neither in the summer nor </span><span class="gemarra-regular">in the rainy season.</span>
The Gemara asks concerning Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion: <span class="gemarra-regular">And does Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi in general <span class="gemarra-regular">accept </span>the concept of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular">? But didn’t Rabbi Shimon, son </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi, <span class="gemarra-regular">inquire of Rabbi </span>Yehuda HaNasi: <span class="gemarra-regular">Unripe dates</span> that are placed in a basket <span class="gemarra-regular">to ripen </span>until they are edible, <span class="gemarra-regular">what is </span>the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">according to Rabbi Shimon</span> ben Yoḥai? Are they considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span> or not? <span class="gemarra-regular">He said</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> to him </span>in response: <span class="gemarra-regular">There is no </span>recognition of the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> according to Rabbi Shimon, </span>

Daf 40b

<span class="gemarra-regular">except</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> for </span>the case of <span class="gemarra-regular">dried figs and raisins </span>in the midst of the drying process <span class="gemarra-regular">alone. These </span>are fruits that are fit to be eaten fresh and were deliberately removed from use to allow them to undergo a drying process, during which time they are inedible; they have therefore been actively removed from one’s mind for the interim. Unripe dates, however, are unfit to be eaten fresh and become fit for eating only when they are ripe. Therefore, if one places unripe dates in a basket to ripen, they are never completely removed from his mind, not having been changed from an edible state to an inedible state, and are permitted. If so, desert animals, which are similarly never completely removed from one’s mind, should also not be considered <span class="it-text">muktze</span>. Why, then, does Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi indicate that they have the status of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>? 
The Gemara suggests several resolutions: <span class="gemarra-regular">If you wish, say </span>that <span class="gemarra-regular">these </span>desert animals <span class="gemarra-regular">are also considered similar to dried fig</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> and raisins, </span>as by sending them outside the town the owner has actively removed them from use. <span class="gemarra-regular">And if </span><span class="gemarra-regular">you wish, say </span>instead that the fact that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi told his son that Rabbi Shimon does not accept the <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="it-text">muktze</span> except for the case of dried figs and raisins does not prove anything about his own opinion; <span class="gemarra-regular">he stated </span>this only <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the statement </span><span class="gemarra-regular">of Rabbi Shimon, </span>but <span class="gemarra-regular">he himself does not hold accordingly</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span> 
<span class="gemarra-regular">And if you wish, say </span>a different answer: He himself, like Rabbi Shimon, did not accept the concept of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, and when he spoke in the <span class="it-text">baraita</span> <span class="gemarra-regular">he was speaking</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>for the sake of argument, <span class="gemarra-regular">in accordance with the </span><span class="gemarra-regular">words </span>of <span class="gemarra-regular">the Rabbi</span><span class="gemarra-regular">s</span> who had spoken before him, saying to them, in effect: <span class="gemarra-regular">According to my </span>opinion, <span class="gemarra-regular">there</span><span class="gemarra-regular"> is no </span><span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="gemarra-italic">muktze</span> at all, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, and all animals may be slaughtered on the Festival. <span class="gemarra-regular">But </span>even <span class="gemarra-regular">according to your approach</span><span class="gemarra-regular">, </span>that there is a <span class="it-text">halakha</span> of <span class="it-text">muktze</span>, <span class="gemarra-regular">agree with </span><span class="gemarra-regular">me, in any event, </span>that with regard to a case <span class="gemarra-regular">where they go out and graze on Passover and enter </span><span class="gemarra-regular">again at the first rainfall, they are </span>considered <span class="gemarra-regular">domestic animals </span>and should be permitted. <span class="gemarra-regular">But the Rabbis said to him: </span><span class="gemarra-regular">No, </span>even those <span class="gemarra-regular">are desert animals</span><span class="gemarra-regular">.</span>
